 Chapter
 
  Elizabeth passed the chief of the night in Elizabeth sister ’s room , and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the enquiries which Elizabeth very early received from Charles by a housemaid , and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on Charles sisters . In spite of this amendment , however , Elizabeth requested to have a note sent to Longbourn , desiring Elizabeth mother to visit Jane , and form Elizabeth own judgment of Jane situation . a note was immediately dispatched , and a note contents as quickly complied with . Elizabeth mother , accompanied by Elizabeth mother two youngest girls , reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast . 
 
  Had Elizabeth mother found Jane in any apparent danger , Elizabeth mother would have been very miserable ; but being satisfied on seeing Jane that Jane illness was not alarming , Elizabeth mother had no wish of Jane recovering immediately , as Jane restoration to health would probably remove Jane from Netherfield . Elizabeth mother would not listen , therefore , to Elizabeth sister ’s proposal of being carried home ; neither did the apothecary , who arrived about the same time , think Elizabeth sister ’s proposal of being carried home at all advisable . After sitting a little while with Jane , on Caroline ’s appearance and invitation , Elizabeth mother and three daughters all attended Caroline ’s into the breakfast parlour . Charles met Elizabeth mother and three daughters all with hopes that Elizabeth mother had not found Miss Bennet worse than Elizabeth mother expected . 
 
  “ Indeed Elizabeth mother have , Charles , ” was Elizabeth mother answer . “ Miss Bennet is a great deal too ill to be moved . Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving Miss Bennet . We must trespass a little longer on Charles kindness . ” 
 
  “ Removed ! ” cried Charles . “ moving must not be thought of . Charles sister , Elizabeth mother am sure , will not hear of moving . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother may depend upon it , Elizabeth mother , ” said Caroline ’s , with cold civility , “ that Miss Bennet shall receive every possible attention while Miss Bennet remains with Elizabeth mother and three daughters all . ” 
 
  Elizabeth mother was profuse in Elizabeth mother acknowledgments . 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother am sure , ” Elizabeth mother added , “ if it was not for such good friends Elizabeth mother do not know what would become of Miss Bennet , for Miss Bennet is very ill indeed , and suffers a vast deal , though with the greatest patience in the world , which is always the way with Miss Bennet , for Miss Bennet has , without exception , the sweetest temper Elizabeth mother ever met with . Elizabeth mother often tell Elizabeth mother other girls Elizabeth mother other girls are nothing to Miss Bennet . You have a sweet room here , Charles , and a charming prospect over that gravel walk . Elizabeth mother do not know a place in the country that is equal to Netherfield . Charles will not think of quitting Netherfield in a hurry , Elizabeth mother hope , though Charles have but a short lease . ” 
 
  “ Whatever Charles do is done in a hurry , ” replied Charles ; “ and therefore if Charles should resolve to quit Netherfield , Charles should probably be off in five minutes . At present , however , Charles consider Charles as quite fixed here . ” 
 
  “ consider is exactly what Elizabeth mother should have supposed of Charles , ” said Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother begin to comprehend Elizabeth mother , do Elizabeth mother ? ” cried Charles , turning towards Elizabeth mother . 
 
  “ Oh ! yes — Elizabeth mother understand Elizabeth perfectly . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother wish Elizabeth mother might take this for a compliment ; but to be so easily seen through Elizabeth mother am afraid is pitiful . ” 
 
  “ That is as it happens . It does not necessarily follow that a deep , intricate character is more or less estimable than such a one as Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , ” cried Elizabeth mother , “ remember where Elizabeth are , and do not run on in the wild manner that Elizabeth are suffered to do at home . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother did not know before , ” continued Charles immediately , “ that Elizabeth were a studier of character . It must be an amusing study . ” 
 
  “ Yes ; but intricate characters are the most amusing . intricate characters have at least that advantage . ” 
 
  “ The country , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ can in general supply but few subjects for such a study . In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined and unvarying society . ” 
 
  “ But people people alter so much , that there is something new to be observed in people for ever . ” 
 
  “ Yes , indeed , ” cried Elizabeth mother , offended by Fitzwilliam manner of mentioning a country neighbourhood . “ Elizabeth mother assure Fitzwilliam there is quite as much of that going on in the country as in town . ” 
 
  Everybody was surprised ; and Fitzwilliam , after looking at Elizabeth mother for a moment , turned silently away . Elizabeth mother Elizabeth mother had gained a complete victory over Fitzwilliam , continued Elizabeth mother triumph . 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother can not see that London has any great advantage over the country , for Elizabeth mother part , except the shops and public places . The country is a vast deal pleasanter , is not the country , Charles ? ” 
 
  “ When Charles am in the country , ” Charles replied , “ Charles never wish to leave the country ; and when Elizabeth mother am in town it is pretty much the same . They have each They advantages , and Elizabeth mother can be equally happy in either . ” 
 
  “ Aye — that is because Elizabeth mother have the right disposition . But Fitzwilliam , ” looking at Fitzwilliam , “ seemed to think the country was nothing at all . ” 
 
  “ Indeed , Elizabeth mother , Elizabeth mother are mistaken , ” said Elizabeth , blushing for Elizabeth mother . “ Elizabeth mother quite mistook Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam only meant that there was not such a variety of people to be met with in the country as in town , which Elizabeth mother must acknowledge to be true . ” 
 
  “ Certainly , Elizabeth , nobody said there were ; but as to not meeting with many people in this neighbourhood , Elizabeth mother believe there are few neighbourhoods larger . Elizabeth mother know Elizabeth mother and three daughters all dine with four - and - twenty families . ” 
 
  Nothing but concern for Elizabeth could enable Charles to keep Charles countenance . Elizabeth was less delicate , and directed Elizabeth eye towards Fitzwilliam with a very expressive smile . Elizabeth , for the sake of saying something that might turn Elizabeth mother ’s thoughts , now asked Elizabeth mother if Charlotte Lucas had been at Longbourn since Charlotte Lucas coming away . 
 
  “ Yes , Charlotte Lucas called yesterday with Charlotte Lucas father . What an agreeable man Charlotte Lucas father is , Charles — is not Charlotte Lucas father ? so much the man of fashion ! So genteel and so easy ! Charlotte Lucas father has always something to say to everybody . That is Elizabeth mother idea of good breeding ; and those persons who fancy those persons who fancy very important and never open those persons who fancy mouths , quite mistake the matter . ” 
 
  “ Did Charlotte Lucas dine with Elizabeth mother ? ” 
 
  “ No , Charlotte Lucas would go home . Elizabeth mother fancy Charlotte Lucas was wanted about the mince - pies . For Elizabeth mother part , Charles , Elizabeth mother always keep servants that can do servants that can do own work ; Elizabeth mother daughters are brought up differently . But everybody is to judge for everybody , and the Lucases are a very good sort of girls , Elizabeth mother assure Charles . It is a pity the Lucases are not handsome ! Not that Elizabeth mother think Charlotte Lucas so very plain — but then Charlotte Lucas is Elizabeth mother and three daughters all particular friend . ” 
 
  “ Charlotte Lucas seems a very pleasant young woman , ” said Charles . 
 
  “ Oh ! dear , yes ; but Charles must own Charlotte Lucas is very plain . Charlotte Lucas Charlotte Lucas has often said so , and envied Elizabeth mother Jane ’s beauty . Elizabeth mother do not like to boast of Elizabeth mother own child , but to be sure , Jane — one does not often see anybody better looking . does is what everybody says . Elizabeth mother do not trust Elizabeth mother own partiality . When Jane was only fifteen , there was a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane , that Elizabeth mother sister - in - law was sure a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane would make Jane an offer before we came away . But , however , a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane did not . Perhaps a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane thought Jane too young . However , a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane wrote some verses on Jane , and very pretty some verses were . ” 
 
  “ And so ended a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane affection , ” said Elizabeth impatiently . “ There has been many a one , Elizabeth fancy , overcome in the same way . Elizabeth wonder who first discovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love ! ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother have been used to consider poetry as the food of love , ” said Fitzwilliam . 
 
  “ Of a fine , stout , healthy love it may . Everything nourishes what is strong already . But if it be only a slight , thin sort of inclination , Elizabeth mother am convinced that one good sonnet will starve it entirely away . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam only smiled ; and the general pause which ensued made Elizabeth tremble lest Elizabeth mother should be exposing Elizabeth mother again . Elizabeth longed to speak , but could think of nothing to say ; and after a short silence Elizabeth mother began repeating Elizabeth mother thanks to Charles for Charles kindness to Jane , with an apology for troubling Charles also with Elizabeth . Charles was unaffectedly civil in Charles answer , and forced Charles younger sister to be civil also , and say what the occasion required . Elizabeth performed Elizabeth part indeed without much graciousness , but Elizabeth mother was satisfied , and soon afterwards ordered Elizabeth mother carriage . Upon this signal , the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls put the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls forward . The two girls had been whispering to each other during the whole visit , and the result of whispering was , that the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls should tax Charles with having promised on Charles first coming into the country to give a ball at Netherfield . 
 
  the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls was a stout , well - grown girl of fifteen , with a fine complexion and good - humoured countenance ; a favourite with the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls mother , whose affection had brought the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls into public at an early age . the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls had high animal spirits , and a sort of natural self - consequence , which the attentions of the officers , to whom the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls uncle ’s good dinners and the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls own easy manners recommended the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls , had increased into assurance . the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls was very equal , therefore , to address Charles on the subject of the ball , and abruptly reminded Charles of Charles promise ; adding , that it would be the most shameful thing in the world if Charles did not keep Charles promise . Charles answer to this sudden attack was delightful to Elizabeth mother ear . 
 
  “ Charles am perfectly ready , Charles assure the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls , to keep Charles engagement ; and when Jane is recovered , the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls shall , if the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls please , name the very day of the ball . But the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls would not wish to be dancing while Jane is ill . the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls 
 
  the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls declared the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls satisfied . “ Oh ! yes — it would be much better to wait till Jane was well , and by that time most likely Captain Carter would be at Meryton again . And when the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls have given the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls ball , ” the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls added , “ the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls shall insist on their giving one also . the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls shall tell Colonel Forster it will be quite a shame if Colonel Forster does not . ” 
 
  the youngest of Elizabeth mother two youngest girls and Elizabeth mother two youngest girls then departed , and Elizabeth returned instantly to Jane , leaving Elizabeth own and Elizabeth relations ’ behaviour to the remarks of the two elegant ladies who waited on Charles sisters and Fitzwilliam ; the latter of whom , however , could not be prevailed on to join in Elizabeth own and Elizabeth relations ’ censure of Elizabeth , in spite of all Caroline ’s witticisms on fine eyes . 
 Chapter 
 
  The day passed much as the day before had done . Mrs. Hurst and Caroline had spent some hours of the morning with the invalid , who continued , though slowly , to mend ; and in the evening Elizabeth joined Mrs. Hurst and Caroline party in the drawing - room . The loo table , however , did not appear . Fitzwilliam was writing , and Caroline , seated near Fitzwilliam , was watching the progress of Fitzwilliam letter , and repeatedly calling off Fitzwilliam attention by messages to Elizabeth . Mrs. Hurst and Charles were at piquet , and Mrs. Hurst was observing Mrs. Hurst and Caroline game . Elizabeth Elizabeth took up some needlework , and was sufficiently amused in attending to what passed between Fitzwilliam and Fitzwilliam companion . The perpetual commendations of Elizabeth either on Fitzwilliam handwriting , or on the evenness of Fitzwilliam lines , or on the length of Fitzwilliam letter , with the perfect unconcern with which Elizabeth praises were received , formed a curious dialogue , and was exactly in unison with Elizabeth opinion of each . 
 
  “ How delighted Georgiana will be to receive such a letter ! ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam made no answer . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam write uncommonly fast . ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet are mistaken . Fitzwilliam write rather slowly . ” 
 
  “ How many letters Fitzwilliam must have occasion to write in the course of a year ! Letters of business , too ! How odious Miss Bennet should think Letters of business ! ” 
 
  “ It is fortunate , then , that Letters of business fall to Fitzwilliam lot instead of to Miss Bennet . ” 
 
  “ Pray tell Elizabeth that Fitzwilliam long to see Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam have already told Elizabeth so once , by Miss Bennet desire . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam am afraid Fitzwilliam do not like Fitzwilliam pen . Let Fitzwilliam mend Fitzwilliam pen for Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam mend pens remarkably well . ” 
 
  “ Thank Fitzwilliam — but Fitzwilliam always mend Fitzwilliam own . ” 
 
  “ How can Fitzwilliam contrive to write so even ? ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam was silent . 
 
  “ Tell Fitzwilliam sister Fitzwilliam am delighted to hear of Elizabeth improvement on the harp , and pray let Elizabeth know that Fitzwilliam am quite in raptures with Elizabeth beautiful little design for a table , and Fitzwilliam think Elizabeth beautiful little design for a table infinitely superior to Miss Grantley ’s . ” 
 
  “ Will Fitzwilliam give Fitzwilliam leave to defer Fitzwilliam raptures till Fitzwilliam write again ? At present Fitzwilliam have not room to do Fitzwilliam raptures justice . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! it is of no consequence . Fitzwilliam shall see Elizabeth in January . But do Fitzwilliam always write such charming long letters to Elizabeth , Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ such charming long letters are generally long ; but whether always charming , it is not for Fitzwilliam to determine . ” 
 
  “ It is a rule with Fitzwilliam , that a person who can write a long letter with ease , can not write ill . ” 
 
  “ That will not do for a compliment to Fitzwilliam , Caroline , ” cried Caroline brother , “ because Fitzwilliam does not write with ease . Fitzwilliam studies too much for words of four syllables . Do not Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam style of writing is very different from Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! ” cried Caroline , “ Charles writes in the most careless way imaginable . Charles leaves out half Charles words , and blots the rest . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ideas flow so rapidly that Fitzwilliam have not time to express Fitzwilliam ideas — by which means Fitzwilliam letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to Fitzwilliam correspondents . ” 
 
  “ Charles humility , Charles , ” said Elizabeth , “ must disarm reproof . ” 
 
  “ Nothing is more deceitful , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ than the appearance of humility . the appearance of humility is often only carelessness of opinion , and sometimes an indirect boast . ” 
 
  “ And which of the two do Fitzwilliam call Fitzwilliam little recent piece of modesty ? ” 
 
  “ an indirect boast ; for Fitzwilliam are really proud of Fitzwilliam defects in writing , because Fitzwilliam consider Fitzwilliam defects in writing as proceeding from a rapidity of thought and carelessness of execution , which , if not estimable , Fitzwilliam think at least highly interesting . The power of doing anything with quickness is always much prized by the possessor , and often without any attention to the imperfection of the performance . When Fitzwilliam told Mother this morning that if Fitzwilliam ever resolved on quitting Netherfield Fitzwilliam should be gone in five minutes , Fitzwilliam meant told to be a sort of panegyric , of compliment to Fitzwilliam — and yet what is there so very laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business undone , and can be of no real advantage to Fitzwilliam or any one else ? ” 
 
  “ Nay , ” cried Charles , “ this is too much , to remember at night all the foolish things that were said in the morning . And yet , upon Charles honour , Charles believed what Charles said of Charles to be true , and Charles believe it at this moment . At least , therefore , Charles did not assume the character of needless precipitance merely to show off before the ladies . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam dare say Fitzwilliam believed it ; but Fitzwilliam am by no means convinced that Fitzwilliam would be gone with such celerity . Fitzwilliam conduct would be quite as dependent on chance as that of any man Fitzwilliam know ; and if , as Fitzwilliam were mounting Fitzwilliam horse , a friend were to say , ‘ Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam had better stay till next week , ’ Fitzwilliam would probably do it , Fitzwilliam would probably not go — and , at another word , might stay a month . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam have only proved by this , ” cried Elizabeth , “ that Charles did not do justice to Charles own disposition . Fitzwilliam have shown Charles off now much more than Charles did Charles . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam am exceedingly gratified , ” said Charles , “ by Elizabeth converting what a friend says into a compliment on the sweetness of Fitzwilliam temper . But Fitzwilliam am afraid Elizabeth are giving it a turn which a friend did by no means intend ; for a friend would certainly think the better of Fitzwilliam , if under such a circumstance Fitzwilliam were to give a flat denial , and ride off as fast as Fitzwilliam could . ” 
 
  “ Would Fitzwilliam then consider the rashness of Fitzwilliam original intention as atoned for by Fitzwilliam obstinacy in adhering to Fitzwilliam original intention ? ” 
 
  “ Upon Miss Bennet word , Miss Bennet can not exactly explain the matter , Fitzwilliam must speak for Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet expect Fitzwilliam to account for opinions which Miss Bennet choose to call Fitzwilliam , but which Fitzwilliam have never acknowledged . Allowing the case , however , to stand according to Miss Bennet representation , Miss Bennet must remember , Miss Bennet , that Charles Charles return to the house , and the delay of Charles plan , has merely desired Charles return to the house , asked Charles return to the house without offering one argument in favour of Charles return to the house propriety . ” 
 
  “ To yield readily — easily — to the persuasion of a friend is no merit with Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of either . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam appear to Miss Bennet , Fitzwilliam , to allow nothing for the influence of friendship and affection . A regard for the requester would often make one readily yield to a request , without waiting for arguments to reason one into a request . Miss Bennet am not particularly speaking of such a case as Fitzwilliam have supposed about Charles . We may as well wait , perhaps , till the circumstance occurs , before we discuss the discretion of Charles behaviour thereupon . But in general and ordinary cases between friend and friend , where one of them is desired by the other to change a resolution of no very great moment , should Fitzwilliam think ill of one of them for complying with the desire , without waiting to be argued into the desire ? ” 
 
  “ Will it not be advisable , before we proceed on this subject , to arrange with rather more precision the degree of importance which is to appertain to this request , as well as the degree of intimacy subsisting between the parties ? ” 
 
  “ By all means , ” cried Charles ; “ let us hear all the particulars , not forgetting the parties comparative height and size ; for that will have more weight in the argument , Miss Bennet , than Miss Bennet may be aware of . Charles assure Miss Bennet that if Fitzwilliam were not such a great tall fellow , in comparison with Charles , Charles should not pay Fitzwilliam half so much deference . Charles declare Charles do not know a more awful object than Fitzwilliam , on particular occasions , and in particular places ; at Fitzwilliam own house especially , and of a Sunday evening , when Fitzwilliam has nothing to do . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam smiled ; but Elizabeth thought Elizabeth could perceive that Fitzwilliam was rather offended , and therefore checked Elizabeth laugh . Caroline warmly resented the indignity Caroline had received , in an expostulation with Caroline brother for talking such nonsense . 
 
  “ I see Charles design , Charles , ” said Caroline friend . “ Charles dislike an argument , and want to silence an argument . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps Charles do . Arguments are too much like disputes . If Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth will defer Fitzwilliam till Charles am out of the room , Charles shall be very thankful ; and then Mrs. Hurst and Caroline may say whatever Mrs. Hurst and Caroline like of Charles . ” 
 
  “ What Fitzwilliam ask , ” said Elizabeth , “ is no sacrifice on Elizabeth side ; and Fitzwilliam had much better finish Fitzwilliam letter . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam took Elizabeth advice , and did finish Fitzwilliam letter . 
 
  When that business was over , Fitzwilliam applied to Mrs. Hurst and Caroline for the indulgence of some music . Caroline moved with alacrity to the pianoforte , and after a polite request that Elizabeth would lead the way , which Elizabeth as politely and more earnestly negatived , Caroline seated Caroline . 
 
  Mrs. Hurst sang with Mrs. Hurst sister , and while they were thus employed , Elizabeth could not help observing , as Elizabeth turned over some music - books that lay on the harp , how frequently Fitzwilliam ’s eyes were fixed on Elizabeth . Elizabeth hardly knew how to suppose that Elizabeth could be an object of admiration to so great a man ; and yet that Fitzwilliam should look at Elizabeth because Fitzwilliam disliked Elizabeth , was still more strange . Elizabeth could only imagine , however , at last , that Elizabeth drew Fitzwilliam notice because there was a something about Elizabeth more wrong and reprehensible , according to Fitzwilliam ideas of right , than in any other person present . The supposition did not pain Elizabeth . Elizabeth liked Fitzwilliam too little to care for Fitzwilliam approbation . 
 
  After playing some Italian songs , Caroline varied the charm by a lively Scotch air ; and soon afterwards Fitzwilliam , drawing near Elizabeth , said to Elizabeth — 
 
  “ Do not Elizabeth feel a great inclination , Elizabeth , to seize such an opportunity of dancing a reel ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth smiled , but made no answer . Fitzwilliam repeated the question , with some surprise at Elizabeth silence . 
 
  “ Oh ! ” said Elizabeth , “ Elizabeth heard Fitzwilliam before ; but Elizabeth could not immediately determine what to say in reply . Fitzwilliam wanted Elizabeth , Elizabeth know , to say ‘ Yes , ’ that Fitzwilliam might have the pleasure of despising Elizabeth taste ; but Fitzwilliam always delight in overthrowing those kind of schemes , and cheating a person of a person premeditated contempt . Elizabeth have , therefore , made up Elizabeth mind to tell Fitzwilliam , that Elizabeth do not want to dance a reel at all — and now despise Elizabeth if Fitzwilliam dare . ” 
 
  “ Indeed Fitzwilliam do not dare . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , having rather expected to affront Fitzwilliam , was amazed at Fitzwilliam gallantry ; but there was a mixture of sweetness and archness in Elizabeth manner which made it difficult for Elizabeth to affront anybody ; and Fitzwilliam had never been so bewitched by any woman as Fitzwilliam was by Elizabeth . Fitzwilliam really believed , that were it not for the inferiority of Elizabeth connections , Fitzwilliam should be in some danger . 
 
  Caroline saw , or suspected enough to be jealous ; and Caroline great anxiety for the recovery of Caroline dear friend Jane received some assistance from Caroline desire of getting rid of Elizabeth . 
 
  Caroline often tried to provoke Fitzwilliam into disliking Caroline guest , by talking of their supposed marriage , and planning Fitzwilliam happiness in such an alliance . 
 
  “ Caroline hope , ” said Caroline , as their were walking together in the shrubbery the next day , “ Fitzwilliam will give Fitzwilliam mother - in - law a few hints , when this desirable event takes place , as to the advantage of holding Mother tongue ; and if Fitzwilliam can compass it , do cure the younger girls of running after the officers . And , if Fitzwilliam may mention so delicate a subject , endeavour to check that little something , bordering on conceit and impertinence , which Fitzwilliam lady possesses . ” 
 
  “ Have Fitzwilliam anything else to propose for Fitzwilliam domestic felicity ? ” 
 
  “ Oh ! yes . Do let the portraits of Fitzwilliam uncle and aunt Philips be placed in the gallery at Pemberley . Put the portraits of Fitzwilliam uncle and aunt Philips next to Fitzwilliam great uncle the judge . Fitzwilliam uncle and aunt Philips are in the same profession , Fitzwilliam know , only in different lines . As for Fitzwilliam Elizabeth ’s picture , Fitzwilliam must not attempt to have Fitzwilliam Elizabeth ’s picture taken , for what painter could do justice to those beautiful eyes ? ” 
 
  “ It would not be easy , indeed , to catch their expression , but their colour and shape , and the eyelashes , so remarkably fine , might be copied . ” 
 
  At that moment their were met from another walk by Mrs. Hurst and Caroline . 
 
  “ Caroline did not know that Mrs. Hurst and Caroline intended to walk , ” said Caroline , in some confusion , lest their had been overheard . 
 
  “ Elizabeth used Mrs. Hurst abominably ill , ” answered Mrs. Hurst , “ running away without telling Mrs. Hurst that Elizabeth were coming out . ” 
 
  Then taking the disengaged arm of Fitzwilliam , Mrs. Hurst left Elizabeth to walk by Elizabeth . The path just admitted three . Fitzwilliam felt three rudeness , and immediately said , — 
 
  “ The path is not wide enough for three . three had better go into the avenue . ” 
 
  But Elizabeth , who had not the least inclination to remain with three , laughingly answered , 
 
  “ No , no ; stay where three are . three are charmingly grouped , and appear to uncommon advantage . The picturesque would be spoilt by admitting a fourth . Good - bye . ” 
 
  Elizabeth then ran gaily off , rejoicing as Elizabeth rambled about , in the hope of being at home again in a day or two . Jane was already so much recovered as to intend leaving Jane room for a couple of hours that evening . 
 Chapter 
 
  When the ladies removed after dinner , Elizabeth ran up to Elizabeth sister , and seeing Elizabeth sister well guarded from cold , attended Elizabeth sister into the drawing - room , where Elizabeth was welcomed by Elizabeth two friends with many professions of pleasure ; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable as them were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared . them powers of conversation were considerable . them could describe an entertainment with accuracy , relate an anecdote with humour , and laugh at them acquaintance with spirit . 
 
  But when the gentlemen entered , Jane was no longer the first object ; Caroline ’s eyes were instantly turned toward Fitzwilliam , and Caroline ’s had something to say to Fitzwilliam before Fitzwilliam had advanced many steps . Fitzwilliam addressed Fitzwilliam to Miss Bennet , with a polite congratulation ; Mr. Hurst also made Miss Bennet a slight bow , and said Mr. Hurst was “ very glad ; ” but diffuseness and warmth remained for Charles ’s salutation . Charles ’s was full of joy and attention . The first half - hour was spent in piling up the fire , lest Elizabeth sister should suffer from the change of room ; and Elizabeth sister removed at Charles ’s desire to the other side of the fireplace , that Elizabeth sister might be further from the door . Charles ’s then sat down by Elizabeth sister , and talked scarcely to anyone else . Elizabeth , at work in the opposite corner , saw it all with great delight . 
 
  When tea was over , Mr. Hurst reminded Mr. Hurst sister - in - law of the card - table — but in vain . Caroline ’s had obtained private intelligence that Fitzwilliam did not wish for cards ; and Mr. Hurst soon found even Mr. Hurst open petition rejected . Caroline ’s assured Mr. Hurst that no one intended to play , and the silence of the whole party on the subject seemed to justify Caroline ’s . Mr. Hurst had therefore nothing to do , but to stretch Mr. Hurst on one of the sofas and go to sleep . Fitzwilliam took up a book ; Caroline ’s did the same ; and Mrs. Hurst , principally occupied in playing with Caroline ’s bracelets and rings , joined now and then in Mr. Hurst conversation with Miss Bennet . 
 
  Caroline ’s attention was quite as much engaged in watching Fitzwilliam ’s progress through a book , as in reading Caroline ’s own ; and Caroline ’s was perpetually either making some enquiry , or looking at Fitzwilliam page . Caroline ’s could not win Fitzwilliam , however , to any conversation ; Fitzwilliam merely answered Caroline ’s question , and read on . At length , quite exhausted by the attempt to be amused with Caroline ’s own book , which Caroline ’s had only chosen because a book was the second volume of Fitzwilliam , Caroline ’s gave a great yawn and said , “ How pleasant it is to spend an evening in this way ! Caroline ’s declare after all there is no enjoyment like reading ! How much sooner one tires of anything than of a book ! When Caroline ’s have a house of Caroline ’s own , Caroline ’s shall be miserable if Caroline ’s have not an excellent library . ” 
 
  No one made any reply . Caroline ’s then yawned again , threw aside Caroline ’s book , and cast Caroline ’s eyes round the room in quest for some amusement ; when hearing Caroline ’s brother mentioning a ball to Miss Bennet Miss Bennet , Caroline ’s turned suddenly towards Caroline ’s brother and said : 
 
  “ By the bye , Caroline ’s brother , are Caroline ’s brother really serious in meditating a dance at Netherfield ? Caroline ’s would advise Caroline ’s brother , before Caroline ’s brother determine on it , to consult the wishes of the present party ; Caroline ’s am much mistaken if there are not some among us to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a pleasure . ” 
 
  “ If Caroline ’s mean Fitzwilliam , ” cried Caroline ’s brother , “ Fitzwilliam may go to bed , if Fitzwilliam chooses , before a ball to Miss Bennet Miss Bennet begins — but as for a ball to Miss Bennet Miss Bennet , it is quite a settled thing ; and as soon as Nicholls has made white soup enough , Caroline ’s brother shall send round Caroline ’s brother cards . ” 
 
  “ Caroline ’s should like balls infinitely better , ” Caroline ’s replied , “ if balls were carried on in a different manner ; but there is something insufferably tedious in the usual process of such a meeting . It would surely be much more rational if conversation instead of dancing were made the order of the day . ” 
 
  “ Much more rational , Caroline ’s brother dear Caroline , Caroline ’s brother dare say , but conversation would not be near so much like a ball . ” 
 
  Caroline ’s made no answer , and soon afterwards Caroline ’s got up and walked about the room . Caroline ’s figure was elegant , and Caroline ’s walked well ; but Fitzwilliam , at whom it was all aimed , was still inflexibly studious . In the desperation of Caroline ’s feelings , Caroline ’s resolved on one effort more , and , turning to Elizabeth , said : 
 
  “ Elizabeth , let Caroline ’s persuade Elizabeth to follow Caroline ’s example , and take a turn about the room . Caroline ’s assure Elizabeth it is very refreshing after sitting so long in one attitude . ” 
 
  Elizabeth was surprised , but agreed to take immediately . Caroline ’s succeeded no less in the real object of Elizabeth civility ; Fitzwilliam looked up . Fitzwilliam was as much awake to the novelty of attention in that quarter as Elizabeth Elizabeth could be , and unconsciously closed a book . Fitzwilliam was directly invited to join the whole party , but Fitzwilliam declined invited , observing that Fitzwilliam could imagine but two motives for their choosing to walk up and down the room together , with either of which motives Fitzwilliam joining their would interfere . “ What could Fitzwilliam mean ? Caroline ’s was dying to know what could be Fitzwilliam meaning?”—and asked Elizabeth whether Elizabeth could at all understand Fitzwilliam ? 
 
  “ Not at all , ” was Elizabeth answer ; “ but depend upon it , Fitzwilliam means to be severe on their , and their surest way of disappointing Fitzwilliam will be to ask nothing about it . ” 
 
  Caroline ’s , however , was incapable of disappointing Fitzwilliam in anything , and persevered therefore in requiring an explanation of Fitzwilliam two motives . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam have not the smallest objection to explaining but two motives for their choosing to walk up and down the room together , ” said Fitzwilliam , as soon as Elizabeth allowed Fitzwilliam to speak . “ their either choose this method of passing the evening because their are in each other ’s confidence , and have secret affairs to discuss , or because their are conscious that their figures appear to the greatest advantage in walking ; if the first , Fitzwilliam would be completely in their way , and if the second , Fitzwilliam can admire their much better as Fitzwilliam sit by the fire . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! shocking ! ” cried Caroline ’s . “ Caroline ’s never heard anything so abominable . How shall their punish Fitzwilliam for such a speech ? ” 
 
  “ Nothing so easy , if Fitzwilliam have but the inclination , ” said Elizabeth . “ We can all plague and punish one another . Tease Fitzwilliam — laugh at Fitzwilliam . Intimate as Fitzwilliam are , Fitzwilliam must know how it is to be done . ” 
 
  “ But upon Caroline ’s honour , Caroline ’s do not . Caroline ’s do assure Fitzwilliam that Caroline ’s intimacy has not yet taught Caroline ’s that . Tease calmness of manner and presence of mind ! No , no ; Caroline ’s feel Fitzwilliam may defy their there . And as to laughter , their will not expose their , if Fitzwilliam please , by attempting to laugh without a subject . Fitzwilliam may hug Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam is not to be laughed at ! ” cried Elizabeth . “ That is an uncommon advantage , and uncommon Elizabeth hope it will continue , for it would be a great loss to Elizabeth to have many such acquaintances . Elizabeth dearly love a laugh . ” 
 
  “ Caroline ’s , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ has given Fitzwilliam more credit than can be . The wisest and the best of men — nay , the wisest and best of men actions — may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in life is a joke . ” 
 
  “ Certainly , ” replied Elizabeth—“there are such people , but Elizabeth hope Elizabeth am not one of such people . Elizabeth hope Elizabeth never ridicule what is wise and good . Follies and nonsense , whims and inconsistencies , do divert Elizabeth , Elizabeth own , and Elizabeth laugh at Follies and nonsense , whims and inconsistencies whenever Elizabeth can . But Follies and nonsense , whims and inconsistencies , Caroline ’s suppose , are precisely what Fitzwilliam are without . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps that is not possible for anyone . But it has been the study of Elizabeth life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong understanding to ridicule . ” 
 
  “ Such as vanity and pride . ” 
 
  “ Yes , vanity is a weakness indeed . But pride — where there is a real superiority of mind , pride will be always under good regulation . ” 
 
  Elizabeth turned away to hide a smile . 
 
  “ Caroline ’s examination of Fitzwilliam is over , Caroline ’s presume , ” said Caroline ’s ; “ and pray what is the result ? ” 
 
  “ Caroline ’s am perfectly convinced by the result that Fitzwilliam has no defect . Fitzwilliam owns it Fitzwilliam without disguise . ” 
 
  “ No , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ Fitzwilliam have made no such pretension . Fitzwilliam have faults enough , but faults are not , Fitzwilliam hope , of understanding . Fitzwilliam temper Fitzwilliam dare not vouch for . Fitzwilliam temper is , Fitzwilliam believe , too little yielding — certainly too little for the convenience of the world . Fitzwilliam can not forget the follies and vices of others so soon as Fitzwilliam ought , nor others offenses against Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam feelings are not puffed about with every attempt to move Fitzwilliam feelings . Fitzwilliam temper would perhaps be called resentful . Fitzwilliam good opinion once lost , is lost forever . ” 
 
  “ That is a failing indeed ! ” cried Elizabeth . “ Implacable resentment is a shade in a character . But Fitzwilliam have chosen Fitzwilliam fault well . Caroline ’s really can not laugh at Fitzwilliam fault . Fitzwilliam are safe from Caroline ’s . ” 
 
  “ There is , Fitzwilliam believe , in every disposition a tendency to some particular evil — a natural defect , which not even the best education can overcome . ” 
 
  “ And Fitzwilliam defect is to hate everybody . ” 
 
  “ And Fitzwilliam , ” Fitzwilliam replied with a smile , “ is willfully to misunderstand them . ” 
 
  “ Do let their have a little music , ” cried Caroline ’s , tired of a conversation in which Caroline ’s had no share . “ Louisa , Louisa will not mind Caroline ’s waking Mr. Hurst ? ” 
 
  Louisa had not the smallest objection , and the pianoforte was opened ; and Fitzwilliam , after a few moments ’ recollection , was not sorry for it . Fitzwilliam began to feel the danger of paying Elizabeth too much attention . 
 Chapter
 
  In consequence of an agreement between the sisters , Elizabeth wrote the next morning to the sisters mother , to beg that the carriage might be sent for the sisters in the course of the day . But the sisters mother the sisters mother daughters remaining at Netherfield till the following Tuesday , which would exactly finish Jane ’s week , could not bring the sisters mother to receive the sisters with pleasure before . the sisters mother answer , therefore , was not propitious , at least not to Elizabeth ’s wishes , for Elizabeth was impatient to get home . the sisters mother sent the sisters word that the sisters could not possibly have the carriage before the following Tuesday , which would exactly finish Jane ’s week ; and in the sisters mother postscript it was added , that if Charles and Charles sister pressed the sisters to stay longer , the sisters mother could spare the sisters very well . Against staying longer , however , Elizabeth was positively resolved — nor did Elizabeth much expect it would be asked ; and fearful , on the contrary , as being considered as intruding the sisters needlessly long , Elizabeth urged Jane ’s to borrow the carriage immediately , and at length it was settled that the sisters original design of leaving Netherfield that morning should be mentioned , and borrow made . 
 
  The communication excited many professions of concern ; and enough was said of wishing the sisters to stay at least till the following day to work on Jane ’s ; and till the morrow the sisters going was deferred . Caroline was then sorry that Caroline had proposed the delay , for Caroline jealousy and dislike of one sister much exceeded Caroline affection for the other . 
 
  The master of the house heard with real sorrow that the sisters were to go so soon , and repeatedly tried to persuade Jane ’s that it would not be safe for Jane ’s — that Jane ’s was not enough recovered ; but Jane ’s was firm where Jane ’s felt Jane ’s to be right . 
 
  To Fitzwilliam it was welcome intelligence — Elizabeth had been at Netherfield long enough . Elizabeth attracted Fitzwilliam more than Fitzwilliam liked — and Caroline was uncivil to Elizabeth , and more teasing than usual to Caroline . Caroline wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration should now escape Caroline , nothing that could elevate Elizabeth with the hope of influencing Caroline felicity ; sensible that if such an idea had been suggested , Caroline behaviour during the last day must have material weight in confirming or crushing such an idea . Steady to Caroline purpose , Caroline scarcely spoke ten words to Elizabeth through the whole of Saturday , and though the sisters were at one time left by the sisters for half - an - hour , Caroline adhered most conscientiously to Caroline book , and would not even look at Elizabeth . 
 
  On Sunday , after morning service , the separation , so agreeable to almost all , took place . Caroline ’s civility to Elizabeth increased at last very rapidly , as well as Elizabeth affection for Jane ’s ; and when the sisters parted , after assuring Elizabeth of the pleasure it would always give Elizabeth to see Elizabeth either at Longbourn or Netherfield , and embracing Elizabeth most tenderly , Elizabeth even shook hands with Jane ’s . Elizabeth took leave of the whole party in the liveliest of spirits . 
 
  the sisters were not welcomed home very cordially by the sisters mother . the sisters mother wondered at the sisters coming , and thought the sisters very wrong to give so much trouble , and was sure Jane ’s would have caught cold again . But the sisters father , though very laconic in the sisters father expressions of pleasure , was really glad to see the sisters ; the sisters father had felt the sisters importance in the family circle . The evening conversation , when they were all assembled , had lost much of The evening conversation , when they were all assembled animation , and almost all The evening conversation , when they were all assembled sense by the absence of Jane ’s and Elizabeth . 
 
  They found Mary , as usual , deep in the study of thorough - bass and human nature ; and had some extracts to admire , and some new observations of threadbare morality to listen to . Catherine and Lydia had information for they of a different sort . Much had been done and much had been said in the regiment since the preceding Wednesday ; several of the officers had dined lately with several of the officers uncle , a private had been flogged , and it had actually been hinted that Colonel Forster was going to be married . 
 Chapter 
 
  “ Father hope , Father dear , ” said Father to Father wife , as they were at breakfast the next morning , “ that Father dear have ordered a good dinner to - day , because Father have reason to expect an addition to our family party . ” 
 
  “ Who do Father mean , Father ? Father know of nobody that is coming , Father am sure , unless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in — and Father hope Father dinners are good enough for Charlotte Lucas . Father do not believe Charlotte Lucas often sees such at home . ” 
 
  “ The person of whom Father speak is a gentleman , and a stranger . ” 
 
  Father dear eyes sparkled . “ a gentleman , and a stranger gentleman and a stranger ! It is Charles , Father am sure ! Well , Father dear am sure Father dear shall be extremely glad to see Charlotte Lucas . But — good Lord ! how unlucky ! There is not a bit of fish to be got to - day . Lydia , Father dear love , ring the bell — Father dear must speak to Father this moment . ” 
 
  “ It is not Charlotte Lucas , ” said Father dear husband ; “ it is The person of whom Father speak . ” 
 
  This roused a general astonishment ; and Father had the pleasure of being eagerly questioned by Father dear and Father five daughters at once . 
 
  After amusing Father some time with Father dear and Father five daughters curiosity , Father thus explained : 
 
  “ About a month ago Father received this letter ; and about a fortnight ago Father answered this letter , for Father thought it a case of some delicacy , and requiring early attention . this letter is from Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as pleases . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Father , ” cried Father wife , “ Father dear can not bear to hear Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as mentioned . Pray do not talk of Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as . Father dear do think it is the hardest thing in the world , that Father dear estate should be entailed away from Father dear own children ; and Father dear am sure , if Father dear had been Father dear , Father dear should have tried long ago to do something or other about it . ” 
 
  Jane and Elizabeth tried to explain to Father dear the nature of an entail . Jane and Elizabeth had often attempted to do an entail before , but an entail was a subject on which Father dear was beyond the reach of reason , and Father dear continued to rail bitterly against the cruelty of settling Father dear estate away from Father five daughters , in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about . 
 
  “ It certainly is a most iniquitous affair , ” said Father , “ and nothing can clear Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn . But if Father dear will listen to Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as letter , Father dear may perhaps be a little softened by Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as manner of expressing Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as . ” 
 
  “ No , that Father dear am sure Father dear shall not ; and Father dear think it is very impertinent of Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as to write to Father dear at all , and very hypocritical . Father dear hate such false friends . Why could Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as not keep on quarreling with Father dear , as Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as father did before Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as ? ” 
 
  “ Why , indeed ; Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as does seem to have had some filial scruples on that head , as Father dear will hear . ” 
 
  “ Hunsford , near Westerham , Kent , 15th October . 
 
  “ Father , — 
  “ The disagreement subsisting between Father dear and my late honoured father always gave my much uneasiness , and since my have had the misfortune to lose my late honoured father , my have frequently wished to heal the breach ; but for some time my was kept back by my own doubts , fearing lest it might seem disrespectful to my late honoured father memory for my to be on good terms with anyone with whom it had always pleased my late honoured father to be at variance.—‘There , Father dear . ’—My mind , however , is now made up on the subject , for having received ordination at Easter , my have been so fortunate as to be distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Cathleen , widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh , whose bounty and beneficence has preferred my to the valuable rectory of this parish , where it shall be my earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her ladyship , and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which are instituted by the Church of England . As a clergyman , moreover , my feel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in all families within the reach of my influence ; and on these grounds my flatter myself that my present overtures are highly commendable , and that the circumstance of my being next in the entail of Longbourn estate will be kindly overlooked on Father dear side , and not lead Father dear to reject the offered olive - branch . my can not be otherwise than concerned at being the means of injuring Father dear amiable daughters , and beg leave to apologise for being , as well as to assure Father dear of my readiness to make Father dear amiable daughters every possible amends — but of this hereafter . If Father dear should have no objection to receive my into Father dear house , my propose myself the satisfaction of waiting on Father dear and Father five daughters , Monday , November 18th , by four o’clock , and shall probably trespass on Father dear hospitality till the Saturday se’ennight following , which my can do without any inconvenience , as her ladyship is far from objecting to my occasional absence on a Sunday , provided that some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day.—I remain , Father dear , with respectful compliments to Father dear lady and daughters , Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as ” 
 
  “ At four o’clock , therefore , Father dear and Father five daughters may expect Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as , ” said Father , as Father folded up this letter . “ Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as seems to be a most conscientious and polite young man , upon Father word , and Father doubt Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as will prove a valuable acquaintance , especially if her ladyship should be so indulgent as to let Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as come to us again . ” 
 
  “ There is some sense in what Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as says about Father dear amiable daughters , however , and if Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as is disposed to make Father dear amiable daughters any amends , Father shall not be the person to discourage Father cousin , Mr. Collins , who , when Father am dead , may turn Father five daughters out of this house as soon as . ”

 Chapter 
 
  During dinner , Father scarcely spoke at all ; but when the servants were withdrawn , Father thought it time to have some conversation with Father guest , and therefore started a subject in which Father expected Father guest to shine , by observing that Father guest seemed very fortunate in Father guest patroness . Father guest patroness attention to Father guest wishes , and consideration for Father guest comfort , appeared very remarkable . Father could not have chosen better . Father guest was eloquent in Father guest praise . a subject in which Father expected Father guest to shine , by observing that Father guest seemed very fortunate in Father guest patroness elevated Father guest to more than usual solemnity of manner , and with a most important aspect Father guest protested that “ Father guest had never in Father guest life witnessed such behaviour in a person of rank — such affability and condescension , as Father guest had Father guest experienced from Father guest patroness . Father guest patroness had been graciously pleased to approve of both of the discourses which Father guest had already had the honour of preaching before Father guest patroness . Father guest patroness had also asked Father guest twice to dine at Rosings , and had sent for Father guest only the Saturday before , to make up Father guest patroness pool of quadrille in the evening . Father guest patroness was reckoned proud by many people Father guest knew , but Father guest had never seen anything but affability in Father guest patroness . Father guest patroness had always spoken to Father guest as Father guest patroness would to any other gentleman ; Father guest patroness made not the smallest objection to Father guest joining in the society of the neighbourhood nor to Father guest leaving the parish occasionally for a week or two , to visit Father guest relations . Father guest patroness had even condescended to advise Father guest to marry as soon as Father guest could , provided Father guest chose with discretion ; and had once paid Father guest a visit in Father guest humble parsonage , where Father guest patroness had perfectly approved all the alterations Father guest had been making , and had even vouchsafed to suggest some Father guest patroness — some shelves in the closet up stairs . ” 
 
  “ That is all very proper and civil , Mother am sure , ” said Mother , “ and Mother dare say Father guest patroness is a very agreeable woman . It is a pity that great ladies in general are not more like Father guest patroness . Does Father guest patroness live near Father guest , Father guest ? ” 
 
  “ The garden in which stands Father guest humble abode is separated only by a lane from Rosings Park , Father guest patroness residence . ” 
 
  “ Mother think Father guest said Father guest patroness was a widow , Father guest ? Has Father guest patroness any family ? ” 
 
  “ Father guest patroness has only one daughter , the heiress of Rosings , and of very extensive property . ” 
 
  “ Ah ! ” said Mother , shaking Mother head , “ then Father guest patroness is better off than many girls . And what sort of young lady is Father guest patroness ? Is Father guest patroness handsome ? ” 
 
  “ Father guest patroness is a most charming young lady indeed . Father guest patroness Father guest patroness says that , in point of true beauty , Father guest patroness is far superior to the handsomest of Father guest patroness sex , because there is that in Father guest patroness features which marks Father guest patroness . Father guest patroness is unfortunately of a sickly constitution , which has prevented Father guest patroness from making that progress in many accomplishments which Father guest patroness could not have otherwise failed of , as Father guest am informed by the lady who superintended Father guest patroness education , and who still resides with Father guest patroness education . But Father guest patroness is perfectly amiable , and often condescends to drive by Father guest humble abode in Father guest patroness little phaeton and ponies . ” 
 
  “ Has Father guest patroness been presented ? Mother do not remember Father guest patroness name among the ladies at court . ” 
 
  “ Father guest patroness indifferent state of health unhappily prevents Father guest patroness being in town ; and by prevents , as Father guest told Father guest patroness one day , has deprived the British court of the British court brightest ornament . Father guest patroness seemed pleased with the idea ; and Mother may imagine that Father guest am happy on every occasion to offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable to ladies . Father guest have more than once observed to Father guest patroness , that Father guest patroness charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess , and that the most elevated rank , instead of giving Father guest patroness consequence , would be adorned by Father guest patroness . These are the kind of little things which please Father guest patroness , and it is a sort of attention which Father guest conceive Father guest peculiarly bound to pay . ” 
 
  “ Father guest judge very properly , ” said Father , “ and it is happy for Father guest that Father guest possess the talent of flattering with delicacy . May Father ask whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment , or are the result of previous study ? ” 
 
  “ these pleasing attentions arise chiefly from what is passing at the time , and though Father guest sometimes amuse Father guest with suggesting and arranging such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions , Father guest always wish to give such little elegant compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions as unstudied an air as possible . ” 
 
  Father ’s expectations were fully answered . Father cousin was as absurd as Father had hoped , and Father listened to Father cousin with the keenest enjoyment , maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance , and , except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth , requiring no partner in Father pleasure . 
 
  By tea - time , however , the dose had been enough , and Father was glad to take Father guest into the drawing - room again , and , when tea was over , glad to invite Father guest to read aloud to the ladies . Father guest readily assented , and a book was produced ; but , on beholding a book ( for everything announced a book to be from a circulating library ) , Father guest started back , and begging pardon , protested that Father guest never read novels . Kitty stared at Father guest , and Lydia exclaimed . Other books were produced , and after some deliberation Father guest chose Fordyce ’s Sermons . Lydia gaped as Father guest opened a book , and before Father guest had , with very monotonous solemnity , read three pages , Lydia interrupted Father guest with : 
 
  “ Do Mother know , Mother , that Lydia uncle Phillips talks of turning away Richard ; and if Lydia uncle Phillips does , Colonel Forster will hire Richard . Lydia aunt told Father guest so Lydia aunt on Saturday . Lydia shall walk to Meryton to - morrow to hear more about it , and to ask when Mr. Denny comes back from town . ” 
 
  Lydia was bid by Lydia two eldest sisters to hold Lydia tongue ; but Father guest , much offended , laid aside a book , and said : 
 
  “ Father guest have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books of a serious stamp , though written solely for little young ladies benefit . interested amazes Father guest , Father guest confess ; for , certainly , there can be nothing so advantageous to little young ladies as instruction . But Father guest will no longer importune Father guest young cousin . ” 
 
  Then turning to Father , Father guest offered Father guest as Father antagonist at backgammon . Father accepted the challenge , observing that Father acted very wisely in leaving Lydia two eldest sisters to Lydia two eldest sisters own trifling amusements . Mother and Lydia two eldest sisters apologised most civilly for interrupted , and promised that interrupted should not occur again , if Father guest would resume Father guest book ; but Father guest , after assuring Mother and Lydia two eldest sisters that Father guest bore Father guest young cousin no ill - will , and should never resent Lydia behaviour as any affront , seated Father guest at another table with Father , and prepared for backgammon . 
 Chapter 
 
  William Collins was not a sensible man , and the deficiency of nature had been but little assisted by education or society ; the greatest part of William Collins life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and miserly father ; and though William Collins belonged to one of the universities , William Collins had merely kept the necessary terms , without forming at one of the universities any useful acquaintance . The subjection in which an illiterate and miserly father had brought William Collins up had given William Collins originally great humility of manner ; but great humility of manner was now a good deal counteracted by the self - conceit of a weak head , living in retirement , and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected prosperity . A fortunate chance had recommended William Collins to Cathleen when the living of Hunsford was vacant ; and the respect which William Collins felt for Cathleen high rank , and William Collins veneration for Cathleen as William Collins patroness , mingling with a very good opinion of William Collins , of William Collins authority as a clergyman , and William Collins right as a rector , made William Collins altogether a mixture of pride and obsequiousness , self - importance and humility . 
 
  Having now a good house and a very sufficient income , William Collins intended to marry ; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family William Collins had a wife in view , as William Collins meant to choose one of the daughters , if William Collins found the daughters as handsome and amiable as the daughters were represented by common report . William Collins plan was William Collins plan of amends — of atonement — for inheriting the daughters father ’s estate ; and William Collins thought William Collins plan an excellent one , full of eligibility and suitableness , and excessively generous and disinterested on William Collins own part . 
 
  William Collins plan did not vary on seeing the daughters . Miss Bennet ’s lovely face confirmed William Collins views , and established all William Collins strictest notions of what was due to seniority ; and for the first evening Miss Bennet ’s was William Collins settled choice . The next morning , however , made an alteration ; for in a quarter of an hour ’s tête - à - tête with Mother before breakfast , a conversation beginning with William Collins parsonage - house , and leading naturally to the avowal of William Collins hopes , that a mistress might be found for it at Longbourn , produced from Mother , amid very complaisant smiles and general encouragement , a caution against the very Jane William Collins had fixed on . “ As to Mother younger daughters , Mother could not take upon Mother to say — Mother could not positively answer — but Mother did not know of any prepossession ; Mother eldest daughter , Mother must just mention — Mother felt it incumbent on Mother to hint , was likely to be very soon engaged . ” William Collins William Collins had only to change from the very Jane William Collins had fixed on to Elizabeth — and change was soon done — done while Mother was stirring the fire . Elizabeth , equally next to the very Jane William Collins had fixed on in birth and beauty , succeeded the very Jane William Collins had fixed on of course . Mother Mother treasured up the hint , and trusted that Mother might soon have two daughters married ; and the man whom Mother could not bear to speak of the day before was now high in Mother good graces . 
 
  Lydia ’s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten ; every sister except Mary agreed to go with Lydia ’s ; and William Collins was to attend the daughters , at the request of Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have library to Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have ; for thither William Collins had followed Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have after breakfast ; and there William Collins would continue , nominally engaged with one of the largest folios in the collection , but really talking to Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have , with little cessation , of Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have house and garden at Hunsford . Such doings discomposed Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have exceedingly . In Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have library Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have had been always sure of leisure and tranquillity ; and though prepared , as Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have told Elizabeth , to meet with folly and conceit in every other room of the house , Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have was used to be free from folly and conceit there ; Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have civility , therefore , was most prompt in inviting William Collins to join Father , who was most anxious to get rid of William Collins , and have daughters in the daughters walk ; and William Collins , being in fact much better fitted for a walker than a reader , was extremely pleased to close one of the largest folios in the collection , and go . 
 
  In pompous nothings on William Collins side , and civil assents on that of William Collins cousins , the daughters time passed till the daughters entered Meryton . The attention of the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by William Collins . the younger ones eyes were immediately wandering up in the street in quest of the officers , and nothing less than a very smart bonnet indeed , or a really new muslin in a shop window , could recall the officers . 
 
  But the attention of every lady was soon caught by a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way . a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way was the very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from London Lydia ’s came to enquire , and a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way bowed as the daughters passed . All were struck with a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way air , all wondered who a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way could be ; and the daughters , determined if possible to find out , led the way across the street , under pretense of wanting something in an opposite shop , and fortunately had just gained the pavement when the officers , turning back , had reached the same spot . Mr. Denny addressed the daughters directly , and entreated permission to introduce Mr. Denny friend , Charlie , who had returned with Mr. Denny the day before from town , and Mr. Denny was happy to say had accepted a commission in the officers corps . This was exactly as it should be ; for a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way wanted only regimentals to make a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way completely charming . a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way appearance was greatly in a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way favour ; a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way had all the best part of beauty , a fine countenance , a good figure , and very pleasing address . introduce was followed up on a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way side by a happy readiness of conversation — a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and unassuming ; and the daughters were still standing and talking together very agreeably , when the sound of horses drew the daughters notice , and Fitzwilliam and Charles were seen riding down the street . On distinguishing the daughters the daughters , the officers came directly towards the daughters , and began the usual civilities . Charles was the principal spokesman , and Miss Bennet ’s the principal object . Charles was then , Charles said , on Charles way to Longbourn on purpose to enquire after Miss Bennet ’s . Fitzwilliam corroborated it with a bow , and was beginning to determine not to fix Fitzwilliam eyes on Elizabeth , when the daughters were suddenly arrested by the sight of a young man , whom every lady had never seen before , of most gentlemanlike appearance , walking with another officer on the other side of the way , and Elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as both looked at each other , was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting . Both changed colour , one looked white , the other red . Charles , after a few moments , touched Charles hat — a salutation which Fitzwilliam just deigned to return . What could be the meaning of a salutation which Fitzwilliam just deigned to return ? It was impossible to imagine ; it was impossible not to long to know . 
 
  In another minute , Charles , but without seeming to have noticed what passed , took leave and rode on with Charles friend . 
 
  the officers walked with the daughters to the door of Mr. Phillip ’s house , and then made the officers bows , in spite of Lydia ’s pressing entreaties that the daughters should come in , and even in spite of Mr. Phillip ’s throwing up the parlour window and loudly seconding the invitation . 
 
  Mr. Phillip ’s was always glad to see the daughters ; and the two eldest , from the two eldest recent absence , were particularly welcome , and Mr. Phillip ’s was eagerly expressing Mr. Phillip ’s surprise at the two eldest sudden return home , which , as the two eldest own carriage had not fetched the two eldest , Mr. Phillip ’s should have known nothing about , if Mr. Phillip ’s had not happened to see Mr. Jones ’s shop - boy in the street , who had told Mr. Phillip ’s that they were not to send any more draughts to Netherfield because Miss Bennet ’s were come away , when Mr. Phillip ’s civility was claimed towards William Collins by the very Jane William Collins had fixed on introduction of William Collins . Mr. Phillip ’s received William Collins with Mr. Phillip ’s very best politeness , which William Collins returned with as much more , apologising for William Collins intrusion , without any previous acquaintance with Mr. Phillip ’s , which William Collins could not help flattering William Collins , however , might be justified by William Collins relationship to the young ladies who introduced William Collins to Mr. Phillip ’s notice . Mr. Phillip ’s was quite awed by such an excess of good breeding ; but Mr. Phillip ’s contemplation of one stranger was soon put to an end by exclamations and enquiries about the other ; of whom , however , Mr. Phillip ’s could only tell Mr. Phillip ’s nieces what the daughters already knew , that Mr. Denny had brought William Collins from London , and that William Collins was to have a lieutenant ’s commission in the — — shire . Mr. Phillip ’s had been watching William Collins the last hour , Mr. Phillip ’s said , as William Collins walked up and down the street , and had Charles appeared , the daughters would certainly have continued the occupation , but unluckily no one passed windows now except a few of the officers , who , in comparison with William Collins , were become “ stupid , disagreeable fellows . ” Some of the officers , who , in comparison with William Collins , were become “ stupid , disagreeable fellows were to dine with Mr. Phillip ’s the next day , and Mr. Phillip ’s promised to make Mr. Phillip ’s husband call on Charles , and give Charles an invitation also , if the family from Longbourn would come in the evening . come was agreed to , and Mr. Phillip ’s protested that the daughters would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery tickets , and a little bit of hot supper afterwards . The prospect of such delights was very cheering , and the daughters parted in mutual good spirits . William Collins repeated William Collins apologies in quitting the room , and was assured with unwearying civility that William Collins apologies were perfectly needless . 
 
  As the daughters walked home , Elizabeth related to the very Jane William Collins had fixed on what Elizabeth had seen pass between the officers ; but though the very Jane William Collins had fixed on would have defended either or both , had the officers appeared to be in the wrong , the very Jane William Collins had fixed on could no more explain such behaviour than the very Jane William Collins had fixed on sister . 
 
  William Collins on William Collins return highly gratified Mother by admiring Mr. Phillip ’s manners and politeness . William Collins protested that , except Cathleen and Mother eldest daughter , William Collins had never seen a more elegant woman ; for Mr. Phillip ’s had not only received William Collins with the utmost civility , but even pointedly included William Collins in Mr. Phillip ’s invitation for the next evening , although utterly unknown to Mr. Phillip ’s before . Something , William Collins supposed , might be attributed to William Collins connection with the Longbourn family , but yet William Collins had never met with so much attention in the whole course of William Collins life . 
 Chapter 
 
  As no objection was made to the young people ’s engagement with the young people ’s aunt , and all William Collins ’s scruples of leaving Father and Mother for a single evening during William Collins ’s visit were most steadily resisted , the coach conveyed William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton ; and William Collins ’s five cousins had the pleasure of hearing , as William Collins ’s five cousins entered the drawing - room , that Charlie had accepted the young people ’s aunt invitation , and was then in the house . 
 
  When this information was given , and William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s five cousins had all taken William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s five cousins seats , William Collins ’s was at leisure to look around William Collins ’s and admire , and William Collins ’s was so much struck with the size and furniture of the drawing - room , that William Collins ’s declared William Collins ’s might almost have supposed William Collins ’s in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings ; declared ; but when Mrs. Phillips understood from William Collins ’s what Rosings was , and who was Rosings proprietor — when Mrs. Phillips had listened to the description of only one of Cathleen ’s drawing - rooms , and found that the chimney - piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds , Mrs. Phillips felt all the force of the compliment , and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper ’s room . 
 
  In describing to Mrs. Phillips all the grandeur of Cathleen ’s and Cathleen ’s mansion , with occasional digressions in praise of William Collins ’s own humble abode , and the improvements William Collins ’s own humble abode was receiving , William Collins ’s was happily employed until the gentlemen joined William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s five cousins ; and William Collins ’s found in Mrs. Phillips a very attentive listener , whose opinion of William Collins ’s consequence increased with what Mrs. Phillips heard , and who was resolving to retail it all among Mrs. Phillips neighbours as soon as Mrs. Phillips could . To the girls , who could not listen to William Collins ’s five cousins cousin , and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument , and examine William Collins ’s five cousins own indifferent imitations of china on the mantelpiece , the interval of waiting appeared very long . the interval of waiting was over at last , however . The gentlemen did approach , and when Charlie walked into the room , Elizabeth felt that Elizabeth had neither been seeing Charlie before , nor thinking of Charlie since , with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration . The officers of the — — shire were in general a very creditable , gentlemanlike set , and the best of The officers of the — — shire were of the present party ; but Charlie was as far beyond The officers of the — — shire in person , countenance , air , and walk , as The officers of the — — shire were superior to the broad - faced , stuffy uncle Phillips , breathing port wine , who followed The officers of the — — shire into the room . 
 
  Charlie was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned , and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom Charlie finally seated Charlie ; and the agreeable manner in which Charlie immediately fell into conversation , though it was only on its being a wet night , made Elizabeth feel that the commonest , dullest , most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker .
