  Charlotte Lucas hardly had time to answer , before they were joined by Kitty , who came to tell the same news ; and no sooner had they entered the breakfast - room , where Mother was alone , than Mother likewise began on the subject , calling on Charlotte Lucas for Charlotte Lucas compassion , and entreating Charlotte Lucas to persuade Charlotte Lucas friend Elizabeth to comply with the wishes of all Elizabeth family . “ Pray do , Charlotte Lucas , ” Mother added in a melancholy tone , “ for nobody is on Mother side , nobody takes part with Mother . Mother am cruelly used , nobody feels for Mother poor nerves . ” 
 
  Charlotte Lucas reply was spared by the entrance of Jane and Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Aye , there Elizabeth comes , ” continued Mother , “ looking as unconcerned as may be , and caring no more for the family than if the family were at York , provided Elizabeth can have Elizabeth own way . But Mother tell Elizabeth , Elizabeth — if Elizabeth take it into Elizabeth head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way , Elizabeth will never get a husband at all — and Mother am sure Mother do not know who is to maintain Elizabeth when Elizabeth father is dead . Mother shall not be able to keep Elizabeth — and so Mother warn Elizabeth . Mother have done with Elizabeth from this very day . Mother told Elizabeth in the library , Elizabeth know , that Mother should never speak to Elizabeth again , and Elizabeth will find Mother as good as Mother word . Mother have no pleasure in talking to undutiful children . Not that Mother have much pleasure , indeed , in talking to anybody . People who suffer as Mother do from nervous complaints can have no great inclination for talking . Nobody can tell what Mother suffer ! But it is always so . Those who do not complain are never pitied . ” 
 
  Elizabeth listened in silence to this effusion , sensible that any attempt to reason with Mother or soothe Mother would only increase the irritation . Mother talked on , therefore , without interruption from any of Elizabeth , till Elizabeth were joined by William Collins , who entered the room with an air more stately than usual , and on perceiving whom , Mother said to Elizabeth , “ Now , Mother do insist upon it , that Elizabeth , hold Elizabeth tongues , and let Mother and William Collins have a little conversation together . ” 
 
  Elizabeth passed quietly out of the room , Jane and Kitty followed , but Lydia stood Lydia ground , determined to hear all Lydia could ; and Charlotte Lucas , detained first by the civility of William Collins Collins , whose enquiries after Charlotte Lucas and all Charlotte Lucas family were very minute , and then by a little curiosity , satisfied Charlotte Lucas with walking to the window and pretending not to hear . In a doleful voice Mother began a little conversation : “ Oh ! William Collins ! ” 
 
  “ Father dear madam , ” replied William Collins , “ let us be for ever silent on this point . Far be it from William Collins , ” William Collins presently continued , in a voice that marked William Collins displeasure , “ to resent the behaviour of Elizabeth . Resignation to inevitable evils is the duty of us all ; the peculiar duty of a young man who has been so fortunate as William Collins have been in early preferment ; and William Collins trust William Collins am resigned . Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of William Collins positive happiness had William Collins fair cousin honoured William Collins with Elizabeth hand ; for William Collins have often observed that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of the blessing denied value in our estimation . Elizabeth will not , William Collins hope , consider William Collins as showing any disrespect to the family , William Collins dear madam , by thus withdrawing William Collins pretensions to Mother daughter ’s favour , without having paid Mother and Father the compliment of requesting Mother and Father to interpose Mother and Father authority in William Collins behalf . William Collins conduct may , William Collins fear , be objectionable in having accepted William Collins dismission from Mother daughter ’s lips instead of Mother own . But we are all liable to error . William Collins have certainly meant well through the whole affair . William Collins object has been to secure an amiable companion for William Collins , with due consideration for the advantage of all Mother family , and if William Collins manner has been at all reprehensible , William Collins here beg leave to apologise . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  The discussion of William Collins ’s offer was now nearly at an end , and Elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending The discussion of William Collins ’s offer , and occasionally from some peevish allusions of Elizabeth mother . As for William Collins ’s William Collins ’s , William Collins ’s feelings were chiefly expressed , not by embarrassment or dejection , or by trying to avoid Elizabeth , but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence . William Collins ’s scarcely ever spoke to Elizabeth , and the assiduous attentions which William Collins ’s had been so sensible of William Collins ’s were transferred for the rest of the day to Miss Lucas , whose civility in listening to William Collins ’s was a seasonable relief to The whole party , and especially to Miss Lucas , whose civility in listening to William Collins ’s was a seasonable relief to The whole party , and especially to friend . 
 
  The morrow produced no abatement of Elizabeth mother ill - humour or ill health . William Collins ’s was also in the same state of angry pride . Elizabeth had hoped that William Collins ’s resentment might shorten William Collins ’s visit , but William Collins ’s plan did not appear in the least affected by William Collins ’s resentment . William Collins ’s was always to have gone on Saturday , and to Saturday William Collins ’s meant to stay . 
 
  After breakfast , the girls walked to Meryton to enquire if Charlie were returned , and to lament over William Collins ’s absence from the Netherfield ball . William Collins ’s joined the girls on the girls entering Meryton , and attended the girls to the girls aunt ’s where William Collins ’s regret and vexation , and the concern of everybody , was well talked over . To Elizabeth , however , William Collins ’s voluntarily acknowledged that the necessity of William Collins ’s absence had been self - imposed . 
 
  “ William Collins ’s found , ” said William Collins ’s , “ as the time drew near that William Collins ’s had better not meet Fitzwilliam ; that to be in the same room , the same party with Fitzwilliam for so many hours together , might be more than William Collins ’s could bear , and that scenes might arise unpleasant to more than William Collins ’s . ” 
 
  Elizabeth highly approved William Collins ’s forbearance , and they had leisure for a full discussion of William Collins ’s forbearance , and for all the commendation which they civilly bestowed on each other , as George and another officer walked back with they to Longbourn , and during the walk George particularly attended to Elizabeth . George accompanying them was a double advantage ; Elizabeth felt all the compliment George accompanying them offered to Elizabeth , and George accompanying them was most acceptable as an occasion of introducing George to Elizabeth father and mother . 
 
  Soon after them return , a letter was delivered to Miss Bennet ; a letter came from Netherfield . The envelope contained a sheet of elegant , little , hot - pressed paper , well covered with a lady ’s fair , flowing hand ; and Elizabeth saw Miss Bennet countenance change as Miss Bennet read a letter , and saw Miss Bennet dwelling intently on some particular passages . Miss Bennet recollected Miss Bennet soon , and putting a letter away , tried to join with Miss Bennet usual cheerfulness in the general conversation ; but Elizabeth felt an anxiety on the subject which drew off Elizabeth attention even from George ; and no sooner had George and George companion taken leave , than a glance from Miss Bennet invited Elizabeth to follow Miss Bennet up stairs . When them had gained them own room , Miss Bennet , taking out a letter , said : 
 
  “ a letter is from a lady ’s ; what a letter contains has surprised Miss Bennet a good deal . The whole party have left Netherfield by this time , and are on The whole party way to town — and without any intention of coming back again . Elizabeth shall hear what a lady ’s says . ” 
 
  Miss Bennet then read the first sentence aloud , which comprised the information of The whole party having just resolved to follow The whole party brother to town directly , and of The whole party meaning to dine in Grosvenor Street , where Mr. Hurst had a house . The next was in these words : “ Miss Bennet do not pretend to regret anything Miss Bennet shall leave in Hertfordshire , except Elizabeth society , Elizabeth ; but we will hope , at some future period , to enjoy many returns of that delightful intercourse we have known , and in the meanwhile may lessen the pain of separation by a very frequent and most unreserved correspondence . Miss Bennet depend on Elizabeth for that . ” To these highflown expressions Elizabeth listened with all the insensibility of distrust ; and though the suddenness of The whole party removal surprised Elizabeth , Elizabeth saw nothing in it really to lament ; it was not to be supposed that The whole party absence from Netherfield would prevent Charlie being there ; and as to the loss of The whole party society , Elizabeth was persuaded that Miss Bennet must cease to regard Elizabeth society , in the enjoyment of Miss Bennet . 
 
  “ It is unlucky , ” said Miss Bennet , after a short pause , “ that Elizabeth should not be able to see Elizabeth friends before Elizabeth friends leave the country . But may we not hope that the period of future happiness to which a lady ’s looks forward may arrive earlier than a lady ’s is aware , and that the delightful intercourse Elizabeth have known as friends will be renewed with yet greater satisfaction as sisters ? Charlie will not be detained in London by them . ” 
 
  “ a lady ’s decidedly says that none of The whole party will return into Hertfordshire this winter . Miss Bennet will read it to Elizabeth : ” 
 
  “ When The whole party brother left us yesterday , The whole party brother imagined that the business which took The whole party brother to London might be concluded in three or four days ; but as us are certain the business which took The whole party brother to London can not be so , and at the same time convinced that when Charlie gets to town Charlie will be in no hurry to leave it again , us have determined on following Charlie thither , that Charlie may not be obliged to spend Charlie vacant hours in a comfortless hotel . Many of Miss Bennet acquaintances are already there for the winter ; Miss Bennet wish that Miss Bennet could hear that Elizabeth , Elizabeth , had any intention of making one of Many of Miss Bennet acquaintances — but of making Miss Bennet despair . Miss Bennet sincerely hope Elizabeth Christmas in Hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings , and that Elizabeth beaux will be so numerous as to prevent Elizabeth feeling the loss of the three of whom we shall deprive Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ It is evident by this , ” added Miss Bennet , “ that The whole party brother comes back no more this winter . ” 
 
  “ It is only evident that a lady ’s does not mean that The whole party brother should . ” 
 
  “ Why will Miss Bennet think so ? It must be a lady ’s own doing . a lady ’s is a lady ’s own master . But Elizabeth do not know all . Miss Bennet will read Elizabeth the passage which particularly hurts Miss Bennet . Miss Bennet will have no reserves from Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam is impatient to see Fitzwilliam sister ; and , to confess the truth , we are scarcely less eager to meet Fitzwilliam sister again . Miss Bennet really do not think Fitzwilliam sister has Fitzwilliam sister equal for beauty , elegance , and accomplishments ; and the affection Fitzwilliam sister inspires in Louisa and Miss Bennet is heightened into something still more interesting , from the hope Louisa and Miss Bennet dare entertain of Fitzwilliam sister being hereafter Louisa and Miss Bennet sister . Miss Bennet do not know whether Miss Bennet ever before mentioned to Elizabeth Miss Bennet feelings on this subject ; but Miss Bennet will not leave the country without confiding Miss Bennet feelings on this subject , and Miss Bennet trust Elizabeth will not esteem Miss Bennet feelings on this subject unreasonable . Miss Bennet brother admires Fitzwilliam sister greatly already ; The whole party brother will have frequent opportunity now of seeing Fitzwilliam sister on the most intimate footing ; Fitzwilliam sister relations all wish the connection as much as The whole party brother own ; and a sister ’s partiality is not misleading Miss Bennet , Miss Bennet think , when Miss Bennet call Charlie most capable of engaging any woman ’s heart . With all these circumstances to favour an attachment , and nothing to prevent an attachment , am Miss Bennet wrong , Elizabeth , in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness of so many ? ” 
 
  “ What do Elizabeth think of the passage which particularly hurts Miss Bennet , Miss Bennet dear Elizabeth ? ” said Miss Bennet as Miss Bennet finished the passage which particularly hurts Miss Bennet . “ Is the passage which particularly hurts Miss Bennet not clear enough ? Does the passage which particularly hurts Miss Bennet not expressly declare that a lady ’s neither expects nor wishes Miss Bennet to be a lady ’s sister ; that a lady ’s is perfectly convinced of The whole party brother indifference ; and that if a lady ’s suspects the nature of Miss Bennet feelings for The whole party brother , a lady ’s means ( most kindly ! ) to put Miss Bennet on Miss Bennet guard ? Can there be any other opinion on this subject ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , there can ; for Miss Bennet is totally different . Will Elizabeth hear it ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth Most willingly . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth shall have it in a few words . a lady ’s sees that a lady ’s brother is in love with Elizabeth , and wants The whole party brother to marry Fitzwilliam sister . a lady ’s follows The whole party brother to town in hope of keeping The whole party brother there , and tries to persuade Elizabeth that The whole party brother does not care about Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Miss Bennet shook Miss Bennet head . 
 
  “ Indeed , Elizabeth , Elizabeth ought to believe Miss Bennet . No one who has ever seen Elizabeth together can doubt The whole party brother affection . a lady ’s , Miss Bennet am sure , can not . a lady ’s is not such a simpleton . Could a lady ’s have seen half as much love in Fitzwilliam for a lady ’s , a lady ’s would have ordered a lady ’s wedding clothes . But the case is this : We are not rich enough or grand enough for them ; and a lady ’s is the more anxious to get Fitzwilliam sister for a lady ’s brother , from the notion that when there has been one intermarriage , a lady ’s may have less trouble in achieving a second ; in which there is certainly some ingenuity , and Miss Bennet dare say it would succeed , if Cathleen were out of the way . But , Miss Bennet dearest Jane , Elizabeth can not seriously imagine that because a lady ’s tells Elizabeth The whole party brother greatly admires Fitzwilliam sister , The whole party brother is in the smallest degree less sensible of Elizabeth merit than when The whole party brother took leave of Elizabeth on Tuesday , or that it will be in a lady ’s power to persuade The whole party brother that , instead of being in love with Elizabeth , The whole party brother is very much in love with a lady ’s friend . ” 
 
  “ If we thought alike of a lady ’s , ” replied Miss Bennet , “ Elizabeth representation of all this might make Miss Bennet quite easy . But Miss Bennet know the foundation is unjust . a lady ’s is incapable of wilfully deceiving anyone ; and all that Miss Bennet can hope in this case is that a lady ’s is deceiving a lady ’s . ” 
 
  “ That is right . Elizabeth could not have started a more happy idea , since Elizabeth will not take comfort in Miss Bennet . Believe a lady ’s to be deceived , by all means . Elizabeth have now done Elizabeth duty by a lady ’s , and must fret no longer . ” 
 
  “ But , Miss Bennet , can Miss Bennet be happy , even supposing the best , in accepting a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry elsewhere ? ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet must decide for Miss Bennet , ” said Elizabeth ; “ and if , upon mature deliberation , Miss Bennet find that the misery of disobliging The whole party brother two sisters is more than equivalent to the happiness of being The whole party brother wife , Elizabeth advise Miss Bennet by all means to refuse The whole party brother . ” 
 
  “ How can Elizabeth talk so ? ” said Miss Bennet , faintly smiling . “ Elizabeth must know that though Miss Bennet should be exceedingly grieved at The whole party brother two sisters disapprobation , Miss Bennet could not hesitate . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth did not think Miss Bennet would ; and that being the case , Elizabeth can not consider Miss Bennet situation with much compassion . ” 
 
  “ But if The whole party brother returns no more this winter , Miss Bennet choice will never be required . A thousand things may arise in six months ! ” 
 
  The idea of The whole party brother returning no more Elizabeth treated with the utmost contempt . The idea of The whole party brother returning no more appeared to Elizabeth merely the suggestion of a lady ’s interested wishes , and Elizabeth could not for a moment suppose that those wishes , however openly or artfully spoken , could influence a young man so totally independent of everyone . 
 
  Elizabeth represented to Miss Bennet as forcibly as possible what Elizabeth felt on this subject , and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect . Miss Bennet temper was not desponding , and Miss Bennet was gradually led to hope , though the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope , that Charlie would return to Netherfield and answer every wish of Miss Bennet heart . 
 
  They agreed that Elizabeth mother should only hear of the departure of the family , without being alarmed on the score of The whole party brother conduct ; but even this partial communication gave Elizabeth mother a great deal of concern , and Elizabeth mother bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that the girls should happen to go away just as the girls were all getting so intimate together . After lamenting it , however , at some length , Elizabeth mother had the consolation that Charlie would be soon down again and soon dining at Longbourn , and the conclusion of all was the comfortable declaration , that though George had been invited only to a family dinner , Elizabeth mother would take care to have two full courses . 
 Chapter 
 
  The Bennets were engaged to dine with the Lucases and again during the chief of the day was Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins . Elizabeth took an opportunity of thanking Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins . “ It keeps William Collins in good humour , ” said Elizabeth , “ and Elizabeth am more obliged to Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins than Elizabeth can express . ” Charlotte assured Elizabeth of Charlotte satisfaction in being useful , and that being amply repaid Charlotte for the little sacrifice of Charlotte time . This was very amiable , but Charlotte ’s kindness extended farther than Elizabeth had any conception of ; This object was nothing else than to secure Elizabeth from any return of William Collins ’s addresses , by engaging William Collins ’s addresses towards Charlotte . Such was Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins scheme ; and appearances were so favourable , that when both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins parted at night , Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins would have felt almost secure of success if William Collins had not been to leave Hertfordshire so very soon . But here Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins did injustice to the fire and independence of William Collins character , for the fire and independence of William Collins character led William Collins to escape out of Longbourn House the next morning with admirable slyness , and hasten to Lucas Lodge to throw William Collins at Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins feet . William Collins was anxious to avoid the notice of William Collins cousins , from a conviction that if William Collins cousins saw William Collins depart , William Collins cousins could not fail to conjecture William Collins design , and William Collins was not willing to have the attempt known till the attempt success might be known likewise ; for though feeling almost secure , and with reason , for Charlotte had been tolerably encouraging , William Collins was comparatively diffident since the adventure of Wednesday . William Collins reception , however , was of the most flattering kind . Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins perceived William Collins from an upper window as William Collins walked towards Longbourn House , and instantly set out to meet William Collins accidentally in the lane . But little had Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins there . 
 
  In as short a time as William Collins ’s long speeches would allow , everything was settled between both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins to the satisfaction of both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins ; and as both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins entered Longbourn House William Collins earnestly entreated Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins to name the day that was to make William Collins the happiest of men ; and though such a solicitation must be waived for the present , Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins felt no inclination to trifle with William Collins happiness . The stupidity with which William Collins was favoured by nature must guard William Collins courtship from any charm that could make a woman wish for its continuance ; and Miss Lucas , who accepted William Collins solely from the pure and disinterested desire of an establishment , cared not how soon an establishment were gained . 
 
  William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins were speedily applied to for William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins consent ; and William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins consent was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity . William Collins ’s present circumstances made William Collins a most eligible match for William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins daughter , to whom William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins could give little fortune ; and William Collins prospects of future wealth were exceedingly fair . Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins began directly to calculate , with more interest than the matter had ever excited before , how many years longer William Collins was likely to live ; and William Collins gave it as William Collins decided opinion , that whenever William Collins should be in possession of the Longbourn estate , it would be highly expedient that both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins should make both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins appearance at St. James ’s . The whole family , in short , were properly overjoyed on the occasion . The younger girls formed hopes of coming out a year or two sooner than The younger girls might otherwise have done ; and the boys were relieved from the boys apprehension of Charlotte ’s dying an old maid . Charlotte Charlotte was tolerably composed . Charlotte had gained Charlotte point , and had time to consider of Charlotte point . Charlotte reflections were in general satisfactory . William Collins , to be sure , was neither sensible nor agreeable ; William Collins society was irksome , and William Collins attachment to Charlotte must be imaginary . But still William Collins would be Charlotte husband . Without thinking highly either of men or matrimony , marriage had always been Charlotte object ; marriage was the only provision for well - educated young women of small fortune , and however uncertain of giving happiness , must be well - educated young women of small fortune pleasantest preservative from want . This preservative Charlotte had now obtained ; and at the age of twenty - seven , without having ever been handsome , Charlotte felt all the good luck of it . The least agreeable circumstance in the business was the surprise the business must occasion to Elizabeth , whose friendship Charlotte valued beyond that of any other person . Elizabeth would wonder , and probably would blame Charlotte ; and though Elizabeth resolution was not to be shaken , Elizabeth feelings must be hurt by such a disapprobation . Charlotte resolved to give Elizabeth the information Charlotte , and therefore charged William Collins , when William Collins returned to Longbourn to dinner , to drop no hint of what had passed before any of the family . A promise of secrecy was of course very dutifully given , but A promise of secrecy could not be kept without difficulty ; for the curiosity excited by William Collins long absence burst forth in such very direct questions on William Collins return as required some ingenuity to evade , and William Collins was at the same time exercising great self - denial , for William Collins was longing to publish William Collins prosperous love . 
 
  As William Collins was to begin William Collins journey too early on the morrow to see any of the family , the ceremony of leave - taking was performed when the ladies moved for the night ; and Mother , with great politeness and cordiality , said how happy the ladies should be to see William Collins at Longbourn again , whenever William Collins engagements might allow William Collins to visit the ladies . 
 
  “ William Collins dear madam , ” William Collins replied , “ this invitation is particularly gratifying , because this invitation is what William Collins have been hoping to receive ; and Mother may be very certain that William Collins shall avail William Collins of this invitation as soon as possible . ” 
 
  the ladies were all astonished ; and Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , immediately said : 
 
  “ But is there not danger of Cathleen ’s disapprobation here , William Collins ? William Collins had better neglect William Collins relations than run the risk of offending Cathleen ’s . ” 
 
  “ Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , , ” replied William Collins , “ William Collins am particularly obliged to Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , for this friendly caution , and Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , may depend upon William Collins not taking so material a step without Cathleen ’s concurrence . ” 
 
  “ William Collins can not be too much upon William Collins guard . Risk anything rather than Cathleen ’s displeasure ; and if William Collins find Cathleen ’s displeasure likely to be raised by William Collins coming to the family again , which Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , should think exceedingly probable , stay quietly at home , and be satisfied that the family shall take no offence . ” 
 
  “ Believe William Collins , Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , , William Collins gratitude is warmly excited by such affectionate attention ; and depend upon it , Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , will speedily receive from William Collins a letter of thanks for this , and for every other mark of Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , regard during William Collins stay in Hertfordshire . As for William Collins fair cousins , though William Collins absence may not be long enough to render William Collins absence necessary , William Collins shall now take the liberty of wishing William Collins fair cousins health and happiness , not excepting William Collins cousin Elizabeth . ” 
 
  With proper civilities the ladies then withdrew ; the ladies equally surprised that William Collins meditated a quick return . Mother wished to understand by it that William Collins thought of paying William Collins addresses to one of Mother younger girls , and Mary might have been prevailed on to accept William Collins . Mother rated William Collins abilities much higher than any of the others ; there was a solidity in William Collins reflections which often struck Mother , and though by no means so clever as Mother , Mother thought that if encouraged to read and improve William Collins by such an example as Mother , William Collins might become a very agreeable companion . But on the following morning , every hope of this kind was done away . Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins called soon after breakfast , and in a private conference with Elizabeth related the event of the day before . 
 
  The possibility of William Collins ’s fancying William Collins in love with Elizabeth had once occurred to Elizabeth within the last day or two ; but that Charlotte could encourage William Collins seemed almost as far from possibility as Elizabeth could encourage William Collins Elizabeth , and Elizabeth astonishment was consequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum , and Elizabeth could not help crying out : 
 
  “ Engaged to William Collins ! Elizabeth dear Charlotte — impossible ! ” 
 
  The steady countenance which Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins had commanded in telling Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins story , gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a reproach ; though , as it was no more than Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins expected , Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins soon regained Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins composure , and calmly replied : 
 
  “ Why should Elizabeth be surprised , Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins dear Elizabeth ? Do Elizabeth think it incredible that William Collins should be able to procure any woman ’s good opinion , because William Collins was not so happy as to succeed with Elizabeth ? ” 
 
  But Elizabeth had now recollected Elizabeth , and making a strong effort for it , was able to assure with tolerable firmness that the prospect of both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins relationship was highly grateful to Elizabeth , and that Elizabeth wished Elizabeth all imaginable happiness . 
 
  “ Charlotte see what Elizabeth are feeling , ” replied Charlotte . “ Elizabeth must be surprised , very much surprised — so lately as William Collins was wishing to marry Elizabeth . But when Elizabeth have had time to think it over , Charlotte hope Elizabeth will be satisfied with what Charlotte have done . Charlotte am not romantic , Father , who could by no means wish for so speedy a return , know ; Charlotte never was . Charlotte ask only a comfortable home ; and considering William Collins ’s character , connection , and situation in life , Charlotte am convinced that Charlotte chance of happiness with William Collins is as fair as most people can boast on entering the marriage state . ” 
 
  Elizabeth quietly answered “ Undoubtedly ; ” and after an awkward pause , both William Collins and Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to William Collins returned to the rest of the family . Charlotte did not stay much longer , and Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what Elizabeth had heard . It was a long time before Elizabeth became at all reconciled to the idea of so unsuitable a match . The strangeness of William Collins ’s making two offers of marriage within three days was nothing in comparison of William Collins being now accepted . Elizabeth had always felt that Charlotte ’s opinion of matrimony was not exactly like Elizabeth own , but Elizabeth had not supposed it to be possible that , when called into action , Charlotte would have sacrificed every better feeling to worldly advantage . Charlotte the wife of William Collins was a most humiliating picture ! And to the pang of a friend disgracing a friend disgracing and sunk in a friend disgracing esteem , was added the distressing conviction that it was impossible for a friend disgracing to be tolerably happy in the lot a friend disgracing had chosen . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth was sitting with Elizabeth mother and sisters , reflecting on what Elizabeth had heard , and doubting whether Elizabeth was authorised to mention it , when Sir William Lucas Sir William Lucas appeared , sent by Elizabeth , to announce Elizabeth engagement to the family . With many compliments to Elizabeth mother and sisters , and much self - gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the houses , Sir William Lucas unfolded the matter — to an audience not merely wondering , but incredulous ; for Mother , with more perseverance than politeness , protested Sir William Lucas must be entirely mistaken ; and Lydia , always unguarded and often uncivil , boisterously exclaimed : 
 
  “ Good Lord ! Sir William Lucas , how can Sir William Lucas tell such a story ? Do not Sir William Lucas know that William Collins wants to marry Elizabeth ? ” 
 
  Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne without anger such treatment ; but Sir William Lucas good breeding carried Sir William Lucas through it all ; and though Sir William Lucas begged leave to be positive as to the truth of Sir William Lucas information , Sir William Lucas listened to all their impertinence with the most forbearing courtesy . 
 
  Elizabeth , feeling it incumbent on Elizabeth to relieve Sir William Lucas from so unpleasant a situation , now put Elizabeth forward to confirm Sir William Lucas account , by mentioning Elizabeth prior knowledge of Sir William Lucas account from Charlotte Charlotte ; and endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of Elizabeth mother and sisters by the earnestness of Elizabeth congratulations to Sir William Lucas , in which Elizabeth was readily joined by Jane , and by making a variety of remarks on the happiness that might be expected from the match , the excellent character of William Collins , and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London . 
 
  Mother was in fact too much overpowered to say a great deal while Sir William Lucas remained ; but no sooner had Sir William Lucas left Elizabeth mother and sisters than Mother feelings found a rapid vent . In the first place , Mother persisted in disbelieving the whole of the matter ; secondly , Mother was very sure that William Collins had been taken in ; thirdly , Mother trusted that they would never be happy together ; and fourthly , that the match might be broken off . Two inferences , however , were plainly deduced from the whole of the matter : one , that Elizabeth was the real cause of the mischief ; and the other that Mother Mother had been barbarously misused by them all ; and on these two points Mother principally dwelt during the rest of the day . Nothing could console and nothing could appease Mother . Nor did the day wear out Mother resentment . A week elapsed before Mother could see Elizabeth without scolding Elizabeth , a month passed away before Mother could speak to Sir William Lucas or Lady Lucas without being rude , and many months were gone before Mother could at all forgive Elizabeth . 
 
  Father ’s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion , and such as Father ’s did experience Father ’s pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort ; for it gratified Father ’s , Father ’s said , to discover that Charlotte Lucas , whom Father ’s had been used to think tolerably sensible , was as foolish as Father ’s wife , and more foolish than Elizabeth ! 
 
  Jane confessed Jane a little surprised at the match ; but Jane said less of Jane astonishment than of Jane earnest desire for they happiness ; nor could Elizabeth persuade Jane to consider the match as improbable . Kitty and Lydia were far from envying Lady Lucas , for William Collins was only a clergyman ; and the match affected Kitty and Lydia in no other way than as a piece of news to spread at Meryton . 
 
  Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort on Mother the comfort of having a daughter well married ; and Lady Lucas called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy Lady Lucas was , though Mother ’s sour looks and ill - natured remarks might have been enough to drive happiness away . 
 
  Between Elizabeth and Charlotte there was a restraint which kept Elizabeth and Charlotte mutually silent on the subject ; and Elizabeth felt persuaded that no real confidence could ever subsist between Elizabeth and Charlotte again . Elizabeth disappointment in Charlotte made Elizabeth turn with fonder regard to Elizabeth sister , of whose rectitude and delicacy Elizabeth was sure Elizabeth opinion could never be shaken , and for whose happiness Elizabeth grew daily more anxious , as Charles had now been gone a week and nothing more was heard of Charles return . 
 
  Jane had sent Caroline an early answer to Jane letter , and was counting the days till Jane might reasonably hope to hear again . The promised letter of thanks from William Collins arrived on Tuesday , addressed to Father ’s , and written with all the solemnity of gratitude which a twelvemonth ’s abode in the family might have prompted . After discharging Sir William Lucas conscience on that head , Sir William Lucas proceeded to inform Elizabeth mother and sisters , with many rapturous expressions , of Sir William Lucas happiness in having obtained the affection of Elizabeth mother and sisters amiable neighbour , Miss Lucas , and then explained that it was merely with the view of enjoying Lady Lucas society that Sir William Lucas had been so ready to close with Elizabeth mother and sisters kind wish of seeing William Collins again at Longbourn , whither Sir William Lucas hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight ; for Cathleen , Sir William Lucas added , so heartily approved Sir William Lucas marriage , that Cathleen wished Sir William Lucas marriage to take place as soon as possible , which Sir William Lucas trusted would be an unanswerable argument with Sir William Lucas amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making Sir William Lucas the happiest of men . 
 
  William Collins ’s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of pleasure to Mother . On the contrary , Mother was as much disposed to complain of William Collins ’s return into Hertfordshire as Mother husband . It was very strange that William Collins should come to Longbourn instead of to Lucas Lodge ; come was also very inconvenient and exceedingly troublesome . Mother hated having visitors in the house while Mother health was so indifferent , and lovers were of all people the most disagreeable . Such were the gentle murmurs of Mother , and the gentle murmurs of Mother gave way only to the greater distress of Charles ’s continued absence . 
 
  Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on Charles ’s continued absence . Day after day passed away without bringing any other tidings of Charles than the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of Charles coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter ; the report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of Charles coming no more to Netherfield the whole winter . 
 
  Even Elizabeth began to fear — not that Charles was indifferent — but that Charles sisters would be successful in keeping Charles away . Unwilling as Elizabeth was to admit an idea so destructive of Jane ’s happiness , and so dishonorable to the stability of Charles , Elizabeth could not prevent an idea so destructive of Jane ’s happiness , and so dishonorable to the stability of Charles frequently occurring . The united efforts of Charles two unfeeling sisters and of Charles overpowering friend , assisted by the attractions of Georgiana and the amusements of London might be too much , Elizabeth feared , for the strength of Charles attachment . 
 
  As for Jane , Jane anxiety under this suspense was , of course , more painful than Elizabeth ’s , but whatever Jane felt Jane was desirous of concealing , and between Jane and Elizabeth , therefore , Charles ’s continued absence was never alluded to . But as no such delicacy restrained Jane mother , an hour seldom passed in which Mother did not talk of Charles , express Mother impatience for Charles arrival , or even require Jane to confess that if Charles did not come back Mother would think Mother very ill used . It needed all Jane ’s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable tranquillity . 
 
  William Collins returned most punctually on Monday fortnight , but William Collins reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on William Collins first introduction . William Collins was too happy , however , to need much attention ; and luckily for the others , the business of love - making relieved the others from a great deal of William Collins company . The chief of every day was spent by William Collins at Lucas Lodge , and William Collins sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time to make an apology for William Collins absence before the family went to bed . 
 
  Mother was really in a most pitiable state . The very mention of anything concerning the match threw Mother into an agony of ill - humour , and wherever Mother went Mother was sure of hearing the match talked of . The sight of Lady Lucas was odious to Mother . As Mother successor in the house , Mother regarded Lady Lucas with jealous abhorrence . Whenever Charlotte came to see the family , Mother concluded Charlotte to be anticipating the hour of possession ; and whenever Mother spoke in a low voice to William Collins , was convinced that they were talking of the Longbourn estate , and resolving to turn Mother and Mother daughters out of the house , as soon as Father ’s were dead . Mother complained bitterly of all this to Father ’s . 
 
  “ Indeed , Father ’s , ” said Mother , “ it is very hard to think that Charlotte Lucas should ever be mistress of the house , that Mother should be forced to make way for Charlotte , and live to see Charlotte take Charlotte place in the house ! ” 
 
  “ Father ’s dear , do not give way to such gloomy thoughts . Let they hope for better things . Let they flatter they that Father ’s may be the survivor . ” 
 
  This was not very consoling to Mother , and therefore , instead of making any answer , Mother went on as before . 
 
  “ Mother can not bear to think that they should have the Longbourn estate . If it was not for the entail , Mother should not mind it . ” 
 
  “ What should not Mother mind ? ” 
 
  “ Mother should not mind anything at all . ” 
 
  “ Let they be thankful that Mother are preserved from a state of such insensibility . ” 
 
  “ Mother never can be thankful , Father ’s , for anything about the entail . How anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one ’s own daughters , Mother can not understand ; and all for the sake of William Collins too ! Why should William Collins have an estate more than anybody else ? ” 
 
  “ Father ’s leave it to Mother to determine , ” said Father ’s . 
 Chapter 
 
  Caroline ’s letter arrived , and put an end to doubt . The very first sentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for the winter , and concluded with Caroline ’s brother ’s regret at not having had time to pay Caroline ’s brother ’s respects to Caroline ’s brother ’s friends in Hertfordshire before Caroline ’s brother ’s left the country . 
 
  Hope was over , entirely over ; and when Jane could attend to the rest of Caroline ’s letter , Jane found little , except the professed affection of Caroline ’s , that could give Jane any comfort . Georgiana ’s praise occupied the chief of it . Georgiana ’s many attractions were again dwelt on , and Caroline ’s boasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy , and ventured to predict the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in Caroline ’s former letter . Caroline ’s wrote also with great pleasure of Caroline ’s brother ’s being an inmate of Fitzwilliam ’s house , and mentioned with raptures some plans of Fitzwilliam ’s with regard to new furniture . 
 
  Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , heard all this in silent indignation . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this heart was divided between concern for Caroline ’s , and resentment against all others . To Caroline ’s assertion of Caroline ’s brother ’s being partial to Georgiana ’s Caroline ’s paid no credit . That Caroline ’s brother ’s was really fond of Jane , Caroline ’s doubted no more than Caroline ’s had ever done ; and much as Caroline ’s had always been disposed to like Caroline ’s brother ’s , Caroline ’s could not think without anger , hardly without contempt , on that easiness of temper , that want of proper resolution , which now made Caroline ’s brother ’s the slave of Caroline ’s brother ’s designing friends , and led Caroline ’s brother ’s to sacrifice of Caroline ’s brother ’s own happiness to the caprice of Caroline ’s brother ’s designing friends inclination . Had Caroline ’s brother ’s own happiness , however , been the only sacrifice , Caroline ’s brother ’s might have been allowed to sport with Caroline ’s brother ’s own happiness in whatever manner Caroline ’s brother ’s thought best , but Caroline ’s was involved in it , as Caroline ’s thought Caroline ’s brother ’s must be sensible Caroline ’s brother ’s . It was a subject , in short , on which reflection would be long indulged , and must be unavailing . Caroline ’s could think of nothing else ; and yet whether Charles ’s regard had really died away , or were suppressed by Charles ’s friends ’ interference ; whether Charles ’s had been aware of Jane ’s attachment , or whether Jane ’s attachment had escaped Charles ’s observation ; whatever were the case , though Caroline ’s opinion of Charles ’s must be materially affected by the difference , Caroline ’s situation remained the same , Caroline ’s peace equally wounded . 
 
  A day or two passed before Jane had courage to speak of Jane feelings to Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this ; but at last , on Mother ’s leaving their together , after a longer irritation than usual about Netherfield and Netherfield master , Jane could not help saying : 
 
  “ Oh , that Jane dear mother had more command over Mother ’s ! Mother ’s can have no idea of the pain Mother ’s gives Jane by Mother ’s continual reflections on Netherfield master . But Jane will not repine . It can not last long . Netherfield master will be forgot , and we shall all be as we were before . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this looked at Jane with incredulous solicitude , but said nothing . 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this doubt Jane , ” cried Jane , slightly colouring ; “ indeed , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this have no reason . Netherfield master may live in Jane memory as the most amiable man of Jane acquaintance , but live is all . Jane have nothing either to hope or fear , and nothing to reproach Netherfield master with . Thank God ! Jane have not that pain . A little time , therefore — Jane shall certainly try to get the better . ” 
 
  With a stronger voice Jane soon added , “ Jane have this comfort immediately , that it has not been more than an error of fancy on Jane side , and that it has done no harm to anyone but Jane . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Jane ! ” exclaimed Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , “ Jane are too good . Jane sweetness and disinterestedness are really angelic ; Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this do not know what to say to Jane . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this feel as if Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this had never done Jane justice , or loved Jane as Jane deserve . ” 
 
  Miss Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit , and threw back the praise on Miss Bennet sister ’s warm affection . 
 
  “ Nay , ” said Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , “ this is not fair . Miss Bennet wish to think all the world respectable , and are hurt if Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this speak ill of anybody . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this only want to think Miss Bennet perfect , and Miss Bennet set Miss Bennet against think . Do not be afraid of Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this running into any excess , of Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this encroaching on Miss Bennet privilege of universal good - will . Miss Bennet need not . There are few people whom Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this really love , and still fewer of whom Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this think well . The more Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this see of the world , the more am Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dissatisfied with the world ; and every day confirms Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this belief of the inconsistency of all human characters , and of the little dependence that can be placed on the appearance of merit or sense . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this have met with two instances lately , one Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this will not mention ; the other is Charlotte ’s marriage . It is unaccountable ! In every view it is unaccountable ! ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Elizabeth , do not give way to such feelings as these . such feelings as these will ruin Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this happiness . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this do not make allowance enough for difference of situation and temper . Consider William Collins ’s respectability , and Charlotte ’s steady , prudent character . Remember that Charlotte ’s is one of a large family ; that as to fortune , William Collins ’s is a most eligible match ; and be ready to believe , for everybody ’s sake , that Charlotte ’s may feel something like regard and esteem for William Collins ’s . ” 
 
  “ To oblige Miss Bennet , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this would try to believe almost anything , but no one else could be benefited by such a belief as this ; for were Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this persuaded that Charlotte ’s had any regard for William Collins ’s , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this should only think worse of Charlotte ’s understanding than Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this now do of Charlotte ’s heart . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Jane , William Collins ’s is a conceited , pompous , narrow - minded , silly man ; Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Jane know William Collins ’s is , as well as Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this do ; and Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Jane must feel , as well as Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this do , that Charlotte ’s can not have a proper way of thinking . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Jane shall not defend Charlotte ’s , though it is Charlotte ’s . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Jane shall not , for the sake of one individual , change the meaning of principle and integrity , nor endeavour to persuade Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this dear Jane or Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , that selfishness is prudence , and insensibility of danger security for happiness . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this must think Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this language too strong in speaking of both , ” replied Jane ; “ and Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this hope Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this will be convinced of it by seeing them happy together . But enough of this . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this alluded to something else . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this mentioned two instances . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this can not misunderstand Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , but Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this entreat Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , not to pain Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this by thinking William Collins ’s to blame , and saying Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this opinion of William Collins ’s is sunk . We must not be so ready to fancy We intentionally injured . We must not expect a lively young man to be always so guarded and circumspect . It is very often nothing but our own vanity that deceives us . Women fancy admiration means more than admiration does . ” 
 
  “ And men take care that men should . ” 
 
  “ If it is designedly done , men can not be justified ; but Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this have no idea of there being so much design in the world as some persons imagine . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this am far from attributing any part of Charles ’s conduct to design , ” said Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this ; “ but without scheming to do wrong , or to make others unhappy , there may be error , and there may be misery . Thoughtlessness , want of attention to other people ’s feelings , and want of resolution , will do the business . ” 
 
  “ And do Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this impute it to either of Thoughtlessness , want of attention to other people ’s feelings , and want of resolution ? ” 
 
  “ Yes ; to the last . But if Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this go on , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this shall displease Miss Bennet by saying what Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this think of persons Miss Bennet esteem . Stop Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this whilst Miss Bennet can . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this persist , then , in supposing Charles ’s sisters influence Charles ’s ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , in conjunction with Charles ’s friend . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this can not believe it . Why should Charles ’s sisters try to influence Charles ’s ? Charles ’s sisters can only wish Charles ’s happiness ; and if Charles ’s is attached to Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , no other woman can secure Charles ’s happiness . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this first position is false . Charles ’s sisters may wish many things besides Charles ’s happiness ; Charles ’s sisters may wish Charles ’s increase of wealth and consequence ; Charles ’s sisters may wish Charles ’s to marry a girl who has all the importance of money , great connections , and pride . ” 
 
  “ Beyond a doubt , Charles ’s sisters do wish Charles ’s to choose Georgiana ’s , ” replied Jane ; “ but wish may be from better feelings than Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this are supposing . Charles ’s sisters have known Georgiana ’s much longer than Charles ’s sisters have known Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this ; no wonder if Charles ’s sisters love Georgiana ’s better . But , whatever may be Charles ’s sisters own wishes , it is very unlikely Charles ’s sisters should have opposed Charles ’s sisters brother ’s . What sister would think herself at liberty to do it , unless there were something very objectionable ? If Charles ’s sisters believed Charles ’s attached to Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , Charles ’s sisters would not try to part their ; if Charles ’s were so , Charles ’s sisters could not succeed . By supposing such an affection , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this make everybody acting unnaturally and wrong , and Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this most unhappy . Do not distress Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this by the idea . Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this am not ashamed of having been mistaken — or , at least , it is light , it is nothing in comparison of what Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this should feel in thinking ill of Charles ’s or Charles ’s sisters . Let Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this take it in the best light , in the light in which it may be understood . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this could not oppose such a wish ; and from this time Charles ’s name was scarcely ever mentioned between their . 
 
  Mother ’s still continued to wonder and repine at Charles ’s returning no more , and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this did not account for it clearly , there was little chance of Mother ’s ever considering it with less perplexity . Mother ’s daughter endeavoured to convince Mother ’s of what Mother ’s did not believe Mother ’s , that Charles ’s attentions to Jane had been merely the effect of a common and transient liking , which ceased when Charles ’s saw Jane no more ; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at the time , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this had the same story to repeat every day . Mother ’s best comfort was that Charles ’s must be down again in the summer . 
 
  Father treated the matter differently . “ So , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , ” said Father one day , “ Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this sister is crossed in love , Father find . Father congratulate Caroline ’s . Next to being married , a girl likes to be crossed a little in love now and then . be is something to think of , and be gives a girl a sort of distinction among a girl companions . When is Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this turn to come ? Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this will hardly bear to be long outdone by Jane . Now is Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this time . Here are officers enough in Meryton to disappoint all the young ladies in the country . Let George be Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this man . George is a pleasant fellow , and would jilt Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this creditably . ” 
 
  “ Thank Father , Father , but a less agreeable man would satisfy Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this . We must not all expect Jane ’s good fortune . ” 
 
  “ True , ” said Father , “ but it is a comfort to think that whatever of that kind may befall Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this , Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this have an affectionate mother who will make the most of it . ” 
 
  Charles ’s society was of material service in dispelling the gloom which the late perverse occurrences had thrown on many of the Longbourn family . many of the Longbourn family saw Charles ’s often , and to Charles ’s other recommendations was now added that of general unreserve . The whole of what Elizabeth , to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this had already heard , Charles ’s claims on Fitzwilliam ’s , and all that Charles ’s had suffered from Fitzwilliam ’s , was now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed ; and everybody was pleased to know how much everybody had always disliked Fitzwilliam ’s before everybody had known anything of the matter . Miss Bennet Miss Bennet was the only creature who could suppose there might be any extenuating circumstances in the case , unknown to the society of Hertfordshire ; Miss Bennet mild and steady candour always pleaded for allowances , and urged the possibility of mistakes — but by everybody else Fitzwilliam ’s was condemned as the worst of men . 
 Chapter 
 
  After a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity , William Collins was called from William Collins amiable Charlotte by the arrival of Saturday . The pain of separation , however , might be alleviated on William Collins side , by preparations for the reception of William Collins bride ; as William Collins had reason to hope , that shortly after William Collins return into Hertfordshire , the day would be fixed that was to make William Collins the happiest of men . William Collins took leave of William Collins relations at Longbourn with as much solemnity as before ; wished William Collins fair cousins health and happiness again , and promised William Collins fair cousins father another letter of thanks . 
 
  On the following Monday , Mother had the pleasure of receiving Mother brother and Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn . Mother brother was a sensible , gentlemanlike man , greatly superior to Mother brother sister , as well by nature as education . The Netherfield ladies would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived by trade , and within view of Mother brother own warehouses , could have been so well - bred and agreeable . Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn , was an amiable , intelligent , elegant woman , and a great favourite with all Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn Longbourn nieces . Between the two eldest and Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn especially , there subsisted a particular regard . the two eldest had frequently been staying with Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn in town . 
 
  The first part of Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn business on Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn arrival was to distribute Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn presents and describe the newest fashions . When The first part of Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn business on Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn arrival was done Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn had a less active part to play . It became Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn turn to listen . Mother had many grievances to relate , and much to complain of . They had all been very ill - used since Mother last saw Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn . Two of Mother girls had been upon the point of marriage , and after all there was nothing in it . 
 
  “ Mother do not blame Jane , ” Mother continued , “ for Jane would have got Charles if Jane could . But Elizabeth ! Oh , sister ! It is very hard to think that Elizabeth ! might have been William Collins ’s wife by this time , had it not been for Elizabeth ! own perverseness . William Collins made Elizabeth ! an offer in this very room , and Elizabeth ! refused William Collins . The consequence of it is , that Lady Lucas will have a daughter married before Mother have , and that the Longbourn estate is just as much entailed as ever . Lady Lucas are very artful people indeed , Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn . Lady Lucas are all for what Lady Lucas can get . Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with sister am sorry to say it of Lady Lucas , but so it is . It makes Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with sister very nervous and poorly , to be thwarted so in Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with sister own family , and to have neighbours who think of themselves before anybody else . However , Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn coming just at this time is the greatest of comforts , and Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with sister am very glad to hear what Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn tell us , of long sleeves . ” 
 
  Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with , made Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with sister a slight answer , and , in compassion to Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with nieces , turned the conversation . 
 
  When alone with Elizabeth ! afterwards , Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with spoke more on the subject . “ It seems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane , ” said Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with . “ Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with am sorry it went off . But these things happen so often ! A young man , such as Elizabeth ! describe Charles , so easily falls in love with a pretty girl for a few weeks , and when accident separates them , so easily forgets a pretty girl , that these sort of inconsistencies are very frequent . ” 
 
  “ An excellent consolation in its way , ” said Elizabeth ! , “ but its will not do for us . We do not suffer by accident . It does not often happen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of independent fortune to think no more of a girl whom a young man of independent fortune was violently in love with only a few days before . ” 
 
  “ But that expression of ‘ violently in love ’ is so hackneyed , so doubtful , so indefinite , that that expression of ‘ violently in love ’ gives Elizabeth ! very little idea . that expression of ‘ violently in love ’ is as often applied to feelings which arise from a half - hour ’s acquaintance , as to a real , strong attachment . Pray , how violent was Charles ’s love ? ” 
 
  “ Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with never saw a more promising inclination ; Charles was growing quite inattentive to other people , and wholly engrossed by Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn . Every time they met , Charles ’s love was more decided and remarkable . At Charles own ball Charles offended two or three young ladies , by not asking two or three young ladies to dance ; and Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with spoke to Charles twice Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with , without receiving an answer . Could there be finer symptoms ? Is not general incivility the very essence of love ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , yes!—of that kind of love which Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with suppose Charles to have felt . Poor Jane ! Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with am sorry for Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn , because , with Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn disposition , Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn may not get over am immediately . am had better have happened to Elizabeth ! , Elizabeth ! ; Elizabeth ! would have laughed Elizabeth ! out of am sooner . But do Elizabeth ! think Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn would be prevailed upon to go back with us ? Change of scene might be of service — and perhaps a little relief from home may be as useful as anything . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ! was exceedingly pleased with this proposal , and felt persuaded of Elizabeth ! sister ’s ready acquiescence . 
 
  “ Elizabeth ! hope , ” added Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn , “ that no consideration with regard to Charles will influence Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn . We live in so different a part of town , all We connections are so different , and , as Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn well know , we go out so little , that it is very improbable that they should meet at all , unless Charles really comes to see Jane . ” 
 
  “ And comes is quite impossible ; for Charles is now in the custody of Charles friend , and Fitzwilliam would no more suffer Charles to call on Jane in such a part of London ! Elizabeth ! dear aunt , how could Elizabeth ! think of it ? Fitzwilliam may perhaps have heard of such a place as Gracechurch Street , but Fitzwilliam would hardly think a month ’s ablution enough to cleanse Fitzwilliam from such a place as Gracechurch Street impurities , were Fitzwilliam once to enter such a place as Gracechurch Street ; and depend upon it , Charles never stirs without Charles . ” 
 
  “ So much the better . Elizabeth ! hope they will not meet at all . But does not Jane correspond with Mother brother wife , who came as usual to spend the Christmas at Longbourn ? Jane will not be able to help calling . ” 
 
  “ Jane will drop the acquaintance entirely . ” 
 
  But in spite of the certainty in which Elizabeth ! affected to place this point , as well as the still more interesting one of Charles ’s being withheld from seeing Jane , Elizabeth ! felt a solicitude on the subject which convinced Elizabeth ! , on examination , that Elizabeth ! did not consider it entirely hopeless . It was possible , and sometimes Elizabeth ! thought it probable , that Charles affection might be reanimated , and the influence of Charles friends successfully combated by the more natural influence of Jane ’s attractions . 
 
  Miss Bennet accepted Miss Bennet aunt ’s invitation with pleasure ; and the Bingleys were no otherwise in Miss Bennet thoughts at the same time , than as Miss Bennet hoped by Caroline ’s not living in the same house with Miss Bennet brother , Miss Bennet might occasionally spend a morning with Miss Bennet brother , without any danger of seeing Miss Bennet brother . 
 
  The Gardiners stayed a week at Longbourn ; and what with the Phillipses , Lady Lucas , and the officers , there was not a day without its engagement . Mother had so carefully provided for the entertainment of Mother brother and sister , that Mother brother and sister did not once sit down to a family dinner . When its engagement was for home , some of the officers always made part of its engagement — of which officers Charlie was sure to be one ; and on these occasions , Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with , rendered suspicious by Elizabeth ! warm commendation , narrowly observed they . Without supposing they , from what Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with saw , to be very seriously in love , they preference of each other was plain enough to make Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with a little uneasy ; and Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with resolved to speak to Elizabeth ! on the subject before Elizabeth ! left Hertfordshire , and represent to Elizabeth ! the imprudence of encouraging such an attachment . 
 
  To Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with , George had one means of affording pleasure , unconnected with George general powers . About ten or a dozen years ago , before Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with marriage , Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with had spent a considerable time in that very part of Derbyshire to which George belonged . They had , therefore , many acquaintances in common ; and though George had been little there since the death of Fitzwilliam ’s father , it was yet in George power to give Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with fresher intelligence of Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with former friends than Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with had been in the way of procuring . 
 
  Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with had seen Pemberley , and known the late Fitzwilliam by character perfectly well . Here consequently was an inexhaustible subject of discourse . In comparing Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with recollection of Pemberley with the minute description which George could give , and in bestowing Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with tribute of praise on the character of Fitzwilliam , Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with was delighting both George and Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with . On being made acquainted with the present Fitzwilliam ’s treatment of Fitzwilliam , Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with tried to remember some of Fitzwilliam reputed disposition when quite a lad which might agree with it , and was confident at last that Madeline , to whom the chief of this news had been given before , in the course of Jane and Elizabeth ’s correspondence with recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam formerly spoken of as a very proud , ill - natured boy . 
 Chapter 
 
  Madeline ’s caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to Elizabeth alone ; after honestly telling Elizabeth what Madeline ’s thought , Madeline ’s thus went on : 
 
  “ Elizabeth are too sensible a girl , Elizabeth , to fall in love merely because Elizabeth are warned against fall ; and , therefore , Madeline ’s am not afraid of speaking openly . Seriously , Madeline ’s would have Elizabeth be on Elizabeth guard . Do not involve Elizabeth or endeavour to involve Charlie in an affection which the want of fortune would make so very imprudent . Madeline ’s have nothing to say against Charlie ; Charlie is a most interesting young man ; and if Charlie had the fortune Charlie ought to have , Madeline ’s should think Elizabeth could not do better . But as it is , Elizabeth must not let Elizabeth fancy run away with Elizabeth . Elizabeth have sense , and we all expect Elizabeth to use sense . Elizabeth father would depend on Elizabeth resolution and good conduct , Madeline ’s am sure . Elizabeth must not disappoint Elizabeth father . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth dear aunt , Madeline ’s is being serious indeed . ” 
 
  “ Yes , and Madeline ’s hope to engage Elizabeth to be serious likewise . ” 
 
  “ Well , then , Madeline ’s need not be under any alarm . Elizabeth will take care of Elizabeth , and of Charlie too . Charlie shall not be in love with Elizabeth , if Elizabeth can prevent be . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , Elizabeth are not serious now . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth beg Madeline ’s pardon , Elizabeth will try again . At present Elizabeth am not in love with Charlie ; no , Elizabeth certainly am not . But Charlie is , beyond all comparison , the most agreeable man Elizabeth ever saw — and if Charlie becomes really attached to Elizabeth — Elizabeth believe it will be better that Charlie should not . Elizabeth see the imprudence of it . Oh ! that abominable Fitzwilliam !
