Elizabeth father opinion of Elizabeth does Elizabeth the greatest honour , and Elizabeth should be miserable to forfeit the greatest honour . Elizabeth father , however , is partial to Charlie . In short , Elizabeth dear aunt , Elizabeth should be very sorry to be the means of making any of Madeline ’s unhappy ; but since we see every day that where there is affection , young people are seldom withheld by immediate want of fortune from entering into engagements with each other , how can Elizabeth promise to be wiser than so many of Elizabeth fellow - creatures if Elizabeth am tempted , or how am Elizabeth even to know that it would be wisdom to resist ? All that Elizabeth can promise Madeline ’s , therefore , is not to be in a hurry . Elizabeth will not be in a hurry to believe Elizabeth Charlie first object . When Elizabeth am in company with Charlie , Elizabeth will not be wishing . In short , Elizabeth will do Elizabeth best . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps it will be as well if Elizabeth discourage Charlie coming here so very often . At least , Elizabeth should not remind Elizabeth mother of inviting Charlie . ” 
 
  “ As Elizabeth did the other day , ” said Elizabeth with a conscious smile : “ very true , it will be wise in Elizabeth to refrain from remind . But do not imagine that Charlie is always here so often . It is on Madeline ’s account that Charlie has been so frequently invited this week . Madeline ’s know Elizabeth mother ’s ideas as to the necessity of constant company for Elizabeth mother friends . But really , and upon Elizabeth honour , Elizabeth will try to do what Elizabeth think to be the wisest ; and now Elizabeth hope Madeline ’s are satisfied . ” 
 
  Elizabeth aunt assured Elizabeth that Madeline ’s was , and Elizabeth having thanked Madeline ’s for the kindness of Madeline ’s hints , they parted ; a wonderful instance of advice being given on such a point , without being resented . 
 
  Charlie returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted by the Gardiners and Jane ; but as Charlie took up Charlie abode with the Lucases , Charlie arrival was no great inconvenience to Elizabeth mother . Charlie marriage was now fast approaching , and Elizabeth mother was at length so far resigned as to think Charlie marriage inevitable , and even repeatedly to say , in an ill - natured tone , that Elizabeth mother “ wished they might be happy . ” Thursday was to be the wedding day , and on Wednesday Elizabeth mother paid Elizabeth mother farewell visit ; and when Elizabeth mother rose to take leave , Elizabeth , ashamed of Elizabeth mother ’s ungracious and reluctant good wishes , and sincerely affected Elizabeth , accompanied Elizabeth mother out of the room . As they went downstairs together , Charlotte said : 
 
  “ Charlotte shall depend on hearing from Elizabeth very often , Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ That Charlotte certainly shall . ” 
 
  “ And Charlotte have another favour to ask Elizabeth . Will Elizabeth come and see Charlotte ? ” 
 
  “ We shall often meet , Elizabeth hope , in Hertfordshire . ” 
 
  “ Charlotte am not likely to leave Kent for some time . Promise Charlotte , therefore , to come to Hunsford . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could not refuse , though Elizabeth foresaw little pleasure in come . 
 
  “ Elizabeth father and Maria are coming to Charlotte in March , ” added Charlotte , “ and Charlotte hope Elizabeth will consent to be of the party . Indeed , Elizabeth , Elizabeth will be as welcome as either of Elizabeth father and Maria . ” 
 
  Charlie marriage took place ; the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from the church door , and everybody had as much to say , or to hear , on the subject as usual . Elizabeth soon heard from Elizabeth friend ; and their correspondence was as regular and frequent as their correspondence had ever been ; that their correspondence should be equally unreserved was impossible . Elizabeth could never address Charlotte without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over , and though determined not to slacken as a correspondent , slacken was for the sake of what had been , rather than what was . Charlotte ’s first letters were received with a good deal of eagerness ; there could not but be curiosity to know how Charlotte would speak of Charlotte new home , how Charlotte would like Cathleen , and how happy Charlotte would dare pronounce Charlotte to be ; though , when Charlotte ’s first letters were read , Elizabeth felt that Charlotte expressed Charlotte on every point exactly as Elizabeth might have foreseen . Charlotte wrote cheerfully , seemed surrounded with comforts , and mentioned nothing which Charlotte could not praise . The house , furniture , neighbourhood , and roads , were all to Charlotte taste , and Cathleen ’s behaviour was most friendly and obliging . It was Charlie picture of Hunsford and Rosings rationally softened ; and Elizabeth perceived that Elizabeth must wait for Elizabeth own visit there to know the rest . 
 
  Jane had already written a few lines to Jane sister to announce Caroline and Mrs. Hurst safe arrival in London ; and when Jane wrote again , Elizabeth hoped it would be in Elizabeth power to say something of the Bingleys . 
 
  Elizabeth impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience generally is . Jane had been a week in town without either seeing or hearing from Caroline . Jane accounted for been , however , by supposing that Jane last letter to Jane friend from Longbourn had by some accident been lost . 
 
  “ Jane aunt , ” Jane continued , “ is going to - morrow into that part of London , and Jane shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street . ” 
 
  Jane wrote again when the visit was paid , and Jane had seen Caroline . “ Elizabeth did not think Caroline in spirits , ” were Jane words , “ but Caroline was very glad to see Elizabeth , and reproached Elizabeth for giving Caroline no notice of Elizabeth coming to London . Elizabeth was right , therefore , Elizabeth last letter had never reached Caroline . Elizabeth enquired after Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother , of course . Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother was well , but so much engaged with that abominable Fitzwilliam that Caroline and Mrs. Hurst scarcely ever saw Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother . Elizabeth found that Georgiana was expected to dinner . Elizabeth wish Elizabeth could see Georgiana . Elizabeth visit was not long , as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were going out . Elizabeth dare say Elizabeth shall see Caroline and Mrs. Hurst soon here . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth shook Elizabeth head over this second letter . this second letter convinced Elizabeth that accident only could discover to Charlotte Caroline being in town . 
 
  Four weeks passed away , and Jane saw nothing of Charlie . Jane endeavoured to persuade Jane that Jane did not regret it ; but Jane could no longer be blind to Caroline ’s inattention . After waiting at home every morning for a fortnight , and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for Jane , Jane did at last appear ; but the shortness of Jane stay , and yet more , the alteration of Jane manner would allow Jane to deceive Jane no longer . The letter which Jane wrote on this occasion to Elizabeth will prove what Jane felt . 
 
  “ Elizabeth dearest Elizabeth will , Elizabeth am sure , be incapable of triumphing in Elizabeth better judgement , at Elizabeth expense , when Elizabeth confess Elizabeth to have been entirely deceived in Caroline ’s regard for Elizabeth . But , Elizabeth dear sister , though the event has proved Elizabeth right , do not think Elizabeth obstinate if Elizabeth still assert that , considering what Caroline behaviour was , Elizabeth confidence was as natural as Elizabeth suspicion . Elizabeth do not at all comprehend Caroline reason for wishing to be intimate with Elizabeth ; but if the same circumstances were to happen again , Elizabeth am sure Elizabeth should be deceived again . Caroline did not return Elizabeth visit till yesterday ; and not a note , not a line , did Elizabeth receive in the meantime . When Caroline did come , it was very evident that Caroline had no pleasure in come ; Caroline made a slight , formal apology , for not calling before , said not a word of wishing to see Elizabeth again , and was in every respect so altered a creature , that when Caroline went away Elizabeth was perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer . Elizabeth pity , though Elizabeth can not help blaming Caroline . Caroline was very wrong in singling Elizabeth out as Caroline did ; Elizabeth can safely say that every advance to intimacy began on Caroline side . But Elizabeth pity Caroline , because Caroline must feel that Caroline has been acting wrong , and because Elizabeth am very sure that anxiety for Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother is the cause of acting . Elizabeth need not explain Elizabeth farther ; and though we know that anxiety for Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother to be quite needless , yet if Caroline feels that anxiety for Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother , that anxiety for Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother will easily account for Caroline behaviour to Elizabeth ; and so deservedly dear as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother is to Caroline , whatever anxiety Caroline must feel on Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother behalf is natural and amiable . Elizabeth can not but wonder , however , at Caroline having any such fears now , because , if Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother had at all cared about Elizabeth , we must have met , long ago . Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother knows of Elizabeth being in town , Elizabeth am certain , from something Caroline said Caroline ; and yet it would seem , by Caroline manner of talking , as if Caroline wanted to persuade Caroline that Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother is really partial to Georgiana . Elizabeth can not understand it . If Elizabeth were not afraid of judging harshly , Elizabeth should be almost tempted to say that there is a strong appearance of duplicity in all this . But Elizabeth will endeavour to banish every painful thought , and think only of what will make Elizabeth happy — Madeline ’s affection , and the invariable kindness of Elizabeth dear uncle and aunt . Let Elizabeth hear from Madeline ’s very soon . Caroline said something of Caroline never returning to Netherfield again , of giving up the house , but not with any certainty . We had better not mention it . Elizabeth am extremely glad that Madeline ’s have such pleasant accounts from our friends at Hunsford . Pray go to see our friends at Hunsford , with Sir William and Maria . Elizabeth am sure Madeline ’s will be very comfortable there.—Yours , etc . ” 
 
  this second letter gave Elizabeth some pain ; but Elizabeth spirits returned as Elizabeth considered that Jane would no longer be duped , by Caroline at least . All expectation from Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother was now absolutely over . Jane would not even wish for a renewal of Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother attentions . Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother character sunk on every review of Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother character ; and as a punishment for Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother , as well as a possible advantage to Jane , Elizabeth seriously hoped Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother might really soon marry that abominable Fitzwilliam sister , as by George ’s account , she would make Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother abundantly regret what Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother had thrown away . 
 
  Madeline about this time reminded Elizabeth of Elizabeth promise concerning Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother , and required information ; and Elizabeth had such to send as might rather give contentment to Madeline ’s than to Elizabeth . Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother apparent partiality had subsided , Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother attentions were over , Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother was the admirer of some one else . Elizabeth was watchful enough to see it all , but Elizabeth could see it all and write of it all without material pain . Elizabeth heart had been but slightly touched , and Elizabeth vanity was satisfied with believing that Elizabeth would have been Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother only choice , had fortune permitted been . The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most remarkable charm of Elizabeth ; but Elizabeth , less clear - sighted perhaps in this case than in Charlotte ’s , did not quarrel with Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother for Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother wish of independence . Nothing , on the contrary , could be more natural ; and while able to suppose that it cost Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother a few struggles to relinquish Elizabeth , Elizabeth was ready to allow relinquish a wise and desirable measure for both , and could very sincerely wish Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother happy . 
 
  All this was acknowledged to Madeline ’s ; and after relating the circumstances , Elizabeth thus went on : “ Elizabeth am now convinced , Madeline ’s , that Elizabeth have never been much in love ; for had Elizabeth really experienced that pure and elevating passion , Elizabeth should at present detest Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother very name , and wish Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother all manner of evil . But Elizabeth feelings are not only cordial towards Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother ; Elizabeth feelings are even impartial towards Caroline . Elizabeth can not find out that Elizabeth hate Caroline at all , or that Elizabeth am in the least unwilling to think Caroline a very good sort of girl . There can be no love in all this . Elizabeth watchfulness has been effectual ; and though Elizabeth certainly should be a more interesting object to all Elizabeth acquaintances were Elizabeth distractedly in love with Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother , Elizabeth can not say that Elizabeth regret Elizabeth comparative insignificance . Importance may sometimes be purchased too dearly . Caroline and Mrs. Hurst take Caroline and Mrs. Hurst brother defection much more to heart than Elizabeth do . Caroline and Mrs. Hurst are young in the ways of the world , and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that handsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  With no greater events than these in the Longbourn family , and otherwise diversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton , sometimes dirty and sometimes cold , did January and February pass away . March was to take Elizabeth to Hunsford . Elizabeth had not at first thought very seriously of going thither ; but Charlotte , Elizabeth soon found , was depending on the plan and Elizabeth gradually learned to consider the plan Elizabeth with greater pleasure as well as greater certainty . Absence had increased Elizabeth desire of seeing Charlotte again , and weakened Elizabeth disgust of William Collins . There was novelty in the plan , and as , with such a mother and such uncompanionable sisters , home could not be faultless , a little change was not unwelcome for a little change own sake . The journey would moreover give Elizabeth a peep at Jane ; and , in short , as the time drew near , Elizabeth would have been very sorry for any delay . Everything , however , went on smoothly , and was finally settled according to Charlotte ’s first sketch . Elizabeth was to accompany William Collins and William Collins second daughter . The improvement of spending a night in London was added in time , and the plan became perfect as plan could be . 
 
  The only pain was in leaving Elizabeth father , who would certainly miss Elizabeth , and who , when it came to the point , so little liked Elizabeth going , that he told Elizabeth to write to he , and almost promised to answer Elizabeth letter . 
 
  The farewell between Elizabeth and Charlotte was perfectly friendly ; on William Collins side even more . William Collins present pursuit could not make William Collins forget that Elizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve William Collins attention , the first to listen and to pity , the first to be admired ; and in William Collins manner of bidding Elizabeth adieu , wishing Elizabeth every enjoyment , reminding Elizabeth of what Elizabeth was to expect in Cathleen , and trusting their opinion of Elizabeth — their opinion of everybody — would always coincide , there was a solicitude , an interest which Elizabeth felt must ever attach Elizabeth to William Collins with a most sincere regard ; and Elizabeth parted from William Collins convinced that , whether married or single , William Collins must always be Elizabeth model of the amiable and pleasing . 
 
  Elizabeth fellow - travellers the next day were not of a kind to make Elizabeth think William Collins less agreeable . William Collins , and William Collins daughter Maria , a good - humoured girl , but as empty - headed as William Collins , had nothing to say that could be worth hearing , and were listened to with about as much delight as the rattle of the chaise . Elizabeth loved absurdities , but Elizabeth had known William Collins too long . William Collins could tell Elizabeth nothing new of the wonders of William Collins presentation and knighthood ; and William Collins civilities were worn out , like William Collins information . 
 
  It was a journey of only twenty - four miles , and they began it so early as to be in Gracechurch Street by noon . As they drove to Edward ’s door , Jane was at a drawing - room window watching they arrival ; when they entered the passage Jane was there to welcome they , and Elizabeth , looking earnestly in Elizabeth face , was pleased to see Elizabeth face healthful and lovely as ever . On the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls , whose eagerness for their cousin ’s appearance would not allow their to wait in the drawing - room , and whose shyness , as their had not seen Elizabeth for a twelvemonth , prevented their coming lower . All was joy and kindness . The day passed most pleasantly away ; the morning in bustle and shopping , and the evening at one of the theatres . 
 
  Elizabeth then contrived to sit by Elizabeth aunt . Their first object was Elizabeth sister ; and Elizabeth was more grieved than astonished to hear , in reply to Elizabeth minute enquiries , that though Jane always struggled to support Jane spirits , there were periods of dejection . It was reasonable , however , to hope that they would not continue long . Madeline gave Elizabeth the particulars also of Caroline ’s visit in Gracechurch Street , and repeated conversations occurring at different times between Jane and Elizabeth , which proved that Jane had , from Jane heart , given up the acquaintance . 
 
  Madeline then rallied Madeline niece on George ’s desertion , and complimented Elizabeth on bearing George ’s desertion so well . 
 
  “ But Madeline dear Elizabeth , ” Madeline added , “ what sort of girl is William Collins second daughter ? Madeline should be sorry to think our friend mercenary . ” 
 
  “ Pray , Madeline , what is the difference in matrimonial affairs , between the mercenary and the prudent motive ? Where does discretion end , and avarice begin ? Last Christmas Madeline were afraid of George ’s marrying Elizabeth , because marrying would be imprudent ; and now , because George ’s is trying to get a girl with only ten thousand pounds , Madeline want to find out that George ’s is mercenary . ” 
 
  “ If Madeline will only tell Elizabeth what sort of girl William Collins second daughter is , Elizabeth shall know what to think . ” 
 
  “ William Collins second daughter is a very good kind of girl , Madeline believe . Madeline know no harm of William Collins second daughter . ” 
 
  “ But George ’s paid William Collins second daughter not the smallest attention till William Collins second daughter grandfather ’s death made William Collins second daughter mistress of this fortune . ” 
 
  “ No — why should George ’s ? If it were not allowable for George ’s to gain Elizabeth affections because Elizabeth had no money , what occasion could there be for making love to a girl whom George ’s did not care about , and who was equally poor ? ” 
 
  “ But there seems an indelicacy in directing George ’s attentions towards William Collins second daughter so soon after this event . ” 
 
  “ A man in distressed circumstances has not time for all those elegant decorums which other people may observe . If William Collins second daughter does not object to directing , why should we ? ” 
 
  “ William Collins second daughter not objecting does not justify George ’s . William Collins second daughter not objecting only shows William Collins second daughter being deficient in something William Collins second daughter — sense or feeling . ” 
 
  “ Well , ” cried Elizabeth , “ have it as Madeline choose . George ’s shall be mercenary , and William Collins second daughter shall be foolish . ” 
 
  “ No , Elizabeth , that is what Madeline do not choose . Madeline should be sorry , Elizabeth know , to think ill of a young man who has lived so long in Derbyshire . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! if that is all , Elizabeth have a very poor opinion of young men who live in Derbyshire ; and young men who live in Derbyshire intimate friends who live in Hertfordshire are not much better . Elizabeth am sick of them all . Thank Heaven ! Elizabeth am going to - morrow where Elizabeth shall find a man who has not one agreeable quality , who has neither manner nor sense to recommend a man who has not one agreeable quality , who has neither manner nor sense to recommend . Stupid men are the only ones worth knowing , after all . ” 
 
  “ Take care , Elizabeth ; that speech savours strongly of disappointment . ” 
 
  Before they were separated by the conclusion of the play , Elizabeth had the unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany Elizabeth uncle and aunt in a tour of pleasure which Elizabeth uncle and aunt proposed taking in the summer . 
 
  “ Elizabeth uncle and aunt have not determined how far a tour of pleasure which Elizabeth uncle and aunt proposed taking in the summer shall carry Elizabeth uncle and aunt , ” said Madeline , “ but , perhaps , to the Lakes . ” 
 
  No scheme could have been more agreeable to Elizabeth , and Elizabeth acceptance of an invitation to accompany Elizabeth uncle and aunt in a tour of pleasure which Elizabeth uncle and aunt proposed taking in the summer was most ready and grateful . “ Oh , Madeline , ” Elizabeth rapturously cried , “ what delight ! what felicity ! Madeline give Elizabeth fresh life and vigour . Adieu to disappointment and spleen . What are young men to rocks and mountains ? Oh ! what hours of transport Elizabeth uncle and aunt shall spend ! And when Elizabeth uncle and aunt do return , it shall not be like other travellers , without being able to give one accurate idea of anything . Elizabeth uncle and aunt will know where Elizabeth uncle and aunt have gone — Elizabeth uncle and aunt will recollect what Elizabeth uncle and aunt have seen . Lakes , mountains , and rivers shall not be jumbled together in Elizabeth uncle and aunt imaginations ; nor when Elizabeth uncle and aunt attempt to describe any particular scene , will Elizabeth uncle and aunt begin quarreling about any particular scene relative situation . Let Elizabeth uncle and aunt first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of travellers . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  Every object in the next day ’s journey was new and interesting to Elizabeth ; and Elizabeth spirits were in a state of enjoyment ; for Elizabeth had seen Elizabeth sister looking so well as to banish all fear for Elizabeth sister health , and the prospect of Elizabeth sister northern tour was a constant source of delight . 
 
  When they left the high road for the lane to Hunsford , every eye was in search of the Parsonage , and every turning expected to bring the Parsonage in view . The palings of Rosings Park was they boundary on one side . Elizabeth smiled at the recollection of all that Elizabeth had heard of the Parsonage inhabitants .

The garden sloping to the road , the Parsonage standing in The garden sloping to the road , the green pales , and the laurel hedge , everything declared they were arriving . In a moment the whole party were all out of the chaise , rejoicing at the sight of each other . William Collins welcomed William Collins friend with the liveliest pleasure , and Elizabeth was more and more satisfied with coming when Elizabeth found Elizabeth so affectionately received . Elizabeth saw instantly that William Collins manners were not altered by William Collins marriage ; William Collins formal civility was just what William Collins formal civility had been , and William Collins detained Elizabeth some minutes at the small gate which led by a short gravel walk to the Parsonage to hear and satisfy William Collins enquiries after all Elizabeth family . the ladies were then , with no other delay than William Collins pointing out the neatness of the entrance , taken into the Parsonage ; and as soon as the ladies were in the parlour , William Collins welcomed the ladies a second time , with ostentatious formality to William Collins humble abode , and punctually repeated all Charlotte offers of refreshment . 
 
  Elizabeth was prepared to see William Collins in William Collins glory ; and Elizabeth could not help in fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room , the room aspect and the room furniture , William Collins addressed William Collins particularly to Elizabeth , as if wishing to make Elizabeth feel what Elizabeth had lost in refusing William Collins . But though everything seemed neat and comfortable , Elizabeth was not able to gratify William Collins by any sigh of repentance , and rather looked with wonder at Elizabeth friend that Elizabeth could have so cheerful an air with such a companion . When William Collins said anything of which William Collins wife might reasonably be ashamed , which certainly was not unseldom , Elizabeth involuntarily turned Elizabeth eye on Charlotte . Once or twice Elizabeth could discern a faint blush ; but in general Charlotte wisely did not hear . After sitting long enough to admire every article of furniture in the room , from the sideboard to the fender , to give an account of the ladies journey , and of all that had happened in Hunsford , William Collins invited the ladies to take a stroll in the garden , which was large and well laid out , and to the cultivation of which William Collins attended William Collins . To work in the garden , which was large and well laid out , and to the cultivation of which William Collins attended William Collins was one of William Collins most respectable pleasures ; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance with which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise , and owned Charlotte encouraged the exercise as much as possible . Here , leading the way through every walk and cross walk , and scarcely allowing the ladies an interval to utter the praises William Collins asked for , every view was pointed out with a minuteness which left beauty entirely behind . William Collins could number the fields in every direction , and could tell how many trees there were in the most distant clump . But of all the views which the garden , which was large and well laid out , and to the cultivation of which William Collins attended William Collins , or which the country or kingdom could boast , none were to be compared with the prospect of Rosings , afforded by an opening in the trees that bordered the park nearly opposite the front of William Collins house . the Parsonage was a handsome modern building , well situated on rising ground . 
 
  From the garden , which was large and well laid out , and to the cultivation of which William Collins attended William Collins , William Collins would have led the ladies round William Collins two meadows ; but the ladies , not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white frost , turned back ; and while William Collins accompanied William Collins , Charlotte took Elizabeth over the Parsonage , extremely well pleased , probably , to have the opportunity of showing the Parsonage without Charlotte husband ’s help . the Parsonage was rather small , but well built and convenient ; and everything was fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency of which Elizabeth gave Charlotte all the credit . When William Collins could be forgotten , there was really an air of great comfort throughout , and by Charlotte ’s evident enjoyment of it , Elizabeth supposed William Collins must be often forgotten . 
 
  Elizabeth had already learnt that Cathleen was still in the country . It was spoken of again while the ladies were at dinner , when William Collins joining in , observed : 
 
  “ Yes , Miss Elizabeth , Elizabeth will have the honour of seeing Cathleen on the ensuing Sunday at church , and I need not say Elizabeth will be delighted with Cathleen . Cathleen is all affability and condescension , and I doubt not but Elizabeth will be honoured with some portion of Cathleen notice when service is over . I have scarcely any hesitation in saying Cathleen will include Elizabeth and I sister Maria in every invitation with which Cathleen honours us during Elizabeth stay here . Cathleen behaviour to I dear Charlotte is charming . We dine at Rosings twice every week , and are never allowed to walk home . Cathleen carriage is regularly ordered for We . I should say , the carriage the carriage , for Cathleen has several . ” 
 
  “ Cathleen is a very respectable , sensible woman indeed , ” added Charlotte , “ and a most attentive neighbour . ” 
 
  “ Very true , I dear , that is exactly what I say . Cathleen is the sort of woman whom one can not regard with too much deference . ” 
 
  The evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news , and telling again what had already been written ; and when The evening closed , Elizabeth , in the solitude of Elizabeth chamber , had to meditate upon Charlotte ’s degree of contentment , to understand Charlotte address in guiding , and composure in bearing with , William Collins , and to acknowledge that it was all done very well . Elizabeth had also to anticipate how Elizabeth visit would pass , the quiet tenor of their usual employments , the vexatious interruptions of William Collins , and the gaieties of their intercourse with Rosings . A lively imagination soon settled it all . 
 
  About the middle of the next day , as Elizabeth was in Elizabeth room getting ready for a walk , a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in confusion ; and , after listening a moment , Elizabeth heard somebody running up stairs in a violent hurry , and calling loudly after somebody . Elizabeth opened the door and met Maria in the landing place , who , breathless with agitation , cried out — 
 
  “ Oh , my dear Elizabeth ! pray make haste and come into the dining - room , for there is such a sight to be seen ! I sister Maria will not tell Elizabeth what such a sight to be seen is . Make haste , and come down this moment . ” 
 
  Elizabeth asked questions in vain ; I sister Maria would tell Elizabeth nothing more , and down the ladies ran into the dining - room , which fronted the lane to Hunsford , in quest of such a sight to be seen ; It was two ladies stopping in a low phaeton at the small gate which led by a short gravel walk to the Parsonage . 
 
  “ And is this all ? ” cried Elizabeth . “ Elizabeth expected at least that the pigs were got into the garden , which was large and well laid out , and to the cultivation of which William Collins attended William Collins , and here is nothing but Cathleen and Cathleen daughter . ”

Only look at Cathleen . Cathleen is quite a little creature . Who would have thought that Cathleen could be so thin and small ? ” 
 
  “ Cathleen is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind . Why does Cathleen not come in ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , Charlotte says Cathleen hardly ever does . It is the greatest of favours when Cathleen comes in . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth like Cathleen appearance , ” said Elizabeth , struck with other ideas . “ Cathleen looks sickly and cross . Yes , Cathleen will do for him very well . Cathleen will make him a very proper wife . ” William Collins William Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the small gate which led by a short gravel walk to the Parsonage in conversation with the ladies ; and William Collins , to Elizabeth ’s high diversion , was stationed in the doorway , in earnest contemplation of the greatness before William Collins , and constantly bowing whenever Cathleen looked that way . 
 
  At length there was nothing more to be said ; the ladies drove on , and the others returned into the Parsonage . William Collins no sooner saw the ladies than William Collins began to congratulate the ladies on the ladies good fortune , which Charlotte explained by letting the ladies know that the whole party was asked to dine at Rosings the next day . 
 Chapter 
 
  William Collins ’s triumph , in consequence of this invitation , was complete . The power of displaying the grandeur of William Collins ’s patroness to William Collins ’s wondering visitors , and of letting William Collins ’s wondering visitors see William Collins ’s patroness civility towards William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife , was exactly what William Collins ’s had wished for ; and that an opportunity of doing it should be given so soon , was such an instance of William Collins ’s patroness condescension , as William Collins ’s knew not how to admire enough . 
 
  “ William Collins ’s confess , ” said William Collins ’s , “ that William Collins ’s should not have been at all surprised by William Collins ’s patroness asking William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at Rosings . William Collins ’s rather expected , from William Collins ’s knowledge of William Collins ’s patroness affability , that it would happen . But who could have foreseen such an attention as this ? Who could have imagined that William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife should receive an invitation to dine there ( an invitation , moreover , including the whole party ) so immediately after your arrival ! ”

About the court , such instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon . ”

William Collins ’s patroness will not think the worse of Elizabeth for being simply dressed . William Collins ’s patroness likes to have the distinction of rank preserved . ”

William Collins ’s patroness was a tall , large woman , with strongly - marked features , which might once have been handsome .   The dinner was exceedingly handsome , and there were all the servants and all the articles of plate which William Collins ’s had promised ; and , as William Collins ’s had likewise foretold , William Collins ’s took William Collins ’s seat at the bottom of the table , by William Collins ’s patroness desire , and looked as if William Collins ’s felt that life could furnish nothing greater . William Collins ’s carved , and ate , and praised with delighted alacrity ; and every dish was commended , first by William Collins ’s and then by Sir William , who was now enough recovered to echo whatever William Collins ’s son - in - law said , in a manner which Elizabeth wondered William Collins ’s patroness could bear . Mrs. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little William Collins ’s patroness ate , pressing William Collins ’s patroness to try some other dish , and fearing William Collins ’s patroness was indisposed . Maria ’s thought speaking out of the question , and the gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire . 
 
  When William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife returned to the drawing - room , there was little to be done but to hear William Collins ’s patroness talk , which William Collins ’s patroness did without any intermission till coffee came in , delivering William Collins ’s patroness opinion on every subject in so decisive a manner , as proved that William Collins ’s patroness was not used to have William Collins ’s patroness judgement controverted . William Collins ’s patroness enquired into Charlotte ’s domestic concerns familiarly and minutely , gave Charlotte a great deal of advice as to the management of Charlotte ’s domestic concerns ; told Charlotte how everything ought to be regulated in so small a family as Charlotte , and instructed Charlotte as to the care of Charlotte cows and Charlotte poultry . Do Charlotte play and sing , Charlotte ? ” 
 
  “ A little . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! then — some time or other we shall be happy to hear Charlotte . we instrument is a capital one , probably superior to —— Charlotte shall try we instrument some day . Do Charlotte sisters play and sing ? ” 
 
  “ One of Charlotte sisters does . ” 
 
  “ Why did not William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife learn ? William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife ought all to have learned . The Miss Webbs all play , and William Collins ’s has not so good an income as William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife . Do Charlotte draw ? ” 
 
  “ No , not at all . ”

  “ Then , who taught Charlotte ? who attended to Charlotte ? Without a governess , Charlotte must have been neglected . ” 
 
  “ Compared with some families , Elizabeth believe William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife were ; but such of William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife as wished to learn never wanted the means . William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife were always encouraged to read , and had all the masters that were necessary . Those who chose to be idle , certainly might . ” 
 
  “ Aye , no doubt ; but that is what a governess will prevent , and if William Collins ’s patroness had known Charlotte mother , William Collins ’s patroness should have advised Elizabeth mother ’s most strenuously to engage one . William Collins ’s patroness always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady and regular instruction , and nobody but a governess can give education . It is wonderful how many families William Collins ’s patroness have been the means of supplying in that way . William Collins ’s patroness am always glad to get a young person well placed out . Four nieces of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through William Collins ’s patroness means ; and it was but the other day that William Collins ’s patroness recommended another young person , who was merely accidentally mentioned to William Collins ’s patroness , and the family are quite delighted with another young person , who was merely accidentally mentioned to William Collins ’s patroness . William Collins ’s , did William Collins ’s patroness tell William Collins ’s of Lady Metcalf ’s calling yesterday to thank William Collins ’s patroness ? Lady Metcalf ’s finds Miss Pope a treasure . ‘ William Collins ’s patroness , ’ said Lady Metcalf ’s , ‘ William Collins ’s patroness have given Lady Metcalf ’s a treasure . ’ Are any of Charlotte younger sisters out , Charlotte ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , William Collins ’s patroness , all . ” 
 
  “ All ! What , All ! out at once ? Very odd ! And Charlotte only the second . Charlotte younger sisters out before the elder ones are married ! Charlotte younger sisters must be very young ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , Charlotte youngest is not sixteen . Perhaps Charlotte youngest is full young to be much in company . But really , William Collins ’s patroness , Charlotte think it would be very hard upon younger sisters , that younger sisters should not have younger sisters share of society and amusement , because the elder may not have the means or inclination to marry early . The last - born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth as the first . And to be kept back on such a motive ! Charlotte think such a motive would not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind . ” 
 
  “ Upon William Collins ’s patroness word , ” said William Collins ’s patroness , “ Elizabeth give Elizabeth opinion very decidedly for so young a person . Pray , what is Elizabeth age ? ” 
 
  “ With three younger sisters grown up , ” replied Elizabeth , smiling , “ William Collins ’s patroness can hardly expect Elizabeth to own it . ” 
 
  William Collins ’s patroness seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer ; and Elizabeth suspected Elizabeth to be the first creature who had ever dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence . 
 
  “ Elizabeth can not be more than twenty , William Collins ’s patroness am sure , therefore Elizabeth need not conceal Elizabeth age . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth am not one - and - twenty . ” 
 
  When the gentlemen had joined them , and tea was over , the card - tables were placed . William Collins ’s patroness , William Collins ’s , and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat down to quadrille ; and as William Collins ’s patroness chose to play at cassino , William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife had the honour of assisting Mrs. Jenkinson to make up Mrs. Jenkinson party . William Collins ’s patroness , William Collins ’s , and Mr. and Mrs. Collins table was superlatively stupid . Scarcely a syllable was uttered that did not relate to quadrille , except when Mrs. Jenkinson expressed Mrs. Jenkinson fears of William Collins ’s patroness being too hot or too cold , or having too much or too little light . A great deal more passed at the other table . William Collins ’s patroness was generally speaking — stating the mistakes of William Collins ’s patroness , William Collins ’s patroness daughter , and Mrs. Jenkinson , or relating some anecdote of William Collins ’s patroness . William Collins ’s was employed in agreeing to everything William Collins ’s patroness said , thanking William Collins ’s patroness for every fish William Collins ’s won , and apologising if William Collins ’s thought William Collins ’s won too many . William Collins ’s did not say much . William Collins ’s was storing William Collins ’s memory with anecdotes and noble names . 
 
  When William Collins ’s patroness and Elizabeth had played as long as William Collins ’s patroness and Elizabeth chose , the tables were broken up , the carriage was offered to William Collins ’s , gratefully accepted and immediately ordered . William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife then gathered round the fire to hear William Collins ’s patroness determine what weather William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife were to have on the morrow . From these instructions William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife were summoned by the arrival of the carriage ; and with many speeches of thankfulness on William Collins ’s side and as many bows on William Collins ’s William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife departed . As soon as William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s wife had driven from the door , Elizabeth was called on by Elizabeth cousin to give Elizabeth opinion of all that Elizabeth had seen at Rosings , which , for Charlotte ’s sake , Elizabeth made more favourable than Elizabeth opinion of all that Elizabeth had seen at Rosings , which , for Charlotte ’s sake , Elizabeth made more favourable than really was . But Elizabeth commendation , though costing Elizabeth some trouble , could by no means satisfy William Collins ’s , and William Collins ’s was very soon obliged to take Elizabeth praise into William Collins ’s own hands . 
 Chapter 
 
  Sir William stayed only a week at Hunsford , but Sir William visit was long enough to convince Sir William of Sir William daughter ’s being most comfortably settled , and of Sir William daughter ’s possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not often met with . While Sir William was with the whole family , Sir William devoted Sir William morning to driving Sir William out in Sir William gig , and showing Sir William the country ; but when Sir William went away , the whole family returned to the whole family usual employments , and Elizabeth was thankful to find that the whole family did not see more of Elizabeth cousin by the alteration , for the chief of the time between breakfast and dinner was now passed by Sir William either at work in the garden or in reading and writing , and looking out of the window in Sir William own book - room , which fronted the road . The room in which the whole family sat was backwards . Elizabeth had at first rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer the dining - parlour for common use ; the dining - parlour was a better sized room , and had a more pleasant aspect ; but Elizabeth soon saw that Charlotte had an excellent reason for what Charlotte did , for Sir William would undoubtedly have been much less in Sir William own apartment , had they sat in one equally lively ; and Elizabeth gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement . 
 
  From the drawing - room the whole family could distinguish nothing in the lane , and were indebted to Sir William for the knowledge of what carriages went along , and how often especially Cathleen drove by in especially Cathleen phaeton , which Sir William never failed coming to inform the whole family of , though it happened almost every day . especially Cathleen not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage , and had a few minutes ’ conversation with Charlotte , but was scarcely ever prevailed upon to get out . 
 
  Very few days passed in which Sir William did not walk to Rosings , and not many in which Sir William wife did not think it necessary to go likewise ; and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings to be disposed of , Elizabeth could not understand the sacrifice of so many hours . Now and then the whole family were honoured with a call from her ladyship , and nothing escaped her ladyship observation that was passing in the room during these visits . her ladyship examined into the whole family employments , looked at the whole family work , and advised the whole family to do the whole family work differently ; found fault with the arrangement of the furniture ; or detected the housemaid in negligence ; and if her ladyship accepted any refreshment , seemed to do it only for the sake of finding out that Sir William joints of meat were too large for Sir William family . Elizabeth Elizabeth soon perceived , that though her ladyship was not in the commission of the peace of the county , her ladyship was a most active magistrate in her ladyship own parish , the minutest concerns of which were carried to her ladyship by Sir William ; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to be quarrelsome , discontented , or too poor , her ladyship sallied forth into the village to settle any of the cottagers differences , silence any of the cottagers complaints , and scold any of the cottagers into harmony and plenty . 
 
  The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week ; and , allowing for the loss of Sir William , and there being only one card - table in the evening , every such entertainment was the counterpart of the first . the whole family other engagements were few , as the style of living in the neighbourhood in general was beyond Sir William reach . This , however , was no evil to Elizabeth , and upon the whole Elizabeth spent Elizabeth time comfortably enough ; there were half - hours of pleasant conversation with Charlotte , and the weather was so fine for the time of year that Elizabeth had often great enjoyment out of doors . Elizabeth favourite walk , and where Elizabeth frequently went while the others were calling on especially Cathleen , was along the open grove which edged that side of the park , where there was a nice sheltered path , which no one seemed to value but Elizabeth , and where Elizabeth felt beyond the reach of especially Cathleen curiosity . 
 
  In this quiet way , the first fortnight of Elizabeth visit soon passed away . Easter was approaching , and the week preceding Easter was to bring an addition to the family at Rosings , which in so small a circle must be important . Elizabeth had heard soon after Elizabeth arrival that Fitzwilliam was expected there in the course of a few weeks , and though there were not many of Elizabeth acquaintances whom Elizabeth did not prefer , Fitzwilliam coming would furnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties , and Elizabeth might be amused in seeing how hopeless Caroline ’s designs on Fitzwilliam were , by Fitzwilliam behaviour to Fitzwilliam cousin , for whom Fitzwilliam was evidently destined by Cathleen , who talked of Fitzwilliam coming with the greatest satisfaction , spoke of Fitzwilliam in terms of the highest admiration , and seemed almost angry to find that Fitzwilliam had already been frequently seen by Miss Lucas and Miss Lucas . 
 
  Fitzwilliam arrival was soon known at the Parsonage ; for Sir William was walking the whole morning within view of the lodges opening into the lane , in order to have the earliest assurance of Fitzwilliam coming , and after making Sir William bow as the carriage turned into the Park , hurried home with the great intelligence . On the following morning Sir William hastened to Rosings to pay Sir William respects . There were two nephews of especially Cathleen to require two nephews of especially Cathleen , for Fitzwilliam had brought with Fitzwilliam a Fitzwilam , the younger son of Fitzwilliam uncle Lord — — , and , to the great surprise of all the party , when Sir William returned , the gentlemen accompanied Sir William . Charlotte had seen the three gentlemen from Charlotte husband ’s room , crossing the road , and immediately running into the other , told the whole family what an honour the whole family might expect , adding : 
 
  “ Charlotte may thank Elizabeth , Elizabeth , for this piece of civility . Fitzwilliam would never have come so soon to wait upon Charlotte . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment , before the three gentlemen approach was announced by the door - bell , and shortly afterwards the three gentlemen entered the room . a Fitzwilam , the younger son of Fitzwilliam uncle Lord , was about thirty , not handsome , but in person and address most truly the gentleman . Fitzwilliam looked just as Fitzwilliam had been used to look in Hertfordshire — paid Fitzwilliam compliments , with Fitzwilliam usual reserve , to Elizabeth , and whatever might be Fitzwilliam feelings toward Elizabeth friend , met Elizabeth with every appearance of composure . Elizabeth merely curtseyed to Fitzwilliam without saying a word . 
 
  Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly with the readiness and ease of a well - bred man , and talked very pleasantly ; but Fitzwilliam cousin , after having addressed a slight observation on the house and garden to Elizabeth , sat for some time without speaking to anybody . At length , however , Fitzwilliam civility was so far awakened as to enquire of Elizabeth after the health of Elizabeth family . Elizabeth answered Fitzwilliam in the usual way , and after a moment ’s pause , added : 
 
  “ Elizabeth eldest sister has been in town these three months . Have Fitzwilliam never happened to see Elizabeth eldest sister there ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth was perfectly sensible that Fitzwilliam never had ; but Elizabeth wished to see whether Fitzwilliam would betray any consciousness of what had passed between the Bingleys and Jane , and Elizabeth thought Fitzwilliam looked a little confused as Fitzwilliam answered that Fitzwilliam had never been so fortunate as to meet Elizabeth eldest sister . The subject was pursued no farther , and the gentlemen soon afterwards went away . 
 Chapter 
 
  Fitzwilam ’s manners were very much admired at the Parsonage , and the ladies all felt that Fitzwilam ’s must add considerably to the pleasures of the ladies all engagements at Rosings . For the last week the ladies all had seen very little of Cathleen or Cathleen daughter .   asked was accepted of course , and at a proper hour the ladies all joined the party in Cathleen ’s drawing - room . Fitzwilliam now seated Fitzwilliam by Cathleen daughter , and talked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire , of travelling and staying at home , of new books and music , that Cathleen daughter had never been half so well entertained in Cathleen ’s drawing - room before ; and they conversed with so much spirit and flow , as to draw the attention of Cathleen herself , as well as of Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned towards the ladies all with a look of curiosity ; and that Cathleen , after a while , shared the feeling , was more openly acknowledged , for Cathleen did not scruple to call out :

There are few people in England , Cathleen suppose , who have more true enjoyment of music than Cathleen , or a better natural taste . If Cathleen had ever learnt , Cathleen should have been a great proficient . And so would Anne , if Anne health had allowed Anne to apply . Cathleen am confident that Anne would have performed delightfully . How does Georgiana get on , Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam spoke with affectionate praise of Anne proficiency . 
 
  “ Cathleen am very glad to hear such a good account of Anne , ” said Cathleen ; “ and pray tell Anne from Cathleen , that Anne can not expect to excel if Anne does not practice a good deal . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam assure Cathleen , Cathleen , ” Fitzwilliam replied , “ that Anne does not need such advice . Anne practises very constantly . ” 
 
  “ So much the better . practises can not be done too much ; and when Fitzwilliam next write to Anne , Fitzwilliam shall charge Anne not to neglect practises on any account . Fitzwilliam often tell young ladies that no excellence in music is to be acquired without constant practice . Fitzwilliam have told Cathleen daughter several times , that Cathleen daughter will never play really well unless Cathleen daughter practises more ; and though Cathleen daughter has no instrument , Cathleen daughter is very welcome , as Fitzwilliam have often told Cathleen daughter , to come to Rosings every day , and play on the pianoforte in Mrs. Jenkinson ’s room . Cathleen daughter would be in nobody ’s way , you know , in that part of the Parsonage . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam looked a little ashamed of Cathleen ill - breeding , and made no answer .

Cathleen daughter will not be alarmed though Fitzwilliam sister does play so well . There is a stubbornness about Cathleen daughter that never can bear to be frightened at the will of others . Cathleen daughter courage always rises at every attempt to intimidate Cathleen daughter . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam shall not say Cathleen daughter are mistaken , ” Fitzwilliam replied , “ because Cathleen daughter could not really believe Fitzwilliam to entertain any design of alarming Cathleen daughter ; and Fitzwilliam have had the pleasure of Cathleen daughter acquaintance long enough to know that Cathleen daughter find great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which in fact are not Cathleen daughter own . ” 
 
  Cathleen daughter laughed heartily at this picture of Cathleen daughter , and said to Fitzwilliam , “ Fitzwilliam cousin will give Fitzwilliam a very pretty notion of Cathleen daughter , and teach Fitzwilliam not to believe a word Cathleen daughter say . Cathleen daughter am particularly unlucky in meeting with a person so able to expose Cathleen daughter real character , in a part of the world where Cathleen daughter had hoped to pass Cathleen daughter off with some degree of credit .   “ Fitzwilliam am not afraid of Cathleen daughter , ” said Fitzwilliam , smilingly .

  “ Fitzwilliam shall hear then — but prepare Fitzwilliam for something very dreadful . The first time of Fitzwilliam ever seeing Fitzwilliam in Hertfordshire , Fitzwilliam must know , was at a ball — and at a ball , what do Fitzwilliam think Fitzwilliam did ? Fitzwilliam danced only four dances , though gentlemen were scarce ; and , to Fitzwilliam certain knowledge , more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a partner . Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam can not deny the fact . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly beyond Fitzwilliam own party . ” 
 
  “ True ; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball - room . Well , Fitzwilliam , what do Cathleen daughter play next ? Cathleen daughter fingers wait Fitzwilliam orders . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ Fitzwilliam should have judged better , had Fitzwilliam sought an introduction ; but Fitzwilliam am ill - qualified to recommend Fitzwilliam to strangers . ” 
 
  “ Shall we ask Fitzwilliam cousin the reason of am ? ” said Cathleen daughter , still addressing Fitzwilliam . “ Shall we ask Fitzwilliam why a man of sense and education , and who has lived in the world , is ill qualified to recommend Fitzwilliam to strangers ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam can answer Cathleen daughter question , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ without applying to Fitzwilliam . It is because Fitzwilliam will not give Fitzwilliam the trouble . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam certainly have not the talent which some people possess , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ of conversing easily with those Fitzwilliam have never seen before . Fitzwilliam can not catch those Fitzwilliam have never seen before tone of conversation , or appear interested in those Fitzwilliam have never seen before concerns , as Fitzwilliam often see done . ” 
 
  “ Cathleen daughter fingers , ” said Cathleen daughter , “ do not move over the instrument in the masterly manner which Cathleen daughter see so many women ’s do . Cathleen daughter fingers have not the same force or rapidity , and do not produce the same expression . But then Cathleen daughter have always supposed it to be Cathleen daughter own fault — because Cathleen daughter will not take the trouble of practising . It is not that Cathleen daughter do not believe Cathleen daughter fingers as capable as any other woman ’s of superior execution . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam smiled and said , “ Cathleen daughter are perfectly right . Cathleen daughter have employed Cathleen daughter time much better . No one admitted to the privilege of hearing Cathleen daughter can think anything wanting . We neither of We perform to strangers . ”

  “ Cathleen daughter would not play at all amiss if Cathleen daughter practised more , and could have the advantage of a London master . Cathleen daughter has a very good notion of fingering , though Cathleen daughter taste is not equal to Anne ’s . Anne would have been a delightful performer , had Anne health allowed Anne to learn . ”

 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth was sitting by Elizabeth the next morning , and writing to Jane while Mrs. Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village , when Elizabeth was startled by a ring at the door , the certain signal of a visitor . As Elizabeth had heard no carriage , Elizabeth thought a visitor not unlikely to be Cathleen , and under that apprehension was putting away Elizabeth half - finished letter that Elizabeth might escape all impertinent questions , when the door opened , and , to Elizabeth very great surprise , Fitzwilliam , and Fitzwilliam only , entered the room . 
 
  Fitzwilliam seemed astonished too on finding Elizabeth alone , and apologised for Fitzwilliam intrusion by letting Elizabeth know that Fitzwilliam had understood all the ladies were to be within . 
 
  They then sat down , and when Elizabeth enquiries after Rosings were made , seemed in danger of sinking into total silence . It was absolutely necessary , therefore , to think of something , and in this emergence recollecting when Elizabeth had seen Fitzwilliam last in Hertfordshire , and feeling curious to know what Fitzwilliam would say on the subject of their hasty departure , Elizabeth observed : 
 
  “ How very suddenly their quitted Netherfield last November , Fitzwilliam ! It must have been a most agreeable surprise to Charles to see their after Charles so soon ; for , if Elizabeth recollect right , Charles went but the day before . Charles and Charles sisters were well , Elizabeth hope , when Fitzwilliam left London ? ” 
 
  “ Perfectly so , Fitzwilliam thank Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Elizabeth found that Elizabeth was to receive no other answer , and , after a short pause added : 
 
  “ Elizabeth think Elizabeth have understood that Charles has not much idea of ever returning to Netherfield again ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam have never heard Charles say so ; but it is probable that Charles may spend very little of Charles time there in the future . Charles has many friends , and is at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually increasing . ” 
 
  “ If Charles means to be but little at Netherfield , it would be better for the neighbourhood that Charles should give up the place entirely , for then we might possibly get a settled family there . But , perhaps , Charles did not take the place so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as for Charles own , and we must expect Charles to keep the place or quit the place on the same principle . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam should not be surprised , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ if Charles were to give the place up as soon as any eligible purchase offers . ” 
 
  Elizabeth made no answer . Elizabeth was afraid of talking longer of Fitzwilliam friend ; and , having nothing else to say , was now determined to leave the trouble of finding a subject to Fitzwilliam . 
 
  Fitzwilliam took the hint , and soon began with , “ the place seems a very comfortable house . Cathleen , Elizabeth believe , did a great deal to the place when Charles first came to Hunsford . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth believe Cathleen did — and Elizabeth am sure Cathleen could not have bestowed Cathleen kindness on a more grateful object . ” 
 
  “ Charles appears to be very fortunate in Charles choice of a wife . ” 
 
  “ Yes , indeed , Charles friends may well rejoice in Charles having met with one of the very few sensible women who would have accepted Charles , or have made Charles happy if they had . Elizabeth has an excellent understanding — though Elizabeth am not certain that Elizabeth consider Elizabeth marrying Charles as the wisest thing Elizabeth ever did . Elizabeth seems perfectly happy , however , and in a prudential light it is certainly a very good match for Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ It must be very agreeable for Elizabeth to be settled within so easy a distance of Elizabeth own family and friends . ” 
 
  “ An easy distance , do Elizabeth call it ? It is nearly fifty miles . ” 
 
  “ And what is fifty miles of good road ? Little more than half a day ’s journey . Yes , Elizabeth call it a very easy distance . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth should never have considered the distance as one of the advantages of the match , ” cried Elizabeth . “ Elizabeth should never have said Elizabeth was settled near Elizabeth family . ” 
 
  “ the distance is a proof of Elizabeth own attachment to Hertfordshire . Anything beyond the very neighbourhood of Longbourn , Fitzwilliam suppose , would appear far . ” 
 
  As Fitzwilliam spoke there was a sort of smile which Elizabeth fancied Elizabeth understood ; Fitzwilliam must be supposing Elizabeth to be thinking of Jane and Netherfield , and Elizabeth blushed as Elizabeth answered : 
 
  “ Elizabeth do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near a woman family . The far and the near must be relative , and depend on many varying circumstances . Where there is fortune to make the expenses of travelling unimportant , distance becomes no evil . But that is not the case here . Charles and Charles sisters have a comfortable income , but not such a one as will allow of frequent journeys — and Fitzwilliam am persuaded Elizabeth would not call Elizabeth near Elizabeth family under less than half the present distance . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam drew Fitzwilliam chair a little towards Elizabeth , and said , “ Elizabeth can not have a right to such very strong local attachment . Elizabeth can not have been always at Longbourn . ” 
 
  Elizabeth looked surprised . Fitzwilliam experienced some change of feeling ; Fitzwilliam drew back Fitzwilliam chair , took a newspaper from the table , and glancing over a newspaper , said , in a colder voice : 
 
  “ Are Elizabeth pleased with Kent ? ” 
 
  A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued , on either side calm and concise — and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk . The tête - à - tête surprised Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk . Fitzwilliam related the mistake which had occasioned Fitzwilliam intruding on Elizabeth , and after sitting a few minutes longer without saying much to anybody , went away . 
 
  “ What can be the meaning of this ? ” said Charlotte , as soon as Fitzwilliam was gone . “ Charlotte dear , Elizabeth , Fitzwilliam must be in love with Elizabeth , or Fitzwilliam would never have called on us in this familiar way . ” 
 
  But when Elizabeth told of Fitzwilliam silence , it did not seem very likely , even to Charlotte ’s wishes , to be the case ; and after various conjectures , Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk could at last only suppose Fitzwilliam visit to proceed from the difficulty of finding anything to do , which was the more probable from the time of year . All field sports were over . Within doors there was Cathleen , books , and a billiard - table , but gentlemen can not always be within doors ; and in the nearness of the Parsonage , or the pleasantness of the walk to the Parsonage , or of the people who lived in the Parsonage , Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk found a temptation from this period of walking thither almost every day . Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk called at various times of the morning , sometimes separately , sometimes together , and now and then accompanied by Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk aunt . It was plain to Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk that Fitzwilliam came because Fitzwilliam had pleasure in Charlotte and Charlotte sister , just returned from Charlotte sister , just returned from walk society , a persuasion which of course recommended Fitzwilliam still more ; and Elizabeth was reminded by Elizabeth own satisfaction in being with Fitzwilliam , as well as by Fitzwilliam evident admiration of Elizabeth , of Elizabeth former favourite George ; and though , in comparing them , Elizabeth saw there was less captivating softness in Fitzwilliam manners , Elizabeth believed Fitzwilliam might have the best informed mind . 
 
  But why Fitzwilliam came so often to the Parsonage , it was more difficult to understand . came could not be for society , as Fitzwilliam frequently sat there ten minutes together without opening Fitzwilliam lips ; and when Fitzwilliam did speak , speak seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice — a sacrifice to propriety , not a pleasure to Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam seldom appeared really animated . Elizabeth knew not what to make of Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam occasionally laughing at Fitzwilliam stupidity , proved that Fitzwilliam was generally different , which Elizabeth own knowledge of Fitzwilliam could not have told Elizabeth ; and as Elizabeth would liked to have believed this change the effect of love , and the object of that love Elizabeth friend Elizabeth , Elizabeth set Elizabeth seriously to work to find it out . Elizabeth watched Fitzwilliam whenever they were at Rosings , and whenever Fitzwilliam came to Hunsford ; but without much success . Fitzwilliam certainly looked at Elizabeth friend a great deal , but the expression of looked was disputable . looked was an earnest , steadfast gaze , but Elizabeth often doubted whether there were much admiration in looked , and sometimes looked seemed nothing but absence of mind . 
 
  Elizabeth had once or twice suggested to Elizabeth the possibility of Fitzwilliam being partial to Elizabeth , but Elizabeth always laughed at the possibility of Fitzwilliam being partial to Elizabeth ; and Elizabeth did not think it right to press the subject , from the danger of raising expectations which might only end in disappointment ; for in Elizabeth opinion it admitted not of a doubt , that all Elizabeth friend ’s dislike would vanish , if Elizabeth could suppose Fitzwilliam to be in Elizabeth power . 
 
  In Elizabeth kind schemes for Elizabeth , Elizabeth sometimes planned Elizabeth marrying Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam was beyond comparison the most pleasant man ; Fitzwilliam certainly admired Elizabeth , and Fitzwilliam situation in life was most eligible ; but , to counterbalance these advantages , Fitzwilliam had considerable patronage in the church , and Fitzwilliam cousin could have none at all . 
 Chapter 
 
  More than once did Elizabeth , in Elizabeth ramble within the park , unexpectedly meet Fitzwilliam . Elizabeth felt all the perverseness of the mischance that should bring Fitzwilliam where no one else was brought , and , to prevent the mischance that should bring Fitzwilliam where no one else was brought ever happening again , took care to inform Fitzwilliam at first that it was a favourite haunt of Elizabeth . How the mischance that should bring Fitzwilliam where no one else was brought could occur a second time , therefore , was very odd ! Yet the mischance that should bring Fitzwilliam where no one else was brought did , and even a third . It seemed like wilful ill - nature , or a voluntary penance , for on these occasions it was not merely a few formal enquiries and an awkward pause and then away , but Fitzwilliam actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with Elizabeth . Fitzwilliam never said a great deal , nor did Elizabeth give Elizabeth the trouble of talking or of listening much ; but it struck Elizabeth in the course of their third rencontre that Fitzwilliam was asking some odd unconnected questions — about Elizabeth pleasure in being at Hunsford , Elizabeth love of solitary walks , and Elizabeth opinion of Mr. and Mrs. Collins ’s happiness ; and that in speaking of Rosings and Elizabeth not perfectly understanding the house , Fitzwilliam seemed to expect that whenever Elizabeth came into Kent again Elizabeth would be staying there too . Fitzwilliam words seemed to imply it . Could Fitzwilliam have Fitzwilam in Fitzwilliam thoughts ? Elizabeth supposed , if Fitzwilliam meant anything , Fitzwilliam must mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter . It distressed Elizabeth a little , and Elizabeth was quite glad to find Elizabeth at the gate in the pales opposite the Parsonage . 
 
  Elizabeth was engaged one day as Elizabeth walked , in perusing Jane ’s last letter , and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane ’s had not written in spirits , when , instead of being again surprised by Fitzwilliam , Elizabeth saw on looking up that Fitzwilliam was meeting Elizabeth . Putting away Jane ’s last letter immediately and forcing a smile , Elizabeth said : 
 
  “ Elizabeth did not know before that Fitzwilliam ever walked this way . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam have been making the tour of the park , ” Fitzwilliam replied , “ as Fitzwilliam generally do every year , and intend to close the tour of the park with a call at the Parsonage . Are Fitzwilliam going much farther ? ” 
 
  “ No , Fitzwilliam should have turned in a moment . ” 
 
  And accordingly Elizabeth did turn , and they walked towards the Parsonage together . 
 
  “ Do Fitzwilliam certainly leave Kent on Saturday ? ” said Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Yes — if Fitzwilliam does not put it off again . But Fitzwilliam am at Fitzwilliam disposal . Fitzwilliam arranges the business just as Fitzwilliam pleases . ” 
 
  “ And if not able to please Fitzwilliam in the arrangement , Fitzwilliam has at least pleasure in the great power of choice . Elizabeth do not know anybody who seems more to enjoy the power of doing what Fitzwilliam likes than Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam likes to have Fitzwilliam own way very well , ” replied Fitzwilliam . “ But so we all do . It is only that Fitzwilliam has better means of having Fitzwilliam own way than many others , because Fitzwilliam is rich , and many others are poor . Fitzwilliam speak feelingly . A younger son , you know , must be inured to self - denial and dependence . ” 
 
  “ In Fitzwilliam opinion , the younger son of an earl can know very little of either . Now seriously , what have Fitzwilliam ever known of self - denial and dependence ? When have Fitzwilliam been prevented by want of money from going wherever Fitzwilliam chose , or procuring anything Fitzwilliam had a fancy for ? ” 
 
  “ These are home questions — and perhaps Fitzwilliam can not say that Fitzwilliam have experienced many hardships of that nature . But in matters of greater weight , Fitzwilliam may suffer from want of money . Younger sons can not marry where Younger sons like . ” 
 
  “ Unless where Younger sons like women of fortune , which Fitzwilliam think Younger sons very often do . ” 
 
  “ Our habits of expense make Our too dependent , and there are not many in Fitzwilliam rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to money . ” 
 
  “ Is this , ” thought Elizabeth , “ meant for Elizabeth ? ” and Elizabeth coloured at the idea ; but , recovering Elizabeth , said in a lively tone , “ And pray , what is the usual price of an earl ’s younger son ? Unless the elder brother is very sickly , Elizabeth suppose Fitzwilliam would not ask above fifty thousand pounds . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam answered Elizabeth in the same style , and the subject dropped . To interrupt a silence which might make Fitzwilliam fancy Elizabeth affected with what had passed , Elizabeth soon afterwards said : 
 
  “ Elizabeth imagine Fitzwilliam cousin brought Fitzwilliam down with Fitzwilliam chiefly for the sake of having someone at Fitzwilliam disposal . Elizabeth wonder Fitzwilliam does not marry , to secure a lasting convenience of that kind . But , perhaps , Fitzwilliam sister does as well for the present , and , as Fitzwilliam sister is under Fitzwilliam sole care , Fitzwilliam may do what Fitzwilliam likes with Fitzwilliam sister . ” 
 
  “ No , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ that is an advantage which Fitzwilliam must divide with Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam am joined with Fitzwilliam in the guardianship of Georgiana . ” 
 
  “ Are Fitzwilliam indeed ? And pray what sort of guardians do Fitzwilliam make ? Does Fitzwilliam charge give Fitzwilliam much trouble ? Young ladies of Fitzwilliam charge age are sometimes a little difficult to manage , and if Fitzwilliam charge has the true Darcy spirit , Fitzwilliam charge may like to have Fitzwilliam charge own way . ” 
 
  As Elizabeth spoke Elizabeth observed Fitzwilliam looking at Elizabeth earnestly ; and the manner in which Fitzwilliam immediately asked Elizabeth why Elizabeth supposed Georgiana likely to give them any uneasiness , convinced Elizabeth that Elizabeth had somehow or other got pretty near the truth . Elizabeth directly replied : 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam need not be frightened . Elizabeth never heard any harm of Georgiana ; and Elizabeth dare say Georgiana is one of the most tractable creatures in the world . Georgiana is a very great favourite with some ladies of Elizabeth acquaintance , Mrs. Hurst and Caroline . Elizabeth think Elizabeth have heard Fitzwilliam say that Fitzwilliam know some ladies of Elizabeth acquaintance , Mrs. Hurst and Caroline . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam know some ladies of Elizabeth acquaintance , Mrs. Hurst and Caroline a little . some ladies of Elizabeth acquaintance , Mrs. Hurst and Caroline brother is a pleasant gentlemanlike man — some ladies of Elizabeth acquaintance , Mrs. Hurst and Caroline brother is a great friend of Fitzwilliam ’s . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! yes , ” said Elizabeth drily ; “ Fitzwilliam is uncommonly kind to Charles , and takes a prodigious deal of care of Charles . ” 
 
  “ Care of Charles ! Yes , Fitzwilliam really believe Fitzwilliam does take care of Charles in those points where Charles most wants care . From something that Fitzwilliam told Fitzwilliam in their journey hither , Fitzwilliam have reason to think Charles very much indebted to Fitzwilliam . But Fitzwilliam ought to beg Fitzwilliam pardon , for Fitzwilliam have no right to suppose that Charles was the person meant . It was all conjecture . ” 
 
  “ What is it Fitzwilliam mean ? ” 
 
  “ It is a circumstance which Fitzwilliam could not wish to be generally known , because if it were to get round to the lady ’s family , it would be an unpleasant thing . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth may depend upon Fitzwilliam not mentioning it . ” 
 
  “ And remember that Fitzwilliam have not much reason for supposing it to be Charles . What Fitzwilliam told Fitzwilliam was merely this : that Fitzwilliam congratulated Fitzwilliam on having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most imprudent marriage , but without mentioning names or any other particulars , and Fitzwilliam only suspected it to be Charles from believing Charles the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort , and from knowing them to have been together the whole of last summer . ” 
 
  “ Did Fitzwilliam give Fitzwilliam reasons for this interference ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam understood that there were some very strong objections against the lady ’s . ” 
 
  “ And what arts did Fitzwilliam use to separate them ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam did not talk to Fitzwilliam of Fitzwilliam own arts , ” said Fitzwilliam , smiling . “ Fitzwilliam only told Fitzwilliam what Fitzwilliam have now told Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Elizabeth made no answer , and walked on , Elizabeth heart swelling with indignation . After watching Elizabeth a little , Fitzwilliam asked Elizabeth why Elizabeth was so thoughtful . 
 
  “ Elizabeth am thinking of what Fitzwilliam have been telling Elizabeth , ” said Elizabeth . “ Fitzwilliam cousin ’s conduct does not suit Elizabeth feelings . Why was Fitzwilliam to be the judge ? ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth are rather disposed to call Fitzwilliam interference officious ? ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth do not see what right Fitzwilliam had to decide on the propriety of the lady ’s inclination , or why , upon Fitzwilliam own judgement alone , Fitzwilliam was to determine and direct in what manner the lady ’s was to be happy . But , ” Elizabeth continued , recollecting Elizabeth , “ as we know none of the particulars , it is not fair to condemn Fitzwilliam . It is not to be supposed that there was much affection in the case . ” 
 
  “ That is not an unnatural surmise , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ but That is a lessening of the honour of Fitzwilliam cousin ’s triumph very sadly . ” 
 
  This was spoken jestingly ; but it appeared to Elizabeth so just a picture of Fitzwilliam , that Elizabeth would not trust Elizabeth with an answer , and therefore , abruptly changing the conversation talked on indifferent matters until their reached the Parsonage . There , shut into Elizabeth own room , as soon as Fitzwilliam left their , Elizabeth could think without interruption of all that Elizabeth had heard . It was not to be supposed that any other people could be meant than those with whom Elizabeth was connected . There could not exist in the world two men over whom Fitzwilliam could have such boundless influence .
