  With such kinds of histories of their parties and good jokes , did Lydia , assisted by Kitty ’s hints and additions , endeavour to amuse Lydia companions all the way to Longbourn . Elizabeth listened as little as Elizabeth could , but there was no escaping the frequent mention of a certain person we all like name . 
 
  the three young ladies reception at home was most kind . Mother rejoiced to see Jane in undiminished beauty ; and more than once during dinner did Father ’s say voluntarily to Elizabeth : 
 
  “ Mother am glad Elizabeth are come back , Elizabeth . ” 
 
  the three young ladies party in the dining - room was large , for almost all the Lucases came to meet Maria and hear the news ; and various were the subjects that occupied the three young ladies : Lady Lucas was enquiring of Maria , after the welfare and poultry of Lady Lucas eldest daughter ; Mother was doubly engaged , on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from Jane , who sat some way below Mother , and , on the other , retailing them all to the younger Lucases ; and Lydia , in a voice rather louder than any other person ’s , was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who would hear Lydia . 
 
  “ Oh ! Mary , ” said Lydia , “ Lydia wish Mary had gone with Kitty and Elizabeth , for Kitty and Elizabeth had such fun ! As Kitty and Elizabeth went along , Kitty and Elizabeth drew up the blinds , and pretended there was nobody in Father ’s carriage ; and Lydia should have gone so all the way , if Kitty had not been sick ; and when Kitty and Elizabeth got to a certain person we all like , Lydia do think Kitty and Elizabeth behaved very handsomely , for Kitty and Elizabeth treated the other three with the nicest cold luncheon in the world , and if Mary would have gone , Kitty and Elizabeth would have treated Mary too . And then when Kitty and Elizabeth came away it was such fun ! Lydia thought Kitty and Elizabeth never should have got into Father ’s carriage . Lydia was ready to die of laughter . And then Kitty and Elizabeth were so merry all the way home ! Kitty and Elizabeth talked and laughed so loud , that anybody might have heard Kitty and Elizabeth ten miles off ! ” 
 
  To this Mary very gravely replied , “ Far be it from Mary , Lydia , to depreciate such pleasures ! such pleasures would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds . But Mary confess such pleasures would have no charms for Mary — Mary should infinitely prefer a book . ” 
 
  But of this answer Lydia heard not a word . Lydia seldom listened to anybody for more than half a minute , and never attended to Mary at all . 
 
  In the afternoon Lydia was urgent with the rest of the three young ladies to walk to Meryton , and to see how everybody went on ; but Elizabeth steadily opposed the scheme . It should not be said that the Miss Bennets could not be at home half a day before the Miss Bennets were in pursuit of the officers . There was another reason too for Elizabeth opposition . Elizabeth dreaded seeing Charlie again , and was resolved to avoid seeing as long as possible . The comfort to Elizabeth of the officers approaching removal was indeed beyond expression . In a fortnight the three young ladies were to go — and once gone , Elizabeth hoped there could be nothing more to plague Elizabeth on Charlie account . 
 
  Elizabeth had not been many hours at home before Elizabeth found that the Brighton scheme , of which Lydia had given them a hint at the appointed inn where Father ’s carriage was to meet the three young ladies , was under frequent discussion between Elizabeth parents . Elizabeth saw directly that Father ’s had not the smallest intention of yielding ; but Father ’s answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal , that Elizabeth mother , though often disheartened , had never yet despaired of succeeding at last . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth ’s impatience to acquaint Jane with what had happened could no longer be overcome ; and at length , resolving to suppress every particular in which Elizabeth ’s sister was concerned , and preparing Jane to be surprised , Elizabeth ’s related to Jane the next morning the chief of the scene between Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth ’s . 
 
  Jane astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly partiality which made any admiration of Elizabeth ’s appear perfectly natural ; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings . Jane was sorry that Fitzwilliam should have delivered Fitzwilliam sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend Fitzwilliam sentiments ; but still more was Jane grieved for the unhappiness which Jane sister ’s refusal must have given Fitzwilliam . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam being so sure of succeeding was wrong , ” said Jane , “ and certainly ought not to have appeared ; but consider how much Fitzwilliam being so sure of succeeding must increase Fitzwilliam disappointment ! ” 
 
  “ Indeed , ” replied Elizabeth ’s , “ Elizabeth ’s am heartily sorry for Fitzwilliam ; but Fitzwilliam has other feelings , which will probably soon drive away Fitzwilliam regard for Elizabeth ’s . Jane do not blame Elizabeth ’s , however , for refusing Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ Blame Elizabeth ’s ! Oh , no . ” 
 
  “ But Elizabeth ’s blame Elizabeth ’s for having spoken so warmly of George ? ” 
 
  “ No — Elizabeth ’s do not know that Elizabeth ’s were wrong in saying what Elizabeth ’s did . ” 
 
  “ But Jane will know it , when Elizabeth ’s tell Jane what happened the very next day . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s then spoke of the letter , repeating the whole of the letter contents as far as the letter contents concerned George . What a stroke was this for poor Jane ! who would willingly have gone through the world without believing that so much wickedness existed in the whole race of mankind , as was here collected in George . Nor was Fitzwilliam ’s vindication , though grateful to Jane feelings , capable of consoling Jane for such discovery . Most earnestly did Jane labour to prove the probability of error , and seek to clear the one without involving the other . 
 
  “ This will not do , ” said Elizabeth ’s ; “ Jane never will be able to make both of them good for anything . Take Jane choice , but Jane must be satisfied with only one . There is but such a quantity of merit between both of them ; just enough to make one good sort of man ; and of late it has been shifting about pretty much . For Elizabeth ’s part , Elizabeth ’s am inclined to believe it all Fitzwilliam ’s ; but Jane shall do as Jane choose . ” 
 
  It was some time , however , before a smile could be extorted from Jane . 
 
  “ Jane do not know when Jane have been more shocked , ” said Jane . “ George so very bad ! It is almost past belief . And poor Fitzwilliam ! Elizabeth ’s , only consider what Fitzwilliam must have suffered . Such a disappointment ! and with the knowledge of Elizabeth ’s ill opinion , too ! and having to relate such a thing of Jane ! It is really too distressing . Elizabeth ’s am sure Elizabeth ’s must feel it so . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! no , Elizabeth ’s regret and compassion are all done away by seeing Elizabeth ’s so full of both . Elizabeth ’s know Elizabeth ’s will do Fitzwilliam such ample justice , that Elizabeth ’s am growing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent . Elizabeth ’s profusion makes Elizabeth ’s saving ; and if Elizabeth ’s lament over Fitzwilliam much longer , Elizabeth ’s heart will be as light as a feather . ” 
 
  “ Poor George ! there is such an expression of goodness in George countenance ! such an openness and gentleness in George manner ! ” 
 
  “ There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of those two young men . One has got all the goodness , and the other all the appearance of all the goodness . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s never thought Fitzwilliam so deficient in the appearance of it as Elizabeth ’s used to do . ” 
 
  “ And yet Elizabeth ’s meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike to Fitzwilliam , without any reason . It is such a spur to one ’s genius , such an opening for wit , to have a dislike of that kind . One may be continually abusive without saying anything just ; but one can not always be laughing at a man without now and then stumbling on something witty . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s , when Elizabeth ’s first read the letter , Elizabeth ’s am sure Elizabeth ’s could not treat the matter as Elizabeth ’s do now . ” 
 
  “ Indeed , Elizabeth ’s could not . Elizabeth ’s was uncomfortable enough , Elizabeth ’s may say unhappy . And with no one to speak to about what Elizabeth ’s felt , no Jane to comfort Elizabeth ’s and say that Elizabeth ’s had not been so very weak and vain and nonsensical as Elizabeth ’s knew Elizabeth ’s had ! Oh ! how Elizabeth ’s wanted Elizabeth ’s ! ” 
 
  “ How unfortunate that Elizabeth ’s should have used such very strong expressions in speaking of George to Fitzwilliam , for now such very strong expressions do appear wholly undeserved . ” 
 
  “ Certainly . But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness is a most natural consequence of the prejudices Elizabeth ’s had been encouraging . There is one point on which Elizabeth ’s want Jane advice . Elizabeth ’s want to be told whether Elizabeth ’s ought , or ought not , to make our acquaintances in general understand George ’s character . ” Jane Jane paused a little , and then replied , “ Surely there can be no occasion for exposing George so dreadfully . What is Jane opinion ? ” 
 
  “ That exposing ought not to be attempted . Fitzwilliam has not authorised Jane to make Fitzwilliam communication public . On the contrary , every particular relative to Fitzwilliam sister was meant to be kept as much as possible to Jane ; and if Jane endeavour to undeceive people as to the rest of Fitzwilliam conduct , who will believe Jane ? The general prejudice against Fitzwilliam is so violent , that it would be the death of half the good people in Meryton to attempt to place Fitzwilliam in an amiable light . Jane am not equal to it . George will soon be gone ; and therefore it will not signify to anyone here what George really is . Some time hence it will be all found out , and then we may laugh at their stupidity in not knowing it before . At present Jane will say nothing about it . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s are quite right . To have George errors made public might ruin George for ever . George is now , perhaps , sorry for what George has done , and anxious to re - establish a character . We must not make George desperate . ” 
 
  The tumult of Elizabeth ’s mind was allayed by this conversation . Elizabeth ’s had got rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on Elizabeth ’s for a fortnight , and was certain of a willing listener in Jane , whenever Elizabeth ’s might wish to talk again of either . But there was still something lurking behind , of which prudence forbade the disclosure . Elizabeth ’s dared not relate the other half of the letter , nor explain to Jane how sincerely Elizabeth ’s had been valued by Elizabeth ’s friend . Here was knowledge in which no one could partake ; and Elizabeth ’s was sensible that nothing less than a perfect understanding between the parties could justify Elizabeth ’s in throwing off this last encumbrance of mystery . “ And then , ” said Elizabeth ’s , “ if that very improbable event should ever take place , Elizabeth ’s shall merely be able to tell what Charles may tell in a much more agreeable manner Charles . The liberty of communication can not be Elizabeth ’s till The liberty of communication has lost all The liberty of communication value ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s was now , on being settled at home , at leisure to observe the real state of Elizabeth ’s sister ’s spirits . Jane was not happy . Jane still cherished a very tender affection for Charles . Having never even fancied Jane in love before , Jane regard had all the warmth of first attachment , and , from Jane age and disposition , greater steadiness than most first attachments often boast ; and so fervently did Jane value Charles remembrance , and prefer Charles to every other man , that all Jane good sense , and all Jane attention to the feelings of Jane friends , were requisite to check the indulgence of those regrets which must have been injurious to Jane own health and Jane friends tranquillity . 
 
  “ Well , Elizabeth ’s , ” said prudence one day , “ what is Elizabeth ’s opinion now of this sad business of Jane ’s ? For prudence part , prudence am determined never to speak of this sad business of Jane ’s again to anybody . prudence told prudence sister Phillips so the other day . But prudence can not find out that Jane saw anything of Charles in London . Well , Charles is a very undeserving young man — and prudence do not suppose there ’s the least chance in the world of Jane ever getting Charles now . There is no talk of Charles coming to Netherfield again in the summer ; and prudence have enquired of everybody , too , who is likely to know . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s do not believe Charles will ever live at Netherfield any more . ” 
 
  “ Oh well ! it is just as Charles chooses . Nobody wants Charles to come . Though prudence shall always say Charles used prudence daughter extremely ill ; and if prudence was Jane , prudence would not have put up with used . Well , Elizabeth ’s comfort is , Elizabeth ’s am sure Jane will die of a broken heart ; and then Charles will be sorry for what Charles has done . ” 
 
  But as Elizabeth ’s could not receive comfort from any such expectation , Elizabeth ’s made no answer . 
 
  “ Well , Elizabeth ’s , ” continued Elizabeth ’s mother , soon afterwards , “ and so the Collinses live very comfortable , do the Collinses ? Well , well , Elizabeth ’s only hope it will last . And what sort of table do the Collinses keep ? Charlotte is an excellent manager , Elizabeth ’s dare say . If Charlotte is half as sharp as Charlotte mother , Charlotte is saving enough . There is nothing extravagant in the Collinses housekeeping , Elizabeth ’s dare say . ” 
 
  “ No , nothing at all . ” 
 
  “ A great deal of good management , depend upon nothing extravagant in the Collinses housekeeping . Yes , yes . the Collinses will take care not to outrun the Collinses income . the Collinses will never be distressed for money . Well , much good may it do the Collinses ! And so , Elizabeth ’s suppose , the Collinses often talk of having Longbourn when Elizabeth ’s father is dead . the Collinses look upon Longbourn as quite the Collinses own , Elizabeth ’s dare say , whenever that happens . ” 
 
  “ It was a subject which the Collinses could not mention before Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  “ No ; it would have been strange if the Collinses had ; but Elizabeth ’s make no doubt the Collinses often talk of it between the Collinses . Well , if the Collinses can be easy with an estate that is not lawfully the Collinses own , so much the better . Elizabeth ’s should be ashamed of having one that was only entailed on Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  The first week of the regiment ’s return was soon gone . The second began . The second was the last of the regiment ’s stay in Meryton , and all the young ladies in the neighbourhood were drooping apace . The dejection was almost universal . The elder Miss Bennets alone were still able to eat , drink , and sleep , and pursue the usual course of The elder Miss Bennets alone employments . Very frequently were The elder Miss Bennets alone reproached for this insensibility by Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family . 
 
  “ Good Heaven ! what is to become of Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family ? What are Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family to do ? ” would Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family often exclaim in the bitterness of woe . “ How can Elizabeth be smiling so , Elizabeth ? ” 
 
  Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother shared all Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family grief ; Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother remembered what Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother had Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother endured on a similar occasion , five - and - twenty years ago . 
 
  “ Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother am sure , ” said Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother , “ Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother cried for two days together when Colonel Miller ’s regiment went away . Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother thought Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother should have broken Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother heart . ” 
 
  “ Lydia am sure Lydia shall break Lydia , ” said Lydia . 
 
  “ If one could but go to Brighton ! ” observed Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother . 
 
  “ Oh , yes!—if one could but go to Brighton ! But papa is so disagreeable . ” 
 
  “ A little sea - bathing would set me up forever . ” 
 
  “ And me aunt Phillips is sure A little sea - bathing would do me a great deal of good , ” added Kitty . 
 
  Such were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through Longbourn House . Elizabeth tried to be diverted by the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through Longbourn House ; but all sense of pleasure was lost in shame . Elizabeth felt anew the justice of Fitzwilliam ’s objections ; and never had Elizabeth been so much disposed to pardon Fitzwilliam ’s interference in the views of Fitzwilliam ’s friend . 
 
  But the gloom of Lydia ’s prospect was shortly cleared away ; for Lydia received an invitation from Mrs. Forster , the wife of the colonel of the regiment ’s , to accompany Lydia to Brighton . Lydia was a very young woman , and very lately married . A resemblance in good humour and good spirits had recommended Lydia and Lydia to each other , and out of Lydia and Lydia three months ’ acquaintance Lydia and Lydia had been intimate two . 
 
  The rapture of Lydia on this occasion , Lydia adoration of Lydia , the delight of Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother , and the mortification of Kitty , are scarcely to be described . Wholly inattentive to Lydia sister ’s feelings , Lydia flew about Longbourn House in restless ecstasy , calling for everyone ’s congratulations , and laughing and talking with more violence than ever ; whilst the luckless Kitty continued in the parlour repining at Kitty fate in terms as unreasonable as Kitty accent was peevish . 
 
  “ Lydia can not see why Lydia should not ask Lydia as well as Lydia , ” said Lydia , “ Though Lydia am not Lydia particular friend . Lydia have just as much right to be asked as Lydia has , and more too , for Lydia am two years older . ” 
 
  In vain did Elizabeth attempt to make Lydia reasonable , and Jane to make Lydia resigned . As for Elizabeth herself , this invitation was so far from exciting in Elizabeth the same feelings as in Elizabeth mother and Lydia , that Elizabeth considered this invitation as the death warrant of all possibility of common sense for Lydia ; and detestable as such a step must make Elizabeth were it known , Elizabeth could not help secretly advising Elizabeth father not to let Elizabeth go . Elizabeth represented to Elizabeth father all the improprieties of Lydia ’s general behaviour , the little advantage Lydia could derive from the friendship of such a woman as Lydia , and the probability of Lydia being yet more imprudent with such a companion at Brighton , where the temptations must be greater than at home . Elizabeth father heard Elizabeth attentively , and then said : 
 
  “ Lydia will never be easy until Lydia has exposed Lydia in some public place or other , and we can never expect Lydia to do exposed with so little expense or inconvenience to Lydia family as under the present circumstances . ” 
 
  “ If Elizabeth father were aware , ” said Elizabeth , “ of the very great disadvantage to us all which must arise from the public notice of Lydia ’s unguarded and imprudent manner — nay , which has already arisen from it , Elizabeth am sure Elizabeth father would judge differently in the affair . ” 
 
  “ Already arisen ? ” repeated Elizabeth father . “ What , has Lydia frightened away some of Elizabeth lovers ? Poor little Elizabeth ! But do not be cast down . Such squeamish youths as can not bear to be connected with a little absurdity are not worth a regret . Come , let Elizabeth father see the list of pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by Lydia ’s folly . ” 
 
  “ Indeed Elizabeth are mistaken . Elizabeth father have no such injuries to resent . It is not of particular , but of general evils , which Elizabeth father am now complaining . Our importance , our respectability in the world must be affected by the wild volatility , the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark Lydia ’s character . Excuse Elizabeth , for Elizabeth must speak plainly . If Elizabeth father , Elizabeth father , will not take the trouble of checking Lydia exuberant spirits , and of teaching Lydia that Lydia present pursuits are not to be the business of Lydia life , Lydia will soon be beyond the reach of amendment . Lydia character will be fixed , and Lydia will , at sixteen , be the most determined flirt that ever made Lydia or Lydia family ridiculous ; a flirt , too , in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation ; without any attraction beyond youth and a tolerable person ; and , from the ignorance and emptiness of Lydia mind , wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which Lydia rage for admiration will excite . In this danger Kitty also is comprehended . Kitty will follow wherever Lydia leads . Lydia Oh ! Elizabeth father , can Elizabeth father suppose it possible that they will not be censured and despised wherever they are known , and that they sisters will not be often involved in the disgrace ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth father saw that Elizabeth whole heart was in the subject , and affectionately taking Elizabeth hand said in reply : 
 
  “ Do not make Elizabeth uneasy , Elizabeth . Wherever Elizabeth and Jane are known Elizabeth must be respected and valued ; and Elizabeth will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of — or Elizabeth father may say , three — very silly sisters . We shall have no peace at Longbourn House if Lydia does not go to Brighton . Let Lydia go , then . the colonel of the regiment ’s is a sensible man , and will keep Lydia out of any real mischief ; and Lydia is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to anybody . At Brighton Lydia will be of less importance even as a common flirt than Lydia has been here . The officers will find women better worth The officers notice . Let Our hope , therefore , that Lydia being there may teach Lydia Lydia own insignificance . At any rate , Lydia can not grow many degrees worse , without authorising Our to lock Lydia up for the rest of Lydia life . ” 
 
  With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content ; but Elizabeth own opinion continued the same , and Elizabeth left Elizabeth father disappointed and sorry . It was not in Elizabeth nature , however , to increase Elizabeth vexations by dwelling on Elizabeth vexations . Elizabeth was confident of having performed Elizabeth duty , and to fret over unavoidable evils , or augment unavoidable evils by anxiety , was no part of Elizabeth disposition . 
 
  Had Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother known the substance of Lydia conference with Lydia father , Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother indignation would hardly have found expression in Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother united volubility . In Lydia ’s imagination , a visit to Brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness . Lydia saw , with the creative eye of fancy , the streets of that gay bathing - place covered with officers . Lydia saw Lydia the object of attention , to tens and to scores of them at present unknown . Lydia saw all the glories of the camp — the camp tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines , crowded with the young and the gay , and dazzling with scarlet ; and , to complete the view , Lydia saw Lydia seated beneath a tent , tenderly flirting with at least six officers at once . 
 
  Had Lydia known Lydia sister sought to tear Lydia from such prospects and such realities as these , what would have been Lydia sensations ? Lydia sensations could have been understood only by Lydia mother , who might have felt nearly the same . Lydia ’s going to Brighton was all that consoled Lydia for Lydia melancholy conviction of Lydia husband ’s never intending to go there Lydia husband ’s . 
 
  But Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother were entirely ignorant of what had passed ; and Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother raptures continued , with little intermission , to the very day of Lydia ’s leaving home . 
 
  Elizabeth was now to see Charlie for the last time . Having been frequently in company with Charlie since Elizabeth return , agitation was pretty well over ; the agitations of former partiality entirely so . Elizabeth had even learnt to detect , in the very gentleness which had first delighted Elizabeth , an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary . In Charlie present behaviour to Elizabeth , moreover , Elizabeth had a fresh source of displeasure , for the inclination Charlie soon testified of renewing those intentions which had marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve , after what had since passed , to provoke Elizabeth . Elizabeth lost all concern for Charlie in finding Elizabeth thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry ; and while Elizabeth steadily repressed such idle and frivolous gallantry , could not but feel the reproof contained in Charlie believing , that however long , and for whatever cause , Charlie attentions had been withdrawn , Elizabeth vanity would be gratified , and Elizabeth preference secured at any time by Charlie attentions renewal . 
 
  On the very last day of the regiment ’s remaining at Meryton , Charlie dined , with others of the officers , at Longbourn House ; and so little was Elizabeth disposed to part from Charlie in good humour , that on Charlie making some enquiry as to the manner in which Elizabeth time had passed at Hunsford , Elizabeth mentioned Fitzwilam ’s and Fitzwilliam ’s having both spent three weeks at Rosings , and asked Charlie , if Charlie was acquainted with Fitzwilliam ’s . 
 
  Charlie looked surprised , displeased , alarmed ; but with a moment ’s recollection and a returning smile , replied , that Charlie had formerly seen Fitzwilliam ’s often ; and , after observing that Fitzwilliam ’s was a very gentlemanlike man , asked Elizabeth how Elizabeth had liked Fitzwilliam ’s . Elizabeth answer was warmly in Fitzwilliam ’s favour . With an air of indifference Charlie soon afterwards added : 
 
  “ How long did Elizabeth say Fitzwilliam ’s was at Rosings ? ” 
 
  “ Nearly three weeks . ” 
 
  “ And Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam ’s frequently ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , almost every day . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ’s manners are very different from Fitzwilliam ’s cousin ’s . ” 
 
  “ Yes , very different . But Elizabeth think Fitzwilliam ’s improves upon acquaintance . ” 
 
  “ Indeed ! ” cried Charlie with a look which did not escape Charlie . “ And pray , may Charlie ask ? — ” But checking Charlie , Charlie added , in a gayer tone , “ Is it in address that Fitzwilliam ’s improves ? Has Fitzwilliam ’s deigned to add aught of civility to Fitzwilliam ’s ordinary style?—for Charlie dare not hope , ” Charlie continued in a lower and more serious tone , “ that Fitzwilliam ’s is improved in essentials . ” 
 
  “ Oh , no ! ” said Elizabeth . “ In essentials , Elizabeth believe , Fitzwilliam ’s is very much what Fitzwilliam ’s ever was . ” 
 
  While Elizabeth spoke , Charlie looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over Elizabeth words , or to distrust Elizabeth words meaning . There was a something in Elizabeth countenance which made Charlie listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention , while Elizabeth added : 
 
  “ When Elizabeth said that Fitzwilliam ’s improved on acquaintance , Elizabeth did not mean that Fitzwilliam ’s mind or Fitzwilliam ’s manners were in a state of improvement , but that , from knowing Fitzwilliam ’s better , Fitzwilliam ’s disposition was better understood . ” 
 
  Charlie alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look ; for a few minutes Charlie was silent , till , shaking off Charlie embarrassment , Charlie turned to Elizabeth again , and said in the gentlest of accents : 
 
  “ Elizabeth , will readily comprehend how sincerely Charlie must rejoice that Fitzwilliam ’s is wise enough to assume even the appearance of what is right . Fitzwilliam ’s pride , in that direction , may be of service , if not to Fitzwilliam ’s , to many others , for Fitzwilliam ’s pride must only deter Fitzwilliam ’s from such foul misconduct as Charlie have suffered by . Charlie only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which Elizabeth , Charlie imagine , have been alluding , is merely adopted on Fitzwilliam ’s visits to Fitzwilliam ’s aunt , of whose good opinion and judgement Fitzwilliam ’s stands much in awe . Fitzwilliam ’s fear of Fitzwilliam ’s aunt , of whose good opinion and judgement Fitzwilliam ’s stands much in awe has always operated , Charlie know , when they were together ; and a good deal is to be imputed to Fitzwilliam ’s wish of forwarding the match with Cathleen , which Charlie am certain Fitzwilliam ’s has very much at heart . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could not repress a smile at this , but Elizabeth answered only by a slight inclination of the head . Elizabeth saw that Charlie wanted to engage Elizabeth on the old subject of Charlie grievances , and Elizabeth was in no humour to indulge Charlie . The rest of the evening passed with the appearance , on Charlie side , of usual cheerfulness , but with no further attempt to distinguish Elizabeth ; and Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother parted at last with mutual civility , and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again . 
 
  When the party broke up , Lydia returned with Lydia to Meryton , from whence they were to set out early the next morning . The separation between Lydia and Lydia family was rather noisy than pathetic . Kitty was the only one who shed tears ; but Kitty did weep from vexation and envy . Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother was diffuse in Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother good wishes for the felicity of Lydia , and impressive in Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother injunctions that Lydia should not miss the opportunity of enjoying Lydia as much as possible — advice which there was every reason to believe would be well attended to ; and in the clamorous happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell , the more gentle adieus of Lydia sisters were uttered without being heard . 
 Chapter 
 
  Had Elizabeth ’s opinion been all drawn from Elizabeth ’s own family , Elizabeth ’s could not have formed a very pleasing opinion of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort . Elizabeth ’s father , captivated by youth and beauty , and that appearance of good humour which youth and beauty generally give , had married a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for . Respect , esteem , and confidence had vanished for ever ; and all Elizabeth ’s father views of domestic happiness were overthrown . But Elizabeth ’s father was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which Elizabeth ’s father own imprudence had brought on , in any of those pleasures which too often console the unfortunate for the unfortunate folly or the unfortunate vice . Elizabeth ’s father was fond of the country and of books ; and from these tastes had arisen Elizabeth ’s father principal enjoyments . To Elizabeth ’s father wife Elizabeth ’s father was very little otherwise indebted , than as Elizabeth ’s father wife ignorance and folly had contributed to Elizabeth ’s father amusement . This is not the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to a man wife ; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting , the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given . 
 
  Elizabeth ’s , however , had never been blind to the impropriety of Elizabeth ’s father ’s behaviour as a husband . Elizabeth ’s had always seen Elizabeth ’s father ’s behaviour as a husband with pain ; but respecting Elizabeth ’s father abilities , and grateful for Elizabeth ’s father affectionate treatment of Elizabeth ’s , Elizabeth ’s endeavoured to forget what Elizabeth ’s could not overlook , and to banish from Elizabeth ’s thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which , in exposing Elizabeth ’s father wife to the contempt of Elizabeth ’s father wife own children , was so highly reprehensible . But Elizabeth ’s had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage , nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill - judged a direction of talents ; talents , which , rightly used , might at least have preserved the respectability of Elizabeth ’s father daughters , even if incapable of enlarging the mind of Elizabeth ’s father wife . 
 
  When Elizabeth ’s had rejoiced over George ’s departure Elizabeth ’s found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment . Their parties abroad were less varied than before , and at home Elizabeth ’s had a mother and sister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around a mother and sister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around threw a real gloom over a mother and sister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around domestic circle ; and , though Kitty might in time regain Kitty natural degree of sense , since the disturbers of Elizabeth ’s brain were removed , Elizabeth ’s other sister , from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended , was likely to be hardened in all Elizabeth ’s other sister , from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended folly and assurance by a situation of such double danger as a watering - place and a camp . Upon the whole , therefore , Elizabeth ’s found , what has been sometimes found before , that an event to which Elizabeth ’s had looked forward with impatient desire did not , in taking place , bring all the satisfaction Elizabeth ’s had promised Elizabeth ’s . It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity — to have some other point on which Elizabeth ’s wishes and hopes might be fixed , and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation , console Elizabeth ’s for the present , and prepare for another disappointment . Elizabeth ’s tour to the Lakes was now the object of Elizabeth ’s happiest thoughts ; Elizabeth ’s tour to the Lakes was Elizabeth ’s best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of Elizabeth ’s mother and Kitty made inevitable ; and could Elizabeth ’s have included Kitty in the scheme , every part of the scheme would have been perfect . 
 
  “ But it is fortunate , ” thought Elizabeth ’s , “ that Elizabeth ’s have something to wish for . Were the whole arrangement complete , Elizabeth ’s disappointment would be certain . But here , by carrying with Elizabeth ’s one ceaseless source of regret in Elizabeth ’s sister ’s absence , Elizabeth ’s may reasonably hope to have all Elizabeth ’s expectations of pleasure realised . A scheme of which every part promises delight can never be successful ; and general disappointment is only warded off by the defence of some little peculiar vexation . ” 
 
  When Elizabeth ’s went away Elizabeth ’s promised to write very often and very minutely to Elizabeth ’s mother and Kitty ; but Elizabeth ’s letters were always long expected , and always very short . Those to Elizabeth ’s father wife contained little else than that they were just returned from the library , where such and such officers had attended they , and where Elizabeth ’s had seen such beautiful ornaments as made Elizabeth ’s quite wild ; that Elizabeth ’s had a new gown , or a new parasol , which Elizabeth ’s would have described more fully , but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry , as Mrs. Forster called Elizabeth ’s , and they were going off to the camp ; and from Elizabeth ’s correspondence with Elizabeth ’s sister , there was still less to be learnt — for Elizabeth ’s letters to Kitty , though rather longer , were much too full of lines under the words to be made public . 
 
  After the first fortnight or three weeks of Elizabeth ’s absence , health , good humour , and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn . Everything wore a happier aspect . The families who had been in town for the winter came back again , and summer finery and summer engagements arose . Elizabeth ’s father wife was restored to Elizabeth ’s father wife usual querulous serenity ; and , by the middle of June , Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without tears ; an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth ’s hope that by the following Christmas Elizabeth ’s might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention an officer above once a day , unless , by some cruel and malicious arrangement at the War Office , another regiment should be quartered in Meryton . 
 
  The time fixed for the beginning of Edward and Madeline northern tour was now fast approaching , and a fortnight only was wanting of The time fixed for the beginning of Edward and Madeline northern tour , when a letter arrived from Madeline , which at once delayed Edward and Madeline northern tour commencement and curtailed Edward and Madeline northern tour extent . Edward would be prevented by business from setting out till a fortnight later in July , and must be in London again within a month , and as that left too short a period for Edward and Madeline to go so far , and see so much as Edward and Madeline had proposed , or at least to see it with the leisure and comfort Edward and Madeline had built on , Edward and Madeline were obliged to give up the Lakes , and substitute a more contracted tour , and , according to the present plan , were to go no farther northwards than Derbyshire . In Derbyshire there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of Edward and Madeline three weeks ; and to Madeline Madeline had a peculiarly strong attraction . Madeline , was probably as great an object of Elizabeth ’s curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock , Chatsworth , Dovedale , or the Peak . 
 
  Elizabeth ’s was excessively disappointed ; Elizabeth ’s had set Elizabeth ’s heart on seeing the Lakes , and still thought there might have been time enough . But it was Elizabeth ’s business to be satisfied — and certainly Elizabeth ’s temper to be happy ; and all was soon right again . 
 
  With the mention of Derbyshire there were many ideas connected . It was impossible for Elizabeth ’s to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and the word owner . “ But surely , ” said Elizabeth ’s , “ Elizabeth ’s may enter Derbyshire with impunity , and rob Derbyshire of a few petrified spars without the word owner perceiving Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  The period of expectation was now doubled . Four weeks were to pass away before Elizabeth ’s uncle and aunt ’s arrival . But Elizabeth ’s uncle and aunt ’s did pass away , and Edward and Madeline , with Edward and Madeline four children , did at length appear at Longbourn . Edward and Madeline four children , were to be left under the particular care of Edward and Madeline four children cousin Jane , who was the general favourite , and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted Kitty for attending to Edward and Madeline four children in every way — teaching Edward and Madeline four children , playing with Edward and Madeline four children , and loving Edward and Madeline four children . 
 
  Edward and Madeline stayed only one night at Longbourn , and set off the next morning with Elizabeth ’s in pursuit of novelty and amusement . One enjoyment was certain — that of suitableness of companions ; a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear inconveniences — cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure — and affection and intelligence , which might supply it among Edward and Madeline if there were disappointments abroad . 
 
  It is not the object of this work to give a description of Derbyshire , nor of any of the remarkable places through which Edward and Madeline route thither lay ; Oxford , Blenheim , Warwick , Kenilworth , Birmingham , etc . are sufficiently known . A small part of Derbyshire is all the present concern . To the little town of Lambton , the scene of Madeline ’s former residence , and where Madeline had lately learned some acquaintance still remained , Edward and Madeline bent Edward and Madeline steps , after having seen all the principal wonders of Derbyshire ; and within five miles of the little town of Lambton , the scene of Madeline ’s former residence , and where Madeline had lately learned some acquaintance still remained , Elizabeth ’s found from Madeline that Pemberley was situated . Pemberley was not in Edward and Madeline direct road , nor more than a mile or two out of Edward and Madeline direct road . In talking over Edward and Madeline route the evening before , Madeline expressed an inclination to see Pemberley again . Edward declared Edward willingness , and Elizabeth ’s was applied to for Elizabeth ’s approbation . 
 
  “ Madeline love , should not Elizabeth ’s like to see a place of which Elizabeth ’s have heard so much ? ” said Elizabeth ’s aunt ; “ a place , too , with which so many of Elizabeth ’s acquaintances are connected . George ’s passed all George ’s youth there , Elizabeth ’s know . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s was distressed . Elizabeth ’s felt that Elizabeth ’s had no business at Pemberley , and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing Pemberley . Elizabeth ’s must own that Elizabeth ’s was tired of seeing great houses ; after going over so many , Elizabeth ’s really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains . 
 
  Madeline abused Madeline stupidity . “ If Pemberley were merely a fine house richly furnished , ” said Madeline , “ Madeline should not care about Pemberley Madeline ; but the grounds are delightful . They have some of the finest woods in the country . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s said no more — but Elizabeth ’s mind could not acquiesce . The possibility of meeting Fitzwilliam , while viewing Pemberley , instantly occurred . meeting would be dreadful ! Elizabeth ’s blushed at The possibility of meeting Fitzwilliam , while viewing Pemberley , and thought it would be better to speak openly to Elizabeth ’s aunt than to run such a risk . But against this there were objections ; and Elizabeth ’s finally resolved that it could be the last resource , if Elizabeth ’s private enquiries to the absence of the family were unfavourably answered . 
 
  Accordingly , when Elizabeth ’s retired at night , Elizabeth ’s asked the chambermaid whether Pemberley were not a very fine place ? what was the name of Pemberley proprietor ? and , with no little alarm , whether the family were down for the summer ? A most welcome negative followed the last question — and Elizabeth ’s alarms now being removed , Elizabeth ’s was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see Pemberley Elizabeth ’s ; and when the subject was revived the next morning , and Elizabeth ’s was again applied to , could readily answer , and with a proper air of indifference , that Elizabeth ’s had not really any dislike to the scheme . To Pemberley , therefore , they were to go .

Pemberley House , situated on the opposite side of a valley , into which the road with some abruptness wound was a large , handsome stone building , standing well on rising ground , and backed by a ridge of high woody hills ; and in front , a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater , but without any artificial appearance . a stream of some natural importance banks were neither formal nor falsely adorned . Elizabeth was delighted . Elizabeth had never seen a place for which nature had done more , or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste . They were all of them warm in They admiration ; and at that moment Elizabeth felt that to be mistress of Pemberley might be something !

  Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant , encouraged Elizabeth communicativeness by Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant questions and remarks ; Mrs. Reynolds , either by pride or attachment , had evidently great pleasure in talking of Mrs. Reynolds master and Georgiana .

  smiled . Elizabeth could not help saying , “ It is very much to the housekeeper master credit , Elizabeth am sure , that Madeline should think so . ” 
 
  “ Madeline say no more than the truth , and everybody will say that knows the housekeeper master , ” replied Madeline . Elizabeth thought this was going pretty far ; and Elizabeth listened with increasing astonishment as the housekeeper added , “ the housekeeper have never known a cross word from the housekeeper master in the housekeeper life , and the housekeeper have known the housekeeper master ever since the housekeeper master was four years old . ” 
 
  This was praise , of all others most extraordinary , most opposite to Elizabeth ideas . That the housekeeper master was not a good - tempered man had been the housekeeper firmest opinion . Elizabeth keenest attention was awakened ; Elizabeth longed to hear more , and was grateful to Elizabeth uncle for saying : 
 
  “ There are very few people of whom so much can be said . Elizabeth are lucky in having the housekeeper master . ”

But Elizabeth have always observed , that they who are good - natured when children , are good - natured when they who are good - natured when children grow up ; and the housekeeper master was always the sweetest - tempered , most generous - hearted boy in the world . ”

  Elizabeth listened , wondered , doubted , and was impatient for more . Mrs. Reynolds could interest Elizabeth on no other point . Mrs. Reynolds related the subjects of the pictures , the dimensions of the rooms , and the price of the furniture , in vain . Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant , highly amused by the kind of family prejudice to which Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant attributed Mrs. Reynolds excessive commendation of Mrs. Reynolds master , soon led again to the subject ; and Mrs. Reynolds dwelt with energy on the housekeeper master many merits as 
 
  proceeded together up the great staircase . 
 
  “ the housekeeper master is the best landlord , and the best master , ” said Mrs. Reynolds , “ that ever lived ; not like the wild young men nowadays , who think of nothing but the wild young men nowadays , who think of nothing but . There is not one of the housekeeper master tenants or servants but will give the housekeeper master a good name . Some people call the housekeeper master proud ; but Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant am sure Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant never saw anything of it . To Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant fancy , it is only because the housekeeper master does not rattle away like other young men . ” 
 
  “ In what an amiable light does this place the housekeeper master ! ” thought Elizabeth .

  walked , “ is not quite consistent with the housekeeper master behaviour to the housekeeper master . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps 
 
  might be deceived . ”

Mrs. Reynolds Mrs. Reynolds anticipated Georgiana ’s delight , when Georgiana should enter a very pretty sitting - room , lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than the apartments below . “ And this is always the way with the housekeeper master , ” Mrs. Reynolds added . “ Whatever can give Georgiana any pleasure is sure to be done in a moment . There is nothing the housekeeper master would not do for Georgiana . ” 
 
  The picture - gallery , and two or three of the principal bedrooms , were all that remained to be shown . In The picture - gallery were many good paintings ; but Elizabeth knew nothing of the art ; and from such as had been already visible below , Elizabeth had willingly turned to look at some drawings of Georgiana ’s , in crayons , whose subjects were usually more interesting , and also more intelligible .

Elizabeth walked in quest of the only face whose features would be known to Elizabeth . The commendation bestowed on the housekeeper master by Mrs. Reynolds was of no trifling nature . What praise is more valuable than the praise of an intelligent servant ? As a brother , a landlord , a master , Elizabeth considered how many people ’s happiness were in the housekeeper master guardianship!—how much of pleasure or pain was it in the housekeeper master power to bestow!—how much of good or evil must be done by the housekeeper master ! Every idea that had been brought forward by the housekeeper was favourable to the housekeeper master character , and as Elizabeth stood before the canvas on which the housekeeper master was represented , and fixed the housekeeper master eyes upon Elizabeth , Elizabeth thought of the housekeeper master regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before ; Elizabeth remembered the housekeeper master regard warmth , and softened the housekeeper master regard impropriety of expression .

Nor did the housekeeper master seem much more at ease ; when the housekeeper master spoke , the housekeeper master accent had none of the housekeeper master accent usual sedateness ; and the housekeeper master repeated the housekeeper master enquiries as to the time of Elizabeth having left Longbourn , and of Elizabeth stay in Derbyshire , so often , and in so hurried a way , as plainly spoke the distraction of the housekeeper master thoughts .

Elizabeth was overpowered by shame and vexation . Elizabeth coming there was the most unfortunate , the most ill - judged thing in the world ! How strange it must appear to the housekeeper master ! In what a disgraceful light might it not strike so vain a man ! It might seem as if Elizabeth had purposely thrown Elizabeth in the housekeeper master way again ! Oh ! why did Elizabeth come ? Or , why did the housekeeper master thus come a day before the housekeeper master was expected ? Had they been only ten minutes sooner , they should have been beyond the reach of the housekeeper master discrimination ; for it was plain that the housekeeper master was that moment arrived — that moment alighted from the housekeeper master horse or the housekeeper master carriage . That the housekeeper master should even speak to Elizabeth was amazing!—but to speak with such civility , to enquire after Elizabeth family ! Never in Elizabeth life had Elizabeth seen the housekeeper master manners so little dignified , never had the housekeeper master spoken with such gentleness as on the meeting . What a contrast did it offer to the housekeeper master last address in Rosings Park , when the housekeeper master put the housekeeper master letter into Elizabeth hand !   , and entered into conversation with Edward , whose manners were very easy and pleasant . Elizabeth could not but be pleased , could not but triumph . I can now say with the housekeeper , that though some people may call the housekeeper master proud , I have seen nothing of it . ”

On the contrary , there is something pleasing about the housekeeper master mouth when the housekeeper master speaks . And there is something of dignity in the housekeeper master countenance that would not give one an unfavourable idea of the housekeeper master heart . In confirmation of this , Elizabeth related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which their had been connected , without actually naming Elizabeth authority , but stating Elizabeth authority to be such as might be relied on .

Fatigued as Elizabeth had been by the morning ’s walk 
 
  had no sooner dined than Elizabeth set off again in quest of Elizabeth former acquaintance , and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years ’ discontinuance . 
 
  The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth much attention for any of 
 
  ; and Elizabeth could do nothing but think , and think with wonder , of Fitzwilliam ’s civility , and , above all , of Fitzwilliam wishing Elizabeth to be acquainted with Fitzwilliam sister . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth had settled it that Fitzwilliam would bring Fitzwilliam sister to visit Elizabeth the very day after Elizabeth reaching Pemberley ; and was consequently resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning . But Elizabeth conclusion was false ; for on the very morning after these visitors arrival at Lambton , these visitors came . these visitors had been walking about the place with some of these visitors new friends , and were just returning to the inn to dress these visitors for dining with the same family , when the sound of a carriage drew these visitors to a window , and these visitors saw these visitors driving up the street . Elizabeth immediately recognizing the livery , guessed what the livery meant , and imparted no small degree of Elizabeth surprise to Elizabeth relations by acquainting Elizabeth relations with the honour which Elizabeth expected . Elizabeth uncle and aunt were all amazement ; and the embarrassment of Elizabeth manner as Elizabeth spoke , joined to the circumstance the circumstance , and many of the circumstances of the preceding day , opened to Elizabeth relations a new idea on the business . Nothing had ever suggested it before , but Elizabeth relations felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for Elizabeth . While these newly - born notions were passing in Elizabeth relations heads , the perturbation of Elizabeth ’s feelings was at every moment increasing . Elizabeth was quite amazed at Elizabeth own discomposure ; but amongst other causes of disquiet , Elizabeth dreaded lest the partiality of Fitzwilliam should have said too much in Elizabeth favour ; and , more than commonly anxious to please , Elizabeth naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail Elizabeth . 
 
  Elizabeth retreated from a window , fearful of being seen ; and as Elizabeth walked up and down the room , endeavouring to compose Elizabeth , saw such looks of enquiring surprise in Elizabeth relations as made everything worse . 
 
  Fitzwilliam sister and Fitzwilliam sister brother appeared , and this formidable introduction took place . With astonishment did Elizabeth see that Elizabeth new acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as Elizabeth . Since Fitzwilliam sister being at Lambton , Elizabeth had heard that Fitzwilliam sister was exceedingly proud ; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced Elizabeth that Fitzwilliam sister was only exceedingly shy . Elizabeth found it difficult to obtain even a word from Fitzwilliam sister beyond a monosyllable . 
 
  Fitzwilliam sister was tall , and on a larger scale than Elizabeth ; and , though little more than sixteen , Fitzwilliam sister figure was formed , and Fitzwilliam sister appearance womanly and graceful . Fitzwilliam sister was less handsome than Fitzwilliam ; but there was sense and good humour in Fitzwilliam sister face , and Fitzwilliam sister manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle . Elizabeth , who had expected to find in Elizabeth as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Fitzwilliam had been , was much relieved by discerning such different feelings . 
 
  They had not long been together before Fitzwilliam told Elizabeth that Charles was also coming to wait on Elizabeth ; and Elizabeth had barely time to express Elizabeth satisfaction , and prepare for such a visitor , when Charles ’s quick step was heard on the stairs , and in a moment Charles entered the room . All Elizabeth ’s anger against Charles had been long done away ; but had Elizabeth still felt any , All Elizabeth ’s anger against Charles could hardly have stood All Elizabeth ’s anger against Charles ground against the unaffected cordiality with which Charles expressed Charles on seeing Elizabeth again . Charles enquired in a friendly , though general way , after Elizabeth family , and looked and spoke with the same good - humoured ease that Charles had ever done . 
 
  To Edward and Madeline Charles was scarcely a less interesting personage than to Elizabeth . Edward and Madeline had long wished to see Charles . The whole party before them , indeed , excited a lively attention . The suspicions which had just arisen of Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth directed Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth observation towards each with an earnest though guarded enquiry ; and Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth soon drew from Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth observation the full conviction that one of Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth at least knew what it was to love . Of Elizabeth sensations Elizabeth sensations remained a little in doubt ; but that Charles was overflowing with admiration was evident enough . 
 
  Elizabeth , on Elizabeth side , had much to do . Elizabeth wanted to ascertain the feelings of each of Elizabeth visitors ; Elizabeth wanted to compose Elizabeth own , and to make Elizabeth agreeable to all ; and in the latter object , where Elizabeth feared most to fail , Elizabeth was most sure of success , for those to whom Elizabeth endeavoured to give pleasure were prepossessed in Elizabeth favour . Charles was ready , Fitzwilliam sister was eager , and Fitzwilliam determined , to be pleased . 
 
  In seeing Charles , Elizabeth thoughts naturally flew to Fitzwilliam sister ; and , oh ! how ardently did Elizabeth long to know whether any of Charles were directed in a like manner . Sometimes Elizabeth could fancy that Charles talked less than on former occasions , and once or twice pleased Elizabeth with the notion that , as Charles looked at Elizabeth , Charles was trying to trace a resemblance . But , though this might be imaginary , Elizabeth could not be deceived as to Charles behaviour to Fitzwilliam sister . No look appeared on either side that spoke particular regard . Nothing occurred between them that could justify the hopes of Charles sister . On this point Elizabeth was soon satisfied ; and two or three little circumstances occurred ere them parted , which , in Elizabeth anxious interpretation , denoted a recollection of Jane not untinctured by tenderness , and a wish of saying more that might lead to the mention of Jane , had Charles dared . Charles observed to Elizabeth , at a moment when the others were talking together , and in a tone which had something of real regret , that it “ was a very long time since Charles had had the pleasure of seeing Jane ; ” and , before Elizabeth could reply , Charles added , “ It is above eight months . We have not met since the 26th of November , when we were all dancing together at Netherfield . ” 
 
  Elizabeth was pleased to find Charles memory so exact ; and Charles afterwards took occasion to ask Elizabeth , when unattended to by any of the rest , whether all Elizabeth sisters were at Longbourn . There was not much in the question , nor in the preceding remark ; but there was a look and a manner which gave them meaning . 
 
  It was not often that Elizabeth could turn Elizabeth eyes on Fitzwilliam himself ; but , whenever Elizabeth did catch a glimpse , Elizabeth saw an expression of general complaisance , and in all that Fitzwilliam said Elizabeth heard an accent so removed from hauteur or disdain of Fitzwilliam companions , as convinced Elizabeth that the improvement of manners which Elizabeth had yesterday witnessed however temporary the improvement of manners which Elizabeth had yesterday witnessed however temporary existence might prove , had at least outlived one day . When Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam thus seeking the acquaintance and courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace — when Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam thus civil , not only to Elizabeth , but to the very relations whom Fitzwilliam had openly disdained , and recollected their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage — the difference , the change was so great , and struck so forcibly on Elizabeth mind , that Elizabeth could hardly restrain Elizabeth astonishment from being visible . Never , even in the company of Fitzwilliam dear friends at Netherfield , or Fitzwilliam dignified relations at Rosings , had Elizabeth seen Fitzwilliam so desirous to please , so free from self - consequence or unbending reserve , as now , when no importance could result from the success of Fitzwilliam endeavours , and when even the acquaintance of those to whom Fitzwilliam attentions were addressed would draw down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and Rosings . 
 
  Elizabeth visitors stayed with their above half - an - hour ; and when Elizabeth visitors arose to depart , Fitzwilliam called on Fitzwilliam sister to join Fitzwilliam in expressing their wish of seeing Edward and Madeline , and Miss Bennet , to dinner at Pemberley , before Edward and Madeline , and Miss Bennet left the country . Fitzwilliam sister , though with a diffidence which marked Fitzwilliam sister little in the habit of giving invitations , readily obeyed . Madeline looked at Elizabeth , desirous of knowing how Elizabeth , felt disposed as to the invitation acceptance , but Elizabeth had turned away Elizabeth head . Presuming however , that turned spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than any dislike of the invitation , and seeing in Elizabeth husband , who was fond of society , a perfect willingness to accept the invitation , Elizabeth ventured to engage for Elizabeth attendance , and the day after the next was fixed on . 
 
  Charles expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth again , having still a great deal to say to Elizabeth , and many enquiries to make after all their Hertfordshire friends . Elizabeth , construing all this into a wish of hearing Charles speak of Charles , was pleased , and on this account , as well as some others , found Elizabeth , when Elizabeth visitors left their , capable of considering the last half - hour with some satisfaction , though while the last half - hour was passing , the enjoyment of the last half - hour had been little . Eager to be alone , and fearful of enquiries or hints from Elizabeth relations , Elizabeth stayed with Elizabeth relations only long enough to hear Elizabeth relations favourable opinion of Charles , and then hurried away to dress . 
 
  But Elizabeth had no reason to fear Edward and Madeline ’s curiosity ; it was not Edward and Madeline wish to force Elizabeth communication . It was evident that Elizabeth was much better acquainted with Fitzwilliam than Edward and Madeline had before any idea of ; it was evident that Fitzwilliam was very much in love with Elizabeth . Edward and Madeline saw much to interest , but nothing to justify enquiry . 
 
  Of Fitzwilliam it was now a matter of anxiety to think well ; and , as far as Edward and Madeline acquaintance reached , there was no fault to find . Edward and Madeline could not be untouched by Fitzwilliam politeness ; and had Edward and Madeline drawn Fitzwilliam character from Edward and Madeline own feelings and Fitzwilliam servant ’s report , without any reference to any other account , the circle in Hertfordshire to which Fitzwilliam was known would not have recognized Fitzwilliam character for Fitzwilliam . There was now an interest , however , in believing Elizabeth ; and Edward and Madeline soon became sensible that the authority of a servant who had known Fitzwilliam since Fitzwilliam was four years old , and whose own manners indicated respectability , was not to be hastily rejected . Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of Edward and Madeline Lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight . Edward and Madeline had nothing to accuse Fitzwilliam of but pride ; pride Fitzwilliam probably had , and if not , it would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market - town where the same family did not visit . It was acknowledged , however , that Fitzwilliam was a liberal man , and did much good among the poor . 
 
  With respect to Fitzwilliam sister , Elizabeth visitors soon found that Fitzwilliam sister was not held there in much estimation ; for though the chief of Fitzwilliam sister concerns with the son of Fitzwilliam sister patron were imperfectly understood , it was yet a well - known fact that , on Fitzwilliam sister quitting Hertfordshire , Fitzwilliam sister had left many debts behind Fitzwilliam sister , which Fitzwilliam afterwards discharged . 
 
  As for Elizabeth , Elizabeth thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than the last ; and the evening , though as this evening passed this evening seemed long , was not long enough to determine Elizabeth feelings towards Fitzwilliam ; and Elizabeth lay awake two whole hours endeavouring to make Elizabeth feelings towards Fitzwilliam out . Elizabeth certainly did not hate Fitzwilliam . No ; hatred had vanished long ago , and Elizabeth had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against Fitzwilliam , that could be so called . The respect created by the conviction of Fitzwilliam valuable qualities , though at first unwillingly admitted , had for some time ceased to be repugnant to Elizabeth feeling ; and The respect created by the conviction of Fitzwilliam valuable qualities was now heightened into somewhat of a friendlier nature , by the testimony so highly in Fitzwilliam favour , and bringing forward Fitzwilliam disposition in so amiable a light , which yesterday had produced . But above all , above respect and esteem , there was a motive within Elizabeth of goodwill which could not be overlooked . a motive within Elizabeth of goodwill which could not be overlooked was gratitude ; gratitude , not merely for having once loved Elizabeth , but for loving Elizabeth still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of Elizabeth manner in rejecting Fitzwilliam , and all the unjust accusations accompanying Elizabeth rejection . Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam greatest enemy , seemed , on this accidental meeting , most eager to preserve the acquaintance , and without any indelicate display of regard , or any peculiarity of manner , where their two selves only were concerned , was soliciting the good opinion of Elizabeth friends , and bent on making Elizabeth known to Fitzwilliam sister . Such a change in a man of so much pride exciting not only astonishment but gratitude — for to love , ardent love , Such a change in a man of so much pride exciting not only astonishment but gratitude must be attributed ; and as such Such a change in a man of so much pride exciting not only astonishment but gratitude impression on Elizabeth was of a sort to be encouraged , as by no means unpleasing , though it could not be exactly defined . Elizabeth respected , Elizabeth esteemed , Elizabeth was grateful to Fitzwilliam , Elizabeth felt a real interest in Fitzwilliam welfare ; and Elizabeth only wanted to know how far Elizabeth wished Fitzwilliam welfare to depend upon Elizabeth , and how far it would be for the happiness of both that Elizabeth should employ the power , which Elizabeth fancy told Elizabeth Elizabeth still possessed , of bringing on Elizabeth the renewal of Fitzwilliam addresses . 
 
  It had been settled in the evening between Fitzwilliam sister and Elizabeth , that such a striking civility as Fitzwilliam sister in coming to see Fitzwilliam sister and Elizabeth on the very day of Fitzwilliam sister arrival at Pemberley , for Fitzwilliam sister had reached it only to a late breakfast , ought to be imitated , though it could not be equalled , by some exertion of politeness on Fitzwilliam sister and Elizabeth side ; and , consequently , that it would be highly expedient to wait on Fitzwilliam sister at Pemberley the following morning . They were , therefore , to go . Elizabeth was pleased ; though when Elizabeth asked Elizabeth the reason , Elizabeth had very little to say in reply . 
 
  Edward left their soon after breakfast . The fishing scheme had been renewed the day before , and a positive engagement made of Edward meeting some of the gentlemen at Pemberley before noon . 
 Chapter 
 
  Convinced as Elizabeth now was that Caroline ’s dislike of Elizabeth had originated in jealousy , Elizabeth could not help feeling how unwelcome Elizabeth appearance at Pemberley must be to Elizabeth , and was curious to know with how much civility on Elizabeth side the acquaintance would now be renewed . 
 
  On reaching the house , the whole party were shown through the hall into the saloon , whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer . the saloon , whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer windows opening to the ground , admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody hills behind the house , and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts which were scattered over the intermediate lawn . 
 
  In the house the whole party were received by Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London . Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London reception of the whole party was very civil , but attended with all the embarrassment which , though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong , would easily give to those who felt those who felt inferior the belief of Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London being proud and reserved . Madeline and Elizabeth , however , did Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London justice , and pitied Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London . 
 
  By Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s the whole party were noticed only by a curtsey ; and , on the whole party being seated , a pause , awkward as such pauses must always be , succeeded for a few moments . a pause , awkward as such pauses must always be was first broken by Mrs. Annesley , a genteel , agreeable - looking woman , whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved her to be more truly well - bred than either of the others ; and between her and Madeline , with occasional help from Elizabeth , the conversation was carried on . Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London looked as if Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London wished for courage enough to join in the conversation ; and sometimes did venture a short sentence when there was least danger of a short sentence being heard . 
 
  Elizabeth soon saw that Elizabeth was Elizabeth closely watched by Caroline ’s , and that Elizabeth could not speak a word , especially to Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London , without calling Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London attention . This observation would not have prevented Elizabeth from trying to talk to Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London , had they not been seated at an inconvenient distance ; but Elizabeth was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much . Elizabeth own thoughts were employing Elizabeth . Elizabeth expected every moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room . Elizabeth wished , Elizabeth feared that the master of the house might be amongst some of the gentlemen ; and whether Elizabeth wished or feared it most , Elizabeth could scarcely determine . After sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour without hearing Caroline ’s voice , Elizabeth was roused by receiving from Caroline ’s a cold enquiry after the health of Elizabeth family . Elizabeth answered with equal indifference and brevity , and the other said no more . 
 
  The next variation which the whole party visit afforded was produced by the entrance of servants with cold meat , cake , and a variety of all the finest fruits in season ; but the entrance of servants with cold meat , cake , and a variety of all the finest fruits in season did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London had been given , to remind Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London of Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London post . There was now employment for the whole party — for though the whole party could not all talk , the whole party could all eat ; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes , nectarines , and peaches soon collected the whole party round the table . 
 
  While thus engaged , Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether Elizabeth most feared or wished for the appearance of Fitzwilliam , by the feelings which prevailed on Fitzwilliam entering the room ; and then , though but a moment before Elizabeth had believed Elizabeth wishes to predominate , Elizabeth began to regret that Fitzwilliam came . 
 
  Fitzwilliam had been some time with Edward , who , with two or three other gentlemen from the house , was engaged by the river , and had left him only on learning that the ladies of Elizabeth family intended a visit to Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London that morning . No sooner did Fitzwilliam appear than Elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed ; a resolution the more necessary to be made , but perhaps not the more easily kept , because Elizabeth saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against the whole party , and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch Fitzwilliam behaviour when Fitzwilliam first came into the room . In no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in Caroline ’s , in spite of the smiles which overspread Caroline ’s face whenever Caroline ’s spoke to one of its objects ; for jealousy had not yet made Caroline ’s desperate , and Caroline ’s attentions to Fitzwilliam were by no means over . Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London , on Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London brother ’s entrance , exerted Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London much more to talk , and Elizabeth saw that Fitzwilliam was anxious for Caroline ’s and Elizabeth to get acquainted , and forwarded as much as possible , every attempt at conversation on either side . Caroline ’s saw all this likewise ; and , in the imprudence of anger , took the first opportunity of saying , with sneering civility : 
 
  “ Pray , Elizabeth , are not the — — shire Militia removed from Meryton ? the — — shire Militia must be a great loss to Elizabeth family . ” 
 
  In Fitzwilliam ’s presence Caroline ’s dared not mention George ’s name ; but Elizabeth instantly comprehended that George ’s was uppermost in Elizabeth thoughts ; and the various recollections connected with George ’s gave Elizabeth a moment ’s distress ; but exerting Elizabeth vigorously to repel the ill - natured attack , Elizabeth presently answered the question in a tolerably detached tone . While Elizabeth spoke , an involuntary glance showed Elizabeth Fitzwilliam , with a heightened complexion , earnestly looking at Elizabeth , and Fitzwilliam sister overcome with confusion , and unable to lift up Caroline ’s eyes . Had Caroline ’s known what pain Caroline ’s was then giving Caroline ’s beloved friend , Caroline ’s undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint ; but Caroline ’s had merely intended to discompose Elizabeth by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom Caroline ’s believed Elizabeth partial , to make Elizabeth betray a sensibility which might injure Elizabeth in Fitzwilliam ’s opinion , and , perhaps , to remind Elizabeth of all the follies and absurdities by which some part of Elizabeth family were connected with that corps .
