Not a syllable had ever reached Elizabeth of Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London meditated elopement . To no creature had Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London meditated elopement been revealed , where secrecy was possible , except to Elizabeth ; and from all Charles ’s connections Elizabeth brother was particularly anxious to conceal Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London meditated elopement , from the very wish which Elizabeth had long ago attributed to Fitzwilliam , of their becoming hereafter Elizabeth own . Fitzwilliam had certainly formed such a plan , and without meaning that such a plan should affect Fitzwilliam endeavour to separate Fitzwilliam from Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London , it is probable that such a plan might add something to Fitzwilliam lively concern for the welfare of Fitzwilliam friend . 
 
  Elizabeth ’s collected behaviour , however , soon quieted Fitzwilliam emotion ; and as Caroline ’s , vexed and disappointed , dared not approach nearer to George ’s , Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London also recovered in time , though not enough to be able to speak any more . Fitzwilliam scarcely recollected Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London interest in the affair , and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn Fitzwilliam thoughts from Elizabeth seemed to have fixed Fitzwilliam thoughts on Elizabeth more and more cheerfully . 
 
  Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned ; and while Fitzwilliam was attending their to their carriage Caroline ’s was venting Caroline ’s feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth ’s person , behaviour , and dress . But Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London would not join Caroline ’s . Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London brother ’s recommendation was enough to ensure Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London favour ; Fitzwilliam judgement could not err . And Fitzwilliam had spoken in such terms of Elizabeth as to leave Georgiana , who was sitting there with Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ’s , and the lady with whom she lived in London without the power of finding Elizabeth otherwise than lovely and amiable . When Fitzwilliam returned to the saloon , Caroline ’s could not help repeating to Fitzwilliam some part of what Caroline ’s had been saying to Caroline ’s . 
 
  “ How very ill Elizabeth looks that morning , Fitzwilliam , ” Caroline ’s cried ; “ Caroline ’s never in Caroline ’s life saw anyone so much altered as Elizabeth is since the winter . Elizabeth is grown so brown and coarse ! Louisa and Caroline ’s were agreeing that Louisa and Caroline ’s should not have known Elizabeth again . ” 
 
  However little Fitzwilliam might have liked such an address , Fitzwilliam contented Fitzwilliam with coolly replying that Fitzwilliam perceived no other alteration than Elizabeth being rather tanned , no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer . 
 
  “ For Caroline ’s own part , ” Caroline ’s rejoined , “ Caroline ’s must confess that Caroline ’s never could see any beauty in Elizabeth . Elizabeth face is too thin ; Elizabeth complexion has no brilliancy ; and Elizabeth features are not at all handsome . Elizabeth nose wants character — there is nothing marked in Elizabeth nose lines . Elizabeth teeth are tolerable , but not out of the common way ; and as for Elizabeth eyes , which have sometimes been called so fine , Caroline ’s could never see anything extraordinary in Elizabeth eyes , which have sometimes been called so fine . Elizabeth eyes , which have sometimes been called so fine have a sharp , shrewish look , which Caroline ’s do not like at all ; and in Elizabeth air altogether there is a self - sufficiency without fashion , which is intolerable . ” 
 
  Persuaded as Caroline ’s was that Fitzwilliam admired Elizabeth , admired was not the best method of recommending Elizabeth ; but angry people are not always wise ; and in seeing Fitzwilliam at last look somewhat nettled , Caroline ’s had all the success Caroline ’s expected . Fitzwilliam was resolutely silent , however , and , from a determination of making Fitzwilliam speak , Caroline ’s continued : 
 
  “ Caroline ’s remember , when we first knew Elizabeth in Hertfordshire , how amazed we all were to find that Elizabeth was a reputed beauty ; and Caroline ’s particularly recollect Fitzwilliam saying one night , after we had been dining at Netherfield , ‘ Elizabeth a beauty!—I should as soon call Caroline ’s a wit . ’ But afterwards Elizabeth seemed to improve on Fitzwilliam , and Caroline ’s believe Fitzwilliam thought Elizabeth rather pretty at one time . ” 
 
  “ Yes , ” replied Fitzwilliam , who could contain Fitzwilliam no longer , “ but that was only when Fitzwilliam first saw Elizabeth , for it is many months since Fitzwilliam have considered Elizabeth as one of the handsomest women of Fitzwilliam acquaintance . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam then went away , and Caroline ’s was left to all the satisfaction of having forced Fitzwilliam to say what gave no one any pain but Caroline ’s . 
 
  Madeline and Elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during Madeline and Elizabeth visit , as Madeline and Elizabeth returned , except what had particularly interested Madeline and Elizabeth . The look and behaviour of everybody Madeline and Elizabeth had seen were discussed , except of Fitzwilliam . Madeline and Elizabeth talked of Fitzwilliam sister , Fitzwilliam friends , Fitzwilliam house , Fitzwilliam fruit — of everything but Fitzwilliam ; yet Elizabeth was longing to know what Madeline thought of Fitzwilliam , and Madeline would have been highly gratified by Elizabeth beginning the subject . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from Jane on their first arrival at Lambton ; and this disappointment had been renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there ; but on the third Elizabeth repining was over , and Elizabeth sister justified , by the receipt of two letters from Jane at once , on one of which was marked that it had been missent elsewhere . Elizabeth was not surprised at marked , as Jane had written the direction remarkably ill . 
 
  their had just been preparing to walk as two letters from Jane at once came in ; and Elizabeth uncle and aunt , leaving Elizabeth to enjoy two letters from Jane at once in quiet , set off by Elizabeth uncle and aunt . The one missent must first be attended to ; missent had been written five days ago . The beginning contained an account of all their little parties and engagements , with such news as the country afforded ; but the latter half , which was dated a day later , and written in evident agitation , gave more important intelligence . the latter half , which was dated a day later , and written in evident agitation was to this effect : 
 
  “ Since writing the above , dearest Elizabeth , something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature ; but I am afraid of alarming Elizabeth — be assured that we are all well . What I have to say relates to poor Lydia . An express came at twelve last night , just as we were all gone to bed , from Colonel Forster , to inform we that poor Lydia was gone off to Scotland with one of Colonel Forster officers ; to own the truth , with George ! Imagine we surprise . To Kitty , however , it does not seem so wholly unexpected . I am very , very sorry . So imprudent a match on both sides ! But I am willing to hope the best , and that George character has been misunderstood . Thoughtless and indiscreet I can easily believe George , but this step ( and let we rejoice over this step ) marks nothing bad at heart . George choice is disinterested at least , for George must know I father can give poor Lydia nothing . Our poor mother is sadly grieved . I father bears it better . How thankful am I that Our never let George and our poor Lydia know what has been said against George ; Our must forget it ourselves . George and our poor Lydia were off Saturday night about twelve , as is conjectured , but were not missed till yesterday morning at eight . An express was sent off directly . I dear Elizabeth , George and our poor Lydia must have passed within ten miles of we . Colonel Forster gives we reason to expect George here soon . poor Lydia left a few lines for George wife , informing George wife of George and our poor Lydia intention . I must conclude , for I can not be long from I poor mother . I am afraid Elizabeth will not be able to make it out , but I hardly know what I have written . ” 
 
  Without allowing Elizabeth time for consideration , and scarcely knowing what Elizabeth felt , Elizabeth on finishing this letter instantly seized the other , and opening the other with the utmost impatience , read as follows : this letter had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first . 
 
  “ By this time , Elizabeth , Elizabeth have received I hurried letter ; I wish this letter may be more intelligible , but though not confined for time , I head is so bewildered that I can not answer for being coherent . Dearest Elizabeth , I hardly know what I would write , but I have bad news for Elizabeth , and bad news can not be delayed . Imprudent as the marriage between George and our poor Lydia would be , we are now anxious to be assured the marriage between George and our poor Lydia has taken place , for there is but too much reason to fear George and our poor Lydia are not gone to Scotland . Colonel Forster came yesterday , having left Brighton the day before , not many hours after An express . Though poor Lydia short letter to George wife gave them to understand that George and our poor Lydia were going to Gretna Green , something was dropped by Denny expressing Denny belief that George never intended to go there , or to marry poor Lydia at all , which was repeated to Colonel Forster . Colonel Forster did trace George and our poor Lydia easily to Clapham , but no further ; for on entering Clapham , George and our poor Lydia removed into a hackney coach , and dismissed the chaise that brought George and our poor Lydia from Epsom . All that is known after this is , that George and our poor Lydia were seen to continue the London road . I know not what to think . After making every possible enquiry on that side London , Colonel Forster came on into Hertfordshire , anxiously renewing them at all the turnpikes , and at the inns in Barnet and Hatfield , but without any success — no such people had been seen to pass through . With the kindest concern Colonel Forster came on to Longbourn , and broke Colonel Forster apprehensions to us in a manner most creditable to Colonel Forster heart . I am sincerely grieved for George and our poor Lydia , but no one can throw any blame on George and our poor Lydia . Our distress , I dear Elizabeth , is very great . I father and mother believe the worst , but I can not think so ill of George . Many circumstances might make it more eligible for George and our poor Lydia to be married privately in town than to pursue George and our poor Lydia first plan ; and even if George could form such a design against a young woman of poor Lydia connections , which is not likely , can I suppose a young woman of poor Lydia connections , which is not likely so lost to everything ? Impossible ! I grieve to find , however , that Colonel Forster is not disposed to depend upon George and our poor Lydia marriage ; Colonel Forster shook Colonel Forster head when I expressed I hopes , and said Colonel Forster feared George was not a man to be trusted . Our poor mother is really ill , and keeps Our poor mother room . Could Our poor mother exert Our poor mother , it would be better ; but exert is not to be expected . And as to I father , I never in I life saw I father so affected . Poor Kitty has anger for having concealed George and our poor Lydia attachment ; but as it was a matter of confidence , one can not wonder . I am truly glad , dearest Elizabeth , that Elizabeth have been spared something of these distressing scenes ; but now , as the first shock is over , shall I own that I long for Elizabeth return ? I am not so selfish , however , as to press for Elizabeth return , if inconvenient . Adieu ! I take up I pen again to do what I have just told Elizabeth I would not ; but circumstances are such that I can not help earnestly begging Elizabeth to come here as soon as possible . I know I dear uncle and aunt so well , that I am not afraid of requesting it , though I have still something more to ask of the former . I father is going to London with Colonel Forster instantly , to try to discover poor Lydia . What I father means to do I am sure I know not ; but I father excessive distress will not allow I father to pursue any measure in the best and safest way , and Colonel Forster is obliged to be at Brighton again to - morrow evening . In such an exigence , I uncle ’s advice and assistance would be everything in the world ; I dear uncle will immediately comprehend what I must feel , and I rely upon I dear uncle goodness . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! where , where is I dear uncle ? ” cried Elizabeth , darting from Elizabeth seat as Elizabeth finished the letter , in eagerness to follow I dear uncle , without losing a moment of the time so precious ; but as Elizabeth reached the door the door was opened by a servant , and Fitzwilliam appeared . Elizabeth pale face and impetuous manner made Fitzwilliam start , and before Fitzwilliam could recover Fitzwilliam to speak , Elizabeth , hastily exclaimed , “ Elizabeth beg Fitzwilliam pardon , but Elizabeth must leave Fitzwilliam . Elizabeth must find Edward this moment , on business that can not be delayed ; Elizabeth have not an instant to lose . ” 
 
  “ Good God ! what is the matter ? ” cried Fitzwilliam , with more feeling than politeness ; then recollecting Fitzwilliam , “ Fitzwilliam will not detain Elizabeth a minute ; but let Fitzwilliam , or let a servant go after George and our poor Lydia . Elizabeth are not well enough ; Elizabeth can not go Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Elizabeth hesitated , but Elizabeth knees trembled under Elizabeth and Elizabeth felt how little would be gained by Elizabeth attempting to pursue George and our poor Lydia . Calling back a servant , therefore , Elizabeth commissioned a servant , though in so breathless an accent as made Elizabeth almost unintelligible , to fetch George and our poor Lydia home instantly . 
 
  On a servant quitting the room Elizabeth sat down , unable to support Elizabeth , and looking so miserably ill , that it was impossible for Fitzwilliam to leave Elizabeth , or to refrain from saying , in a tone of gentleness and commiseration , “ Let Fitzwilliam call Elizabeth maid . Is there nothing Elizabeth could take to give Elizabeth present relief ? A glass of wine ; shall Fitzwilliam get Elizabeth one ? Elizabeth are very ill . ” 
 
  “ No , Elizabeth thank Fitzwilliam , ” Elizabeth replied , endeavouring to recover Elizabeth . “ There is nothing the matter with Elizabeth . Elizabeth am quite well ; Elizabeth am only distressed by some dreadful news which Elizabeth have just received from Longbourn . ” 
 
  Elizabeth burst into tears as Elizabeth alluded to some dreadful news which Elizabeth have just received from Longbourn , and for a few minutes could not speak another word . Fitzwilliam , in wretched suspense , could only say something indistinctly of Fitzwilliam concern , and observe Elizabeth in compassionate silence . At length Elizabeth spoke again . “ Elizabeth have just had a letter from Jane , with such dreadful news . such dreadful news can not be concealed from anyone . poor Lydia has left all poor Lydia friends — has eloped ; has thrown poor Lydia into the power of — of George . They are gone off together from Brighton . Fitzwilliam know George too well to doubt the rest . poor Lydia has no money , no connections , nothing that can tempt George to — poor Lydia is lost for ever . ” Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam was fixed in astonishment . “ When Elizabeth consider , ” Elizabeth added in a yet more agitated voice , “ that Elizabeth might have prevented it ! I who knew what George was . Had Elizabeth but explained some part of it only — some part of what Elizabeth learnt , to Elizabeth own family ! Had George character been known , this could not have happened . But it is all — all too late now . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam am grieved indeed , ” cried Fitzwilliam ; “ grieved — shocked . But is it certain — absolutely certain ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , yes ! George and our poor Lydia left Brighton together on last night , and were traced almost to London , but not beyond ; George and our poor Lydia are certainly not gone to Scotland . ” 
 
  “ And what has been done , what has been attempted , to recover poor Lydia ? ” 
 
  “ I father is gone to London , and Jane has written to beg I dear uncle immediate assistance ; and we shall be off , Elizabeth hope , in half - an - hour . But nothing can be done — Elizabeth know very well that nothing can be done . How is such a man to be worked on ? How are such a man even to be discovered ? I have not the smallest hope . It is every way horrible ! ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam shook Fitzwilliam head in silent acquiescence . 
 
  “ When Elizabeth eyes were opened to George character — Oh ! had Elizabeth known what Elizabeth ought , what Elizabeth dared to do ! But Elizabeth knew not — Elizabeth was afraid of doing too much . Wretched , wretched mistake ! ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam made no answer . Fitzwilliam seemed scarcely to hear Elizabeth , and was walking up and down the room in earnest meditation , Fitzwilliam brow contracted , Fitzwilliam air gloomy . Elizabeth soon observed , and instantly understood it . Elizabeth power was sinking ; everything must sink under such a proof of family weakness , such an assurance of the deepest disgrace . Elizabeth could neither wonder nor condemn , but the belief of George self - conquest brought nothing consolatory to Elizabeth bosom , afforded no palliation of Elizabeth distress . the belief of George self - conquest was , on the contrary , exactly calculated to make Elizabeth understand Elizabeth own wishes ; and never had Elizabeth so honestly felt that Elizabeth could have loved George , as now , when all love must be vain . 
 
  But self , though self would intrude , could not engross Elizabeth . poor Lydia — the humiliation , the misery Elizabeth was bringing on them all , soon swallowed up every private care ; and covering Elizabeth face with Elizabeth handkerchief , Elizabeth was soon lost to everything else ; and , after a pause of several minutes , was only recalled to a sense of Elizabeth situation by the voice of Elizabeth companion , who , in a manner which , though it spoke compassion , spoke likewise restraint , said , “ I am afraid Elizabeth have been long desiring I absence , nor have I anything to plead in excuse of I stay , but real , though unavailing concern . Would to Heaven that anything could be either said or done on I part that might offer consolation to such distress ! But I will not torment Elizabeth with vain wishes , which may seem purposely to ask for Elizabeth thanks . This unfortunate affair will , I fear , prevent I sister ’s having the pleasure of seeing Elizabeth at Pemberley to - day . ” 
 
  “ Oh , yes . Be so kind as to apologise for us to Georgiana . Say that urgent business calls us home immediately . Conceal the unhappy truth as long as it is possible , Elizabeth know it can not be long . ” 
 
  I readily assured Elizabeth of his secrecy ; again expressed his sorrow for Elizabeth distress , wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present reason to hope , and leaving his compliments for Elizabeth relations , with only one serious , parting look , went away . 
 
  As I quitted the room , Elizabeth felt how improbable it was that George and our poor Lydia should ever see each other again on such terms of cordiality as had marked George and our poor Lydia several meetings in Hertfordshire ; and as Elizabeth threw a retrospective glance over the whole of George and our poor Lydia acquaintance , so full of contradictions and varieties , sighed at the perverseness of those feelings which would now have promoted George and our poor Lydia acquaintance , so full of contradictions and varieties continuance , and would formerly have rejoiced in George and our poor Lydia acquaintance , so full of contradictions and varieties termination . 
 
  If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection , Elizabeth ’s change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty . But if otherwise — if regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or unnatural , in comparison of what is so often described as arising on a first interview with its object , and even before two words have been exchanged , nothing can be said in Elizabeth defence , except that Elizabeth had given somewhat of a trial to the latter method in Elizabeth partiality for George , and that the latter method ill success might , perhaps , authorise Elizabeth to seek the other less interesting mode of attachment . Be that as it may , Elizabeth saw George go with regret ; and in this early example of what poor Lydia infamy must produce , found additional anguish as poor Lydia reflected on that wretched business . Never , since reading Jane ’s second letter , had poor Lydia entertained a hope of George ’s meaning to marry poor Lydia . No one but Jane , poor Lydia thought , could flatter Jane with such an expectation . Surprise was the least of poor Lydia feelings on this development . While the contents of the first letter remained in poor Lydia mind , poor Lydia was all surprise — all astonishment that George should marry a girl whom it was impossible George could marry for money ; and how poor Lydia could ever have attached George had appeared incomprehensible . But now it was all too natural . For such an attachment as this Jane might have sufficient charms ; and though Jane did not suppose poor Lydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement without the intention of marriage , Jane had no difficulty in believing that neither poor Lydia virtue nor poor Lydia understanding would preserve poor Lydia from falling an easy prey . 
 
  Jane had never perceived , while the regiment was in Hertfordshire , that poor Lydia had any partiality for George ; but Jane was convinced that poor Lydia wanted only encouragement to attach poor Lydia to anybody . Sometimes one officer , sometimes another , had been poor Lydia favourite , as their attentions raised their in poor Lydia opinion . poor Lydia affections had continually been fluctuating but never without an object . The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards such a girl — oh ! how acutely did poor Lydia now feel The mischief of neglect and mistaken indulgence towards such a girl ! 
 
  poor Lydia was wild to be at home — to hear , to see , to be upon the spot to share with Jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon poor Lydia , in a family so deranged , a father absent , Our poor mother incapable of exertion , and requiring constant attendance ; and though almost persuaded that nothing could be done for poor Lydia , poor Lydia uncle ’s interference seemed of the utmost importance , and till I dear uncle entered the room poor Lydia impatience was severe . George and our poor Lydia had hurried back in alarm , supposing by a servant account that George and our poor Lydia niece was taken suddenly ill ; but satisfying George and our poor Lydia instantly on that head , poor Lydia eagerly communicated the cause of George and our poor Lydia summons , reading two letters from Jane at once aloud , and dwelling on the postscript of the last with trembling energy . — Though poor Lydia had never been a favourite with George and our poor Lydia , George and our poor Lydia could not but be deeply afflicted . Not poor Lydia , but all were concerned in it ; and after the first exclamations of surprise and horror , Edward promised every assistance in Edward power . Elizabeth , though expecting no less , thanked Edward with tears of gratitude ; and George and our poor Lydia being actuated by one spirit , everything relating to George and our poor Lydia journey was speedily settled . George and our poor Lydia were to be off as soon as possible . “ But what is to be done about Pemberley ? ” cried Madeline . “ John told George and our poor Lydia Fitzwilliam was here when Elizabeth sent for George and our poor Lydia ; was it so ? ” 
 
  “ Yes ; and Elizabeth told John George and our poor Lydia should not be able to keep George and our poor Lydia engagement . That is all settled . ” 
 
  “ That is all settled ; ” repeated Elizabeth , as Elizabeth ran into Elizabeth room to prepare . “ And are they upon such terms as for poor Lydia to disclose the real truth ? Oh , that Elizabeth knew how it was ! ” 
 
  But wishes were vain , or at least could only serve to amuse Elizabeth in the hurry and confusion of the following hour . Had Elizabeth been at leisure to be idle , Elizabeth would have remained certain that all employment was impossible to one so wretched as Elizabeth ; but Elizabeth had Elizabeth share of business as well as Elizabeth aunt , and amongst the rest there were notes to be written to all their friends at Lambton , with false excuses for George and our poor Lydia sudden departure . An hour , however , saw the whole completed ; and Edward meanwhile having settled Edward account at the inn , nothing remained to be done but to go ; and Elizabeth , after all the misery of yesterday morning , found Elizabeth , in a shorter space of time than Elizabeth could have supposed , seated in the carriage , and on the road to Longbourn . 
 Chapter 
 
  “ Elizabeth uncle have been thinking it over again , Elizabeth , ” said Elizabeth uncle , as they drove from the town ; “ and really , upon serious consideration , Elizabeth uncle am much more inclined than Elizabeth uncle was to judge as Elizabeth eldest sister does on the matter . It appears to Elizabeth uncle so very unlikely that any young man should form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or friendless , and who was actually staying in any young man colonel ’s family , that Elizabeth uncle am strongly inclined to hope the best . Could any young man expect that Elizabeth eldest sister friends would not step forward ? Could any young man expect to be noticed again by the regiment , after such an affront to Colonel Forster ? any young man temptation is not adequate to the risk ! ” 
 
  “ Do Elizabeth uncle really think so ? ” cried Elizabeth , brightening up for a moment . 
 
  “ Upon Elizabeth uncle word , ” said Elizabeth uncle , “ Elizabeth uncle begin to be of Elizabeth uncle ’s opinion . It is really too great a violation of decency , honour , and interest , for any young man to be guilty of . Elizabeth uncle can not think so very ill of any young man . Can you Elizabeth , Elizabeth , so wholly give any young man up , as to believe any young man capable of it ? ” 
 
  “ Not , perhaps , of neglecting any young man own interest ; but of every other neglect Elizabeth can believe any young man capable . If , indeed , it should be so ! But Elizabeth dare not hope it . Why should the fugitives not go on to Scotland if that had been the case ? ” 
 
  “ In the first place , ” replied Elizabeth uncle , “ there is no absolute proof that the fugitives are not gone to Scotland . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! but the fugitives removing from the chaise into a hackney coach is such a presumption ! And , besides , no traces of the fugitives were to be found on the Barnet road . ” 
 
  “ Well , then — supposing the fugitives to be in London . the fugitives may be there , though for the purpose of concealment , for no more exceptional purpose . It is not likely that money should be very abundant on either side ; and it might strike the fugitives that the fugitives could be more economically , though less expeditiously , married in London than in Scotland . ” 
 
  “ But why all this secrecy ? Why any fear of detection ? Why must the fugitives marriage be private ? Oh , no , no — be is not likely . any young man most particular friend , you see by Jane ’s account , was persuaded of any young man never intending to marry Jane ’s . any young man will never marry a woman without some money . any young man can not afford some money . And what claims has Lydia — what attraction has Lydia beyond youth , health , and good humour that could make any young man , for Lydia sake , forego every chance of benefiting any young man by marrying well ? As to what restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a dishonourable elopement with Lydia , Elizabeth uncle am not able to judge ; for Elizabeth uncle know nothing of the effects that such a step might produce . But as to Elizabeth other objection , Elizabeth am afraid Elizabeth other objection will hardly hold good . Lydia has no brothers to step forward ; and any young man might imagine , from Elizabeth father ’s behaviour , from Elizabeth father ’s indolence and the little attention Elizabeth father ’s has ever seemed to give to what was going forward in Elizabeth father ’s family , that Elizabeth father ’s would do as little , and think as little about it , as any father could do , in such a matter . ” 
 
  “ But can Elizabeth think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of any young man as to consent to live with any young man on any terms other than marriage ? ” 
 
  “ It does seem , and it is most shocking indeed , ” replied Elizabeth , with tears in Elizabeth eyes , “ that a sister ’s sense of decency and virtue in such a point should admit of doubt . But , really , Elizabeth know not what to say . Perhaps Elizabeth am not doing Lydia justice . But Lydia is very young ; Lydia has never been taught to think on serious subjects ; and for the last half - year , nay , for a twelvemonth — Lydia has been given up to nothing but amusement and vanity . Lydia has been allowed to dispose of Lydia time in the most idle and frivolous manner , and to adopt any opinions that came in Lydia way . Since the — — shire were first quartered in Meryton , nothing but love , flirtation , and officers have been in Lydia head . Lydia has been doing everything in Lydia power by thinking and talking on the subject , to give greater — what shall Elizabeth call it ? susceptibility to Lydia feelings ; which are naturally lively enough . And we all know that any young man has every charm of person and address that can captivate a woman . ” 
 
  “ But Elizabeth see that Jane ’s , ” said Elizabeth aunt , “ does not think so very ill of any young man as to believe any young man capable of the attempt . ” 
 
  “ Of whom does Jane ’s ever think ill ? And who is there , whatever might be the fugitives former conduct , that Jane ’s would think capable of such an attempt , till the fugitives former conduct were proved against the fugitives ? But Jane ’s knows , as well as Elizabeth do , what any young man really is . We both know that any young man has been profligate in every sense of the word ; that any young man has neither integrity nor honour ; that any young man is as false and deceitful as any young man is insinuating . ” 
 
  “ And do Elizabeth really know all this ? ” cried Elizabeth uncle . 
 
  “ Elizabeth do indeed , ” replied Elizabeth , colouring . “ Elizabeth told Elizabeth uncle , the other day , of any young man infamous behaviour to Fitzwilliam ; and Elizabeth uncle Elizabeth uncle , when last at Longbourn , heard in what manner any young man spoke of Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam . And there are other circumstances which Elizabeth am not at liberty — which it is not worth while to relate ; but any young man lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless . From what any young man said of Georgiana Elizabeth was thoroughly prepared to see a proud , reserved , disagreeable girl . Yet any young man knew to the contrary any young man . any young man must know that Georgiana was as amiable and unpretending as we have found Georgiana . ” 
 
  “ But does Lydia know nothing of this ? can Lydia be ignorant of what Elizabeth and Jane ’s seem so well to understand ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , yes!—that , be is the worst of all . Till Elizabeth was in Kent , and saw so much both of Fitzwilliam and Fitzwilliam relation Fitzwilam , Elizabeth was ignorant of the truth Elizabeth . And when Elizabeth returned home , the — — shire was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight ’s time . As that was the case , neither Jane ’s , nor Elizabeth , thought it necessary to make Elizabeth and Jane ’s knowledge public ; for of what use could it apparently be to any one , that the good opinion which all the neighbourhood had of any young man should then be overthrown ? And even when it was settled that Lydia should go with Colonel Forster , the necessity of opening Lydia eyes to any young man character never occurred to Elizabeth . That Lydia could be in any danger from the deception never entered Elizabeth head . That such a consequence as this could ensue , Elizabeth uncle may easily believe , was far enough from Elizabeth thoughts . ” 
 
  “ When they all removed to Brighton , therefore , Elizabeth had no reason , Elizabeth uncle suppose , to believe they all fond of each other ? ” 
 
  “ Not the slightest . Elizabeth can remember no symptom of affection on either side ; and had anything of the kind been perceptible , Elizabeth uncle must be aware that ours is not a family on which anything of the kind could be thrown away . When first any young man entered the corps , Elizabeth eldest sister was ready enough to admire any young man ; but so we all were . Every girl in or near any young man was out of Every girl in or near any young man senses about any young man for the first two months ; but any young man never distinguished Every girl in or near any young man by any particular attention ; and , consequently , after a moderate period of extravagant and wild admiration , Every girl in or near any young man fancy for any young man gave way , and others of the regiment , who treated Every girl in or near any young man with more distinction , again became Every girl in or near any young man favourites . ” 
 
  It may be easily believed , that however little of novelty could be added to the fugitives fears , hopes , and conjectures , on the subject , by its repeated discussion , no other could detain the fugitives from the subject long , during the whole of the journey . From Elizabeth ’s thoughts it was never absent . Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish , self - reproach , Elizabeth could find no interval of ease or forgetfulness . 
 
  They travelled as expeditiously as possible , and , sleeping one night on the road , reached Longbourn by dinner time the next day . It was a comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane ’s could not have been wearied by long expectations . 
 
  The little Gardiners , attracted by the sight of a chaise , were standing on the steps of the house as The little Gardiners entered the paddock ; and , when the carriage drove up to the door , the joyful surprise that lighted up The little Gardiners faces , and displayed itself over The little Gardiners whole bodies , in a variety of capers and frisks , was the first pleasing earnest of The little Gardiners welcome . 
 
  Elizabeth jumped out ; and , after giving each of The little Gardiners a hasty kiss , hurried into the vestibule , where Jane ’s Jane ’s mother ’s apartment , immediately met Elizabeth . 
 
  Elizabeth , as Elizabeth affectionately embraced Jane ’s , whilst tears filled the eyes of Elizabeth and Jane ’s , lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been heard of the fugitives . 
 
  “ Not yet , ” replied Jane ’s . “ But now that Jane ’s dear uncle is come , Jane ’s hope everything will be well . ” 
 
  “ Is Elizabeth father ’s in town ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , Elizabeth father ’s went on Tuesday , as Elizabeth uncle wrote Elizabeth uncle word . ” 
 
  “ And have Elizabeth heard from Elizabeth father ’s often ? ” 
 
  “ We have heard only twice . Elizabeth father ’s wrote Elizabeth a few lines on Wednesday to say that Elizabeth father ’s had arrived in safety , and to give Elizabeth Elizabeth father ’s directions , which Elizabeth particularly begged Elizabeth father ’s to do . Elizabeth father ’s merely added that Elizabeth father ’s should not write again till Elizabeth father ’s had something of importance to mention . ” 
 
  “ And Jane ’s mother — how is Elizabeth eldest sister ? How are Elizabeth all ? ” 
 
  “ Jane ’s mother is tolerably well , Elizabeth uncle trust ; though Elizabeth eldest sister spirits are greatly shaken . Elizabeth eldest sister is up stairs and will have great satisfaction in seeing the others . Elizabeth eldest sister does not yet leave Elizabeth eldest sister dressing - room . Mary and Kitty , thank Heaven , are quite well . ” 
 
  “ But Jane ’s — how are Jane ’s ? ” cried Elizabeth . “ Jane ’s look pale . How much Jane ’s must have gone through ! ” Elizabeth eldest sister Elizabeth sister , however , assured Elizabeth of Elizabeth eldest sister being perfectly well ; and their conversation , which had been passing while Elizabeth uncle and Elizabeth uncle were engaged with Elizabeth uncle and Elizabeth uncle children , was now put an end to by the approach of the whole party . Jane ’s ran to Jane ’s uncle and aunt , and welcomed and thanked Jane ’s uncle and aunt , with alternate smiles and tears . 
 
  When the whole party were all in the drawing - room , the questions which Elizabeth had already asked were of course repeated by the others , and the others soon found that Jane ’s had no intelligence to give . The sanguine hope of good , however , which the benevolence of Jane ’s heart suggested had not yet deserted Jane ’s ; Jane ’s still expected that it would all end well , and that every morning would bring some letter , either from Lydia or Elizabeth father ’s , to explain their proceedings , and , perhaps , announce their marriage . 
 
  Mother , to whose apartment the whole party repaired , after a few minutes ’ conversation together , received the whole party exactly as might be expected ; with tears and lamentations of regret , invectives against the villainous conduct of any young man , and complaints of Mother , to whose apartment the whole party repaired , after a few minutes ’ conversation together , own sufferings and ill - usage ; blaming everybody but any young man . 
 
  “ If Elizabeth had been able , ” said Elizabeth , “ to carry Elizabeth point in going to Brighton , with all Elizabeth family , this would not have happened ; but poor dear Lydia had nobody to take care of Lydia . Why did the Forsters ever let Lydia go out of the Forsters sight ? Elizabeth uncle am sure there was some great neglect or other on the Forsters side , for Lydia is not the kind of girl to do such a thing if Lydia had been well looked after . Elizabeth always thought the Forsters were very unfit to have the charge of Lydia ; but Elizabeth was overruled , as Elizabeth always am . Lydia ! And now here ’s Elizabeth father ’s gone away , and Elizabeth know any young man will fight any young man , wherever any young man meets any young man and then any young man will be killed , and what is to become of us all ? The Collinses will turn Elizabeth and Jane ’s out before any young man is cold in any young man grave , and if Elizabeth uncle are not kind to Elizabeth and Jane ’s , Elizabeth uncle , Elizabeth do not know what Elizabeth and Jane ’s shall do . ” 
 
  the whole party exclaimed against such terrific ideas ; and Elizabeth uncle , after general assurances of Elizabeth uncle affection for Lydia and all Lydia family , told Lydia that Elizabeth uncle meant to be in London the very next day , and would assist Elizabeth father ’s in every endeavour for recovering Lydia . 
 
  “ Do not give way to useless alarm , ” added Elizabeth uncle ; “ though it is right to be prepared for the worst , there is no occasion to look on it as certain . It is not quite a week since the fugitives left Brighton . In a few days more we may gain some news of the fugitives ; and till we know that the fugitives are not married , and have no design of marrying , do not let we give the matter over as lost . As soon as Elizabeth uncle get to town Elizabeth uncle shall go to any young man , and make any young man come home with Elizabeth uncle to Gracechurch Street ; and then we may consult together as to what is to be done . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Elizabeth uncle , ” replied Lydia , “ that is exactly what Lydia could most wish for . And now do , when Elizabeth uncle get to town , find the fugitives out , wherever the fugitives may be ; and if the fugitives are not married already , make the fugitives marry . And as for wedding clothes , do not let the fugitives wait for wedding clothes , but tell Lydia Lydia shall have as much money as Lydia chooses to buy wedding clothes , after the fugitives are married . And , above all , keep Elizabeth father ’s from fighting . Tell Elizabeth father ’s what a dreadful state Elizabeth am in , that Elizabeth am frighted out of Elizabeth wits — and have such tremblings , such flutterings , all over Elizabeth — such spasms in Elizabeth side and pains in Elizabeth head , and such beatings at heart , that Elizabeth can get no rest by night nor by day . And tell Elizabeth dear Lydia not to give any directions about Lydia clothes till Lydia has seen Elizabeth uncle , for Lydia does not know which are the best warehouses . Oh , Elizabeth uncle , how kind Elizabeth uncle are ! Elizabeth know Elizabeth uncle will contrive it all . ” 
 
  But Elizabeth uncle , though Elizabeth uncle assured Lydia again of Elizabeth uncle earnest endeavours in the cause , could not avoid recommending moderation to Lydia , as well in Lydia hopes as Lydia fear ; and after talking with Lydia in this manner till dinner was on the table , the whole party left Lydia to vent all Lydia feelings on the housekeeper , who attended in the absence of the housekeeper , who attended in the absence of daughters . 
 
  Though Lydia brother and sister were persuaded that there was no real occasion for such a seclusion from any young man colonel ’s family , Lydia brother and sister did not attempt to oppose such a seclusion , for Lydia brother and sister knew that Lydia had not prudence enough to hold Lydia tongue before the servants , while Lydia brother and sister waited at table , and judged it better that one only of any young man colonel ’s family , and the one whom Lydia brother and sister could most trust should comprehend all Lydia fears and solicitude on the subject . 
 
  In the dining - room they were soon joined by Mary and Kitty , who had been too busily engaged in Mary and Kitty , who had been too busily engaged in separate apartments to make Mary and Kitty , who had been too busily engaged in appearance before . One came from One books , and the other from Kitty toilette . The faces of Mary and Kitty , who had been too busily engaged in , however , were tolerably calm ; and no change was visible in either , except that the loss of Elizabeth eldest sister , or the anger which Kitty had Kitty incurred in this business , had given more of fretfulness than usual to the accents of Kitty . As for Mary , Mary was mistress enough of Mary to whisper to Elizabeth , with a countenance of grave reflection , soon after they were seated at table : 
 
  “ This is a most unfortunate affair , and will probably be much talked of . But we must stem the tide of malice , and pour into the wounded bosoms of each other the balm of sisterly consolation . ” 
 
  Then , perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying , Mary added , “ Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia , we may draw from the event this useful lesson : that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable ; that one false step involves a female in endless ruin ; that a female reputation is no less brittle than a female reputation is beautiful ; and that a female can not be too much guarded in a female behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex . ” 
 
  Elizabeth lifted up Elizabeth eyes in amazement , but was too much oppressed to make any reply . Mary , however , continued to console Mary with such kind of moral extractions from the evil before them . 
 
  In the afternoon , Elizabeth uncle and Elizabeth uncle were able to be for half - an - hour by Elizabeth uncle and Elizabeth uncle ; and Elizabeth instantly availed Elizabeth of the opportunity of making many enquiries , which Jane ’s was equally eager to satisfy . After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel of this event , which Elizabeth considered as all but certain , and Miss Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible , Jane ’s continued the subject , by saying , “ But tell Elizabeth uncle all and everything about this event which Elizabeth uncle have not already heard . Give Elizabeth uncle further particulars . What did Colonel Forster say ? Had the fugitives no apprehension of anything before the fugitives marriage took place ? the fugitives must have seen the fugitives together for ever . ” 
 
  “ Colonel Forster did own that Colonel Forster had often suspected some partiality , especially on Lydia ’s side , but nothing to give Colonel Forster any alarm . Elizabeth am so grieved for Colonel Forster ! Colonel Forster behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost . Colonel Forster was coming to us , in order to assure us of Colonel Forster concern , before Colonel Forster had any idea of the fugitives not being gone to Scotland : when any idea of the fugitives not being gone to Scotland first got abroad , any idea of the fugitives not being gone to Scotland hastened Colonel Forster journey . ” 
 
  “ And was Denny convinced that any young man would not marry ? Did Denny know of the fugitives intending to go off ? Had Colonel Forster seen Denny Denny ? ” 
 
  “ Yes ; but , when questioned by Denny , Denny denied knowing anything of the fugitives plans , and would not give Denny real opinion about the fugitives plans . Denny did not repeat Denny persuasion of the fugitives not marrying — and from that , Elizabeth am inclined to hope , Denny might have been misunderstood before . ” 
 
  “ And till Colonel Forster came Colonel Forster , not one of the others entertained a doubt , Elizabeth uncle suppose , of the fugitives being really married ? ” 
 
  “ How was it possible that such an idea should enter Elizabeth and Jane ’s brains ? Elizabeth felt a little uneasy — a little fearful of Lydia happiness with any young man in marriage , because Elizabeth knew that any young man conduct had not been always quite right . Elizabeth father and mother knew nothing of knew ; Elizabeth father and mother only felt how imprudent a match it must be . Elizabeth then owned , with a very natural triumph on knowing more than the rest of Elizabeth and Jane ’s , that in Lydia ’s last letter Lydia had prepared Lydia for such a step . Lydia had known , it seems , of the fugitives being in love with each other , many weeks . ” 
 
  “ But not before the fugitives went to Brighton ? ” 
 
  “ No , Elizabeth believe not . ” 
 
  “ And did Colonel Forster appear to think well of any young man any young man ? Does Colonel Forster know any young man real character ? ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth must confess that Colonel Forster did not speak so well of any young man as Colonel Forster formerly did . Colonel Forster believed any young man to be imprudent and extravagant . And since this sad affair has taken place , it is said that any young man left Meryton greatly in debt ; but Elizabeth hope left may be false . ” 
 
  “ Oh , Jane ’s , had we been less secret , had we told what we knew of any young man , this could not have happened ! ” 
 
  “ Perhaps it would have been better , ” replied Jane ’s . “ But to expose the former faults of any person without knowing what any person present feelings were , seemed unjustifiable . We acted with the best intentions . ” 
 
  “ Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia ’s note to Elizabeth eldest sister ? ” 
 
  “ Colonel Forster brought Lydia ’s note to Elizabeth eldest sister with Colonel Forster for us to see . ” 
 
  Jane ’s then took Lydia ’s note to Elizabeth eldest sister from Jane ’s pocket - book , and gave Lydia ’s note to Elizabeth eldest sister to Elizabeth . These were the contents : 
 
  “ Lydia dear Harriet , 
  “ Lydia dear Harriet will laugh when Lydia dear Harriet know where Lydia am gone , and Lydia can not help laughing Lydia at Lydia dear Harriet surprise to - morrow morning , as soon as Lydia am missed . Lydia am going to Gretna Green , and if Lydia dear Harriet can not guess with who , Lydia shall think Lydia dear Harriet a simpleton , for there is but one man in the world Lydia love , and but one man in the world Lydia love is an angel . Lydia should never be happy without but one man in the world Lydia love , so think it no harm to be off . Lydia dear Harriet need not send them word at Longbourn of Lydia going , if Lydia dear Harriet do not like word at Longbourn of Lydia going , for it will make the surprise the greater , when Lydia write to them and sign Lydia name ‘ Lydia . ’ What a good joke it will be ! Lydia can hardly write for laughing . Pray make Lydia excuses to Pratt for not keeping Lydia engagement , and dancing with Pratt to - night . Tell Pratt Lydia hope Pratt will excuse Lydia when Pratt knows all ; and tell Pratt Lydia will dance with Pratt at the next ball we meet , with great pleasure . Lydia shall send for Lydia clothes when Lydia get to Longbourn ; but Lydia wish Lydia dear Harriet would tell Sally to mend a great slit in Lydia worked muslin gown before Lydia clothes are packed up . Good - bye . Give Lydia love to Colonel Forster . Lydia hope Elizabeth uncle will drink to they good journey . 
 
  “ Elizabeth affectionate friend , 
  “ LYDIA BENNET . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! thoughtless , thoughtless Lydia ! ” cried Elizabeth when Elizabeth had finished Lydia ’s note to Elizabeth eldest sister . “ What a letter is Lydia ’s note to Elizabeth eldest sister , to be written at such a moment ! But at least Lydia ’s note to Elizabeth eldest sister shows that Lydia was serious on the subject of the fugitives journey . Whatever Colonel Forster might afterwards persuade Lydia to , it was not on Lydia side a scheme of infamy . Elizabeth poor father ! how Elizabeth father ’s must have felt it ! ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth never saw anyone so shocked . Elizabeth father ’s could not speak a word for full ten minutes . Jane ’s mother was taken ill immediately , and the whole house in such confusion ! ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Jane ’s , ” cried Elizabeth , “ was there a servant belonging to it who did not know the whole story before the end of the day ? ” 
 
  “ Jane ’s do not know . Jane ’s hope there was . But to be guarded at such a time is very difficult . Elizabeth eldest sister was in hysterics , and though Jane ’s endeavoured to give Elizabeth eldest sister every assistance in Jane ’s power , Jane ’s am afraid Jane ’s did not do so much as Jane ’s might have done ! But the horror of what might possibly happen almost took from Jane ’s Jane ’s faculties . ” 
 
  “ Jane ’s attendance upon Elizabeth eldest sister has been too much for Jane ’s . Jane ’s do not look well . Oh that Elizabeth uncle had been with Jane ’s ! Jane ’s have had every care and anxiety upon Jane ’s alone . ” 
 
  “ Mary and Kitty have been very kind , and would have shared in every fatigue , Jane ’s am sure ; but Jane ’s did not think it right for either of Mary and Kitty . Kitty is slight and delicate ; and Mary studies so much , that Mary hours of repose should not be broken in on . Jane ’s aunt Phillips came to Longbourn on Tuesday , after Jane ’s father went away ; and was so good as to stay till Thursday with Jane ’s . Jane ’s aunt Phillips was of great use and comfort to us all . And Lady Lucas has been very kind ; Lady Lucas walked here on Wednesday morning to condole with us , and offered Lady Lucas services , or any of Lady Lucas daughters ’ , if any of Lady Lucas daughters ’ should be of use to us . ” 
 
  “ Lady Lucas had better have stayed at home , ” cried Elizabeth ; “ perhaps Lady Lucas meant well , but , under such a misfortune as this , one can not see too little of one ’s neighbours . Assistance is impossible ; condolence insufferable . Let them triumph over us at a distance , and be satisfied . ” 
 
  Elizabeth eldest sister then proceeded to enquire into the measures which Elizabeth father ’s had intended to pursue , while in town , for the recovery of Elizabeth eldest sister . 
 
  “ Elizabeth father ’s meant Jane ’s believe , ” replied Jane ’s , “ to go to Epsom , the place where the fugitives last changed horses , see the postilions and try if anything could be made out from the postilions . Elizabeth father ’s principal object must be to discover the number of the hackney coach which took the fugitives from Clapham . the hackney coach which took the fugitives from Clapham had come with a fare from London ; and as Elizabeth father ’s thought that the circumstance of a gentleman and lady ’s removing from one carriage into another might be remarked Elizabeth father ’s meant to make enquiries at Clapham . If Elizabeth father ’s could anyhow discover at what house the coachman had before set down the coachman fare , Elizabeth father ’s determined to make enquiries there , and hoped it might not be impossible to find out the stand and number of the hackney coach which took the fugitives from Clapham . Jane ’s do not know of any other designs that Elizabeth father ’s had formed ; but Elizabeth father ’s was in such a hurry to be gone , and Elizabeth father ’s spirits so greatly discomposed , that Jane ’s had difficulty in finding out even so much as this . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  The whole party were in hopes of a letter from Father the next morning , but the post came in without bringing a single line from Father . Father family knew Father to be , on all common occasions , a most negligent and dilatory correspondent ; but at such a time Father family had hoped for exertion . Father family were forced to conclude that Father had no pleasing intelligence to send ; but even of had Father family would have been glad to be certain . Father had waited only for the letters before Father set off . 
 
  When Father was gone , Father family were certain at least of receiving constant information of what was going on , and Father family uncle promised , at parting , to prevail on Father to return to Longbourn , as soon as Father could , to the great consolation of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s not being killed in a duel . 
 
  Madeline and the children were to remain in Hertfordshire a few days longer , as the former thought the former presence might be serviceable to the children . the former shared in the children attendance on Father , and was a great comfort to the children in the children hours of freedom . the children other aunt also visited the children frequently , and always , as the children other aunt said , with the design of cheering and heartening the children up — though , as the children other aunt never came without reporting some fresh instance of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s extravagance or irregularity , the children other aunt seldom went away without leaving the children more dispirited than the children other aunt found the children . 
 
  All Meryton seemed striving to blacken Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s . Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s was declared to be in debt to every tradesman in the place , and Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s intrigues , all honoured with the title of seduction , had been extended into every tradesman ’s family . Everybody declared that Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s was the wickedest young man in the world ; and everybody began to find out that everybody had always distrusted the appearance of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s goodness . Elizabeth , though Elizabeth did not credit above half of what was said , believed enough to make Elizabeth former assurance of Elizabeth ruin more certain ; and even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin , became almost hopeless , more especially as the time was now come when , if yourself and Mother had gone to Scotland , which even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin had never before entirely despaired of , yourself and Mother must in all probability have gained some news of yourself and Mother . 
 
  Father left Longbourn on Sunday ; on Tuesday Father wife received a letter from Father ; it told yourself and Mother that , on Father arrival , Father had immediately found out Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s , and persuaded Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s to come to Gracechurch Street ; that Father had been to Epsom and Clapham , before Father arrival , but without gaining any satisfactory information ; and that Father was now determined to enquire at all the principal hotels in town , as Father thought it possible yourself and Mother might have gone to one of all the principal hotels in town , on yourself and Mother first coming to London , before yourself and Mother procured lodgings . Father did not expect any success from enquire , but as Father brother was eager in enquire , Father meant to assist Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s in pursuing enquire . Father added that Father seemed wholly disinclined at present to leave London and promised to write again very soon . There was also a postscript to this effect : 
 
  “ Father have written to Colonel Forster to desire Colonel Forster to find out , if possible , from some of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s intimates in the regiment , whether Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s has any relations or connections who would be likely to know in what part of town Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s has now concealed Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s . If there were anyone that one could apply to with a probability of gaining such a clue as that , anyone that one could apply to with a probability of gaining such a clue as that might be of essential consequence . At present we have nothing to guide we . Colonel Forster will , Father dare say , do everything in Colonel Forster power to satisfy we on this head . But , on second thoughts , perhaps , Elizabeth could tell we what relations Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s has now living , better than any other person . ” 
 
  Elizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference to Elizabeth authority proceeded ; but it was not in Elizabeth power to give any information of so satisfactory a nature as the compliment deserved . Elizabeth had never heard of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s having had any relations , except a father and mother , both of whom had been dead many years . It was possible , however , that some of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s companions in the — — shire might be able to give more information ; and though Elizabeth was not very sanguine in expecting it , the application was a something to look forward to . 
 
  Every day at Longbourn was now a day of anxiety ; but the most anxious part of each was when the post was expected . The arrival of letters was the grand object of every morning ’s impatience . Through letters , whatever of good or bad was to be told would be communicated , and every succeeding day was expected to bring some news of importance . 
 
  But before yourself and Mother heard again from Father , a letter arrived for yourself and Mother father , from a different quarter , from William Collins ; which , as even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin had received directions to open all that came for even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin in even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin absence , even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin accordingly read ; and Elizabeth , who knew what curiosities even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin letters always were , looked over even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin , and read a letter likewise . a letter was as follows : 
 
  “ Father , 
  “ Father feel Father called upon , by our relationship , and Father situation in life , to condole with Father on the grievous affliction Father are now suffering under , of which we were yesterday informed by a letter from Hertfordshire . Be assured , Father , that William Collins and Father sincerely sympathise with Father and all Father respectable family , in Father present distress , which must be of the bitterest kind , because proceeding from a cause which no time can remove . No arguments shall be wanting on Father part that can alleviate so severe a misfortune — or that may comfort Father , under a circumstance that must be of all others the most afflicting to a parent ’s mind . The death of Father daughter would have been a blessing in comparison of this . And it is the more to be lamented , because there is reason to suppose as Father dear Charlotte informs Father , that this licentiousness of behaviour in Father daughter has proceeded from a faulty degree of indulgence ; though , at the same time , for the consolation of yourself and Mother , Father am inclined to think that Father daughter own disposition must be naturally bad , or Father daughter could not be guilty of such an enormity , at so early an age . Howsoever that may be , Father are grievously to be pitied ; in which opinion Father am not only joined by William Collins , but likewise by Cathleen and Cathleen daughter , to whom Father have related the affair . Cathleen and Cathleen daughter , to whom Father have related the affair agree with Father in apprehending that this false step in one daughter will be injurious to the fortunes of all the others ; for who , as Cathleen Cathleen condescendingly says , will connect themselves with such a family ? And this consideration leads Father moreover to reflect , with augmented satisfaction , on a certain event of last November ; for had a certain event of last November been otherwise , Father must have been involved in all Father sorrow and disgrace . Let Father then advise Father , Father , to console Father as much as possible , to throw off Father unworthy child from Father affection for ever , and leave Father daughter to reap the fruits of Father daughter own heinous offense . 
 
  “ Father am , Father , etc . , etc . ” 
 
  Father did not write again till Father had received an answer from Colonel Forster ; and then Father had nothing of a pleasant nature to send . It was not known that Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s had a single relationship with whom Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s kept up any connection , and it was certain that Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s had no near one living . Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s former acquaintances had been numerous ; but since Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s had been in the regiment , it did not appear that Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s was on terms of particular friendship with any of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s former acquaintances . There was no one , therefore , who could be pointed out as likely to give any news of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s . And in the wretched state of Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s own finances , there was a very powerful motive for secrecy , in addition to Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s fear of discovery by Father daughter relations , for it had just transpired that Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s had left gaming debts behind Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s to a very considerable amount . Colonel Forster believed that more than a thousand pounds would be necessary to clear Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s expenses at Brighton . Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s owed a good deal in town , but Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s debts of honour were still more formidable . Father did not attempt to conceal these particulars from the Longbourn family . even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin heard these particulars with horror . “ A gamester ! ” even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin cried . “ This is wholly unexpected . even Jane , who believed still less of Elizabeth ruin had not an idea of This . ” 
 
  Father added in Father letter , that the children might expect to see Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s at home on the following day , which was Saturday . Rendered spiritless by the ill - success of all their endeavours , Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s had yielded to Colonel Forster entreaty that Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s would return to Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s family , and leave it to Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s to do whatever occasion might suggest to be advisable for continuing yourself and Mother pursuit . When Father was told of this , Father did not express so much satisfaction as the children expected , considering what Father anxiety for Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s life had been before . 
 
  “ What , is Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s coming home , and without Father daughter ? ” Father cried . “ Sure Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s will not leave London before Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s has found yourself and Mother . Who is to fight Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s , and make Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s marry Father daughter , if Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s comes away ? ” 
 
  As Madeline began to wish to be at home , it was settled that Madeline and the children should go to London , at the same time Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s came from The coach . The coach , therefore , took Madeline and the children the first stage of Madeline and the children journey , and brought The coach master back to Longbourn . 
 
  Madeline went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world . Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world name had never been voluntarily mentioned before Madeline and the children by Father daughter ; and the kind of half - expectation which Madeline had formed , of Madeline and the children being followed by a letter from Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world , had ended in nothing . Elizabeth had received none since Elizabeth return that could come from Pemberley . 
 
  The present unhappy state of Longbourn rendered any other excuse for the lowness of Elizabeth spirits unnecessary ; nothing , therefore , could be fairly conjectured from that , though Elizabeth , who was by this time tolerably well acquainted with Elizabeth own feelings , was perfectly aware that , had Elizabeth known nothing of Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world , Elizabeth could have borne the dread of Father daughter infamy somewhat better . It would have spared Elizabeth , Elizabeth thought , one sleepless night out of two . 
 
  When Father arrived , Father had all the appearance of Father usual philosophic composure . Father said as little as Father had ever been in the habit of saying ; made no mention of the business that had taken Father away , and it was some time before the children had courage to speak of the business that had taken Father away . 
 
  It was not till the afternoon , when Father had joined the children at tea , that Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject ; and then , on Elizabeth briefly expressing Elizabeth sorrow for what Father must have endured , Father replied , “ Say nothing of that . Who should suffer but Father ? It has been Father own doing , and Father ought to feel it . ” 
 
  “ Father must not be too severe upon Father , ” replied Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Elizabeth may well warn Elizabeth against such an evil . Human nature is so prone to fall into such an evil ! No , Elizabeth , let Father once in Father life feel how much Father have been to blame . Father am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression . the impression will pass away soon enough . ” 
 
  “ Do Elizabeth suppose yourself and Mother to be in London ? ” 
 
  “ Yes ; where else can yourself and Mother be so well concealed ? ” 
 
  “ And Father daughter used to want to go to London , ” added Kitty . 
 
  “ Father daughter is happy then , ” said Father daughter father drily ; “ and Father daughter residence there will probably be of some duration . ” 
 
  Then after a short silence Father continued : 
 
  “ Elizabeth , Father bear Father no ill - will for being justified in Father advice to Father daughter last May , which , considering the event , shows some greatness of mind . ” 
 
  yourself and Mother were interrupted by Miss Bennet , who came to fetch Father tea . 
 
  “ This is a parade , ” Father cried , “ which does one good ; This gives such an elegance to misfortune ! Another day Father will do the same ; Father will sit in Father library , in Father nightcap and powdering gown , and give as much trouble as Father can ; or , perhaps , Father may defer it till Elizabeth runs away . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth am not going to run away , Father , ” said Elizabeth fretfully . “ If Elizabeth should ever go to Brighton , Elizabeth would behave better than Father daughter . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth go to Brighton . Father would not trust Elizabeth so near Brighton as Eastbourne for fifty pounds ! No , Elizabeth , Father have at last learnt to be cautious , and Elizabeth will feel the effects of learnt . No officer is ever to enter into Father house again , nor even to pass through the village . Balls will be absolutely prohibited , unless Elizabeth stand up with one of Elizabeth sisters . And Elizabeth are never to stir out of doors till Elizabeth can prove that Elizabeth have spent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , began to cry . 
 
  “ Well , well , ” said Father , “ do not make Elizabeth unhappy . If Elizabeth are a good girl for the next ten years , Father will take Elizabeth to a review at the end of the next ten years . ”
