  Two days after Father ’s return , as Jane and Elizabeth were walking together in the shrubbery behind the house , Jane and Elizabeth saw the housekeeper coming towards Jane and Elizabeth , and , concluding that the housekeeper came to call Jane and Elizabeth to Jane and Elizabeth mother , went forward to meet the housekeeper ; but , instead of the expected summons , when Jane and Elizabeth approached the housekeeper , the housekeeper said to Miss Bennet , “ the housekeeper beg Miss Bennet pardon , Miss Bennet , for interrupting Miss Bennet , but the housekeeper was in hopes Miss Bennet might have got some good news from town , so the housekeeper took the liberty of coming to ask . Miss Bennet 
 
  Miss Bennet What do the housekeeper mean , Miss Bennet ? We have heard nothing from town . ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet , ” cried Jane and Elizabeth mother , in great astonishment , “ do n’t Miss Bennet know there is an express come for master from Edward ? master has been here this half - hour , and master has had a letter . ” 
 
  Away ran Jane and Elizabeth , too eager to get in to have time for speech . Jane and Elizabeth ran through the vestibule into the breakfast - room ; from thence to the library ; Father ’s was in neither ; and Jane and Elizabeth were on the point of seeking Father ’s up stairs with Jane and Elizabeth mother , when Jane and Elizabeth were met by the butler , who said : 
 
  “ If Jane and Elizabeth are looking for the butler , who said : 
 
  “ If Jane and Elizabeth are looking for master , Jane and Elizabeth , Father ’s is walking towards the little copse . ” 
 
  Upon this information , Jane and Elizabeth instantly passed through the hall once more , and ran across the lawn after Jane and Elizabeth father , who was deliberately pursuing Father ’s way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock . 
 
  Jane , who was not so light nor so much in the habit of running as Elizabeth , soon lagged behind , while Jane sister , panting for breath , came up with Father ’s , and eagerly cried out : 
 
  “ Oh , Father ’s , what news — what news ? Have Father ’s heard from Jane uncle ? ” 
 
  “ Yes Elizabeth have had a letter from master by express . ” 
 
  “ Well , and what news does a letter from master by express bring — good or bad ? ” 
 
  “ What is there of good to be expected ? ” said Father ’s , taking a letter from Father ’s pocket . “ But perhaps Elizabeth would like to read a letter . ” 
 
  Elizabeth impatiently caught a letter from Father ’s hand . Jane now came up . 
 
  “ Read a letter aloud , ” said Father ’s , “ for Father ’s hardly know Father ’s what a letter is about . ” 
 
  “ Gracechurch Street , Monday , August 2 . 
 
  “ Elizabeth dear Brother , 
  “ At last Elizabeth am able to send Elizabeth dear Brother some tidings of Elizabeth niece , and such as , upon the whole , Elizabeth hope it will give Elizabeth dear Brother satisfaction . Soon after Elizabeth dear Brother left Elizabeth on Saturday , Elizabeth was fortunate enough to find out in what part of London they were . The particulars Elizabeth reserve till we meet ; it is enough to know The particulars are discovered . Elizabeth have seen they — ” 
      “ Then it is as Jane always hoped , ” cried Jane ; “ they are married ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth read on : 
 
  “ Elizabeth have seen they . They are not married , nor can Elizabeth find there was any intention of being so ; but if Elizabeth dear Brother are willing to perform the engagements which Elizabeth have ventured to make on Elizabeth dear Brother side , Elizabeth hope it will not be long before they are . All that is required of Elizabeth dear Brother is , to assure to Elizabeth dear Brother daughter , by settlement , Elizabeth niece equal share of the five thousand pounds secured among Elizabeth dear Brother children after the decease of Elizabeth dear Brother and Elizabeth sister ; and , moreover , to enter into an engagement of allowing Elizabeth niece , during Elizabeth dear Brother life , one hundred pounds per annum . These are conditions which , considering everything , Elizabeth had no hesitation in complying with , as far as Elizabeth thought Elizabeth privileged , for Elizabeth dear Brother . Elizabeth shall send this by express , that no time may be lost in bringing Elizabeth Elizabeth dear Brother answer . Elizabeth dear Brother will easily comprehend , from The particulars , that Charlie ’s circumstances are not so hopeless as Charlie ’s circumstances are generally believed to be . The world has been deceived in that respect ; and Elizabeth am happy to say there will be some little money , even when all Charlie ’s debts are discharged , to settle on Elizabeth niece , in addition to Elizabeth niece own fortune . If , as Elizabeth conclude will be the case , Elizabeth dear Brother send Elizabeth full powers to act in Elizabeth dear Brother name throughout the whole of this business , Elizabeth will immediately give directions to Haggerston for preparing a proper settlement . There will not be the smallest occasion for Elizabeth dear Brother coming to town again ; therefore stay quiet at Longbourn , and depend on Elizabeth diligence and care . Send back Elizabeth dear Brother answer as fast as Elizabeth dear Brother can , and be careful to write explicitly . We have judged it best that Elizabeth niece should be married from the house . Elizabeth niece comes to We to - day . Elizabeth shall write again as soon as anything more is determined on . Elizabeth dear Brother , etc . , 
 
  “ EDW . GARDINER . ” 
 
  “ Is it possible ? ” cried Elizabeth , when Elizabeth had finished . “ Can it be possible that good man will marry Elizabeth niece ? ” 
 
  “ George is not so undeserving , then , as we thought good man , ” said Jane . “ Father ’s , Elizabeth congratulate Father ’s . ” 
 
  “ And have Father ’s answered a letter ? ” cried Elizabeth . 
 
  “ No ; but it must be done soon . ” 
 
  Most earnestly did Elizabeth then entreat Father ’s to lose no more time before Father ’s wrote . 
 
  “ Oh ! Father ’s , ” Elizabeth cried , “ come back and write immediately . Consider how important every moment is in such a case . ” 
 
  “ Let Jane write for Father ’s , ” said Jane , “ if Father ’s dislike the trouble Father ’s . ” 
 
  “ Father ’s dislike the trouble very much , ” Father ’s replied ; “ but it must be done . ” 
 
  And so saying , Father ’s turned back with Jane and Elizabeth , and walked towards the house . 
 
  “ And may Elizabeth ask — ” said Elizabeth ; “ but the terms , Elizabeth suppose , must be complied with . ” 
 
  “ Complied with ! Elizabeth am only ashamed of good man asking so little . ” 
 
  “ And they must marry ! Yet good man is such a man ! ” 
 
  “ Yes , yes , they must marry . There is nothing else to be done . But there are two things that Elizabeth want very much to know ; one is , how much money Elizabeth uncle has laid down to bring it about ; and the other , how am Elizabeth ever to pay Jane uncle . ” 
 
  “ Money ! Elizabeth uncle ! ” cried Jane , “ what do Father ’s mean , Father ’s ? ” 
 
  “ Father ’s mean , that no man in no man in senses would marry Elizabeth niece on so slight a temptation as one hundred a year during Father ’s life , and fifty after Father ’s am gone . ” 
 
  “ That is very true , ” said Elizabeth ; “ though That had not occurred to Elizabeth before . good man debts to be discharged , and something still to remain ! Oh ! it must be Elizabeth uncle ’s doings ! Generous , good man , Elizabeth am afraid good man has distressed good man . A small sum could not do all this . ” 
 
  “ No , ” said Father ’s ; “ good man ’s a fool if good man takes Elizabeth niece with a farthing less than ten thousand pounds . Elizabeth should be sorry to think so ill of good man , in the very beginning of our relationship . ” 
 
  “ Ten thousand pounds ! Heaven forbid ! How is half such a sum to be repaid ? ” 
 
  Father ’s made no answer , and each of Jane and Elizabeth , deep in thought , continued silent till Jane and Elizabeth reached the house . Father ’s then went on to the library to write , and Jane and Elizabeth walked into the breakfast - room . 
 
  “ And they are really to be married ! ” cried Elizabeth , as soon as Jane and Elizabeth were by Jane and Elizabeth . “ How strange are is ! And for are Jane and Elizabeth are to be thankful . That they should marry , small as is they chance of happiness , and wretched as is good man character , Jane and Elizabeth are forced to rejoice . Oh , Elizabeth niece ! ” 
 
  “ Jane comfort Jane with thinking , ” replied Jane , “ that good man certainly would not marry Elizabeth niece if good man had not a real regard for Elizabeth niece . Though Jane uncle has done something towards clearing good man , Jane can not believe that ten thousand pounds , or anything like ten thousand pounds , has been advanced . good man has children of good man own , and may have more . How could good man spare half ten thousand pounds ? ” 
 
  “ If good man were ever able to learn what good man debts have been , ” said Elizabeth , “ and how much is settled on good man side on Elizabeth niece , we shall exactly know what Edward has done for them , because good man has not sixpence of good man own . The kindness of Elizabeth uncle and aunt can never be requited . Elizabeth uncle and aunt taking Elizabeth niece home , and affording Elizabeth niece Elizabeth uncle and aunt personal protection and countenance , is such a sacrifice to Elizabeth niece advantage as years of gratitude can not enough acknowledge . By this time Elizabeth niece is actually with Elizabeth uncle and aunt ! If such goodness does not make Elizabeth niece miserable now , Elizabeth niece will never deserve to be happy ! What a meeting for Elizabeth niece , when Elizabeth niece first sees Elizabeth aunt ! ” 
 
  “ We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side , ” said Jane : “ Jane hope and trust they will yet be happy . good man consenting to marry Elizabeth niece is a proof , Jane will believe , that good man is come to a right way of thinking . they mutual affection will steady they ; and Jane flatter Jane they will settle so quietly , and live in so rational a manner , as may in time make they past imprudence forgotten . ” 
 
  “ they conduct has been such , ” replied Elizabeth , “ as neither Jane , nor Elizabeth , nor anybody can ever forget . It is useless to talk of they conduct . ” 
 
  It now occurred to Jane and Elizabeth that Jane and Elizabeth mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened . Jane and Elizabeth went to the library , therefore , and asked Jane and Elizabeth father whether Father ’s would not wish Jane and Elizabeth to make happened known to Jane and Elizabeth mother . Father ’s was writing and , without raising Father ’s head , coolly replied : 
 
  “ Just as Elizabeth please . ” 
 
  “ May we take Elizabeth uncle ’s letter to read to Elizabeth niece ? ” 
 
  “ Take whatever Elizabeth like , and get away . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth took a letter from Father ’s writing - table , and they went up stairs together . Mary and Kitty were both with Jane and Elizabeth mother : one communication would , therefore , do for all . After a slight preparation for good news , a letter was read aloud . Jane and Elizabeth mother could hardly contain Jane and Elizabeth mother . As soon as Jane had read Edward ’s hope of Elizabeth niece being soon married , Jane joy burst forth , and every following sentence added to Jane joy exuberance . Jane was now in an irritation as violent from delight , as Jane had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation . To know that Jane daughter would be married was enough . Jane was disturbed by no fear for Jane felicity , nor humbled by any remembrance of Jane misconduct . 
 
  “ Jane dear , dear Lydia ! ” Jane cried . “ This is delightful indeed ! Elizabeth niece will be married ! Jane shall see Elizabeth niece again ! Elizabeth niece will be married at sixteen ! Jane good , kind brother ! Jane knew how it would be . Jane knew Edward would manage everything ! How Jane long to see Elizabeth niece ! and to see good man too ! But the clothes , the clothes ! Jane will write to Jane sister Gardiner about the clothes directly . Elizabeth , Elizabeth dear , run down to Elizabeth father , and ask Father ’s how much Father ’s will give Elizabeth niece . How merry we shall be together when we meet ! ” 
 
  Jane and Elizabeth mother eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports , by leading Elizabeth thoughts to the obligations which Edward ’s behaviour laid them all under . 
 
  “ For we must attribute this happy conclusion , ” Elizabeth added , “ in a great measure to Edward kindness . We are persuaded that Edward has pledged Edward to assist Charlie ’s with money . ” 
 
  “ Well , ” cried Jane and Elizabeth mother , “ it is all very right ; who should do assist but Charlie ’s own uncle ? If Edward had not had a family of Edward own , Elizabeth and Elizabeth children must have had all Edward money , Elizabeth dear Brother know ; and it is the first time Elizabeth and Elizabeth children have ever had anything from Edward , except a few presents . Well ! Jane and Elizabeth mother am so happy ! In a short time Elizabeth shall have Elizabeth niece married . Jane and Elizabeth mother How well it sounds ! And Elizabeth niece was only sixteen last June . Elizabeth dear Jane , Elizabeth am in such a flutter , that Elizabeth am sure Elizabeth ca n’t write ; so Elizabeth will dictate , and Jane write for Elizabeth .   Elizabeth was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico , muslin , and cambric , and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders , had not Jane , though with some difficulty , persuaded Elizabeth to wait till Father ’s was at leisure to be consulted . One day ’s delay , Jane observed , would be of small importance ; and Jane mother was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual . Other schemes , too , came into Elizabeth head . 
 
  “ Elizabeth will go to Meryton , ” said Elizabeth , “ as soon as Elizabeth am dressed , and tell the good , good news to Elizabeth sister Philips . And as Elizabeth come back , Elizabeth can call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long . Kitty , run down and order the carriage . An airing would do Elizabeth a great deal of good , Elizabeth am sure . Girls , can Elizabeth do anything for Girls in Meryton ? Oh ! Here comes Miss Bennet ! Elizabeth dear Hill , have Miss Bennet heard the good , good news ? Elizabeth niece is going to be married ; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at Elizabeth niece wedding . ” 
 
  Miss Bennet began instantly to express Miss Bennet joy . Elizabeth received Miss Bennet congratulations amongst the rest , and then , sick of this folly , took refuge in Elizabeth own room , that Elizabeth might think with freedom . 
 
  Elizabeth niece situation must , at best , be bad enough ; but that Elizabeth niece situation was no worse , Elizabeth had need to be thankful . Elizabeth felt it so ; and though , in looking forward , neither rational happiness nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for Elizabeth niece , in looking back to what they had feared , only two hours ago , Elizabeth felt all the advantages of what they had gained . 
 Chapter 
 
  Father had very often wished before this period of Father life that , instead of spending Father whole income , Father had laid by an annual sum for the better provision of Father children , and of Father wife , if Father wife survived Father . Father now wished it more than ever . Had Father done Father duty in that respect , Father wife need not have been indebted to Father wife uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for Father wife . The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be Father wife husband might then have rested in The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be Father wife husband proper place . 
 
  Father was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone should be forwarded at the sole expense of Father brother - in - law , and Father was determined , if possible , to find out the extent of Father brother - in - law assistance , and to discharge the obligation as soon as Father could . 
 
  When first Father had married , economy was held to be perfectly useless , for , of course , Father brother - in - law and Father wife were to have a son . a son was to join in cutting off the entail , as soon as a son should be of age , and Father wife and younger children would by that means be provided for . Five daughters successively entered the world , but yet a son was to come ; and Father wife , for many years after Father wife birth , had been certain that a son would . This event had at last been despaired of , but it was then too late to be saving . Father wife had no turn for economy , and Father wife husband ’s love of independence had alone prevented Father brother - in - law and Father wife exceeding Father brother - in - law and Father wife income . 
 
  Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Father wife and Father children . But in what proportions Five thousand pounds should be divided amongst Father children depended on the will of the parents . This was one point , with regard to Father wife , at least , which was now to be settled , and Father could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before Father . In terms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of Father brother - in - law , though expressed most concisely , Father then delivered on paper Father perfect approbation of all that was done , and Father willingness to fulfil the engagements that had been made for Father . Father had never before supposed that , could Father brother - in - law be prevailed on to marry Father wife , marry would be done with so little inconvenience to Father as by the present arrangement . Father would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser by the hundred that was to be paid them ; for , what with Father wife board and pocket allowance , and the continual presents in money which passed to Father wife through Father wife hands , Father wife expenses had been very little within that sum . 
 
  That it would be done with such trifling exertion on Father side , too , was another very welcome surprise ; for Father wish at present was to have as little trouble in the business as possible . When the first transports of rage which had produced Father activity in seeking Father wife were over , Father naturally returned to all Father former indolence . Father letter was soon dispatched ; for , though dilatory in undertaking business , Father was quick in Father letter execution . Father begged to know further particulars of what Father was indebted to Father brother , but was too angry with Father wife to send any message to Father wife . 
 
  The good news spread quickly through the house , and with proportionate speed through the neighbourhood . The good news was borne in the neighbourhood with decent philosophy . To be sure , it would have been more for the advantage of conversation had Father wife come upon the town ; or , as the happiest alternative , been secluded from the world , in some distant farmhouse . But there was much to be talked of in marrying Father wife ; and the good - natured wishes for Father wife well - doing which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton lost but a little of all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton spirit in this change of circumstances , because with such an husband Father wife misery was considered certain . 
 
  It was a fortnight since Father wife had been downstairs ; but on this happy day Father wife again took Father wife seat at the head of Father wife table , and in spirits oppressively high . No sentiment of shame gave a damp to Father wife triumph . The marriage of a daughter , which had been the first object of Father wife wishes since Jane was sixteen , was now on the point of accomplishment , and Father wife thoughts and Father wife words ran wholly on those attendants of elegant nuptials , fine muslins , new carriages , and servants . Father wife was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for Father wife daughter , and , without knowing or considering what their income might be , rejected many as deficient in size and importance . 
 
  “ Haye Park might do , ” said Father wife , “ if the Gouldings could quit Haye Park — or the great house at Stoke , if the drawing - room were larger ; but Ashworth is too far off ! Father wife could not bear to have Father wife ten miles from Father wife ; and as for Pulvis Lodge , the attics are dreadful . ” 
 
  Father wife husband allowed Father wife to talk on without interruption while the servants remained . But when the servants had withdrawn , Father wife husband ’s said to Father wife : “ Father wife , before Father wife take any or all of these houses for Father wife son and Father wife , let us come to a right understanding . Into one house in this neighbourhood Father wife son and Father wife shall never have admittance . Father wife husband ’s will not encourage the impudence of either , by receiving Father wife son and Father wife at Longbourn . ” 
 
  A long dispute followed this declaration ; but Father was firm . A long dispute soon led to another ; and Father wife found , with amazement and horror , that Father would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for Father wife . Father protested that Father wife should receive from Father no mark of affection whatever on the occasion . Father wife could hardly comprehend it . That Father anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable resentment as to refuse Father daughter a privilege without which Father wife marriage would scarcely seem valid , exceeded all Father wife could believe possible . Father wife was more alive to the disgrace which Father wife want of new clothes must reflect on Father wife nuptials , than to any sense of shame at Father wife eloping and living with Father brother - in - law a fortnight before Father wife nuptials took place . 
 
  Father wife was now most heartily sorry that Father wife had , from the distress of the moment , been led to make Father brother - in - law acquainted with their fears for Father wife sister ; for since Father wife marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement , their might hope to conceal the elopement unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot . 
 
  Father wife had no fear of the elopement spreading farther through Father brother - in - law means . There were few people on whose secrecy Father wife would have more confidently depended ; but , at the same time , there was no one whose knowledge of a sister ’s frailty would have mortified Father wife so much — not , however , from any fear of disadvantage from a sister ’s frailty individually to Father wife , for , at any rate , there seemed a gulf impassable between them . Had Father wife marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms , it was not to be supposed that Father brother - in - law would connect Father brother - in - law with a family where , to every other objection , would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with Father brother - in - law Father brother - in - law so justly scorned . 
 
  From such a connection Father wife could not wonder that Father brother - in - law would shrink . The wish of procuring Father wife regard , which Father wife had assured Father wife of Father brother - in - law feeling in Derbyshire , could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this . Father wife was humbled , Father wife was grieved ; Father wife repented , though Father wife hardly knew of what . Father wife became jealous of Father brother - in - law esteem , when Father wife could no longer hope to be benefited by Father brother - in - law esteem . Father wife wanted to hear of Father brother - in - law , when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence . Father wife was convinced that Father wife could have been happy with Father brother - in - law , when it was no longer likely they should meet . 
 
  What a triumph for Father brother - in - law , as Father wife often thought , could Father brother - in - law know that the proposals which Father wife had proudly spurned only four months ago , would now have been most gladly and gratefully received ! Father brother - in - law was as generous , Father wife doubted not , as the most generous of Father brother - in - law sex ; but while Father brother - in - law was mortal , there must be a triumph . 
 
  Father wife began now to comprehend that Father brother - in - law was exactly the man who , in disposition and talents , would most suit Father wife . Father brother - in - law understanding and temper , though unlike Father wife own , would have answered all Father wife wishes . It was an union that must have been to the advantage of both ; by Father wife ease and liveliness , Father brother - in - law mind might have been softened , Father brother - in - law manners improved ; and from Father brother - in - law judgement , information , and knowledge of the world , Father wife must have received benefit of greater importance . 
 
  But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was . An union of a different tendency , and precluding the possibility of the other , was soon to be formed in both family . 
 
  How Father brother - in - law and Father wife were to be supported in tolerable independence , Father wife could not imagine . But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because a couple who were only brought together because passions were stronger than a couple who were only brought together because virtue , Father wife could easily conjecture . 
 
  Edward soon wrote again to Edward brother . To Father ’s acknowledgments Edward briefly replied , with assurance of Edward eagerness to promote the welfare of any of Edward family ; and concluded with entreaties that the subject might never be mentioned to Edward again . The principal purport of Edward letter was to inform Edward brother that Charlie had resolved on quitting the militia . 
 
  “ It was greatly Edward wish that Charlie should do so , ” Edward added , “ as soon as Charlie marriage was fixed on . And Edward think Edward brother will agree with Edward , in considering the removal from the militia as highly advisable , both on Charlie account and Edward niece ’s . It is Charlie ’s intention to go into the regulars ; and among Charlie former friends , there are still some who are able and willing to assist Charlie in the army . Charlie has the promise of an ensigncy in General — — ’s regiment , now quartered in the North . It is an advantage to have General — — ’s regiment , now quartered in the North so far from this part of the kingdom . Charlie promises fairly ; and Edward hope among different people , where they may each have a character to preserve , they will both be more prudent . Edward have written to Colonel Forster , to inform Colonel Forster of our present arrangements , and to request that Colonel Forster will satisfy the various creditors of Charlie in and near Brighton , with assurances of speedy payment , for which Edward have pledged Edward . And will Edward brother give Edward brother the trouble of carrying similar assurances to Charlie creditors in Meryton , of whom Edward shall subjoin a list according to Charlie information ? Charlie has given in all Charlie debts ; Edward hope at least Charlie has not deceived us . Charlie has our directions , and all will be completed in a week . They will then join General — — ’s regiment , now quartered in the North , unless they are first invited to Longbourn ; and Edward understand from Madeline , that Father wife is very desirous of seeing Edward brother before Father wife leaves the South . Father wife is well , and begs to be dutifully remembered to Edward brother and Father wife mother.—Yours , etc . , 
 
  “ Edward . ” 
 
  Father and Father daughters saw all the advantages of Father brother - in - law removal from the — — shire as clearly as Edward could do . But Father wife was not so well pleased with Father brother - in - law removal . Father wife being settled in the North , just when Father wife had expected most pleasure and pride in Father wife company , for Father wife had by no means given up Father wife plan of their residing in Hertfordshire , was a severe disappointment ; and , besides , it was such a pity that Father wife should be taken from a regiment where Father wife was acquainted with everybody , and had so many favourites . 
 
  “ Father wife is so fond of Colonel Forster , ” said Father wife , “ it will be quite shocking to send Father wife away ! And there are several of the young men , too , that Father wife likes very much . The officers may not be so pleasant in General — — ’s regiment , now quartered in the North . ” 
 
  Father daughter ’s request , for such it might be considered , of being admitted into both family again before Father wife set off for the North , received at first an absolute negative . But Jane and Elizabeth , who agreed in wishing , for the sake of Father wife feelings and consequence , that Father wife should be noticed on Father wife marriage by the parents , urged Father brother - in - law so earnestly yet so rationally and so mildly , to receive Father wife and Father brother - in - law at Longbourn , as soon as Father wife and Father brother - in - law were married , that Father brother - in - law was prevailed on to think as Father wife and Father brother - in - law thought , and act as Father wife and Father brother - in - law wished . And Father wife had the satisfaction of knowing that Father wife would be able to show Father wife in the neighbourhood before Father wife was banished to the North . When Father wrote again to Father brother , therefore , Father sent Father permission for Father wife and Father brother - in - law to come ; and it was settled , that as soon as the ceremony was over , Father wife and Father brother - in - law should proceed to Longbourn . Father wife was surprised , however , that Father brother - in - law should consent to such a scheme , and had Father wife consulted only Father wife own inclination , any meeting with Father brother - in - law would have been the last object of Father wife wishes . 
 Chapter 
 
  Their sister ’s wedding day arrived ; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for Their sister ’s probably more than Their sister ’s felt for Their sister ’s . The carriage was sent to meet the young couple at — — , and the young couple were to return in The carriage by dinner - time . the young couple arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets , and Jane more especially , who gave Their sister ’s the feelings which would have attended Jane , had Jane been the culprit , and was wretched in the thought of what Jane sister must endure . 
 
  the young couple came . The family were assembled in the breakfast room to receive the young couple . Smiles decked the face of Mother as the carriage drove up to the door ; Mother husband looked impenetrably grave ; Mother daughters , alarmed , anxious , uneasy . 
 
  Their sister ’s voice was heard in the vestibule ; the door was thrown open , and Their sister ’s ran into the room . Their sister ’s mother stepped forwards , embraced Their sister ’s , and welcomed Their sister ’s with rapture ; gave Mother hand , with an affectionate smile , to George , who followed Their sister ’s ; and wished the young couple joy with an alacrity which shewed no doubt of the young couple happiness . 
 
  the young couple reception from Father , to whom the young couple then turned , was not quite so cordial . Father , to whom the young couple then turned countenance rather gained in austerity ; and Father , to whom the young couple then turned scarcely opened Father , to whom the young couple then turned lips . The easy assurance of the young couple , indeed , was enough to provoke Father , to whom the young couple then turned . Elizabeth was disgusted , and the elder Miss Bennets was shocked . Their sister ’s was Lydia still ; untamed , unabashed , wild , noisy , and fearless . Their sister ’s turned from sister to sister , demanding their congratulations ; and when at length their sat down , looked eagerly round the room , took notice of some little alteration in the room , and observed , with a laugh , that it was a great while since Their sister ’s had been there . 
 
  George , who followed was not at all more distressed than Their sister ’s , but George , who followed manners were always so pleasing , that had George , who followed character and George , who followed marriage been exactly what George , who followed character and George , who followed marriage ought , George , who followed smiles and George , who followed easy address , while George , who followed claimed their relationship , would have delighted their . Elizabeth had not before believed George , who followed quite equal to such assurance ; but Elizabeth sat down , resolving within Elizabeth to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man . Elizabeth blushed , and Jane blushed ; but the cheeks of Jane and Elizabeth Jane and Elizabeth confusion suffered no variation of colour . 
 
  There was no want of discourse . Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother could neither of Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother talk fast enough ; and George , who followed , began enquiring after George , who followed acquaintance in that neighbourhood , with a good humoured ease which Elizabeth felt very unable to equal in Elizabeth replies . Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother seemed each of Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother to have the happiest memories in the world . Nothing of the past was recollected with pain ; and Their sister ’s led voluntarily to subjects which Their sister ’s sisters would not have alluded to for the world . 
 
  “ Only think of its being three months , ” Their sister ’s cried , “ since Their sister ’s went away ; it seems but a fortnight Their sister ’s declare ; and yet there have been things enough happened in the time . Good gracious ! when Their sister ’s went away , Their sister ’s am sure Their sister ’s had no more idea of being married till Their sister ’s came back again ! though Their sister ’s thought it would be very good fun if Their sister ’s was . ” 
 
  Their sister ’s father lifted up Father , to whom the young couple then turned eyes . Jane was distressed . Elizabeth looked expressively at Their sister ’s ; but Elizabeth Elizabeth chose to be insensible , gaily continued , “ Oh ! Mother , do the people hereabouts know Elizabeth am married to - day ? Elizabeth was afraid the people hereabouts might not ; and we overtook William Goulding in William Goulding curricle , so Elizabeth was determined William Goulding should know am , and so Elizabeth let down the side - glass next to William Goulding , and took off Elizabeth glove , and let Elizabeth hand just rest upon the window frame , so that William Goulding might see the ring , and then Elizabeth bowed and smiled like anything . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth could bear it no longer . Elizabeth got up , and ran out of the room ; and returned no more , till Elizabeth heard the young couple passing through the hall to the dining parlour . Elizabeth then joined the young couple soon enough to see Their sister ’s , with anxious parade , walk up to Their sister ’s mother ’s right hand , and hear Their sister ’s say to Their sister ’s eldest sister , “ Ah ! Jane , Their sister ’s take Jane place now , and Jane must go lower , because Their sister ’s am a married woman . ” 
 
  It was not to be supposed that time would give Their sister ’s that embarrassment from which Their sister ’s had been so wholly free at first . Their sister ’s ease and good spirits increased . Their sister ’s longed to see Mrs. Phillips , the Lucases , and all their other neighbours , and to hear Their sister ’s called “ Mrs. Wickham ” by each of Mrs. Phillips , the Lucases , and all their other neighbours ; and in the mean time , Their sister ’s went after dinner to show Their sister ’s ring , and boast of being married , to Mrs. Phillips and the two housemaids . 
 
  “ Well , Mother , ” said Their sister ’s , when they were all returned to the breakfast room , “ and what do Mother think of Mother husband ? Is not Mother husband a charming man ? Their sister ’s am sure Their sister ’s sisters must all envy Their sister ’s . Their sister ’s only hope Their sister ’s sisters may have half Their sister ’s good luck . Their sister ’s sisters must all go to Brighton . Brighton is the place to get husbands . What a pity it is , Mother , we did not all go . ” 
 
  “ Very true ; and if Mother had Mother will , we should . But Mother dear Lydia , Mother do n’t at all like Their sister ’s going such a way off . Must going be so ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , lord ! yes;—there is nothing in that . Their sister ’s shall like it of all things . Mother and George , who followed , and Their sister ’s sisters , must come down and see us . us shall be at Newcastle all the winter , and Their sister ’s dare say there will be some balls , and Their sister ’s will take care to get good partners for them all . ” 
 
  “ Mother should like it beyond anything ! ” said Their sister ’s mother . 
 
  “ And then when Their sister ’s go away , Their sister ’s may leave one or two of Mother sisters behind Their sister ’s ; and Mother dare say Mother shall get husbands for one or two of Mother sisters before the winter is over . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth thank Mother for Elizabeth share of the favour , ” said Elizabeth ; “ but Elizabeth do not particularly like Mother way of getting husbands . ” 
 
  the young couple visitors were not to remain above ten days with the young couple . Charlie had received Charlie commission before Charlie left London , and Charlie was to join Charlie regiment at the end of a fortnight . 
 
  No one but Mother regretted that the young couple visitors stay would be so short ; and Mother made the most of the time by visiting about with Their sister ’s , and having very frequent parties at home . very frequent parties at home were acceptable to all ; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did think , than such as did not . 
 
  George , who followed affection for Their sister ’s was just what Elizabeth had expected to find George , who followed affection for Their sister ’s ; not equal to Their sister ’s for George , who followed . Elizabeth had scarcely needed Elizabeth present observation to be satisfied , from the reason of things , that their elopement had been brought on by the strength of Their sister ’s love , rather than by George , who followed ; and Elizabeth would have wondered why , without violently caring for Their sister ’s , George , who followed chose to elope with Their sister ’s at all , had Their sister ’s not felt certain that George , who followed flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances ; and if was were the case , George , who followed was not the young man to resist an opportunity of having a companion . 
 
  Their sister ’s was exceedingly fond of George , who followed . George , who followed was Their sister ’s dear George on every occasion ; no one was to be put in competition with George , who followed . George , who followed did every thing best in the world ; and Their sister ’s was sure George , who followed would kill more birds on the first of September , than any body else in the country . 
 
  One morning , soon after the young couple visitors arrival , as Their sister ’s was sitting with Their sister ’s two elder sisters , Their sister ’s said to Elizabeth : 
 
  “ Elizabeth , Their sister ’s never gave Elizabeth an account of Their sister ’s wedding , Their sister ’s believe . Elizabeth were not by , when Their sister ’s told Mother and the others all about Their sister ’s wedding . Are not Elizabeth curious to hear how Their sister ’s wedding was managed ? ” 
 
  “ No really , ” replied Elizabeth ; “ Elizabeth think there can not be too little said on the subject . ” 
 
  “ La ! Their sister ’s are so strange ! But Their sister ’s must tell the young couple how Their sister ’s wedding went off . We were married , you know , at St. Clement ’s , because George , who followed lodgings were in St. Clement ’s . And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven o’clock . Their sister ’s uncle and aunt and Their sister ’s were to go together ; and the others were to meet We at the church . Well , Monday morning came , and Their sister ’s was in such a fuss ! Their sister ’s was so afraid , you know , that something would happen to put Their sister ’s wedding off , and then Their sister ’s should have gone quite distracted . And there was Their sister ’s aunt , all the time Their sister ’s was dressing , preaching and talking away just as if Their sister ’s aunt was reading a sermon . However , Their sister ’s did not hear above one word in ten , for Their sister ’s was thinking , Mother may suppose , of George , who followed . Their sister ’s longed to know whether George , who followed would be married in George , who followed blue coat . ” 
 
  “ Well , and so we breakfasted at ten as usual ; Their sister ’s thought it would never be over ; for , by the bye , the young couple are to understand , that Their sister ’s uncle and aunt were horrid unpleasant all the time Their sister ’s was with Their sister ’s uncle and aunt . If the young couple ’ll believe Their sister ’s , Their sister ’s did not once put Their sister ’s foot out of doors , though Their sister ’s was there a fortnight . Not one party , or scheme , or anything . To be sure London was rather thin , but , however , the Little Theatre was open . Well , and so just as the carriage came to the door , Their sister ’s uncle was called away upon business to that horrid man Mr. Stone . And then , you know , when once they get together , there is no end of it . Well , Their sister ’s was so frightened Their sister ’s did not know what to do , for Their sister ’s uncle was to give Their sister ’s away ; and if we were beyond the hour , we could not be married all day . But , luckily , Their sister ’s uncle came back again in ten minutes ’ time , and then we all set out . However , Their sister ’s recollected afterwards that if Their sister ’s uncle had been prevented going , Their sister ’s wedding need not be put off , for Fitzwilliam might have done as well . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ! ” repeated Elizabeth , in utter amazement . 
 
  “ Oh , yes!—he was to come there with George , who followed , you know . But gracious Their sister ’s ! Their sister ’s quite forgot ! Their sister ’s ought not to have said a word about it . Their sister ’s promised them so faithfully ! What will George , who followed say ? It was to be such a secret ! ” 
 
  “ If it was to be secret , ” said Jane , “ say not another word on the subject . Their sister ’s may depend upon Jane seeking no further . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! certainly , ” said Elizabeth , though burning with curiosity ; “ we will ask Their sister ’s no questions . ” 
 
  “ Thank Elizabeth , ” said Their sister ’s , “ for if Elizabeth did , Their sister ’s should certainly tell the young couple , and then George , who followed would be angry . ” 
 
  On such encouragement to ask , Elizabeth was forced to put it out of Elizabeth power , by running away . 
 
  But to live in ignorance on such a point was impossible ; or at least it was impossible not to try for information . Fitzwilliam had been at Their sister ’s wedding . It was exactly a scene , and exactly among people , where Fitzwilliam had apparently least to do , and least temptation to go . Conjectures as to the meaning of it , rapid and wild , hurried into Elizabeth brain ; but Elizabeth was satisfied with none . Those that best pleased Elizabeth , as placing Fitzwilliam conduct in the noblest light , seemed most improbable . Elizabeth could not bear such suspense ; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper , wrote a short letter to Elizabeth aunt , to request an explanation of what Their sister ’s had dropt , if an explanation of what Their sister ’s had dropt were compatible with the secrecy which had been intended . 
 
  “ the young couple may readily comprehend , ” Elizabeth added , “ what Elizabeth curiosity must be to know how a person unconnected with any of us , and ( comparatively speaking ) a stranger to our family , should have been amongst the young couple at such a time . Pray write instantly , and let Their sister ’s understand it — unless it is , for very cogent reasons , to remain in the secrecy which Their sister ’s seems to think necessary ; and then Their sister ’s must endeavour to be satisfied with ignorance . ” 
 
  “ Not that Their sister ’s shall , though , ” Their sister ’s added to Their sister ’s , as Their sister ’s finished a short letter ; “ and Their sister ’s aunt , if Their sister ’s aunt do not tell Their sister ’s in an honourable manner , Their sister ’s shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it out . ” 
 
  Jane ’s delicate sense of honour would not allow Jane to speak to Elizabeth privately of what Their sister ’s had let fall ; Elizabeth was glad of it;—till it appeared whether Elizabeth enquiries would receive any satisfaction , Elizabeth had rather be without a confidante . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to Elizabeth letter as soon as Elizabeth possibly could . Elizabeth was no sooner in possession of an answer to Elizabeth letter than , hurrying into the little copse , where Elizabeth was least likely to be interrupted , Elizabeth sat down on one of the benches and prepared to be happy ; for the length of Elizabeth letter convinced Elizabeth that Elizabeth letter did not contain a denial . 
 
  “ Gracechurch Street , Sept. 6 . 
 
  “ Elizabeth , 
 
  “ M. GARDINER have just received Elizabeth letter , and shall devote this whole morning to answering Elizabeth letter , as M. GARDINER foresee that a little writing will not comprise what M. GARDINER have to tell Elizabeth . M. GARDINER must confess M. GARDINER surprised by Elizabeth application ; M. GARDINER did not expect Elizabeth application from Elizabeth . Do n’t think M. If Elizabeth do not choose to understand M. GARDINER , forgive M. GARDINER impertinence . Elizabeth uncle is as much surprised as M. GARDINER am — and nothing but the belief of Elizabeth being a party concerned would have allowed Elizabeth uncle to act as Elizabeth uncle has done . But if Elizabeth are really innocent and ignorant , M. GARDINER must be more explicit . 
 
  “ On the very day of M. GARDINER coming home from Longbourn , Elizabeth uncle had a most unexpected visitor . Fitzwilliam called , and was shut up with Elizabeth uncle several hours . It was all over before M. GARDINER arrived ; so M. GARDINER curiosity was not so dreadfully racked as Elizabeth seems to have been . a most unexpected visitor came to tell Edward that a most unexpected visitor had found out where Elizabeth sister and Charlie were , and that a most unexpected visitor had seen and talked with Elizabeth sister and Charlie ; George repeatedly , Lydia once . From what M. GARDINER can collect , a most unexpected visitor left Derbyshire only one day after ourselves , and came to town with the resolution of hunting for Elizabeth sister and Charlie . The motive professed was a most unexpected visitor conviction of its being owing to a most unexpected visitor that George ’s worthlessness had not been so well known as to make it impossible for any young woman of character to love or confide in a most unexpected visitor . a most unexpected visitor generously imputed the whole to a most unexpected visitor mistaken pride , and confessed that a most unexpected visitor had before thought it beneath a most unexpected visitor to lay a most unexpected visitor private actions open to the world . a most unexpected visitor character was to speak for a most unexpected visitor character . a most unexpected visitor called it , therefore , a most unexpected visitor duty to step forward , and endeavour to remedy an evil which had been brought on by a most unexpected visitor . If a most unexpected visitor had another motive , M. GARDINER am sure another motive would never disgrace a most unexpected visitor . a most unexpected visitor had been some days in town , before a most unexpected visitor was able to discover Elizabeth sister and Charlie ; but a most unexpected visitor had something to direct a most unexpected visitor search , which was more than ourselves had ; and the consciousness of something to direct a most unexpected visitor search , which was more than ourselves had was another reason for a most unexpected visitor resolving to follow ourselves . 
 
  “ There is a lady , it seems , a Mrs. Younge , who was some time ago governess to Georgiana , and was dismissed from her charge on some cause of disapprobation , though a most unexpected visitor did not say what . This Mrs. Younge then took a large house in Edward - street , and has since maintained This Mrs. Younge by letting lodgings . This Mrs. Younge was , a most unexpected visitor knew , intimately acquainted with George ; and a most unexpected visitor went to This Mrs. Younge for intelligence of George as soon as a most unexpected visitor got to town . But it was two or three days before a most unexpected visitor could get from This Mrs. Younge what a most unexpected visitor wanted . This Mrs. Younge would not betray This Mrs. Younge trust , M. GARDINER suppose , without bribery and corruption , for This Mrs. Younge really did know where This Mrs. Younge friend was to be found . George indeed had gone to This Mrs. Younge on their first arrival in London , and had This Mrs. Younge been able to receive their into This Mrs. Younge house , their would have taken up their abode with This Mrs. Younge . At length , however , a most unexpected visitor procured the wished - for direction . They were in — — street . a most unexpected visitor saw George , and afterwards insisted on seeing Lydia . a most unexpected visitor first object with Lydia , a most unexpected visitor acknowledged , had been to persuade Lydia to quit Lydia present disgraceful situation , and return to Lydia friends as soon as Lydia friends could be prevailed on to receive Lydia , offering a most unexpected visitor assistance , as far as it would go . But a most unexpected visitor found Lydia absolutely resolved on remaining where Lydia was . Lydia cared for none of Lydia friends ; Lydia wanted no help of a most unexpected visitor ; Lydia would not hear of leaving George . Lydia was sure they should be married some time or other , and it did not much signify when . Since such were Lydia feelings , it only remained , a most unexpected visitor thought , to secure and expedite a marriage , which , in a most unexpected visitor very first conversation with George , a most unexpected visitor easily learnt had never been a most unexpected visitor design . a most unexpected visitor confessed a most unexpected visitor obliged to leave the regiment , on account of some debts of honour , which were very pressing ; and scrupled not to lay all the ill - consequences of Lydia ’s flight on Lydia own folly alone . a most unexpected visitor meant to resign a most unexpected visitor commission immediately ; and as to a most unexpected visitor future situation , a most unexpected visitor could conjecture very little about a most unexpected visitor future situation . George must go somewhere , but George did not know where , and George knew George should have nothing to live on . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam asked George why George had not married Elizabeth sister at once . Though George was not imagined to be very rich , Fitzwilliam would have been able to do something for George , and George situation must have been benefited by marriage . But Fitzwilliam found , in reply to this question , that George still cherished the hope of more effectually making George fortune by marriage in some other country . Under such circumstances , however , George was not likely to be proof against the temptation of immediate relief . 
 
  “ They met several times , for there was much to be discussed . George of course wanted more than George could get ; but at length was reduced to be reasonable .

Fitzwilliam did not leave Fitzwilliam name , and till the next day it was only known that Fitzwilliam had called on business . 
 
  “ On Saturday Fitzwilliam came again . George was gone , Elizabeth uncle at home , and , as M. GARDINER said before , they had a great deal of talk together . 
 
  “ They met again on Sunday , and then M. GARDINER saw Fitzwilliam too . It was not all settled before Monday : as soon as it was , the express was sent off to Longbourn . But ourselves visitor was very obstinate . M. GARDINER fancy , Elizabeth , that obstinacy is the real defect of Fitzwilliam character , after all . Fitzwilliam has been accused of many faults at different times , but this is the true one . Nothing was to be done that Fitzwilliam did not do Fitzwilliam ; though M. GARDINER am sure ( and M. GARDINER do not speak it to be thanked , therefore say nothing about it ) , Elizabeth uncle would most readily have settled the whole . 
 
  “ They battled it together for a long time , which was more than either the gentleman or lady concerned in it deserved . But at last Elizabeth uncle was forced to yield , and instead of being allowed to be of use to Elizabeth sister , was forced to put up with only having the probable credit of it , which went sorely against the grain ; and M. GARDINER really believe Elizabeth letter this morning gave Elizabeth uncle great pleasure , because Elizabeth letter this morning required an explanation that would rob Elizabeth uncle of Elizabeth uncle borrowed feathers , and give the praise where the praise was due . But , Elizabeth , this must go no farther than Elizabeth , or Jane at most . 
 
  “ Elizabeth know pretty well , M. GARDINER suppose , what has been done for the young people . a most unexpected visitor debts are to be paid , amounting , M. GARDINER believe , to considerably more than a thousand pounds , another thousand in addition to Lydia own settled upon Lydia , and a most unexpected visitor commission purchased . The reason why all this was to be done by him alone , was such as M. GARDINER have given above . It was owing to him alone , to him alone reserve and want of proper consideration , that George ’s character had been so misunderstood , and consequently that George had been received and noticed as George was . Perhaps there was some truth in this ; though M. GARDINER doubt whether him alone reserve , or anybody ’s reserve , can be answerable for the event . But in spite of all this fine talking , M. GARDINER dear Elizabeth , Elizabeth may rest perfectly assured that Elizabeth uncle would never have yielded , if we had not given him alone credit for another interest in the affair . 
 
  “ When all this was resolved on , George returned again to George friends , who were still staying at Pemberley ; but it was agreed that George should be in London once more when the wedding took place , and all money matters were then to receive the last finish . 
 
  “ M. GARDINER believe M. GARDINER have now told Elizabeth every thing . It is a relation which Elizabeth tell M. GARDINER is to give Elizabeth great surprise ; M. GARDINER hope at least a relation which Elizabeth tell M. GARDINER is to give Elizabeth great surprise will not afford Elizabeth any displeasure . Lydia came to us ; and George had constant admission to the house . George was exactly what George had been , when M. GARDINER knew George in Hertfordshire ; but M. GARDINER would not tell Elizabeth how little M. GARDINER was satisfied with Lydia behaviour while Lydia staid with us , if M. GARDINER had not perceived , by Jane ’s letter last Wednesday , that Lydia conduct on coming home was exactly of a piece with it , and therefore what M. GARDINER now tell Elizabeth can give Elizabeth no fresh pain . M. GARDINER talked to Lydia repeatedly in the most serious manner , representing to Lydia all the wickedness of what Lydia had done , and all the unhappiness Lydia had brought on Lydia family . If Lydia heard M. GARDINER , it was by good luck , for M. GARDINER am sure Lydia did not listen . M. GARDINER was sometimes quite provoked , but then M. GARDINER recollected M. GARDINER dear Elizabeth and Jane , and for Elizabeth sister and Charlie sakes had patience with Lydia . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam was punctual in Fitzwilliam return , and as Lydia informed Elizabeth , attended the wedding . Fitzwilliam dined with us the next day , and was to leave town again on Wednesday or Thursday . Will Elizabeth be very angry with M. GARDINER , M. GARDINER dear Elizabeth , if M. GARDINER take this opportunity of saying ( what M. GARDINER was never bold enough to say before ) how much M. GARDINER like Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam behaviour to us has , in every respect , been as pleasing as when us were in Derbyshire . Fitzwilliam understanding and opinions all please M. GARDINER ; Fitzwilliam wants nothing but a little more liveliness , and that , if Fitzwilliam marry prudently , Fitzwilliam wife may teach Fitzwilliam . M. GARDINER thought Fitzwilliam very sly;—he hardly ever mentioned Elizabeth name . But slyness seems the fashion . 
 
  “ Pray forgive M. GARDINER if M. GARDINER have been very presuming , or at least do not punish M. GARDINER so far as to exclude M. GARDINER from P. M. GARDINER shall never be quite happy till M. GARDINER have been all round the park . A low phaeton , with a nice little pair of ponies , would be the very thing . 
 
  “ But M. GARDINER must write no more . The children have been wanting M. GARDINER this half hour . 
 
  “ Elizabeth , very sincerely , 
  “ M. GARDINER . ” 
 
  The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits , in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the greatest share . The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had produced of what Fitzwilliam might have been doing to forward Elizabeth sister ’s match , which Elizabeth had feared to encourage as an exertion of goodness too great to be probable , and at the same time dreaded to be just , from the pain of obligation , were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true ! Fitzwilliam had followed them purposely to town , Fitzwilliam had taken on Fitzwilliam all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research ; in which supplication had been necessary to a woman whom Fitzwilliam must abominate and despise , and where Fitzwilliam was reduced to meet , frequently meet , reason with , persuade , and finally bribe , Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam always most wished to avoid , and whose very name it was punishment to Fitzwilliam to pronounce . Fitzwilliam had done all this for Elizabeth sister . Elizabeth heart did whisper that Fitzwilliam had done all this for Elizabeth . But whisper was a hope shortly checked by other considerations , and Elizabeth soon felt that even Elizabeth vanity was insufficient , when required to depend on Fitzwilliam affection for Elizabeth — for a woman who had already refused Fitzwilliam — as able to overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with George . George George ! Every kind of pride must revolt from the connection . George had , to be sure , done much . Elizabeth was ashamed to think how much . But George had given a reason for George interference , which asked no extraordinary stretch of belief . It was reasonable that George should feel George had been wrong ; George had liberality , and George had the means of exercising liberality ; and though Elizabeth would not place Elizabeth as George principal inducement , Elizabeth could , perhaps , believe that remaining partiality for Elizabeth might assist George endeavours in a cause where Elizabeth peace of mind must be materially concerned . It was painful , exceedingly painful , to know that they were under obligations to George . They owed the restoration of Lydia , Lydia character , every thing , to George . Oh ! how heartily did Elizabeth grieve over every ungracious sensation Elizabeth had ever encouraged , every saucy speech Elizabeth had ever directed towards George . For Elizabeth Elizabeth was humbled ; but Elizabeth was proud of George . Proud that in a cause of compassion and honour , George had been able to get the better of George . Elizabeth read over Elizabeth sister commendation of George again and again . Elizabeth sister commendation of George was hardly enough ; but Elizabeth sister commendation of George pleased Elizabeth . Elizabeth was even sensible of some pleasure , though mixed with regret , on finding how steadfastly both Elizabeth and Elizabeth uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted between Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth . 
 
  Elizabeth was roused from Elizabeth seat , and Elizabeth reflections , by some one ’s approach ; and before Elizabeth could strike into another path , Elizabeth was overtaken by George . 
 
  “ George am afraid George interrupt Elizabeth solitary ramble , Elizabeth ? ” said George , as George joined Elizabeth . 
 
  “ George certainly do , ” Elizabeth replied with a smile ; “ but it does not follow that the interruption must be unwelcome . ” 
 
  “ George should be sorry indeed , if interrupt were . they were always good friends ; and now they are better . ” 
 
  “ True . Are the others coming out ? ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth do not know . Mother and Lydia are going in the carriage to Meryton . And so , George dear sister , George find , from they uncle and aunt , that Elizabeth have actually seen Pemberley . ” 
 
  Elizabeth replied in the affirmative . 
 
  “ Elizabeth almost envy George the pleasure , and yet Elizabeth believe it would be too much for Elizabeth , or else Elizabeth could take it in Elizabeth way to Newcastle . And Elizabeth saw This Mrs. Younge , Elizabeth suppose ? Poor Reynolds , This Mrs. Younge was always very fond of Elizabeth . But of course This Mrs. Younge did not mention M. GARDINER name to George . ” 
 
  “ Yes , This Mrs. Younge did . ” 
 
  “ And what did This Mrs. Younge say ? ” 
 
  “ That George were gone into the regiment , and This Mrs. Younge was afraid had — not turned out well . At such a distance as that , you know , things are strangely misrepresented . ” 
 
  “ Certainly , ” George replied , biting George lips . Elizabeth hoped Elizabeth had silenced George ; but George soon afterwards said : 
 
  “ George was surprised to see Fitzwilliam in town last month . We passed each other several times . George wonder what Fitzwilliam can be doing there . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps preparing for Fitzwilliam marriage with Cathleen , ” said Elizabeth . “ It must be something particular , to take Fitzwilliam there at this time of year . ” 
 
  “ Undoubtedly . Did Elizabeth see Fitzwilliam while Elizabeth were at Lambton ? George thought George understood from the Gardiners that Elizabeth had . ” 
 
  “ Yes ; Fitzwilliam introduced us to Fitzwilliam sister . ” 
 
  “ And do Elizabeth like Cathleen ? ” 
 
  “ Very much . ” 
 
  “ George have heard , indeed , that Cathleen is uncommonly improved within this year or two . When George last saw Cathleen , Cathleen was not very promising . George am very glad Elizabeth liked Cathleen . George hope Cathleen will turn out well . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth dare say Cathleen will ; Cathleen has got over the most trying age . ” 
 
  “ Did Elizabeth go by the village of Kympton ? ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth do not recollect that Elizabeth did . ” 
 
  “ M. GARDINER mention the village of Kympton , because the village of Kympton is the living which M. GARDINER ought to have had . the village of Kympton the village of Kympton would have suited M. GARDINER in every respect . ” 
 
  “ How should M. GARDINER have liked making sermons ? ” 
 
  “ Exceedingly well . M. GARDINER should have considered making as part of M. GARDINER duty , and the exertion would soon have been nothing . One ought not to repine;—but , to be sure , it would have been such a thing for M. GARDINER ! The quiet , the retirement of such a life would have answered all M. GARDINER ideas of happiness ! But such a life was not to be . Did Elizabeth ever hear Fitzwilliam mention the circumstance , when Elizabeth were in Kent ? ”

  “ M. GARDINER did ! and declared was not wholly without foundation . George may remember what M. GARDINER told George on that point , when first we talked of that point . ” 
 
  They were now almost at the door of the house , for Elizabeth had walked fast to get rid of a most unexpected visitor ; and unwilling , for Elizabeth sake , to provoke a most unexpected visitor , Elizabeth only said in reply , with a good - humoured smile : 
 
  “ Come , Charlie , They are brother and sister , George know . Do not let They quarrel about the past . In future , Elizabeth hope They shall be always of one mind . ” 
 
  Elizabeth held out Elizabeth hand ; a most unexpected visitor kissed Elizabeth hand with affectionate gallantry , though a most unexpected visitor hardly knew how to look , and they entered the house . 
 Chapter 
 
  Charlie was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation that Charlie never again distressed Charlie , or provoked Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , by introducing the subject of this conversation ; and Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was pleased to find that Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had said enough to keep Charlie quiet .

Mother was quite in the fidgets . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth looked at Jane , and smiled and shook Charlie dear sister Elizabeth head by turns .

  “ Charlie dear sister Elizabeth may depend on it , ” replied the other , “ for Mrs. Nicholls was in Meryton last night ; the other saw Mrs. Nicholls passing by , and went out the other on purpose to know the truth of it ; and Mrs. Nicholls told the other that it was certain true . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth must feel it ; and the usual satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , because Charlie dear sister Elizabeth have always so much . ” 
 
  Charlie arrived .  Chapter 
 
  As soon as the gentlemen were gone , Elizabeth walked out to recover Elizabeth spirits ; or in other words , to dwell without interruption on those subjects that must deaden them more . Fitzwilliam ’s behaviour astonished and vexed Elizabeth .

  On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn ; and the two who were most anxiously expected , to the credit of the two who were most anxiously expected , to the credit of punctuality as sportsmen , were in very good time . Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed placed Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed by Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed .
