  “ What did Elizabeth say of Elizabeth , that Elizabeth did not deserve ? For , though Elizabeth accusations were ill - founded , formed on mistaken premises , Elizabeth behaviour to Elizabeth at the time had merited the severest reproof . Elizabeth behaviour to Elizabeth at the time was unpardonable . Elizabeth can not think of Elizabeth behaviour to Elizabeth at the time without abhorrence . ” 
 
  “ We will not quarrel for the greater share of blame annexed to that evening , ” said Elizabeth . “ The conduct of neither , if strictly examined , will be irreproachable ; but since then , we have both , Elizabeth hope , improved in civility . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth can not be so easily reconciled to Elizabeth . The recollection of what Elizabeth then said , of Elizabeth conduct , Elizabeth manners , Elizabeth expressions during the whole of it , is now , and has been many months , inexpressibly painful to Elizabeth . Elizabeth reproof , so well applied , Elizabeth shall never forget : ‘ had Elizabeth behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner . ’ Those were Elizabeth words . Fitzwilliam know not , Fitzwilliam can scarcely conceive , how Elizabeth words have tortured me;—though it was some time , Elizabeth confess , before Elizabeth was reasonable enough to allow Elizabeth words justice . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth was certainly very far from expecting Elizabeth words to make so strong an impression . Elizabeth had not the smallest idea of Elizabeth words being ever felt in such a way . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam can easily believe it . Elizabeth thought Elizabeth then devoid of every proper feeling , Fitzwilliam am sure Elizabeth did . The turn of Elizabeth countenance Elizabeth shall never forget , as Elizabeth said that Elizabeth could not have addressed Elizabeth in any possible way that would induce Elizabeth to accept Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! do not repeat what Elizabeth then said . These recollections will not do at all . Elizabeth assure Fitzwilliam that Elizabeth have long been most heartily ashamed of These recollections . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam mentioned Fitzwilliam letter . “ Did Fitzwilliam letter , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ did Fitzwilliam letter soon make Elizabeth think better of Fitzwilliam ? Did Elizabeth , on reading Fitzwilliam letter , give any credit to Fitzwilliam letter contents ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth explained what Fitzwilliam letter effect on Elizabeth had been , and how gradually all Elizabeth former prejudices had been removed . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam knew , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ that what Fitzwilliam wrote must give Elizabeth pain , but Fitzwilliam letter was necessary . Fitzwilliam hope Elizabeth have destroyed Fitzwilliam letter . There was one part especially , the opening of Fitzwilliam letter , which Fitzwilliam should dread Elizabeth having the power of reading again . Fitzwilliam can remember some expressions which might justly make Elizabeth hate Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam letter shall certainly be burnt , if Elizabeth believe Fitzwilliam letter essential to the preservation of Fitzwilliam regard ; but , though we have both reason to think Fitzwilliam opinions not entirely unalterable , Fitzwilliam opinions are not , Fitzwilliam hope , quite so easily changed as are implies . ” 
 
  “ When Fitzwilliam wrote Fitzwilliam letter , ” replied Fitzwilliam , “ Fitzwilliam believed Fitzwilliam perfectly calm and cool , but Fitzwilliam am since convinced that Fitzwilliam letter was written in a dreadful bitterness of spirit . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam letter , perhaps , began in bitterness , but Fitzwilliam letter did not end so . The adieu is charity itself . But think no more of Fitzwilliam letter . The feelings of the person who wrote , and the person who received Fitzwilliam letter , are now so widely different from what The feelings of the person who wrote , and the person who received Fitzwilliam letter were then , that every unpleasant circumstance attending Fitzwilliam letter ought to be forgotten . Elizabeth must learn some of Fitzwilliam philosophy . Think only of the past as the past remembrance gives Elizabeth pleasure . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam can not give Elizabeth credit for any philosophy of the kind . Elizabeth retrospections must be so totally void of reproach , that the contentment arising from Elizabeth retrospections is not of philosophy , but , what is much better , of innocence . But with Fitzwilliam , it is not so . Painful recollections will intrude which can not , which ought not , to be repelled . Fitzwilliam have been a selfish being all Fitzwilliam life , in practice , though not in principle . As a child Fitzwilliam was taught what was right , but Fitzwilliam was not taught to correct Fitzwilliam temper . Fitzwilliam was given good principles , but left to follow good principles in pride and conceit . Unfortunately an only son ( for many years an only child ) , Fitzwilliam was spoilt by Fitzwilliam parents , who , though good Fitzwilliam parents , who , though good ( Fitzwilliam father , particularly , all that was benevolent and amiable ) , allowed , encouraged , almost taught Fitzwilliam to be selfish and overbearing ; to care for none beyond Fitzwilliam own family circle ; to think meanly of all the rest of the world ; to wish at least to think meanly of all the rest of the world sense and worth compared with Fitzwilliam own . Such Fitzwilliam was , from eight to eight and twenty ; and such Fitzwilliam might still have been but for Elizabeth , dearest , loveliest Elizabeth ! What do Fitzwilliam not owe Elizabeth ! Elizabeth taught Fitzwilliam a lesson , hard indeed at first , but most advantageous . By Elizabeth , Fitzwilliam was properly humbled . Fitzwilliam came to Elizabeth without a doubt of Fitzwilliam reception . Elizabeth showed Fitzwilliam how insufficient were all Fitzwilliam pretensions to please a woman worthy of being pleased . ” 
 
  “ Had Elizabeth then persuaded Elizabeth that Elizabeth should ? ” 
 
  “ Indeed Elizabeth had . What will Elizabeth think of Elizabeth vanity ? Elizabeth believed Elizabeth to be wishing , expecting Elizabeth addresses . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth manners must have been in fault , but not intentionally , Elizabeth assure Elizabeth . Elizabeth never meant to deceive Elizabeth , but Elizabeth spirits might often lead Elizabeth wrong . How Elizabeth must have hated Fitzwilliam after that evening ? ” 
 
  “ Hate Fitzwilliam ! Elizabeth was angry perhaps at first , but Elizabeth anger soon began to take a proper direction . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth am almost afraid of asking what Elizabeth thought of Elizabeth , when They met at Pemberley . Elizabeth blamed Elizabeth for coming ? ” 
 
  “ No indeed ; Elizabeth felt nothing but surprise . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth surprise could not be greater than Elizabeth in being noticed by Elizabeth . Elizabeth conscience told Elizabeth that Elizabeth deserved no extraordinary politeness , and Elizabeth confess that Elizabeth did not expect to receive more than Elizabeth due . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam object then , ” replied Fitzwilliam , “ was to show Elizabeth , by every civility in Fitzwilliam power , that Fitzwilliam was not so mean as to resent the past ; and Fitzwilliam hoped to obtain Elizabeth forgiveness , to lessen Elizabeth ill opinion , by letting Elizabeth see that Elizabeth reproofs had been attended to . How soon any other wishes introduced any other wishes Fitzwilliam can hardly tell , but Fitzwilliam believe in about half an hour after Fitzwilliam had seen Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam then told Elizabeth of Georgiana ’s delight in Georgiana ’s acquaintance , and of Georgiana ’s disappointment at Georgiana ’s acquaintance sudden interruption ; which naturally leading to the cause of Georgiana ’s acquaintance sudden interruption , Georgiana ’s soon learnt that Fitzwilliam resolution of following Georgiana ’s from Derbyshire in quest of Georgiana ’s sister had been formed before Fitzwilliam quitted the inn , and that Fitzwilliam gravity and thoughtfulness there had arisen from no other struggles than what such a purpose must comprehend . 
 
  Elizabeth expressed Elizabeth gratitude again , but it was too painful a subject to each , to be dwelt on farther . 
 
  After walking several miles in a leisurely manner , and too busy to know anything about it , they found at last , on examining They watches , that it was time to be at home . 
 
  “ What could become of Charles and Jane ! ” was a wonder which introduced the discussion of Charles and Jane affairs . Fitzwilliam was delighted with Charles and Jane engagement ; Fitzwilliam friend had given Fitzwilliam the earliest information of Charles and Jane engagement . 
 
  “ Elizabeth must ask whether Fitzwilliam were surprised ? ” said Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Not at all . When Fitzwilliam went away , Fitzwilliam felt that Charles and Jane engagement would soon happen . ” 
 
  “ That is to say , Fitzwilliam had given Fitzwilliam permission . Elizabeth guessed as much . ” And though Fitzwilliam exclaimed at the term , Elizabeth found that it had been pretty much the case . 
 
  “ On the evening before Fitzwilliam going to London , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ Fitzwilliam made a confession to Charles , which Fitzwilliam believe Fitzwilliam ought to have made long ago . Fitzwilliam told Charles of all that had occurred to make Fitzwilliam former interference in Charles affairs absurd and impertinent . Charles surprise was great . Charles had never had the slightest suspicion . Fitzwilliam told Charles , moreover , that Fitzwilliam believed Fitzwilliam mistaken in supposing , as Fitzwilliam had done , that Elizabeth sister was indifferent to Charles ; and as Fitzwilliam could easily perceive that Charles attachment to Jane was unabated , Fitzwilliam felt no doubt of Charles and Jane happiness together . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could not help smiling at Fitzwilliam easy manner of directing Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Did Fitzwilliam speak from Fitzwilliam own observation , ” said Elizabeth , “ when Fitzwilliam told Charles that Jane loved Charles , or merely from Elizabeth information last spring ? ” 
 
  “ From the former . Fitzwilliam had narrowly observed Jane during the two visits which Fitzwilliam had lately made here ; and Fitzwilliam was convinced of Jane affection . ” 
 
  “ And Fitzwilliam assurance of Jane affection , Elizabeth suppose , carried immediate conviction to Charles . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam assurance of Jane affection did . Charles is most unaffectedly modest . Charles diffidence had prevented Charles depending on Charles own judgment in so anxious a case , but Charles reliance on Fitzwilliam made every thing easy . Fitzwilliam was obliged to confess one thing , which for a time , and not unjustly , offended Charles . Fitzwilliam could not allow Fitzwilliam to conceal that Elizabeth sister had been in town three months last winter , that Fitzwilliam had known been , and purposely kept been from Charles . Charles was angry . But Charles anger , Fitzwilliam am persuaded , lasted no longer than Charles remained in any doubt of Elizabeth sister ’s sentiments . Charles has heartily forgiven Fitzwilliam now . ” 
 
  Elizabeth longed to observe that Charles had been a most delightful friend ; so easily guided that Charles worth was invaluable ; but Elizabeth checked Elizabeth . Elizabeth remembered that Charles had yet to learn to be laughed at , and it was rather too early to begin . In anticipating the happiness of Charles , which of course was to be inferior only to Fitzwilliam own , Fitzwilliam continued the conversation till they reached the house . In the hall they parted . 
 Chapter 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth , where can Jane dear Elizabeth have been walking to ? ” was a question which Jane dear Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as Jane dear Elizabeth entered their room , and from all the others when their sat down to table . Jane dear Elizabeth had only to say in reply , that their had wandered about , till Jane dear Elizabeth was beyond Jane dear Elizabeth own knowledge . Jane dear Elizabeth coloured as Jane dear Elizabeth spoke ; but neither coloured , nor anything else , awakened a suspicion of the truth . 
 
  The evening passed quietly , unmarked by anything extraordinary . The acknowledged lovers talked and laughed , the unacknowledged were silent . Fitzwilliam was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth ; and Jane dear Elizabeth , agitated and confused , rather knew that Jane dear Elizabeth was happy than felt Jane dear Elizabeth to be so ; for , besides the immediate embarrassment , there were other evils before Jane dear Elizabeth . Jane dear Elizabeth anticipated what would be felt in the family when Jane dear Elizabeth situation became known ; Jane dear Elizabeth was aware that no one liked Fitzwilliam but Jane ; and even feared that with the others it was a dislike which not all Fitzwilliam fortune and consequence might do away . 
 
  At night Jane dear Elizabeth opened Jane dear Elizabeth heart to Jane . Though suspicion was very far from Miss Bennet ’s general habits , Miss Bennet ’s was absolutely incredulous here . 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth are joking , Jane dear Elizabeth . This can not be!—engaged to Fitzwilliam ! No , no , Jane dear Elizabeth shall not deceive Miss Bennet ’s . Miss Bennet ’s know This to be impossible . ” 
 
  “ This is a wretched beginning indeed ! Jane dear Elizabeth sole dependence was on Jane ; and Jane dear Elizabeth am sure nobody else will believe Jane dear Elizabeth , if Jane do not . Yet , indeed , Jane dear Elizabeth am in earnest . Jane dear Elizabeth speak nothing but the truth . Fitzwilliam still loves Jane dear Elizabeth , and their are engaged . ” 
 
  Jane looked at Jane dear Elizabeth doubtingly . “ Oh , Jane dear Elizabeth ! it can not be . Miss Bennet ’s know how much Jane dear Elizabeth dislike Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet ’s know nothing of the matter . That is all to be forgot . Perhaps Jane dear Elizabeth did not always love Fitzwilliam so well as Jane dear Elizabeth do now . But in such cases as these , a good memory is unpardonable . This is the last time Jane dear Elizabeth shall ever remember it Jane dear Elizabeth . ” Miss Bennet ’s Miss Bennet ’s still looked all amazement . Jane dear Elizabeth again , and more seriously assured Miss Bennet ’s of its truth . 
 
  “ Good Heaven ! can it be really so ! Yet now Jane must believe Jane dear Elizabeth , ” cried Jane . “ Jane dear Elizabeth , Miss Bennet ’s would — Miss Bennet ’s do congratulate Jane dear Elizabeth — but are Jane dear Elizabeth certain ? forgive the question — are Jane dear Elizabeth quite certain that Jane dear Elizabeth can be happy with Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ There can be no doubt of be . It is settled between their already , that their are to be the happiest couple in the world . But are Jane pleased , Jane ? Shall Jane like to have such a brother ? ” 
 
  “ Very , very much . Nothing could give either Fitzwilliam or Jane more delight . But we considered it , we talked of it as impossible . And do Jane dear Elizabeth really love Fitzwilliam quite well enough ? Oh , Jane dear Elizabeth ! do anything rather than marry without affection . Are Jane dear Elizabeth quite sure that Jane dear Elizabeth feel what Jane dear Elizabeth ought to do ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , yes ! Miss Bennet ’s will only think Jane dear Elizabeth feel more than Jane dear Elizabeth ought to do , when Jane dear Elizabeth tell Miss Bennet ’s all . ” 
 
  “ What do Jane dear Elizabeth mean ? ” 
 
  “ Why , Jane dear Elizabeth must confess that Jane dear Elizabeth love Fitzwilliam better than Jane dear Elizabeth do Fitzwilliam . Jane dear Elizabeth am afraid Miss Bennet ’s will be angry . ” 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth , now be serious . Miss Bennet ’s want to talk very seriously . Let Miss Bennet ’s know every thing that Miss Bennet ’s am to know , without delay . Will Jane dear Elizabeth tell Miss Bennet ’s how long Jane dear Elizabeth have loved Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ loved has been coming on so gradually , that Jane dear Elizabeth hardly know when loved began . But Jane dear Elizabeth believe Jane dear Elizabeth must date loved from Jane dear Elizabeth first seeing Fitzwilliam beautiful grounds at Pemberley . ” 
 
  Another entreaty that Jane dear Elizabeth would be serious , however , produced the desired effect ; and Jane dear Elizabeth soon satisfied Jane by Jane dear Elizabeth solemn assurances of attachment . When convinced on that article , Miss Bennet ’s had nothing further to wish . 
 
  “ Now Miss Bennet ’s am quite happy , ” said Miss Bennet ’s , “ for Jane dear Elizabeth will be as happy as Miss Bennet ’s . Miss Bennet ’s always had a value for Fitzwilliam . Were it for nothing but Fitzwilliam love of Jane dear Elizabeth , Miss Bennet ’s must always have esteemed Fitzwilliam ; but now , as Fitzwilliam friend and Jane dear Elizabeth husband , there can be only Charles and Jane dear Elizabeth more dear to Miss Bennet ’s . But Jane dear Elizabeth , Jane dear Elizabeth have been very sly , very reserved with Miss Bennet ’s . How little did Jane dear Elizabeth tell Miss Bennet ’s of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton ! Miss Bennet ’s owe all that Miss Bennet ’s know of it to another , not to Jane dear Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth told Miss Bennet ’s the motives of Jane dear Elizabeth secrecy . Jane dear Elizabeth had been unwilling to mention Fitzwilliam ; and the unsettled state of Jane dear Elizabeth own feelings had made Jane dear Elizabeth equally avoid the name of Fitzwilliam friend . But now Jane dear Elizabeth would no longer conceal from Miss Bennet ’s Fitzwilliam share in Lydia ’s marriage . All was acknowledged , and half the night spent in conversation . 
 
  “ Good gracious ! ” cried Miss Bennet ’s , as Miss Bennet ’s stood at a window the next morning , “ if that disagreeable Fitzwilliam is not coming here again with our dear Charles ! What can Fitzwilliam mean by being so tiresome as to be always coming here ? Miss Bennet ’s had no notion but Fitzwilliam would go a - shooting , or something or other , and not disturb our with Fitzwilliam company . What shall our do with Fitzwilliam ? Jane dear Elizabeth , Jane dear Elizabeth must walk out with Fitzwilliam again , that Fitzwilliam may not be in Fitzwilliam way . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal ; yet was really vexed that Miss Bennet ’s should be always giving Fitzwilliam such an epithet . 
 
  As soon as they entered , Fitzwilliam looked at Jane dear Elizabeth so expressively , and shook hands with such warmth , as left no doubt of Fitzwilliam good information ; and Fitzwilliam soon afterwards said aloud , “ Miss Bennet ’s , have Miss Bennet ’s no more lanes hereabouts in which Jane dear Elizabeth may lose Jane dear Elizabeth way again to - day ? ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet ’s advise Fitzwilliam , and Jane dear Elizabeth , and Kitty , ” said Miss Bennet ’s , “ to walk to Oakham Mount this morning . walk is a nice long walk , and Fitzwilliam has never seen the view . ” 
 
  “ walk may do very well for Fitzwilliam , and Jane dear Elizabeth , and Kitty , ” replied Fitzwilliam ; “ but Fitzwilliam am sure walk will be too much for Kitty . Wo n’t it , Kitty ? ” Kitty owned that Kitty had rather stay at home . Fitzwilliam professed a great curiosity to see the view from Oakham Mount , and Jane dear Elizabeth silently consented . As Jane dear Elizabeth went up stairs to get ready , Miss Bennet ’s followed Jane dear Elizabeth , saying : 
 
  “ Miss Bennet ’s am quite sorry , Jane dear Elizabeth , that Jane dear Elizabeth should be forced to have Fitzwilliam all to Jane dear Elizabeth . But Miss Bennet ’s hope Jane dear Elizabeth will not mind have : it is all for Jane ’s sake , Jane dear Elizabeth know ; and there is no occasion for talking to Fitzwilliam , except just now and then . So , do not put Jane dear Elizabeth to inconvenience . ” 
 
  During their walk , it was resolved that Father ’s consent should be asked in the course of the evening . Jane dear Elizabeth reserved to Jane dear Elizabeth the application for Miss Bennet ’s . Jane dear Elizabeth could not determine how Jane dear Elizabeth mother would take the application for Miss Bennet ’s ; sometimes doubting whether all Fitzwilliam wealth and grandeur would be enough to overcome Miss Bennet ’s abhorrence of Fitzwilliam . But whether Jane dear Elizabeth were violently set against the match , or violently delighted with the match , it was certain that Jane dear Elizabeth manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit to Jane dear Elizabeth sense ; and Jane dear Elizabeth could no more bear that Fitzwilliam should hear the first raptures of Jane dear Elizabeth joy , than the first vehemence of Jane dear Elizabeth disapprobation . 
 
  In the evening , soon after Father ’s withdrew to the library , Jane dear Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam rise also and follow Father ’s , and Jane dear Elizabeth agitation on seeing it was extreme . Jane dear Elizabeth did not fear Jane dear Elizabeth father ’s opposition , but Father ’s was going to be made unhappy ; and that it should be through Jane dear Elizabeth means — that Jane dear Elizabeth , should be distressing Father ’s by Jane dear Elizabeth choice , should be filling Father ’s with fears and regrets in disposing of Jane dear Elizabeth — was a wretched reflection , and Jane dear Elizabeth sat in misery till Fitzwilliam appeared again , when , looking at Fitzwilliam , Jane dear Elizabeth was a little relieved by Fitzwilliam smile . In a few minutes Fitzwilliam approached the table where Jane dear Elizabeth was sitting with Kitty ; and , while pretending to admire Jane dear Elizabeth work said in a whisper , “ Go to Jane dear Elizabeth father , Father ’s wants Jane dear Elizabeth in the library . ” Jane dear Elizabeth was gone directly . 
 
  Father ’s was walking about the room , looking grave and anxious . “ Jane dear Elizabeth , ” said Father ’s , “ what are Jane dear Elizabeth doing ? Are Jane dear Elizabeth out of Jane dear Elizabeth senses , to be accepting Fitzwilliam ? Have not Jane dear Elizabeth always hated Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  How earnestly did Jane dear Elizabeth then wish that Jane dear Elizabeth former opinions had been more reasonable , Jane dear Elizabeth expressions more moderate ! It would have spared Jane dear Elizabeth from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give ; but explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give were now necessary , and Jane dear Elizabeth assured Father ’s , with some confusion , of Jane dear Elizabeth attachment to Fitzwilliam . 
 
  “ Or , in other words , Jane dear Elizabeth are determined to have Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam is rich , to be sure , and Jane dear Elizabeth may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane . But will more fine clothes and fine carriages make Jane dear Elizabeth happy ? ” 
 
  “ Have Father ’s any other objection , ” said Jane dear Elizabeth , “ than Father ’s belief of Jane dear Elizabeth indifference ? ” 
 
  “ None at all . We all know Fitzwilliam to be a proud , unpleasant sort of man ; but this would be nothing if Jane dear Elizabeth really liked Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth do , Jane dear Elizabeth do like Fitzwilliam , ” Jane dear Elizabeth replied , with tears in Jane dear Elizabeth eyes , “ Jane dear Elizabeth love Fitzwilliam . Indeed Fitzwilliam has no improper pride . Fitzwilliam is perfectly amiable . Father ’s do not know what Fitzwilliam really is ; then pray do not pain Jane dear Elizabeth by speaking of Fitzwilliam in such terms . ” 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth , ” said Father ’s , “ Father ’s have given Fitzwilliam Father ’s consent . Fitzwilliam is the kind of man , indeed , to whom Father ’s should never dare refuse anything , which Fitzwilliam condescended to ask . Father ’s now give it to Jane dear Elizabeth , if Jane dear Elizabeth are resolved on having Fitzwilliam . But let Father ’s advise Jane dear Elizabeth to think better of it . Father ’s know Jane dear Elizabeth disposition , Jane dear Elizabeth . Father ’s know that Jane dear Elizabeth could be neither happy nor respectable , unless Jane dear Elizabeth truly esteemed Fitzwilliam ; unless Jane dear Elizabeth looked up to Fitzwilliam as a superior . Jane dear Elizabeth lively talents would place Jane dear Elizabeth in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage . Jane dear Elizabeth could scarcely escape discredit and misery . Jane dear Elizabeth , let Father ’s not have the grief of seeing Jane dear Elizabeth unable to respect Jane dear Elizabeth partner in life . Jane dear Elizabeth know not what Jane dear Elizabeth are about . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth , was earnest and solemn in Jane dear Elizabeth reply ; and at length , by repeated assurances that Fitzwilliam was really the object of Jane dear Elizabeth choice , by explaining the gradual change which Jane dear Elizabeth estimation of Fitzwilliam had undergone , relating Jane dear Elizabeth absolute certainty that Fitzwilliam affection was not the work of a day , but had stood the test of many months ’ suspense , and enumerating with energy all Fitzwilliam good qualities , Jane dear Elizabeth did conquer Jane dear Elizabeth father ’s incredulity , and reconcile Father ’s to the match . 
 
  “ Well , Father ’s dear , ” said Father ’s , when Jane dear Elizabeth ceased speaking , “ Father ’s have no more to say . If this be the case , Fitzwilliam deserves Jane dear Elizabeth . Father ’s could not have parted with Jane dear Elizabeth , Jane dear Elizabeth , to anyone less worthy . ” 
 
  To complete the favourable impression , Jane dear Elizabeth then told Father ’s what Fitzwilliam had voluntarily done for Lydia ’s . Father ’s heard Jane dear Elizabeth with astonishment . 
 
  “ This is an evening of wonders , indeed ! And so , Fitzwilliam did every thing ; made up the match , gave the money , paid Fitzwilliam debts , and got Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam commission ! So much the better . It will save Father ’s a world of trouble and economy . Had it been Jane dear Elizabeth uncle ’s doing , Father ’s must and would have paid Jane dear Elizabeth uncle ’s ; but these violent young lovers carry every thing these violent young lovers own way . Father ’s shall offer to pay Fitzwilliam to - morrow ; Fitzwilliam will rant and storm about Fitzwilliam love for Jane dear Elizabeth , and there will be an end of the matter . ” 
 
  Father ’s then recollected Jane dear Elizabeth embarrassment a few days before , on Father ’s reading William Collins ’s letter ; and after laughing at Jane dear Elizabeth some time , allowed Jane dear Elizabeth at last to go — saying , as Miss Bennet ’s quitted the room , “ If any young men come for Mary or Kitty , send any young men in , for Miss Bennet ’s am quite at leisure . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight ; and , after half an hour ’s quiet reflection in Jane dear Elizabeth own room , Jane dear Elizabeth was able to join the others with tolerable composure . Every thing was too recent for gaiety , but the evening passed tranquilly away ; there was no longer anything material to be dreaded , and the comfort of ease and familiarity would come in time . 
 
  When Miss Bennet ’s went up to Miss Bennet ’s dressing - room at night , Jane dear Elizabeth followed Miss Bennet ’s , and made the important communication . the important communication effect was most extraordinary ; for on first hearing the important communication , Miss Bennet ’s sat quite still , and unable to utter a syllable . Nor was it under many , many minutes that Miss Bennet ’s could comprehend what Miss Bennet ’s heard ; though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of the family , or that came in the shape of a lover to any of the family . Miss Bennet ’s began at length to recover , to fidget about in Miss Bennet ’s chair , get up , sit down again , wonder , and bless Miss Bennet ’s . 
 
  “ Good gracious ! Father ’s bless Miss Bennet ’s ! only think ! dear Miss Bennet ’s ! Fitzwilliam ! Who would have thought it ! And is it really true ? Oh ! Jane dear Elizabeth ! how rich and how great Jane dear Elizabeth will be ! What pin - money , what jewels , what carriages Jane dear Elizabeth will have ! Jane ’s is nothing to it — nothing at all . Miss Bennet ’s am so pleased — so happy . Such a charming man!—so handsome ! so tall!—Oh , Miss Bennet ’s dear Elizabeth ! pray apologise for Miss Bennet ’s having disliked Fitzwilliam so much before . Miss Bennet ’s hope Fitzwilliam will overlook disliked . Jane dear Elizabeth A house in town ! Every thing that is charming ! Three daughters married ! Ten thousand a year ! Oh , Lord ! What will become of Jane dear Elizabeth . Jane dear Elizabeth shall go distracted . ” 
 
  This was enough to prove that Miss Bennet ’s approbation need not be doubted : and Jane dear Elizabeth , rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by Jane dear Elizabeth , soon went away . But before Jane dear Elizabeth had been three minutes in Jane dear Elizabeth own room , Jane dear Elizabeth mother followed Jane dear Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth , ” Miss Bennet ’s cried , “ Miss Bennet ’s can think of nothing else ! Ten thousand a year , and very likely more ! ’ Tis as good as a Lord ! And a special licence . Jane dear Elizabeth must and shall be married by a special licence . But Jane dear Elizabeth , tell Miss Bennet ’s what dish Fitzwilliam is particularly fond of , that Miss Bennet ’s may have it to - morrow . ” 
 
  This was a sad omen of what Jane dear Elizabeth mother ’s behaviour to Fitzwilliam might be ; and Jane dear Elizabeth found that , though in the certain possession of Fitzwilliam warmest affection , and secure of Jane dear Elizabeth relations ’ consent , there was still something to be wished for . But the morrow passed off much better than Jane dear Elizabeth expected ; for Miss Bennet ’s luckily stood in such awe of Fitzwilliam that Miss Bennet ’s ventured not to speak to Fitzwilliam , unless it was in Miss Bennet ’s power to offer Fitzwilliam any attention , or mark Miss Bennet ’s deference for Fitzwilliam opinion . 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing Jane dear Elizabeth father taking pains to get acquainted with Fitzwilliam ; and Father ’s soon assured Jane dear Elizabeth that Father ’s was rising every hour in Father ’s esteem . 
 
  “ Father ’s admire all Father ’s three sons - in - law highly , ” said Father ’s . “ Fitzwilliam , perhaps , is Father ’s favourite ; but Father ’s think Father ’s shall like Fitzwilliam quite as well as Jane ’s . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth ’s spirits soon rising to playfulness again , Elizabeth ’s wanted Fitzwilliam to account for Fitzwilliam having ever fallen in love with Elizabeth ’s . “ How could Fitzwilliam begin ? ” said Elizabeth ’s . “ Elizabeth ’s can comprehend Fitzwilliam going on charmingly , when Fitzwilliam had once made a beginning ; but what could set Fitzwilliam off in the first place ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam can not fix on the hour , or the spot , or the look , or the words , which laid the foundation . It is too long ago . Fitzwilliam was in the middle before Fitzwilliam knew that Fitzwilliam had begun . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam beauty Fitzwilliam had early withstood , and as for Fitzwilliam manners — Fitzwilliam behaviour to Fitzwilliam was at least always bordering on the uncivil , and Fitzwilliam never spoke to Fitzwilliam without rather wishing to give Fitzwilliam pain than not . Now be sincere ; did Fitzwilliam admire Fitzwilliam for Fitzwilliam impertinence ? ” 
 
  “ For the liveliness of Elizabeth ’s mind , Fitzwilliam did . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam may as well call Fitzwilliam impertinence impertinence at once . Fitzwilliam impertinence was very little less . The fact is , that Fitzwilliam were sick of civility , of deference , of officious attention . Fitzwilliam were disgusted with the women who were always speaking , and looking , and thinking for Fitzwilliam approbation alone . Fitzwilliam roused , and interested Fitzwilliam , because Fitzwilliam was so unlike the women who were always speaking , and looking , and thinking for Fitzwilliam approbation alone . Had Fitzwilliam not been really amiable , Fitzwilliam would have hated Fitzwilliam for it ; but in spite of the pains Fitzwilliam took to disguise Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam feelings were always noble and just ; and in Fitzwilliam heart , Fitzwilliam thoroughly despised the persons who so assiduously courted Fitzwilliam . There — Fitzwilliam have saved Fitzwilliam the trouble of accounting for it ; and really , all things considered , Fitzwilliam begin to think it perfectly reasonable . To be sure , Fitzwilliam knew no actual good of Fitzwilliam — but nobody thinks of that when nobody fall in love . ” 
 
  “ Was there no good in Fitzwilliam affectionate behaviour to Jane while Jane was ill at Netherfield ? ” 
 
  “ Dearest Jane ! who could have done less for Jane ? But make a virtue of it by all means . Fitzwilliam good qualities are under Fitzwilliam protection , and Fitzwilliam are to exaggerate Fitzwilliam good qualities as much as possible ; and , in return , it belongs to Fitzwilliam to find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with Fitzwilliam as often as may be ; and Fitzwilliam shall begin directly by asking Fitzwilliam what made Fitzwilliam so unwilling to come to the point at last . What made Fitzwilliam so shy of Fitzwilliam , when Fitzwilliam first called , and afterwards dined here ? Why , especially , when Fitzwilliam called , did Fitzwilliam look as if Fitzwilliam did not care about Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ Because Fitzwilliam were grave and silent , and gave Fitzwilliam no encouragement . ” 
 
  “ But Fitzwilliam was embarrassed . ” 
 
  “ And so was I. ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam might have talked to Fitzwilliam more when Fitzwilliam came to dinner . ” 
 
  “ A man who had felt less , might . ” 
 
  “ How unlucky that Fitzwilliam should have a reasonable answer to give , and that Fitzwilliam should be so reasonable as to admit it ! But Fitzwilliam wonder how long Fitzwilliam would have gone on , if Fitzwilliam had been left to Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam wonder when Fitzwilliam would have spoken , if Fitzwilliam had not asked Fitzwilliam ! Fitzwilliam resolution of thanking Fitzwilliam for Fitzwilliam kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect . Too much , Fitzwilliam am afraid ; for what becomes of the moral , if our comfort springs from a breach of promise ? for Fitzwilliam ought not to have mentioned the subject . mentioned will never do . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam need not distress Fitzwilliam . The moral will be perfectly fair . Cathleen ’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all Fitzwilliam doubts . Fitzwilliam am not indebted for Fitzwilliam present happiness to Fitzwilliam eager desire of expressing Fitzwilliam gratitude . Fitzwilliam was not in a humour to wait for any opening of Fitzwilliam . Cathleen ’s intelligence had given Fitzwilliam hope , and Fitzwilliam was determined at once to know every thing . ” 
 
  “ Cathleen ’s has been of infinite use , which ought to make Cathleen ’s happy , for Cathleen ’s loves to be of use . But tell Elizabeth ’s , what did Fitzwilliam come down to Netherfield for ? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed ? or had Fitzwilliam intended any more serious consequence ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam real purpose was to see Fitzwilliam , and to judge , if Fitzwilliam could , whether Fitzwilliam might ever hope to make Fitzwilliam love Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam avowed one , or what Fitzwilliam avowed to Fitzwilliam , was to see whether Cathleen ’s were still partial to Charles , and if Cathleen ’s were , to make the confession to Charles which Fitzwilliam have since made . ” 
 
  “ Shall Fitzwilliam ever have courage to announce to Cathleen ’s what is to befall Cathleen ’s ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam am more likely to want time than courage , Fitzwilliam . But it ought to be done , and if Fitzwilliam will give Fitzwilliam a sheet of paper , it shall be done directly . ” 
 
  “ And if Fitzwilliam had not a letter to write Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam might sit by Fitzwilliam and admire the evenness of Fitzwilliam writing , as another young lady once did . But Fitzwilliam have an aunt , too , who must not be longer neglected . ” 
 
  From an unwillingness to confess how much Elizabeth ’s intimacy with Fitzwilliam had been over - rated , Elizabeth ’s had never yet answered Madeline ’s long letter ; but now , having that to communicate which Elizabeth ’s knew would be most welcome , Elizabeth ’s was almost ashamed to find that Elizabeth ’s uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness , and immediately wrote as follows : 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s would have thanked Fitzwilliam before , Fitzwilliam , as Elizabeth ’s ought to have done , for Fitzwilliam long , kind , satisfactory , detail of particulars ; but to say the truth , Elizabeth ’s was too cross to write . Fitzwilliam supposed more than really existed . But now suppose as much as Fitzwilliam choose ; give a loose rein to Fitzwilliam fancy , indulge Fitzwilliam imagination in every possible flight which the subject will afford , and unless Fitzwilliam believe Elizabeth ’s actually married , Fitzwilliam can not greatly err . Fitzwilliam must write again very soon , and praise Fitzwilliam a great deal more than Fitzwilliam did in Fitzwilliam last . Elizabeth ’s thank Fitzwilliam , again and again , for not going to the Lakes . How could Elizabeth ’s be so silly as to wish going ! Fitzwilliam idea of the ponies is delightful . We will go round the Park every day . Elizabeth ’s am the happiest creature in the world . Perhaps other people have said so before , but not one with such justice . Elizabeth ’s am happier even than Jane ; Jane only smiles , Elizabeth ’s laugh . Fitzwilliam sends Fitzwilliam all the love in the world that Fitzwilliam can spare from Elizabeth ’s . Fitzwilliam are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas . Fitzwilliam , etc . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam ’s letter to Cathleen ’s was in a different style ; and still different from either was what Father sent to William Collins , in reply to Father last . 
 
  “ Dear Sir,“I must trouble William Collins once more for congratulations . Elizabeth ’s will soon be the wife of Fitzwilliam . Console Cathleen ’s as well as William Collins can . But , if Fitzwilliam were William Collins , Fitzwilliam would stand by Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam has more to give . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam sincerely , etc . ” 
 
  Caroline ’s congratulations to Caroline ’s brother , on Caroline ’s brother approaching marriage , were all that was affectionate and insincere . Caroline ’s wrote even to Jane on the occasion , to express Caroline ’s delight , and repeat all Caroline ’s former professions of regard . Jane was not deceived , but Jane was affected ; and though feeling no reliance on Caroline ’s , could not help writing Caroline ’s a much kinder answer than Jane knew was deserved . 
 
  The joy which Georgiana expressed on receiving similar information , was as sincere as Georgiana brother ’s in sending similar information . Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all Georgiana delight , and all Georgiana earnest desire of being loved by Georgiana sister . 
 
  Before any answer could arrive from William Collins , or any congratulations to Elizabeth ’s from William Collins wife , the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses were come the Collinses to Lucas Lodge . The reason of come was soon evident . Cathleen ’s had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of Cathleen ’s nephew ’s letter , that Charlotte , really rejoicing in Caroline ’s brother approaching marriage , was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over . At such a moment , the arrival of William Collins was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth ’s , though in the course of their meetings Elizabeth ’s must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought , when Elizabeth ’s saw Fitzwilliam exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of Elizabeth ’s husband . Fitzwilliam bore it , however , with admirable calmness . Fitzwilliam could even listen to William Collins , when Fitzwilliam complimented William Collins on carrying away the brightest jewel of the country , and expressed Fitzwilliam hopes of their all meeting frequently at St. James ’s , with very decent composure . If Fitzwilliam did shrug Fitzwilliam shoulders , it was not till William Collins was out of sight . 
 
  Mrs. Phillips ’s vulgarity was another , and perhaps a greater , tax on William Collins forbearance ; and though Mrs. Phillips ’s , as well as Mrs. Phillips ’s sister , stood in too much awe of William Collins to speak with the familiarity which Charles ’s good humour encouraged , yet , whenever Mrs. Phillips ’s did speak , Mrs. Phillips ’s must be vulgar . Nor was Mrs. Phillips ’s respect for William Collins , though Mrs. Phillips ’s respect for William Collins made Mrs. Phillips ’s more quiet , at all likely to make Mrs. Phillips ’s more elegant . Elizabeth ’s did all Elizabeth ’s could to shield William Collins from the frequent notice of either , and was ever anxious to keep William Collins to Elizabeth ’s , and to those of Elizabeth ’s family with whom William Collins might converse without mortification ; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of the season of courtship pleasure , all this added to the hope of the future ; and Elizabeth ’s looked forward with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing to either , to all the comfort and elegance of they family party at Pemberley . 
 Chapter
 
  Happy for all Mother maternal feelings was the day on which Mother got rid of Mother two most deserving daughters . With what delighted pride Mother afterwards visited Jane , and talked of Elizabeth , may be guessed . I wish I could say , for the sake of Mother family , that the accomplishment of Mother earnest desire in the establishment of so many of Mother children produced so happy an effect as to make Mother a sensible , amiable , well - informed woman for the rest of Mother life ; though perhaps it was lucky for Mother husband , who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form , that Mother still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly . 
 
  Father missed Father second daughter exceedingly ; Father affection for Elizabeth drew Father oftener from home than anything else could do . Father delighted in going to Pemberley , especially when Father was least expected . 
 
  Charles and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth . So near a vicinity to Jane mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to Charles easy temper , or Jane affectionate heart . The darling wish of Charles sisters was then gratified ; Charles bought an estate in a neighbouring county to Derbyshire , and Jane and Elizabeth , in addition to every other source of happiness , were within thirty miles of each other . 
 
  Kitty , to Kitty very material advantage , spent the chief of Kitty time with Kitty two elder sisters . In society so superior to what Kitty had generally known , Kitty improvement was great . Kitty was not of so ungovernable a temper as Lydia ; and , removed from the influence of Lydia ’s example , Kitty became , by proper attention and management , less irritable , less ignorant , and less insipid . From the further disadvantage of Lydia ’s society Kitty was of course carefully kept , and though Lydia frequently invited Kitty to come and stay with Lydia , with the promise of balls and young men , Kitty father would never consent to Kitty going . 
 
  Mary was the only daughter who remained at home ; and Mary was necessarily drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mother ’s being quite unable to sit alone . Mary was obliged to mix more with the world , but Mary could still moralize over every morning visit ; and as Mary was no longer mortified by comparisons between Mary sisters ’ beauty and Mary own , it was suspected by Mary father that Mary submitted to the change without much reluctance . 
 
  As for George and Lydia , George and Lydia characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of Mary sisters . George bore with philosophy the conviction that Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of George ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to Elizabeth ; and in spite of every thing , was not wholly without hope that George might yet be prevailed on to make George fortune . The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on Elizabeth marriage , explained to Elizabeth that , by Lydia at least , if not by Lydia , such a hope was cherished . The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on Elizabeth marriage was to this effect : 
 
  “ Lydia dear Elizabeth , 
  “ Lydia wish Elizabeth joy . If Elizabeth love George half as well as Lydia do Lydia dear George , Elizabeth must be very happy . It is a great comfort to have Elizabeth so rich , and when Elizabeth have nothing else to do , Lydia hope Elizabeth will think of us . Lydia am sure George would like a place at court very much , and Lydia do not think us shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help . Any place would do , of about three or four hundred a year ; but however , do not speak to George about it , if Elizabeth had rather not . 
 
  “ Elizabeth , etc . ” 
 
  As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not , Elizabeth endeavoured in Elizabeth answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind . Such relief , however , as it was in Elizabeth power to afford , by the practice of what might be called economy in Elizabeth own private expences , Elizabeth frequently sent them . It had always been evident to Elizabeth that such an income as them , under the direction of two persons so extravagant in them wants , and heedless of the future , must be very insufficient to them support ; and whenever them changed them quarters , either Jane or Elizabeth were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging them bills . them manner of living , even when the restoration of peace dismissed them to a home , was unsettled in the extreme . them were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap situation , and always spending more than them ought . George affection for Elizabeth soon sunk into indifference ; Elizabeth lasted a little longer ; and in spite of Elizabeth youth and Elizabeth manners , Elizabeth retained all the claims to reputation which Elizabeth marriage had given Elizabeth . 
 
  Though George could never receive George at Pemberley , yet , for Elizabeth ’s sake , George assisted George further in George profession . Lydia was occasionally a visitor there , when Lydia husband was gone to enjoy George in London or Bath ; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently staid so long , that even Charles ’s good humour was overcome , and even Charles ’s proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone . 
 
  Caroline was very deeply mortified by Elizabeth marriage ; but as Caroline thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley , Caroline dropt all Caroline resentment ; was fonder than ever of Georgiana , almost as attentive to George as heretofore , and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth . 
 
  Pemberley was now Georgiana ’s home ; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what George had hoped to see . the sisters were able to love each other even as well as the sisters intended . Georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of Elizabeth ; though at first Georgiana often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at Elizabeth lively , sportive , manner of talking to George . George , Georgiana now saw the object of open pleasantry . Georgiana mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in Georgiana way . By Elizabeth ’s instructions , Georgiana began to comprehend that a woman may take liberties with a woman husband which a brother will not always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than a brother . 
 
  Cathleen was extremely indignant on the marriage of Cathleen nephew ; and as Cathleen gave way to all the genuine frankness of Cathleen character in Cathleen reply to the letter which announced the marriage of Cathleen nephew arrangement , Cathleen sent Cathleen nephew language so very abusive , especially of Elizabeth , that for some time all intercourse was at an end . But at length , by Elizabeth ’s persuasion , Cathleen nephew was prevailed on to overlook the offence , and seek a reconciliation ; and , after a little further resistance on the part of Cathleen nephew aunt , Cathleen resentment gave way , either to Cathleen affection for Cathleen nephew , or Cathleen curiosity to see how Cathleen nephew wife conducted Elizabeth ; and Cathleen condescended to wait on them at Pemberley , in spite of that pollution which Pemberley woods had received , not merely from the presence of such a mistress , but the visits of Elizabeth uncle and aunt from the city . 
 
  With the Gardiners , them were always on the most intimate terms . George , as well as Elizabeth , really loved the Gardiners ; and George , as well as Elizabeth were both ever sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who , by bringing Elizabeth into Derbyshire , had been the means of uniting George , as well as Elizabeth . 
ChapterChapter 
  It is a truth universally acknowledged , that a single man in possession of a good fortune , must be in want of a wife . 
 
  However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on such a man first entering a neighbourhood , this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families , that such a man is considered as the rightful property of some one or other of the surrounding families daughters . 
 
  “ Mother dear Father , ” said Mother to Mother dear Father one day , “ have Mother dear Father heard that Netherfield Park is let at last ? ” 
 
  Mother dear Father replied that Mother dear Father had not . 
 
  “ But Netherfield Park is , ” returned Mother ; “ for Mrs. Long has just been here , and Mrs. Long told Mother all about Netherfield Park . ” 
 
  Mother dear Father made no answer . 
 
  “ Do not Mother dear Father want to know who has taken Netherfield Park ? ” cried Mother impatiently . 
 
  “ Mother dear Father want to tell Mother , and Mother have no objection to hearing it . ” 
 
  This was invitation enough . 
 
  “ Why , Mother dear Father dear , Mother must know , Mrs. Long says that Netherfield Park is taken by a young man of large fortune from the north of England ; that a young man of large fortune from the north of England came down on Monday in a chaise and four to see Netherfield Park , and was so much delighted with Netherfield Park that a young man of large fortune from the north of England agreed with Mr. Morris immediately ; that a young man of large fortune from the north of England is to take possession before Michaelmas , and some of a young man of large fortune from the north of England servants are to be in the house by the end of next week . ” 
 
  “ What is a young man of large fortune from the north of England name ? ” 
 
  “ a young man of large fortune from the north of England name 
 
  “ Is a young man of large fortune from the north of England married or single ? ” 
 
  “ Oh ! single , Mother dear Father dear , to be sure ! a young man of large fortune from the north of England What a fine thing for our girls ! ” 
 
  “ How so ? how can it affect our girls ? ” 
 
  “ Mother dear Father , ” replied Mother , “ how can Mother dear Father be so tiresome ! Mother dear Father must know that Mother am thinking of a young man of large fortune from the north of England marrying one of our girls . ” 
 
  “ Is that a young man of large fortune from the north of England design in settling here ? ” 
 
  “ Design ! nonsense , how can Mother dear Father talk so ! But it is very likely that a young man of large fortune from the north of England may fall in love with one of our girls , and therefore Mother dear Father must visit a young man of large fortune from the north of England as soon as a young man of large fortune from the north of England comes . ” 
 
  “ Mother dear Father see no occasion for visit . Mother and our girls may go , or Mother may send our girls by our girls , which perhaps will be still better , for as Mother are as handsome as any of our girls , a young man of large fortune from the north of England might like Mother the best of the party . ” 
 
  “ Mother dear Father dear , Mother dear Father flatter Mother dear Father . Mother dear Father certainly have had Mother dear Father share of beauty , but Mother dear Father do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now . When a woman has five grown - up daughters , a woman ought to give over thinking of a woman own beauty . ” 
 
  “ In such cases , a woman has not often much beauty to think of . ” 
 
  “ But , Mother dear Father dear , Mother dear Father must indeed go and see a young man of large fortune from the north of England when a young man of large fortune from the north of England comes into the neighbourhood . ” 
 
  “ It is more than Mother dear Father engage for , Mother dear Father assure Mother . ” 
 
  “ But consider our girls . Only think what an establishment it would be for one of our girls . Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go , merely on that account , for in general , you know , Sir William and Lady Lucas visit no newcomers . Indeed Mother dear Father must go , for it will be impossible for us to visit a young man of large fortune from the north of England , if Mother dear Father do not . ” 
 
  “ Mother dear Father are over scrupulous , surely . Mother dear Father dare say a young man of large fortune from the north of England will be very glad to see Mother dear Father ; and Mother dear Father will send a few lines by Mother dear Father to assure a young man of large fortune from the north of England of Mother dear Father hearty consent to a young man of large fortune from the north of England marrying whichever a young man of large fortune from the north of England chooses of our girls ; though Mother dear Father must throw in a good word for Mother dear Father little Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ Mother dear Father desire Mother dear Father will do no such thing . Mother dear Father little Elizabeth is not a bit better than the others ; and Mother dear Father am sure Mother dear Father little Elizabeth is not half so handsome as Jane , nor half so good - humoured as Lydia . But Mother dear Father are always giving Mother dear Father little Elizabeth the preference . ” 
 
  “ the others have none of the others much to recommend the others , ” replied Mother dear Father ; “ the others are all silly and ignorant like other girls ; but Mother dear Father little Elizabeth has something more of quickness than Mother dear Father little Elizabeth sisters . ” 
 
  “ Mother dear Father , how can Mother dear Father abuse Mother dear Father own children in such a way ? Mother dear Father take delight in vexing Mother dear Father . Mother dear Father have no compassion on Mother dear Father poor nerves . ” 
 
  “ Mother dear Father mistake Mother dear Father , Mother dear Father dear . Mother dear Father have a high respect for Mother dear Father poor nerves . Mother dear Father poor nerves are Mother dear Father old friends . Mother dear Father have heard Mother dear Father mention Mother dear Father poor nerves with consideration these twenty years at least . ” 
 
  “ Ah , Mother dear Father do not know what Mother dear Father suffer . ” 
 
  “ But Mother dear Father hope Mother dear Father will get over it , and live to see many young men of four thousand a year come into the neighbourhood . ” 
 
  “ It will be no use to us , if twenty such should come , since Mother dear Father will not visit twenty such . ” 
 
  “ Depend upon it , Mother dear Father dear , that when there are twenty , Mother dear Father will visit twenty . ” 
 
  Mother dear Father was so odd a mixture of quick parts , sarcastic humour , reserve , and caprice , that the experience of three - and - twenty years had been insufficient to make Mother dear Father wife understand Mother dear Father character . Mother mind was less difficult to develop . Mother was a woman of mean understanding , little information , and uncertain temper . When Mother was discontented , Mother fancied Mother nervous . The business of Mother life was to get our girls married ; The business of Mother life solace was visiting and news . 
 Chapter
 
  Father was among the earliest of those who waited on Charles . Father had always intended to visit Charles , though to the last always assuring Father wife that Father should not go ; and till the evening after the visit was paid Father wife had no knowledge of visit . visit was then disclosed in the following manner . Observing Father second daughter employed in trimming a hat , Father suddenly addressed Father second daughter with , 
 
  “ Father hope Charles will like a hat , Father second daughter . ” 
 
  “ We are not in a way to know what Charles likes , ” said Father wife resentfully , “ since we are not to visit . ” 
 
  “ But Father wife forget , Father wife , ” said Father second daughter , “ that we shall meet Charles at the assemblies , and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce Charles . ” 
 
  “ Father do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing . Mrs. Long has two nieces of Mrs. Long own . Mrs. Long is a selfish , hypocritical woman , and Father have no opinion of Mrs. Long . ” 
 
  “ No more have Father , ” said Father ; “ and Father am glad to find that Father second daughter do not depend on Mrs. Long serving Father second daughter . ” 
 
  Father wife deigned not to make any reply ; but , unable to contain Father wife , began scolding one of Father wife daughters . 
 
  “ Do n’t keep coughing so , one of Father wife daughters , for heaven ’s sake ! Have a little compassion on Father wife nerves . one of Father wife daughters tear Father wife nerves to pieces . ” 
 
  “ one of Father wife daughters has no discretion in one of Father wife daughters coughs , ” said one of Father wife daughters father ; “ one of Father wife daughters times Father wife nerves ill . ” 
 
  “ one of Father wife daughters do not cough for one of Father wife daughters own amusement , ” replied one of Father wife daughters fretfully . “ When is Father second daughter next ball to be , Father second daughter ? ” 
 
  “ To - morrow fortnight . ” 
 
  “ Aye , so it is , ” cried Father wife , “ and Mrs. Long does not come back till the day before ; so , it will be impossible for Mrs. Long to introduce Charles , for Mrs. Long will not know Charles Mrs. Long . ” 
 
  “ Then , Father second daughter , Father second daughter may have the advantage of Father second daughter friend , and introduce Charles to Father second daughter friend . ” 
 
  “ Impossible , Father , impossible , when Father second daughter am not acquainted with Charles Father second daughter ; how can Father be so teasing ? ” 
 
  “ Father honour Father second daughter circumspection . A fortnight ’s acquaintance is certainly very little . One can not know what a man really is by the end of a fortnight . But if we do not venture somebody else will ; and after all , Mrs. Long and Father second daughter friend nieces must stand two nieces of Mrs. Long own chance ; and , therefore , as Father second daughter friend will think it an act of kindness , if Father second daughter decline the office , Father will take the office on Father . ” 
 
  Father wife daughters stared at Father wife daughters father . Father wife said only , “ Nonsense , nonsense ! ” 
 
  “ What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation ? ” cried Father . “ Do Father wife consider the forms of introduction , and the stress that is laid on the forms of introduction , as nonsense ? Father can not quite agree with Father wife there . What say Father wife , Father wife ? for Father wife are a young lady of deep reflection , Father know , and read great books and make extracts . ” 
 
  Father wife wished to say something very sensible , but knew not how . 
 
  “ While Father wife is adjusting Father wife ideas , ” Father continued , “ let us return to Charles . ” 
 
  “ Father wife am sick of Charles , ” cried Father wife . 
 
  “ Father wife am sorry to hear that ; but why did not Father wife tell Father wife so before ? If Father wife had known as much this morning , Father wife certainly would not have called on Charles . It is very unlucky ; but as Father wife have actually paid the visit , we can not escape the acquaintance now . ” 
 
  The astonishment of Father wife daughters was just what Father wished ; that of Father wife perhaps surpassing the rest ; though when the first tumult of joy was over , Father wife began to declare that it was what Father wife had expected all the while . 
 
  “ How good it was in Father , Father wife dear Father ! But Father wife knew Father wife should persuade Father at last . Father wife was sure Father loved Father wife daughters too well to neglect such an acquaintance . Well , how pleased Father am ! and it is such a good joke , too , that Father should have gone this morning , and never said a word about it till now . ” 
 
  “ Now , one of Father wife daughters , one of Father wife daughters may cough as much as one of Father wife daughters choose , ” said Father ; and , as Father spoke , Father left the room , fatigued with the raptures of Father wife . 
 
  “ What an excellent father Father wife daughters have , Father wife daughters , ” said Father wife , when the door was shut . “ Father wife do not know how Father wife daughters will ever make Father amends for Father kindness ; or Father wife either , for that matter . At our time of life , it is not so pleasant , Father can tell Father wife daughters , to be making new acquaintance every day ; but for Father wife daughters sakes , our would do anything . Lydia , Father love , though Lydia are the youngest , Father dare say Charles will dance with Lydia at the next ball . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! ” said Lydia stoutly , “ Lydia am not afraid ; for though Lydia am the youngest , Lydia ’m the tallest . ” 
 
  The rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon Lydia would return Father ’s visit , and determining when Father wife daughters should ask Lydia to dinner .
