  Not all that Mother , however , with the assistance of Mother five daughters , could ask on the subject , was sufficient to draw from Mother husband any satisfactory description of Charles . Mother five daughters attacked Charles in various ways ; with barefaced questions , ingenious suppositions , and distant surmises ; but Charles eluded the skill of Mother five daughters ; and Mother five daughters were at last obliged to accept the second - hand intelligence of Mother five daughters neighbour , Lady Lucas . Mother five daughters neighbour , Lady Lucas report was highly favourable . Mother husband had been delighted with Charles . Charles was quite young , wonderfully handsome , extremely agreeable , and , to crown the whole , Charles meant to be at the next assembly with a large party . Nothing could be more delightful ! To be fond of dancing was a certain step towards falling in love ; and very lively hopes of Charles ’s heart were entertained . 
 
  “ If Mother can but see one of Mother five daughters happily settled at Netherfield , ” said Mother to Mother husband , “ and all the others equally well married , Mother shall have nothing to wish for . ” 
 
  In a few days Charles returned Mother husband visit , and sat about ten minutes with Mother husband in Mother husband library . Charles had entertained hopes of being admitted to a sight of Mother five daughters ; but Charles saw Mother husband . Mother five daughters were somewhat more fortunate , for Mother five daughters had the advantage of ascertaining from an upper window , that Charles wore a blue coat and rode a black horse . 
 
  An invitation to dinner was soon afterwards dispatched ; and already had Mother planned the courses that were to do credit to Mother housekeeping , when an answer arrived which deferred it all . Charles was obliged to be in town the following day , and consequently unable to accept the honour of Mother five daughters invitation , etc . Mother was quite disconcerted . Mother could not imagine what business Charles could have in town so soon after Charles arrival in Hertfordshire ; and Mother began to fear that Charles might be always flying about from one place to another , and never settled at Netherfield as Charles ought to be . Mother five daughters neighbour , Lady Lucas quieted Mother fears a little by starting the idea of Charles being gone to London only to get a large party for the ball ; and a report soon followed that Charles was to bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen with Charles to the next assembly . Mother five daughters grieved over such a number of ladies ; but were comforted the day before the ball by hearing , that instead of twelve , Charles had brought only six with Charles from London , Charles five sisters and a cousin . And when the party entered the assembly room the party consisted of only five altogether ; Charles , Charles two sisters , the husband of the eldest , and another young man . 
 
  Charles was good - looking and gentlemanlike ; Charles had a pleasant countenance , and easy , unaffected manners . Charles sisters were fine women , with an air of decided fashion . Charles brother - in - law , Mr. Hurst , merely looked Charles ; but Charles friend Fitzwilliam soon drew the attention of the room by Charles friend Fitzwilliam fine , tall person , handsome features , noble mien , and the report which was in general circulation within five minutes after Charles friend Fitzwilliam entrance , of Charles friend Fitzwilliam having ten thousand a year . The gentlemen pronounced Charles friend Fitzwilliam to be a fine figure of a man , the ladies declared Charles friend Fitzwilliam was much handsomer than Charles , and Charles friend Fitzwilliam was looked at with great admiration for about half the evening , till Charles friend Fitzwilliam manners gave a disgust which turned the tide of Charles friend Fitzwilliam popularity ; for Charles friend Fitzwilliam was discovered to be proud , to be above Charles friend Fitzwilliam company , and above being pleased ; and not all Charles friend Fitzwilliam large estate in Hertfordshire could then save Charles friend Fitzwilliam from having a most forbidding , disagreeable countenance , and being unworthy to be compared with Charles friend Fitzwilliam friend . 
 
  Charles had soon made Charles acquainted with all the principal people in the room ; Charles was lively and unreserved , danced every dance , was angry that the ball closed so early , and talked of giving one Charles at Netherfield . Such amiable qualities must speak for Such amiable qualities . What a contrast between Charles and Charles friend ! Charles friend Fitzwilliam danced only once with Charles brother - in - law , Mr. Hurst and once with Caroline , declined being introduced to any other lady , and spent the rest of the evening in walking about the assembly room , speaking occasionally to one of Charles friend Fitzwilliam own party . Charles friend Fitzwilliam character was decided . Charles friend Fitzwilliam was the proudest , most disagreeable man in the world , and everybody hoped that Charles friend Fitzwilliam would never come there again . Amongst the most violent against Charles friend Fitzwilliam was Mother , whose dislike of Charles friend Fitzwilliam general behaviour was sharpened into particular resentment by Charles friend Fitzwilliam having slighted one of Mother five daughters . 
 
  Elizabeth had been obliged , by the scarcity of gentlemen , to sit down for two dances ; and during part of two dances , Charles friend Fitzwilliam had been standing near enough for Elizabeth to overhear a conversation between Charles friend Fitzwilliam and Charles , who came from two dances for a few minutes , to press Charles to join two dances . 
 
  “ Come , Charles friend Fitzwilliam , ” said Charles , “ Charles must have Charles friend Fitzwilliam dance . Charles hate to see Charles friend Fitzwilliam standing about by Charles friend Fitzwilliam in this stupid manner . Charles friend Fitzwilliam had much better dance . ” 
 
  Charles friend Fitzwilliam Charles friend Fitzwilliam certainly shall not . You know how Charles friend Fitzwilliam detest dance , unless Charles friend Fitzwilliam am particularly acquainted with Charles friend Fitzwilliam partner . At such an assembly as this , dance would be insupportable . Mother five daughters are engaged , and there is not another woman in the room whom it would not be a punishment to Charles friend Fitzwilliam to stand up with . ” 
 
  “ Charles would not be so fastidious as Charles friend Fitzwilliam are , ” cried Charles , “ for a kingdom ! Upon Charles honour , Charles never met with so many pleasant girls in Charles life as Charles have this evening ; and there are several of so many pleasant girls Charles friend Fitzwilliam see uncommonly pretty . ” 
 
  “ Charles are dancing with Elizabeth , ” said Charles friend Fitzwilliam , looking at Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Oh ! Elizabeth is the most beautiful creature Charles friend Fitzwilliam ever beheld ! But there is one of Elizabeth sisters sitting down just behind Charles friend Fitzwilliam , who is very pretty , and Charles friend Fitzwilliam dare say very agreeable . Do let Charles friend Fitzwilliam ask Charles friend Fitzwilliam partner to introduce Charles friend Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Which do Charles friend Fitzwilliam mean ? ” and turning round , Charles friend Fitzwilliam looked for a moment at Elizabeth , till catching Elizabeth eye , Charles friend Fitzwilliam withdrew Charles friend Fitzwilliam own and coldly said , “ Elizabeth is tolerable ; but not handsome enough to tempt Charles friend Fitzwilliam ; and Charles friend Fitzwilliam am in no humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted by other men . Charles friend Fitzwilliam had better return to Charles friend Fitzwilliam partner and enjoy Elizabeth smiles , for Charles friend Fitzwilliam are wasting Charles friend Fitzwilliam time with Charles friend Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  Charles followed Charles friend Fitzwilliam advice . Charles friend Fitzwilliam walked off ; and Elizabeth remained with no very cordial feelings towards Charles friend Fitzwilliam . Elizabeth told the story , however , with great spirit among Elizabeth friends ; for Elizabeth had a lively , playful disposition , which delighted in anything ridiculous . 
 
  The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to the whole family . Mother had seen Elizabeth much admired by the Netherfield party . Charles had danced with Elizabeth twice , and Elizabeth had been distinguished by Charles sisters . Jane was as much gratified by this as Jane mother could be , though in a quieter way . Elizabeth felt Jane ’s pleasure . Mary had heard Mary mentioned to Caroline as the most accomplished girl in the neighbourhood ; and Catherine and Lydia had been fortunate enough to be never without partners , which was all that Catherine and Lydia had yet learnt to care for at a ball . Catherine and Lydia returned , therefore , in good spirits to Longbourn , the village where Catherine and Lydia lived , and of which Catherine and Lydia were the principal inhabitants . Catherine and Lydia found Mother husband still up . With a book Mother husband was regardless of time ; and on the present occasion Mother husband had a good deal of curiosity as to the event of an evening which had raised such splendid expectations . Mother husband had rather hoped that all Mother husband wife ’s views on Elizabeth would be disappointed ; but Mother husband soon found that Mother husband had a very different story to hear . 
 
  “ Oh , Mother dear Father , ” as Elizabeth entered the room , “ we have had a most delightful evening , a most excellent ball . Elizabeth wish Mother husband had been there . Jane was so admired , nothing could be like it . Everybody said how well Jane looked ; and Charles thought Jane quite beautiful , and danced with Jane twice . Only think of that , Elizabeth ; Charles actually danced with Jane twice ; and Jane was the only creature in the room that Charles asked a second time . First of all , Charles asked Mother five daughters neighbour , Lady Lucas . Elizabeth was so vexed to see Charles stand up with Mother five daughters neighbour , Lady Lucas ; but , however , Charles did not admire Mother five daughters neighbour , Lady Lucas at all ; indeed , nobody can , you know ; and Charles seemed quite struck with Jane as Jane was going down the dance . So Charles enquired who Jane was , and got introduced , and asked Jane for the two next . Then , the two third Charles danced with Miss King , and the two fourth with Mother five daughters neighbour , Lady Lucas , and the two fifth with Jane again , and the two sixth with Elizabeth , and the Boulanger — ” 
 
  “ If Charles had had any compassion for Mother husband , ” cried Mother husband husband impatiently , “ Charles would not have danced half so much ! For God ’s sake , say no more of Charles partners . Oh that Charles had sprained Charles ankle in the first dance ! ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Mother dear , ” continued Mother , “ Mother am quite delighted with Charles . Charles is so excessively handsome ! and Charles sisters are charming women . Mother never in Mother life saw anything more elegant than Charles sisters dresses . Mother dare say the lace upon Charles brother - in - law , Mr. Hurst gown — ” 
 
  Here Elizabeth was interrupted again . Mother husband protested against any description of finery . Elizabeth was therefore obliged to seek another branch of the subject , and related , with much bitterness of spirit and some exaggeration , the shocking rudeness of Charles friend Fitzwilliam . 
 
  “ But Mother can assure Charles friend Fitzwilliam , ” Elizabeth added , “ that Elizabeth does not lose much by not suiting Charles friend Fitzwilliam fancy ; for Charles friend Fitzwilliam is a most disagreeable , horrid man , not at all worth pleasing . So high and so conceited that there was no enduring Charles friend Fitzwilliam ! Charles friend Fitzwilliam walked here , and Charles friend Fitzwilliam walked there , fancying Charles friend Fitzwilliam so very great ! Not handsome enough to dance with ! Mother wish Charles friend Fitzwilliam had been there , Charles friend Fitzwilliam , to have given Charles friend Fitzwilliam one of Charles friend Fitzwilliam set - downs . Mother quite detest Charles friend Fitzwilliam . ” 
 Chapter
 
  When Jane and Elizabeth were alone , the former , who had been cautious in the former , who had been cautious in praise of Charles before , expressed to Elizabeth how very much the former , who had been cautious in admired Charles . 
 
  “ Charles is just what a young man ought to be , ” said the former , who had been cautious in , “ sensible , good - humoured , lively ; and the former , who had been cautious in never saw such happy manners!—so much ease , with such perfect good breeding ! ” 
 
  “ Charles is also handsome , ” replied Elizabeth , “ which a young man ought likewise to be , if a young man possibly can . Charles character is thereby complete . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth was very much flattered by Charles asking Elizabeth to dance a second time . Elizabeth did not expect such a compliment . ” 
 
  “ Did not Elizabeth ? I did for Elizabeth . But that is one great difference between us . Compliments always take Elizabeth by surprise , and I never . What could be more natural than Charles asking Elizabeth again ? Charles could not help seeing that Elizabeth were about five times as pretty as every other woman in the room . No thanks to Charles gallantry for seeing . Well , Charles certainly is very agreeable , and I give Elizabeth leave to like Charles . Elizabeth have liked many a stupider person . ” 
 
  “ Dear Elizabeth ! ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Elizabeth are a great deal too apt , you know , to like people in general . Elizabeth never see a fault in anybody . All the world are good and agreeable in Elizabeth eyes . I never heard Elizabeth speak ill of a human being in I life . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth would wish not to be hasty in censuring any one ; but Elizabeth always speak what Elizabeth think . ” 
 
  “ I know Elizabeth do ; and it is that which makes the wonder . With Elizabeth good sense , to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of others ! Affectation of candour is common enough;—one meets with Affectation of candour everywhere . But to be candid without ostentation or design — to take the good of everybody ’s character and make everybody ’s character still better , and say nothing of the bad — belongs to Elizabeth . And so , Elizabeth like Charles sisters , too , do Elizabeth ? Charles sisters manners are not equal to Charles . ” 
 
  “ Certainly not ; at first . But Charles sisters are very pleasing women when you converse with Charles sisters . Caroline is to live with Caroline brother , and keep Caroline brother house ; and Jane am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming neighbour in Caroline . ” 
 
  Elizabeth listened in silence , but was not convinced ; Charles sisters behaviour at the assembly had not been calculated to please in general ; and with more quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than Elizabeth sister , and with a judgment too unassailed by any attention to Elizabeth , Elizabeth was very little disposed to approve Charles sisters . Charles sisters were in fact very fine ladies ; not deficient in good humour when Charles sisters were pleased , nor in the power of being agreeable where Charles sisters chose it ; but proud and conceited . Charles sisters were rather handsome , had been educated in one of the first private seminaries in town , had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds , were in the habit of spending more than Charles sisters ought , and of associating with people of rank ; and were therefore in every respect entitled to think well of Charles sisters , and meanly of others . Charles sisters were of a respectable family in the north of England ; a circumstance more deeply impressed on Charles sisters memories than that Charles sisters brother ’s fortune and Charles sisters own had been acquired by trade . 
 
  Charles inherited property to the amount of nearly a hundred thousand pounds from Charles father , who had intended to purchase an estate , but did not live to do purchase . Charles intended it likewise , and sometimes made choice of Charles county ; but as Charles was now provided with a good house and the liberty of a manor , it was doubtful to many of those who best knew the easiness of Charles temper , whether Charles might not spend the remainder of Charles days at Netherfield , and leave the next generation to purchase . 
 
  Charles sisters were very anxious for Charles having an estate of Charles own ; but though Charles was now established only as a tenant , Caroline was by no means unwilling to preside at Charles table , nor was Mrs. Hurst , who had married a man of more fashion than fortune , less disposed to consider a good house as Mrs. Hurst home when it suited Mrs. Hurst . Charles had not been of age two years , when Charles was tempted by an accidental recommendation to look at a good house . Charles did look at a good house , and into a good house for half an hour , was pleased with the situation and the principal rooms , satisfied with what the owner said in its praise , and took a good house immediately . 
 
  Between Charles and Fitzwilliam there was a very steady friendship , in spite of great opposition of character . Charles was endeared to Fitzwilliam by the easiness , openness , and ductility of Fitzwilliam temper , though no disposition could offer a greater contrast to Charles own , and though with Charles own Charles never appeared dissatisfied . On the strength of Fitzwilliam ’s regard Charles had the firmest reliance , and of Fitzwilliam judgment the highest opinion . In understanding , Fitzwilliam was the superior . Charles was by no means deficient , but Fitzwilliam was clever . Fitzwilliam was at the same time haughty , reserved , and fastidious , and Fitzwilliam manners , though well bred , were not inviting . In that respect Charles friend had greatly the advantage . Charles was sure of being liked wherever Charles appeared , Fitzwilliam was continually giving offence . 
 
  The manner in which Charles and Fitzwilliam spoke of the assembly was sufficiently characteristic . Charles had never met with pleasanter people or prettier girls in I life ; everybody had been most kind and attentive to Charles ; there had been no formality , no stiffness ; Charles had soon felt acquainted with all the room ; and as to Caroline , Charles could not conceive an angel more beautiful . Fitzwilliam , on the contrary , had seen a collection of people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion , for none of whom Fitzwilliam had felt the smallest interest , and from none received either attention or pleasure . Caroline Fitzwilliam acknowledged to be pretty , but Caroline smiled too much . 
 
  Mrs. Hurst and Caroline allowed it to be so — but still Mrs. Hurst and Caroline admired Caroline and liked Caroline , and pronounced Caroline to be a sweet girl , and one whom Mrs. Hurst and Caroline should not object to know more of . Caroline was therefore established as a sweet girl , and Fitzwilliam felt authorised by such commendation to think of Caroline as Fitzwilliam chose . 
 Chapter
 
  Within a short walk of Longbourn lived a family with whom the Bennets were particularly intimate . Sir William Lucas had been formerly in trade in Meryton , where Sir William Lucas had made a tolerable fortune , and risen to the honour of knighthood by an address to the king during Sir William Lucas mayoralty . the honour of knighthood had perhaps been felt too strongly . the honour of knighthood had given Sir William Lucas a disgust to Sir William Lucas business and to Sir William Lucas residence in a small market town ; and , quitting them both , Sir William Lucas had removed with Sir William Lucas family to a house about a mile from Meryton , where Sir William Lucas had made a tolerable fortune , and risen to the honour of knighthood by an address to the king during Sir William Lucas mayoralty , denominated from that period Lucas Lodge , where Sir William Lucas could think with pleasure of Sir William Lucas own importance , and , unshackled by business , occupy Sir William Lucas solely in being civil to all the world . For , though elated by Sir William Lucas rank , Sir William Lucas rank did not render Sir William Lucas supercilious ; on the contrary , Sir William Lucas was all attention to everybody . By nature inoffensive , friendly , and obliging , Sir William Lucas presentation at St. James ’s had made Sir William Lucas courteous . 
 
  Lady Lucas was a very good kind of woman , not too clever to be a valuable neighbour to Mother . the Miss Lucases and the Bennets had several children . The eldest of several children , a sensible , intelligent young woman , about twenty - seven , was Elizabeth ’s intimate friend . 
 
  That the Miss Lucases and the Bennets should meet to talk over a ball was absolutely necessary ; and the morning after the assembly brought the former to Longbourn to hear and to communicate . 
 
  “ Charlotte began the evening well , Charlotte , ” said Mother with civil self - command to Charlotte . “ Charlotte were Charles ’s first choice . ” 
 
  Charlotte Yes ; but Charles ’s seemed to like Charles ’s second better . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Charlotte mean Jane , Charlotte suppose , because Charles ’s danced with Jane twice . To be sure that did seem as if Charles ’s admired Jane — indeed Charlotte rather believe Charles ’s did — Charlotte heard something about it — but Charlotte hardly know what — something about Mr. Robinson . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps Mother mean what Charlotte overheard between Charles ’s and Mr. Robinson ; did not Charlotte mention it to Mother ? Mr. Robinson ’s asking Charles ’s how Charles ’s liked our Meryton , where Sir William Lucas had made a tolerable fortune , and risen to the honour of knighthood by an address to the king during Sir William Lucas mayoralty assemblies , and whether Charles ’s did not think there were a great many pretty women in the room , and which Charles ’s thought the prettiest ? and Charles ’s answering immediately to the last question—‘Oh ! Jane , beyond a doubt , there can not be two opinions on that point . ’ ” 
 
  “ Upon Mother word ! Well , that was very decided indeed — that does seem as if — but , however , it may all come to nothing , Mother know . ” 
 
  “ My overhearings were more to the purpose than Elizabeth ’s , Elizabeth ’s , ” said Charlotte . “ Sir William Lucas is not so well worth listening to as Sir William Lucas friend , is he?—Poor Elizabeth!—to be only just tolerable . ” 
 
  “ Mother beg My would not put it into Elizabeth ’s head to be vexed by Sir William Lucas ill - treatment , for Sir William Lucas is such a disagreeable man that it would be quite a misfortune to be liked by Sir William Lucas . Mrs. Long told Charlotte last night that Sir William Lucas sat close to Mrs. Long for half an hour without once opening Sir William Lucas lips . ” 
 
  “ Are Mother quite sure , ma’am?—is not there a little mistake ? ” said Jane . “ Jane certainly saw Sir William Lucas speaking to Mrs. Long . ” 
 
  “ Aye — because Mrs. Long asked Sir William Lucas at last how Sir William Lucas liked Netherfield , and Sir William Lucas could not help answering Mrs. Long ; but Mrs. Long said Sir William Lucas seemed very angry at being spoke to . ” 
 
  “ Caroline told Jane , ” said Jane , “ that Sir William Lucas never speaks much unless among Sir William Lucas intimate acquaintance . With Sir William Lucas intimate acquaintance Sir William Lucas is remarkably agreeable . ” 
 
  “ Mother do not believe a word of it , Mother dear . If Sir William Lucas had been so very agreeable , Sir William Lucas would have talked to Mrs. Long . But Mother can guess how it was ; everybody says that Sir William Lucas is eat up with pride , and Mother dare say Sir William Lucas had heard somehow that Mrs. Long does not keep a carriage , and had come to a ball in a hack chaise . ” 
 
  “ Mother do not mind Sir William Lucas not talking to Mrs. Long , ” said Mother , “ but Mother wish Sir William Lucas had danced with Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  “ Another time , Elizabeth ’s , ” said Elizabeth ’s mother , “ Mother would not dance with Sir William Lucas , if Mother were Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  “ Mother believe , Mother , Mother may safely promise Mother never to dance with Sir William Lucas . ” 
 
  “ Sir William Lucas pride , ” said Mother , “ does not offend Mother so much as pride often does , because there is an excuse for Sir William Lucas pride . One can not wonder that so very fine a young man , with family , fortune , everything in Sir William Lucas favour , should think highly of Sir William Lucas . If Mother may so express it , Sir William Lucas has a right to be proud . ” 
 
  “ That is very true , ” replied Elizabeth ’s , “ and Elizabeth ’s could easily forgive Sir William Lucas pride , if Sir William Lucas had not mortified Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  “ Pride , ” observed Mary , who piqued Mary , who piqued upon the solidity of Mary , who piqued reflections , “ is a very common failing , Mary , who piqued believe . By all that Mary , who piqued have ever read , Mary , who piqued am convinced that Pride is very common indeed ; that human nature is particularly prone to Pride , and that there are very few of us who do not cherish a feeling of self - complacency on the score of some quality or other , real or imaginary . Vanity and pride are different things , though Vanity and pride are often used synonymously . A person may be proud without being vain . Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves , vanity to what our would have others think of our . ” 
 
  “ If a young Lucas , who came with were as rich as Sir William Lucas , ” cried a young Lucas , who came with a young Lucas , who came with sisters , “ a young Lucas , who came with should not care how proud a young Lucas , who came with was . a young Lucas , who came with would keep a pack of foxhounds , and drink a bottle of wine every day . ” 
 
  “ Then a young Lucas , who came with would drink a great deal more than a young Lucas , who came with ought , ” said Mother ; “ and if Mother were to see a young Lucas , who came with at it , Mother should take away a young Lucas , who came with bottle directly . ” a young Lucas , who came with a young Lucas , who came with protested that Mother should not ; Mother continued to declare that Mother would , and the argument ended only with the visit . 
 Chapter 
 
  The ladies of Longbourn soon waited on those of Netherfield . The visit was returned in due form . Miss Bennet ’s pleasing manners grew on the goodwill of Mrs. Hurst and Caroline ; and though the mother was found to be intolerable , and the younger sisters not worth speaking to , a wish of being better acquainted with the younger sisters was expressed towards the two eldest . By Jane this attention was received with the greatest pleasure ; but Elizabeth still saw superciliousness in the two eldest treatment of everybody , hardly excepting even Elizabeth sister , and could not like the two eldest ; though the two eldest kindness to Jane , such as the two eldest kindness to Jane was , had a value as arising in all probability from the influence of the two eldest brother ’s admiration . It was generally evident whenever the two eldest brother ’s and Jane met , that the two eldest brother ’s did admire Jane ; and to Elizabeth it was equally evident that Jane was yielding to the preference which Jane had begun to entertain for the two eldest brother ’s from the first , and was in a way to be very much in love ; but Elizabeth considered with pleasure that it was not likely to be discovered by the world in general , since Jane united with great strength of feeling , a composure of temper and a uniform cheerfulness of manner which would guard Jane from the suspicions of the impertinent . Elizabeth mentioned this to Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas . 
 
  “ It may perhaps be pleasant , ” replied Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas , “ to be able to impose on the public in such a case ; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be so very guarded . If a woman conceals a woman affection with the same skill from the object of a woman affection , a woman may lose the opportunity of fixing the object of a woman affection ; and it will then be but poor consolation to believe the world equally in the dark . There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every attachment , that it is not safe to leave any to itself . We can all begin freely — a slight preference is natural enough ; but there are very few of us who have heart enough to be really in love without encouragement . In nine cases out of ten , a woman had better show more affection than a woman feels . the two eldest brother ’s likes Jane undoubtedly ; but the two eldest brother ’s may never do more than like Jane , if Jane does not help the two eldest brother ’s on . ” 
 
  “ But Jane does help the two eldest brother ’s on , as much as Jane nature will allow . If Elizabeth can perceive Jane regard for the two eldest brother ’s , the two eldest brother ’s must be a simpleton indeed not to discover Jane regard for the two eldest brother ’s too . ” 
 
  “ Remember , Elizabeth , that the two eldest brother ’s does not know Jane ’s disposition as Elizabeth do . ” 
 
  “ But if a woman is partial to a man , and does not endeavour to conceal is , a man must find is out . ” 
 
  “ Perhaps a man must , if a man sees enough of a woman . But though the two eldest brother ’s and Jane meet tolerably often , it is never for many hours together ; and as the two eldest brother ’s and Jane always see each other in large mixed parties , it is impossible that every moment should be employed in conversing together . Jane should therefore make the most of every half - hour in which Jane can command the two eldest brother ’s attention . When Jane is secure of the two eldest brother ’s , there will be leisure for falling in love as much as Jane chooses . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth plan is a good one , ” replied Elizabeth , “ where nothing is in question but the desire of being well married ; and if Elizabeth were determined to get a rich husband , or any husband , Elizabeth dare say Elizabeth should adopt Elizabeth plan . But these are not Jane ’s feelings ; Jane is not acting by design . As yet , Jane can not even be certain of the degree of Jane own regard , nor of Jane own regard reasonableness . Jane has known the two eldest brother ’s only a fortnight . Jane danced four dances with the two eldest brother ’s at Meryton ; Jane saw the two eldest brother ’s one morning at the two eldest brother ’s own house , and has since dined in company with the two eldest brother ’s four times . This is not quite enough to make Jane understand the two eldest brother ’s character . ” 
 
  “ Not as Elizabeth represent it . Had Jane merely dined with the two eldest brother ’s , Jane might only have discovered whether the two eldest brother ’s had a good appetite ; but Elizabeth must remember that four evenings have been also spent together — and four evenings may do a great deal . ” 
 
  “ Yes ; these four evenings have enabled the two eldest brother ’s and Jane to ascertain that the two eldest brother ’s and Jane like Vingt - un better than Commerce ; but with respect to any other leading characteristic , Elizabeth do not imagine that much has been unfolded . ” 
 
  “ Well , ” said Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas , “ Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas wish Jane success with all Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas heart ; and if Jane were married to the two eldest brother ’s to - morrow , Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas should think Jane had as good a chance of happiness as if Jane were to be studying the two eldest brother ’s character for a twelvemonth . Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance . If the dispositions of the parties are ever so well known to each other , or ever so similar beforehand , are does not advance the parties felicity in the least . the parties always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to have the parties share of vexation ; and it is better to know as little as possible of the defects of the person with whom you are to pass your life . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas make the two eldest brother ’s laugh , Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas ; but it is not sound . Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas know it is not sound , and that Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas would never act in this way Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas . ” 
 
  Occupied in observing the two eldest brother ’s attentions to Jane , Elizabeth was far from suspecting that Elizabeth was Elizabeth becoming an object of some interest in the eyes of his friend . his friend had at first scarcely allowed Elizabeth to be pretty ; his friend had looked at Elizabeth without admiration at the ball ; and when the two eldest brother ’s and Jane next met , his friend looked at Elizabeth only to criticise . But no sooner had his friend made it clear to his friend and his friend friends that Elizabeth had hardly a good feature in Elizabeth face , than his friend began to find Elizabeth face was rendered uncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of Elizabeth dark eyes . To this discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying . Though his friend had detected with a critical eye more than one failure of perfect symmetry in Elizabeth form , his friend was forced to acknowledge Elizabeth figure to be light and pleasing ; and in spite of his friend asserting that Elizabeth manners were not those of the fashionable world , his friend was caught by Elizabeth manners easy playfulness . Of this Elizabeth was perfectly unaware;—to Elizabeth his friend was only the man who made his friend agreeable nowhere , and who had not thought Elizabeth handsome enough to dance with . 
 
  his friend began to wish to know more of Elizabeth , and as a step towards conversing with Elizabeth his friend , attended to Elizabeth conversation with others . his friend doing so drew Elizabeth notice . It was at Sir William Lucas ’s , where a large party were assembled . 
 
  “ What does his friend mean , ” said Elizabeth to Elizabeth friend Miss Lucas , “ by listening to Elizabeth conversation with Colonel Forster ? ” 
 
  “ That is a question which his friend only can answer . ” 
 
  “ But if his friend does listening any more Elizabeth shall certainly let his friend know that Elizabeth see what his friend is about . his friend has a very satirical eye , and if Elizabeth do not begin by being impertinent Elizabeth , Elizabeth shall soon grow afraid of his friend . ” 
 
  On his friend approaching the group soon afterwards , though without seeming to have any intention of speaking , Elizabeth defied Elizabeth to mention such a subject to Elizabeth , which immediately provoking Elizabeth to do it , Elizabeth turned to Elizabeth and said , 
 
  “ Did not Elizabeth think , Elizabeth , that Elizabeth expressed Elizabeth uncommonly well just now , when Elizabeth was teasing Colonel Forster to give the group a ball at Meryton ? ” 
 
  “ With great energy ; but it is a subject which always makes a lady energetic . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth are severe on us . ” 
 
  “ It will be Elizabeth turn soon to be teased , ” said Elizabeth . “ Elizabeth am going to open the instrument , Elizabeth , and Elizabeth know what follows . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth are a very strange creature by way of a friend!—always wanting Elizabeth to play and sing before anybody and everybody ! If Elizabeth vanity had taken a musical turn , Elizabeth would have been invaluable ; but as it is , Elizabeth would really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of hearing the very best performers . ” On Elizabeth persevering , however , Elizabeth added , “ Very well ; if it must be so , it must . ” And gravely glancing at Elizabeth , “ There is a fine old saying , which everybody here is of course familiar with—‘Keep your breath to cool your porridge,’—and Elizabeth shall keep Elizabeth to swell Elizabeth song . ” 
 
  Elizabeth performance was pleasing , though by no means capital . After a song or two , and before Elizabeth could reply to the entreaties of several that Elizabeth would sing again , Elizabeth was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by Elizabeth sister Mary , who having , in consequence of being the only plain one in the family , worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments , was always impatient for display . 
 
  
 
  had neither genius nor taste ; and though vanity had given 
 
  application , vanity had given 
 
  likewise a pedantic air and conceited manner , which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than 
 
  had reached . Elizabeth , easy and unaffected , had been listened to with much more pleasure , though not playing half so well ; and

  younger sisters , who with some of the Lucases , and two or three officers , joined eagerly in dancing at one end of the room . Elizabeth Elizabeth stood near the group in silent indignation at such a mode of passing the evening , to the exclusion of all conversation , and was too much engrossed by Elizabeth own thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas ’s was Elizabeth neighbour , till Sir William Lucas ’s thus began . 
 
  “ What a charming amusement for young people this is , Elizabeth ! There is nothing like dancing after all . sir consider dancing as one of the first refinements of polished societies . ” 
 
  “ Certainly , sir ; and this has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst the less polished societies of the world.—Every savage can dance . ” 
 
  Sir William Lucas ’s only smiled . “ his friend performs delightfully , ” sir continued after a pause , on seeing the two eldest brother ’s join the group ; “ and sir doubt not that Elizabeth are an adept in the science Elizabeth , Elizabeth . Elizabeth 
 
  “ sir saw Elizabeth dance at Meryton , Elizabeth believe , sir . ” 
 
  “ Yes , indeed , and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight . Do Elizabeth often dance at St. James ’s ? ” 
 
  “ Never , sir . ” 
 
  “ Do Elizabeth not think it would be a proper compliment to St. James ’s ? ” 
 
  “ It is a compliment which Elizabeth never pay to any place if Elizabeth can avoid it . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth have a house in town , sir conclude ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth bowed . 
 
  “ Elizabeth had once some thoughts of fixing in town Elizabeth — for Elizabeth am fond of superior society ; but Elizabeth did not feel quite certain that the air of town would agree with Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Elizabeth paused in hopes of an answer ; but Elizabeth was not disposed to make any ; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards the group , Elizabeth was struck with the notion of doing a very gallant thing , and called out to Elizabeth , 
 
  “ Elizabeth dear Elizabeth , why are not Elizabeth dancing ? Elizabeth , Elizabeth must allow Elizabeth to present Jane to Elizabeth as a very desirable partner . Elizabeth can not refuse to dance , Elizabeth am sure , when so much beauty is before Elizabeth . ” And , taking Elizabeth hand , Elizabeth would have given Elizabeth hand to Elizabeth , when Elizabeth instantly drew back , and said with some discomposure to Sir William Lucas ’s , 
 
  “ Indeed , Sir William Lucas ’s , Elizabeth have not the least intention of dancing . Elizabeth entreat Sir William Lucas ’s not to suppose that Elizabeth moved this way in order to beg for a partner . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , with grave propriety , requested to be allowed the honour of Elizabeth hand , but in vain . Elizabeth was determined ; nor did Sir William Lucas ’s at all shake Elizabeth purpose by Elizabeth attempt at persuasion . 
 
  “ Elizabeth excel so much in the dance , Elizabeth , that it is cruel to deny Elizabeth the happiness of seeing Elizabeth ; and though Elizabeth dislikes the amusement in general , Elizabeth can have no objection , Elizabeth am sure , to oblige us for one half - hour . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth is all politeness , ” said Elizabeth , smiling . 
 
  “ Elizabeth is , indeed — but , considering the inducement , Elizabeth dear Elizabeth , we can not wonder at Elizabeth complaisance ; for who would object to such a partner ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth looked archly , and turned away . Elizabeth resistance had not injured Elizabeth with Elizabeth , and Elizabeth was thinking of Elizabeth with some complacency , when thus accosted by Caroline , 
 
  “ sir can guess the subject of Elizabeth reverie . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth should imagine not . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings in this manner — in such society ; and indeed sir am quite of Elizabeth opinion . sir was never more annoyed ! The insipidity , and yet the noise ; the nothingness , and yet the self - importance of all these people ! What would sir give to hear Elizabeth strictures on all these people ! ” 
 
  “ sir conjecture is totally wrong , Elizabeth assure sir . Elizabeth mind was more agreeably engaged . Elizabeth have been meditating on the very great pleasure which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow . ” 
 
  sir immediately fixed sir eyes on Elizabeth face , and desired Elizabeth would tell sir what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections . Elizabeth replied with great intrepidity , 
 
  “ Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ! ” repeated sir . “ sir am all astonishment . How long has Elizabeth been such a favourite?—and pray when am Elizabeth to wish Elizabeth joy ? ” 
 
  “ That is exactly the question which Elizabeth expected Elizabeth to ask . A lady ’s imagination is very rapid ; A lady ’s imagination jumps from admiration to love , from love to matrimony , in a moment . Elizabeth knew Elizabeth would be wishing Elizabeth joy . ” 
 
  “ Nay , if Elizabeth are so serious about it , Elizabeth shall consider the matter as absolutely settled . Elizabeth will have a charming mother - in - law , indeed , and of course a charming mother - in - law will be always at Pemberley with Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Elizabeth listened to Elizabeth with perfect indifference , while Elizabeth chose to entertain Elizabeth in this manner ; and as Elizabeth composure convinced Elizabeth that all was safe , Elizabeth wit flowed long . 
 Chapter 
 
  Father ’s property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two thousand a year , which , unfortunately for  
 
  Father ’s daughters , was entailed , in default of heirs male , on a distant relation ; and  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s fortune , though ample for  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s situation in life , could but ill supply the deficiency of  
 
  Father ’s .  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s father had been an attorney in Meryton , and had left  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s four thousand pounds . 
 
   
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s had a sister married to a Mr. Phillips , who had been a clerk to  
 
  Father ’s , and succeeded  
 
  Father ’s in the business , and a brother settled in London in a respectable line of trade . 
 
  The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton ; a most convenient distance for the young ladies , who were usually tempted thither three or four times a week , to pay their duty to  
 
  Father ’s daughters aunt and to a milliner ’s shop just over the way . The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia , were particularly frequent in these attentions ; The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia minds were more vacant than The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia , and when nothing better offered , a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia morning hours and furnish conversation for the evening ; and however bare of news the country in general might be , The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia always contrived to learn some from The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia aunt . At present , indeed , The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia were well supplied both with news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the neighbourhood ; a militia regiment was to remain the whole winter , and Meryton was the headquarters . 
 
  The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia visits to  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s were now productive of the most interesting intelligence . Every day added something to The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia knowledge of the officers ’ names and connections . The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia lodgings were not long a secret , and at length The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia began to know the officers ’ the officers ’ .  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s visited The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia , and visited opened to  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s nieces a source of felicity unknown before . The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia could talk of nothing but officers ; and Charles ’s large fortune , the mention of which gave animation to The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia mother , was worthless in The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia eyes when opposed to the regimentals of an ensign . 
 
  After listening one morning to The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia effusions on this subject , Father coolly observed , 
 
  “ From all that Father can collect by The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia manner of talking , The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia must be two of the silliest girls in the country . Father have suspected be some time , but Father am now convinced . ” 
 
  Catherine was disconcerted , and made no answer ; but Lydia , with perfect indifference , continued to express Lydia admiration of Captain Carter , and Lydia hope of seeing Captain Carter in the course of the day , as Captain Carter was going the next morning to London . 
 
  “  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s am astonished ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s dear , ” said  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s , “ that Lydia should be so ready to think Lydia own children silly . If  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s wished to think slightingly of anybody ’s children , anybody ’s children should not be of  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s own , however . ” 
 
  “ If  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s children are silly ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s must hope to be always sensible of are . ” 
 
  “ Yes — but as it happens , Lydia own children are all of them very clever . ” 
 
  “ This is the only point ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s flatter  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s , on which we do not agree .  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s had hoped that we sentiments coincided in every particular , but  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s must so far differ from Lydia as to think The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia uncommonly foolish . ” 
 
  “ Lydia dear Father , Father must not expect such girls to have the sense of such girls father and mother . When such girls get to our age ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s dare say such girls will not think about officers any more than we do .  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s remember the time when  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s liked a red coat  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s very well — and , indeed , so  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s do still at  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s heart ; and if a smart young colonel , with five or six thousand a year , should want one of  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s girls ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s shall not say nay to a smart young colonel , with five or six thousand a year ; and  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s thought Colonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William ’s in Colonel Forster regimentals . ” 
 
  “  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s , ” cried Lydia , “ Lydia aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain Carter do not go so often to Miss Watson ’s as Colonel Forster and Captain Carter did when Colonel Forster and Captain Carter first came ;  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s sees Colonel Forster and Captain Carter now very often standing in Clarke ’s library . ” 
 
   
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with a note for Lydia ; a note for Lydia came from Netherfield , and the footman with a note for Lydia waited for an answer .  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s eyes sparkled with pleasure , and  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s was eagerly calling out , while  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s daughter read , 
 
  “ Well , Lydia , who is a note for Lydia from ? What is a note for Lydia about ? What does he say ? Well , Lydia , make haste and tell us ; make haste , Father love . ” 
 
  “ a note for Lydia is from Caroline , ” said Lydia , and then read a note for Lydia aloud . 
 
  “ Father DEAR FRIEND , — 
  “ If Lydia are not so compassionate as to dine to - day with Louisa and Father , we shall be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives , for a whole day ’s tête - à - tête between two women can never end without a quarrel . Come as soon as The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia can on the receipt of a note for Lydia . Father brother and the gentlemen are to dine with the officers.—Yours ever , 
 
  “ Caroline ” 
 
  “ With the officers ’ ! ” cried Lydia . “ Lydia wonder  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s did not tell us of that . ” 
 
  “ Dining out , ” said  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s , “ Dining is very unlucky . ” 
 
  “ Can Lydia have the carriage ? ” said Lydia . 
 
  “ No ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s dear , Lydia had better go on horseback , because it seems likely to rain ; and then Lydia must stay all night . ” 
 
  “ That would be a good scheme , ” said Elizabeth , “ if  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s were sure that they would not offer to send Lydia home . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! but the gentlemen will have Charles ’s chaise to go to Meryton ; and the Hursts have no horses to the Hursts . ” 
 
  “ Lydia had much rather go in the carriage . ” 
 
  “ But , Lydia , Lydia father can not spare the horses ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s am sure . the horses are wanted in the farm , Father , are not the horses ? ” 
 
  “ the horses are wanted in the farm much oftener than Father can get the horses . ” 
 
  “ But if Father have got the horses to - day , ” said Elizabeth , “  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s purpose will be answered . ” 
 
  Elizabeth did at last extort from Elizabeth father an acknowledgment that the horses were engaged . Lydia was therefore obliged to go on horseback , and  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s attended Lydia to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a bad day . Lydia hopes were answered ; Lydia had not been gone long before it rained hard . Lydia sisters were uneasy for Lydia , but Lydia mother was delighted . The rain continued the whole evening without intermission ; Lydia certainly could not come back . 
 
  “ This was a lucky idea of  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s , indeed ! ” said  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s , more than once , as if the credit of making it rain were all  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s own . Till the next morning , however ,  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s was not aware of all the felicity of  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s contrivance . Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield brought the following note for Elizabeth : 
 
  “ Father DEAREST Elizabeth , — 
  “ Father find Father very unwell this morning , which , Father suppose , is to be imputed to Father getting wet through yesterday . Father kind friends will not hear of Father returning home till Father am better . Father kind friends insist also on Father seeing Mr. Jones — therefore do not be alarmed if Father should hear of Mr. Jones having been to Father — and , excepting a sore throat and headache , there is not much the matter with me.—Yours , & c. ” 
 
  “ Well , Elizabeth , ” said Father , when Elizabeth had read a note for Lydia aloud , “ if Lydia should have a dangerous fit of illness — if Lydia should die , it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of Charles ’s , and under Elizabeth orders . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Elizabeth am not at all afraid of Lydia dying . People do not die of little trifling colds . Lydia will be taken good care of . As long as Lydia stays there , it is all very well . Elizabeth would go and see Lydia if Elizabeth could have the carriage . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , feeling really anxious , was determined to go to Lydia , though the carriage was not to be had ; and as Elizabeth was no horsewoman , walking was Elizabeth only alternative . Elizabeth declared Elizabeth resolution . 
 
  “ How can Elizabeth be so silly , ” cried Elizabeth mother , “ as to think of such a thing , in all this dirt ! Elizabeth will not be fit to be seen when Elizabeth get there . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth shall be very fit to see Lydia — which is all Elizabeth want . ” 
 
  “ Is this a hint to Father , Elizabeth , ” said Elizabeth father , “ to send for the horses ? ” 
 
  “ No , indeed . Elizabeth do not wish to avoid the walk . The distance is nothing , when one has a motive ; only three miles . Elizabeth shall be back by dinner . ” 
 
  “  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s admire the activity of Elizabeth benevolence , ” observed  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s , “ but every impulse of feeling should be guided by reason ; and , in  
 
  Father ’s daughters mother ’s opinion , exertion should always be in proportion to what is required . ” 
 
  “ Catherine and Lydia will go as far as Meryton with Elizabeth , ” said Catherine and Lydia . Elizabeth accepted Catherine and Lydia company , and The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia set off together . 
 
  “ If we make haste , ” said Lydia , as we walked along , “ perhaps we may see something of Captain Carter before Captain Carter goes . ” 
 
  In Meryton we parted ; Catherine repaired to the lodgings of one of the officers ’ wives , and Elizabeth continued Elizabeth walk alone , crossing field after field at a quick pace , jumping over stiles and springing over puddles with impatient activity , and finding Elizabeth at last within view of the house , with weary ankles , dirty stockings , and a face glowing with the warmth of exercise . 
 
  Elizabeth was shown into the breakfast - parlour , where all but Lydia were assembled , and where Elizabeth appearance created a great deal of surprise . That Elizabeth should have walked three miles so early in the day , in such dirty weather , and by Elizabeth , was almost incredible to Catherine and Lydia ; and Elizabeth was convinced that Catherine and Lydia held Elizabeth in contempt for it . Elizabeth was received , however , very politely by Catherine and Lydia ; and in Catherine and Lydia brother ’s manners there was something better than politeness ; there was good humour and kindness . Fitzwilliam said very little , and Caroline nothing at all . Caroline was divided between admiration of the brilliancy which exercise had given to Elizabeth complexion , and doubt as to the occasion ’s justifying Elizabeth coming so far alone . Caroline was thinking only of Caroline breakfast . 
 
  Caroline enquiries after Caroline sister were not very favourably answered . Lydia had slept ill , and though up , was very feverish , and not well enough to leave Lydia room . Elizabeth was glad to be taken to Lydia immediately ; and Lydia Lydia note how much Lydia longed for such a visit , was delighted at Elizabeth entrance . Lydia was not equal , however , to much conversation , and when Caroline left them together , could attempt little beside expressions of gratitude for the extraordinary kindness Lydia was treated with . Elizabeth silently attended Lydia . 
 
  When breakfast was over , them were joined by Catherine ; and Elizabeth began to like Catherine Elizabeth , when Elizabeth saw how much affection and solicitude Catherine showed for Lydia . The apothecary came , and having examined The apothecary patient , said , as might be supposed , that Lydia had caught a violent cold , and that they must endeavour to get the better of a violent cold ; advised Lydia to return to bed , and promised Lydia some draughts . The advice was followed readily , for the feverish symptoms increased , and Lydia head ached acutely . Elizabeth did not quit Elizabeth room for a moment , nor were the other ladies often absent ; the other ladies being out , The two youngest of the family , Catherine and Lydia had in fact nothing to do elsewhere . 
 
  When the clock struck three , Elizabeth felt that Elizabeth must go , and very unwillingly said so . Caroline offered Elizabeth the carriage , and Elizabeth only wanted a little pressing to accept the carriage , when Lydia testified such concern in parting with Elizabeth , that Caroline was obliged to convert offered to an invitation to remain at Netherfield for the present . Elizabeth most thankfully consented , and a servant was dispatched to The village of Longbourn to acquaint the family with Elizabeth stay , and bring back a supply of clothes . 
 Chapter 
 
  At five o’clock the two ladies retired to dress , and at half - past six Elizabeth was summoned to dinner . To the civil enquiries which then poured in , and amongst which Elizabeth had the pleasure of distinguishing the much superior solicitude of Charles ’s , Elizabeth could not make a very favourable answer . Jane was by no means better . the two ladies , on hearing was , repeated three or four times how much the two ladies were grieved , how shocking it was to have a bad cold , and how excessively the two ladies disliked being ill the two ladies ; and then thought no more of the matter : and the two ladies indifference towards Jane when not immediately before the two ladies , restored Elizabeth to the enjoyment of all Elizabeth original dislike . 
 
  the two ladies brother , indeed , was the only one of the party whom Elizabeth could regard with any complacency . the two ladies brother anxiety for Jane was evident , and the two ladies brother attentions to Jane most pleasing , and the two ladies brother attentions to Jane prevented Elizabeth feeling Elizabeth so much an intruder as Elizabeth believed Elizabeth was considered by the others . Elizabeth had very little notice from any but the two ladies brother . Caroline was engrossed by Fitzwilliam , Caroline sister scarcely less so ; and as for Mr. Hurst , by whom Elizabeth sat , Mr. Hurst , by whom Elizabeth sat was an indolent man , who lived only to eat , drink , and play at cards ; who , when Mr. Hurst , by whom Elizabeth sat found Elizabeth prefer a plain dish to a ragout , had nothing to say to Elizabeth . 
 
  When dinner was over , Elizabeth returned directly to Jane , and Caroline began abusing Elizabeth as soon as Elizabeth was out of the room . Elizabeth manners were pronounced to be very bad indeed , a mixture of pride and impertinence ; Elizabeth had no conversation , no style , no taste , no beauty . Caroline thought the same , and added , 
 
  “ Elizabeth has nothing , in short , to recommend Elizabeth , but being an excellent walker . Caroline shall never forget Elizabeth appearance this morning . Elizabeth really looked almost wild . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth did , indeed , Caroline . Caroline could hardly keep Caroline countenance . Very nonsensical to come at all ! Why must Elizabeth be scampering about the country , because Jane had a cold ? Elizabeth hair so untidy , so blowsy ! ” 
 
  “ Yes , and Elizabeth petticoat ; Caroline hope you saw Elizabeth petticoat , six inches deep in mud , Caroline am absolutely certain ; and the gown which had been let down to hide it not doing its office . ” 
 
  “ Caroline picture may be very exact , Caroline , ” said Charles ; “ but this was all lost upon Charles . Charles thought Miss Elizabeth looked remarkably well when Elizabeth came into the room this morning . Elizabeth dirty petticoat quite escaped Charles notice . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam observed Elizabeth petticoat , Fitzwilliam , Caroline am sure , ” said Caroline ; “ and Caroline am inclined to think that Fitzwilliam would not wish to see Fitzwilliam sister make such an exhibition . ” 
 
  “ Certainly not . ” 
 
  “ To walk three miles , or four miles , or five miles , or whatever it is , above Elizabeth ankles in dirt , and alone , quite alone ! what could Elizabeth mean by walk ? walk seems to me to show an abominable sort of conceited independence , a most country - town indifference to decorum . ” 
 
  “ walk shows an affection for Jane that is very pleasing , ” said Charles . 
 
  “ Caroline am afraid , Fitzwilliam , ” observed Caroline , in a half whisper , “ that this adventure has rather affected Fitzwilliam admiration of Jane fine eyes . ” 
 
  “ Not at all , ” Fitzwilliam replied ; “ Jane fine eyes were brightened by the exercise . ” A short pause followed this speech , and Caroline began again . 
 
  “ Caroline have an excessive regard for Jane , Jane is really a very sweet girl , and Caroline wish with all Caroline heart Jane were well settled . But with such a father and mother , and such low connections , Caroline am afraid there is no chance of were . ” 
 
  “ Caroline think Caroline have heard Fitzwilliam say that their uncle is an attorney in Meryton . ” 
 
  “ Yes ; and their have another , who lives somewhere near Cheapside . ” 
 
  “ That is capital , ” added Jane sister , and they both laughed heartily . 
 
  “ If their had uncles enough to fill all Cheapside , ” cried Charles , “ had would not make their one jot less agreeable . ” 
 
  “ But had must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any consideration in the world , ” replied Fitzwilliam . 
 
  To this speech Charles made no answer ; but the two ladies gave this speech the two ladies hearty assent , and indulged the two ladies mirth for some time at the expense of the two ladies dear friend ’s vulgar relations . 
 
  With a renewal of tenderness , however , the two ladies repaired to Elizabeth room on leaving the dining - parlour , and sat with Elizabeth till summoned to coffee . Elizabeth was still very poorly , and Elizabeth would not quit Elizabeth at all , till late in the evening , when Elizabeth had the comfort of seeing Elizabeth asleep , and when it appeared to Elizabeth rather right than pleasant that Elizabeth should go downstairs Elizabeth . On entering the drawing - room Elizabeth found the party at loo , and was immediately invited to join the party ; but suspecting the party to be playing high Elizabeth declined invited , and making Elizabeth the excuse , said Elizabeth would amuse Elizabeth for the short time Elizabeth could stay below , with a book . Caroline looked at Elizabeth with astonishment . 
 
  “ Do Elizabeth prefer reading to cards ? ” said Caroline ; “ prefer is rather singular . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , ” said Caroline , “ despises cards . Elizabeth is a great reader , and has no pleasure in anything else . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth deserve neither such praise nor such censure , ” cried Elizabeth ; “ Elizabeth am not a great reader , and Elizabeth have pleasure in many things . ” 
 
  “ In nursing Elizabeth Caroline am sure Elizabeth have pleasure , ” said Charles ; “ and Caroline hope pleasure will soon be increased by seeing Elizabeth quite well . ” 
 
  Elizabeth thanked Charles from Elizabeth heart , and then walked towards a table where a few books were lying . Charles immediately offered to fetch Elizabeth others ; all that Charles library afforded . 
 
  “ And Charles wish Charles library were larger for Elizabeth benefit and Charles own credit ; but Charles am an idle fellow , and though Charles have not many , Charles have more than Charles ever looked into . ” 
 
  Elizabeth assured Charles that Elizabeth could suit Elizabeth perfectly with those in the room . 
 
  “ Charles am astonished , ” said Caroline , “ that Charles father should have left so small a collection of books . What a delightful library Fitzwilliam have at Pemberley , Fitzwilliam ! ” 
 
  “ It ought to be good , ” Fitzwilliam replied , “ it has been the work of many generations . ” 
 
  “ And then Fitzwilliam have added so much to it Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam are always buying books . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam can not comprehend the neglect of a family library in such days as these . ” 
 
  “ Neglect ! Caroline am sure Fitzwilliam neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of that noble place . Charles , when Charles build Charles house , Elizabeth wish Charles house may be half as delightful as Pemberley . ” 
 
  “ Charles wish Charles house may . ” 
 
  “ But Elizabeth would really advise Charles to make Charles purchase in that neighbourhood , and take Pemberley for a kind of model . There is not a finer county in England than that neighbourhood . ” 
 
  Charles With all Charles heart ; Charles will buy Pemberley Pemberley if Fitzwilliam will sell Pemberley . ” 
 
  “ Caroline am talking of possibilities , Charles . ” 
 
  “ Upon Elizabeth word , Caroline , Elizabeth should think it more possible to get Pemberley by purchase than by imitation . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth was so much caught by what passed , as to leave Elizabeth very little attention for a book ; and soon laying a book wholly aside , Elizabeth drew near the card - table , and stationed Elizabeth between Charles and Charles eldest sister , to observe the game . 
 
  “ Is Georgiana much grown since the spring ? ” said Caroline ; “ will Georgiana be as tall as Caroline am ? ” 
 
  “ Caroline think Georgiana will . Georgiana is now about Elizabeth ’s height , or rather taller . ” 
 
  “ How Caroline long to see Georgiana again ! Caroline never met with anybody who delighted Caroline so much . Such a countenance , such manners!—and so extremely accomplished for Georgiana age ! Georgiana performance on the pianoforte is exquisite . ” 
 
  “ It is amazing to Charles , ” said Charles , “ how young ladies can have patience to be so very accomplished as All young ladies are . ” 
 
  “ All young ladies accomplished ! Caroline dear Charles , what do Charles mean ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , All young ladies , Charles think . All young ladies paint tables , cover screens , and net purses . Charles scarcely know any one who can not do all this , and Charles am sure Charles never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time , without being informed that a young lady was very accomplished . ” 
 
  “ Charles list of the common extent of accomplishments , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ has too much truth . The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen . But Fitzwilliam am very far from agreeing with Charles in Charles estimation of ladies in general . Fitzwilliam can not boast of knowing more than half a dozen , in the whole range of Fitzwilliam acquaintance , that are really accomplished . ” 
 
  “ Nor Caroline , Elizabeth am sure , ” said Caroline . 
 
  “ Then , ” observed Elizabeth , “ Elizabeth must comprehend a great deal in Elizabeth idea of an accomplished woman . ” 
 
  Elizabeth Yes ; Elizabeth do comprehend a great deal in Elizabeth idea of an accomplished woman . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! certainly , ” cried Fitzwilliam faithful assistant , “ no one can be really esteemed accomplished who does not greatly surpass what is usually met with . A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music , singing , drawing , dancing , and the modern languages , to deserve the word ; and besides music , singing , drawing , dancing , and the modern languages , A woman must possess a certain something in A woman air and manner of walking , the tone of A woman voice , A woman address and expressions , or the word will be but half deserved . ” 
 
  “ All this A woman must possess , ” added Fitzwilliam , “ and to all this A woman must yet add something more substantial , in the improvement of A woman mind by extensive reading . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth am no longer surprised at Elizabeth knowing only six accomplished women . Elizabeth rather wonder now at Elizabeth knowing any . ” 
 
  “ Are Elizabeth so severe upon Elizabeth own sex as to doubt the possibility of all this ? ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth never saw such a woman . Elizabeth never saw such capacity , and taste , and application , and elegance , as Fitzwilliam describe , united . ” 
 
  Caroline and Caroline the two ladies cried out against the injustice of Elizabeth implied doubt , and were both protesting that the two ladies knew many women who answered this description , when Caroline called the two ladies to order , with bitter complaints of the two ladies inattention to what was going forward . As all conversation was thereby at an end , Elizabeth soon afterwards left the room . 
 
  “ Elizabeth , ” said Caroline , when the door was closed on Elizabeth , “ is one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the other sex by undervaluing themselves own ; and with many men , Caroline dare say , seek succeeds . But , in Caroline opinion , seek is a paltry device , a very mean art . ” 
 
  “ Undoubtedly , ” replied Fitzwilliam , to whom this remark was chiefly addressed , “ there is meanness in all the arts which ladies sometimes condescend to employ for captivation . Whatever bears affinity to cunning is despicable . ” 
 
  Caroline was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to continue the subject . 
 
  Elizabeth joined the two ladies again only to say that Elizabeth was worse , and that Elizabeth could not leave Elizabeth . Charles urged Mr. Jones ’s being sent for immediately ; while Mr. Jones ’s sisters , convinced that no country advice could be of any service , recommended an express to town for one of the most eminent physicians . an express to town for one of the most eminent physicians Elizabeth would not hear of ; but Elizabeth was not so unwilling to comply with Mr. Jones ’s sisters brother ’s proposal ; and it was settled that Mr. Jones ’s should be sent for early in the morning , if Elizabeth were not decidedly better . Charles was quite uncomfortable ; the two ladies declared that the two ladies were miserable . the two ladies solaced the two ladies wretchedness , however , by duets after supper , while Charles could find no better relief to Charles feelings than by giving Charles housekeeper directions that every possible attention might be paid to Elizabeth and Elizabeth sister . 
 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth passed the chief of the night in Elizabeth sister ’s room , and in the morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the enquiries which Elizabeth very early received from Charles by a housemaid , and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on Charles sisters . In spite of this amendment , however , Elizabeth requested to have a note sent to Longbourn , desiring Elizabeth mother to visit Jane , and form Elizabeth own judgment of Jane situation . a note was immediately dispatched , and a note contents as quickly complied with . Elizabeth mother , accompanied by Elizabeth mother two youngest girls , reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast . 
 
  Had Elizabeth mother found Jane in any apparent danger , Elizabeth mother would have been very miserable ; but being satisfied on seeing Jane that Jane illness was not alarming , Elizabeth mother had no wish of Jane recovering immediately , as Jane restoration to health would probably remove Jane from Netherfield . Elizabeth mother would not listen , therefore , to Elizabeth sister ’s proposal of being carried home ; neither did the apothecary , who arrived about the same time , think Elizabeth sister ’s proposal of being carried home at all advisable . After sitting a little while with Jane , on Caroline ’s appearance and invitation , Elizabeth mother and three daughters all attended Caroline ’s into the breakfast parlour . Charles met Elizabeth mother and three daughters all with hopes that Elizabeth mother had not found Miss Bennet worse than Elizabeth mother expected . 
 
  “ Indeed Elizabeth mother have , Charles , ” was Elizabeth mother answer . “ Miss Bennet is a great deal too ill to be moved . Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving Miss Bennet . We must trespass a little longer on Charles kindness . ” 
 
  “ Removed ! ” cried Charles . “ moving must not be thought of . Elizabeth sister ’s , Elizabeth mother am sure , will not hear of Miss Bennet removal . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother may depend upon it , Elizabeth mother , ” said Caroline ’s , with cold civility , “ that Miss Bennet shall receive every possible attention while Miss Bennet remains with Elizabeth mother and three daughters all . ” 
 
  Elizabeth mother was profuse in Elizabeth mother acknowledgments . 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother am sure , ” Elizabeth mother added , “ if it was not for such good friends Elizabeth mother do not know what would become of Miss Bennet , for Miss Bennet is very ill indeed , and suffers a vast deal , though with the greatest patience in the world , which is always the way with Miss Bennet , for Miss Bennet has , without exception , the sweetest temper Elizabeth mother ever met with . Elizabeth mother often tell Elizabeth mother other girls Elizabeth mother other girls are nothing to Miss Bennet . You have a sweet room here , Charles , and a charming prospect over that gravel walk . Elizabeth mother do not know a place in the country that is equal to Netherfield . Charles will not think of quitting Netherfield in a hurry , Elizabeth mother hope , though Charles have but a short lease . ” 
 
  “ Whatever Charles do is done in a hurry , ” replied Charles ; “ and therefore if Charles should resolve to quit Netherfield , Charles should probably be off in five minutes . At present , however , Charles consider Charles as quite fixed here . ” 
 
  “ consider is exactly what Elizabeth mother should have supposed of Charles , ” said Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother begin to comprehend Elizabeth mother , do Elizabeth mother ? ” cried Charles , turning towards Elizabeth mother . 
 
  “ Oh ! yes — Elizabeth mother understand Elizabeth perfectly . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother wish Elizabeth mother might take this for a compliment ; but to be so easily seen through Elizabeth mother am afraid is pitiful . ” 
 
  “ That is as it happens . It does not necessarily follow that a deep , intricate character is more or less estimable than such a one as Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , ” cried Elizabeth mother , “ remember where Elizabeth are , and do not run on in the wild manner that Elizabeth are suffered to do at home . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother did not know before , ” continued Charles immediately , “ that Elizabeth were a studier of character . It must be an amusing study . ” 
 
  “ Yes ; but intricate characters are the most amusing . intricate characters have at least that advantage . ” 
 
  “ The country , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ can in general supply but few subjects for such a study . In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined and unvarying society . ” 
 
  “ But people people alter so much , that there is something new to be observed in people for ever . ” 
 
  “ Yes , indeed , ” cried Elizabeth mother , offended by Fitzwilliam manner of mentioning a country neighbourhood . “ Elizabeth mother assure Fitzwilliam there is quite as much of that going on in the country as in town . ” 
 
  Everybody was surprised ; and Fitzwilliam , after looking at Elizabeth mother for a moment , turned silently away . Elizabeth mother Elizabeth mother had gained a complete victory over Fitzwilliam , continued Elizabeth mother triumph . 
 
  “ Elizabeth mother can not see that London has any great advantage over the country , for Elizabeth mother part , except the shops and public places . The country is a vast deal pleasanter , is not the country , Charles ? ” 
 
  “ When Charles am in the country , ” Charles replied , “ Charles never wish to leave the country ; and when Elizabeth mother am in town it is pretty much the same . They have each They advantages , and Elizabeth mother can be equally happy in either . ” 
 
  “ Aye — that is because Elizabeth mother have the right disposition . But Fitzwilliam , ” looking at Fitzwilliam , “ seemed to think the country was nothing at all . ” 
 
  “ Indeed , Elizabeth mother , Elizabeth mother are mistaken , ” said Elizabeth , blushing for Elizabeth mother . “ Elizabeth mother quite mistook Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam only meant that there was not such a variety of people to be met with in the country as in town , which Elizabeth mother must acknowledge to be true . ” 
 
  “ Certainly , Elizabeth , nobody said there were ; but as to not meeting with many people in this neighbourhood , Elizabeth mother believe there are few neighbourhoods larger . Elizabeth mother know Elizabeth mother and three daughters all dine with four - and - twenty families . ” 
 
  Nothing but concern for Elizabeth could enable Charles to keep Charles countenance . Charles sister was less delicate , and directed Elizabeth eye towards Fitzwilliam with a very expressive smile . Elizabeth , for the sake of saying something that might turn Elizabeth mother ’s thoughts , now asked Elizabeth mother if Charlotte Lucas had been at Longbourn since Charlotte Lucas coming away . 
 
  “ Yes , Charlotte Lucas called yesterday with Charlotte Lucas father . What an agreeable man Charlotte Lucas father is , Charles — is not Charlotte Lucas father ? so much the man of fashion ! So genteel and so easy ! Charlotte Lucas father has always something to say to everybody . That is Elizabeth mother idea of good breeding ; and those persons who fancy those persons who fancy very important and never open those persons who fancy mouths , quite mistake the matter . ” 
 
  “ Did Charlotte Lucas dine with Elizabeth mother ? ” 
 
  “ No , Charlotte Lucas would go home . Elizabeth mother fancy Charlotte Lucas was wanted about the mince - pies . For Elizabeth mother part , Charles , Elizabeth mother always keep servants that can do servants that can do own work ; Elizabeth mother daughters are brought up differently . But everybody is to judge for everybody , and the Lucases are a very good sort of girls , Elizabeth mother assure Charles . It is a pity the Lucases are not handsome ! Not that Elizabeth mother think Charlotte Lucas so very plain — but then Charlotte Lucas is Elizabeth mother and three daughters all particular friend . ” 
 
  “ Charlotte Lucas seems a very pleasant young woman , ” said Charles . 
 
  “ Oh ! dear , yes ; but Charles must own Charlotte Lucas is very plain . Charlotte Lucas Charlotte Lucas has often said so , and envied Elizabeth mother Jane ’s beauty . Elizabeth mother do not like to boast of Elizabeth mother own child , but to be sure , Jane — one does not often see anybody better looking . does is what everybody says . Elizabeth mother do not trust Elizabeth mother own partiality . When Jane was only fifteen , there was a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane , that Elizabeth mother sister - in - law was sure a gentleman at Elizabeth mother brother Gardiner ’s in town so much in love with Jane would make Jane an offer before we came away .
