Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam , was one of the best men that ever breathed , and the truest friend Elizabeth ever had ; and Elizabeth can never be in company with this Fitzwilliam without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections . Fitzwilliam behaviour to Elizabeth has been scandalous ; but Elizabeth verily believe Elizabeth could forgive Fitzwilliam anything and everything , rather than Fitzwilliam disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of Fitzwilliam father . ” 
 
  Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase , and listened with all Elizabeth heart ; but the delicacy of it prevented further enquiry . Charlie Charlie began to speak on more general topics , Meryton , the neighbourhood , the society , appearing highly pleased with all that Charlie had yet seen , and speaking of the society with gentle but very intelligible gallantry . 
 
  “ It was the prospect of constant society , and good society , ” Charlie added , “ which was Charlie chief inducement to enter the — — shire . Charlie knew it to be a most respectable , agreeable corps , and Charlie friend Denny tempted Charlie further by Charlie friend Denny account of their present quarters , and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintances Meryton had procured their present quarters . Society , Charlie own , is necessary to Charlie . Charlie have been a disappointed man , and Charlie spirits will not bear solitude . Charlie must have employment and society . A military life is not what Charlie was intended for , but circumstances have now made A military life eligible . The church ought to have been Charlie profession — Charlie was brought up for the church , and Charlie should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living , had a most valuable living pleased Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Indeed ! ” 
 
  “ Yes — the late Fitzwilliam bequeathed Charlie the next presentation of the best living in Fitzwilliam gift . Fitzwilliam was Charlie godfather , and excessively attached to Charlie . Charlie can not do justice to Fitzwilliam kindness . Fitzwilliam meant to provide for Charlie amply , and thought Fitzwilliam had done it ; but when the living fell , the living was given elsewhere . ” 
 
  “ Good heavens ! ” cried Elizabeth ; “ but how could that be ? How could Fitzwilliam will be disregarded ? Why did Elizabeth not seek legal redress ? ” 
 
  “ There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give Elizabeth no hope from law . A man of honour could not have doubted the intention , but Fitzwilliam chose to doubt the intention — or to treat the bequest as a merely conditional recommendation , and to assert that Elizabeth had forfeited all claim to the living by extravagance , imprudence — in short anything or nothing . Certain it is , that the living became vacant two years ago , exactly as Elizabeth was of an age to hold the living , and that the living was given to another man ; and no less certain is it , that Elizabeth can not accuse Elizabeth of having really done anything to deserve to lose the living . Elizabeth have a warm , unguarded temper , and Elizabeth may have spoken Elizabeth opinion of Fitzwilliam , and to Fitzwilliam , too freely . Elizabeth can recall nothing worse . But the fact is , that we are very different sort of men , and that Fitzwilliam hates Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ This is quite shocking ! Fitzwilliam deserves to be publicly disgraced . ” 
 
  “ Some time or other Fitzwilliam will be — but it shall not be by Elizabeth . Till Elizabeth can forget Fitzwilliam father , Elizabeth can never defy or expose Fitzwilliam . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth honoured Elizabeth for such feelings , and thought Elizabeth handsomer than ever as Elizabeth expressed such feelings . 
 
  “ But what , ” said Elizabeth , after a pause , “ can have been Fitzwilliam motive ? What can have induced Fitzwilliam to behave so cruelly ? ” 
 
  “ A thorough , determined dislike of Charlie — a dislike which Elizabeth can not but attribute in some measure to jealousy . Had the late Fitzwilliam liked Charlie less , Fitzwilliam son might have borne with Charlie better ; but Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam uncommon attachment to Charlie irritated Fitzwilliam , Elizabeth believe , very early in life . Fitzwilliam had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood — the sort of preference which was often given Charlie . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth had not thought Fitzwilliam so bad as this — though Elizabeth have never liked Fitzwilliam . Elizabeth had not thought so very ill of Fitzwilliam . Elizabeth had supposed Fitzwilliam to be despising Fitzwilliam fellow - creatures in general , but did not suspect Fitzwilliam of descending to such malicious revenge , such injustice , such inhumanity as this . ” 
 
  After a few minutes ’ reflection , however , Elizabeth continued , “ Elizabeth do remember Fitzwilliam boasting one day , at Netherfield , of the implacability of Fitzwilliam resentments , of Fitzwilliam having an unforgiving temper . Fitzwilliam disposition must be dreadful . ” 
 
  “ Charlie will not trust Charlie on the subject , ” replied Charlie ; “ Charlie can hardly be just to Fitzwilliam . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth was again deep in thought , and after a time exclaimed , “ To treat in such a manner Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam father ! ” Elizabeth could have added , “ A young man , too , like Charlie , whose very countenance may vouch for Charlie being amiable”—but Elizabeth contented Elizabeth with , “ and one , too , who had probably been Fitzwilliam companion from childhood , connected together , as Elizabeth think Charlie said , in the closest manner ! ” 
 
  “ William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s five cousins were born in the same parish , within the same park ; the greatest part of William Collins ’s and William Collins ’s five cousins youth was passed together ; inmates of the same house , sharing the same amusements , objects of the same parental care . Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam began life in the profession which Charlie uncle , Mr. Phillips , appears to do so much credit to — but Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam gave up everything to be of use to the late Fitzwilliam and devoted all Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam time to the care of the Pemberley property . Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam was most highly esteemed by Fitzwilliam , a most intimate , confidential friend . Fitzwilliam often acknowledged Fitzwilliam to be under the greatest obligations to Charlie father ’s active superintendence , and when , immediately before Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam death , Fitzwilliam gave Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam a voluntary promise of providing for Charlie , Charlie am convinced that Fitzwilliam felt a voluntary promise of providing for Charlie to be as much a debt of gratitude to Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam , as of Fitzwilliam affection to Charlie . ” 
 
  “ How strange ! ” cried Elizabeth . “ How abominable ! Elizabeth wonder that the very pride of this Fitzwilliam has not made Fitzwilliam just to Charlie ! If from no better motive , that Fitzwilliam should not have been too proud to be dishonest — for dishonesty Elizabeth must call it . ” 
 
  “ It is wonderful , ” replied Charlie , “ for almost all Fitzwilliam actions may be traced to pride ; and pride had often been Fitzwilliam best friend . pride has connected Fitzwilliam nearer with virtue than with any other feeling . But we are none of we consistent , and in Fitzwilliam behaviour to Elizabeth there were stronger impulses even than pride . ” 
 
  “ Can such abominable pride as Fitzwilliam have ever done Fitzwilliam good ? ” 
 
  “ Yes . pride has often led Fitzwilliam to be liberal and generous , to give Fitzwilliam money freely , to display hospitality , to assist Fitzwilliam tenants , and relieve the poor . Family pride , and filial pride — for Fitzwilliam is very proud of what Fitzwilliam father was — have done this . Not to appear to disgrace Fitzwilliam family , to degenerate from the popular qualities , or lose the influence of the Pemberley property , is a powerful motive . Fitzwilliam has also brotherly pride , which , with some brotherly affection , makes Fitzwilliam a very kind and careful guardian of Fitzwilliam sister , and you will hear Fitzwilliam generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers . ” 
 
  “ What sort of girl is Fitzwilliam sister ? ” 
 
  Charlie shook Charlie head . “ Charlie wish Charlie could call Fitzwilliam sister amiable . It gives Charlie pain to speak ill of a Darcy . But Fitzwilliam sister is too much like Fitzwilliam sister brother — very , very proud . As a child , Fitzwilliam sister was affectionate and pleasing , and extremely fond of Charlie ; and Charlie have devoted hours and hours to Fitzwilliam sister amusement . But Fitzwilliam sister is nothing to Charlie now . Fitzwilliam sister is a handsome girl , about fifteen or sixteen , and , Charlie understand , highly accomplished . Since Fitzwilliam father , Miss Bennet , the late Fitzwilliam death , Fitzwilliam sister home has been London , where a lady lives with Fitzwilliam sister , and superintends Fitzwilliam sister education . ” 
 
  After many pauses and many trials of other subjects , Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first , and saying : 
 
  “ Elizabeth am astonished at Fitzwilliam intimacy with Charlie ! How can Charlie , be in friendship with Fitzwilliam ? How can Mr. and Mrs. Phillips suit each other ? Do Elizabeth know Charlie ? ” 
 
  “ Not at all . ” 
 
  “ Charlie is a sweet - tempered , amiable , charming man . Charlie can not know what Fitzwilliam is . ” 
 
  “ Probably not ; but Fitzwilliam can please where Fitzwilliam chooses . Fitzwilliam does not want abilities . Fitzwilliam can be a conversible companion if Fitzwilliam thinks it worth Fitzwilliam while . Among those who are at all Fitzwilliam equals in consequence , Fitzwilliam is a very different man from what Fitzwilliam is to the less prosperous . Fitzwilliam pride never deserts Fitzwilliam ; but with the rich Fitzwilliam is liberal - minded , just , sincere , rational , honourable , and perhaps agreeable — allowing something for fortune and figure . ” 
 
  The whist party soon afterwards breaking up , the players gathered round the other table and William Collins ’s took William Collins ’s station between William Collins ’s cousin Elizabeth and Mrs. Phillips . The usual enquiries as to William Collins ’s success were made by Mrs. Phillips . William Collins ’s success had not been very great ; William Collins ’s had lost every point ; but when Mrs. Phillips began to express Mrs. Phillips concern thereupon , William Collins ’s assured Mrs. Phillips with much earnest gravity that it was not of the least importance , that William Collins ’s considered the money as a mere trifle , and begged that Mrs. Phillips would not make Mrs. Phillips uneasy . 
 
  “ William Collins ’s know very well , Mrs. Phillips , ” said William Collins ’s , “ that when persons sit down to a card - table , persons must take persons chances of these things , and happily William Collins ’s am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object . There are undoubtedly many who could not say the same , but thanks to Cathleen ’s , William Collins ’s am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters . ” 
 
  Charlie ’s attention was caught ; and after observing William Collins ’s for a few moments , Charlie asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether Elizabeth relation was very intimately acquainted with the family of de Bourgh . 
 
  “ Cathleen ’s , ” Elizabeth replied , “ has very lately given William Collins ’s a living . Elizabeth hardly know how William Collins ’s was first introduced to Cathleen ’s notice , but William Collins ’s certainly has not known Cathleen ’s long . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth know of course that Cathleen ’s and Lady Anne Darcy were sisters ; consequently that Cathleen ’s is aunt to the present Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ No , indeed , Elizabeth did not . Elizabeth knew nothing at all of Cathleen ’s connections . Elizabeth never heard of Cathleen ’s existence till the day before yesterday . ” 
 
  “ Cathleen ’s , will have a very large fortune , and it is believed that Cathleen ’s and Cathleen ’s cousin will unite the two estates . ” 
 
  This information made Elizabeth smile , as Elizabeth thought of poor Caroline . Vain indeed must be all poor Caroline attentions , vain and useless poor Caroline affection for poor Caroline sister and poor Caroline praise of poor Caroline , if poor Caroline were already self - destined for another . 
 
  “ William Collins ’s , ” said Elizabeth , “ speaks highly both of Cathleen ’s and Cathleen ’s ; but from some particulars that William Collins ’s has related of Cathleen ’s , Elizabeth suspect Fitzwilliam gratitude misleads Fitzwilliam , and that in spite of Cathleen ’s being Fitzwilliam patroness , Cathleen ’s is an arrogant , conceited woman . ” 
 
  “ Charlie believe Cathleen ’s to be both in a great degree , ” replied Charlie ; “ Charlie have not seen Cathleen ’s for many years , but Charlie very well remember that Charlie never liked Cathleen ’s , and that Cathleen ’s manners were dictatorial and insolent . Cathleen ’s has the reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever ; but Charlie rather believe Cathleen ’s derives part of Cathleen ’s abilities from Cathleen ’s rank and fortune , part from Cathleen ’s authoritative manner , and the rest from the pride of Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam should have an understanding of the first class . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth allowed that Charlie had given a very rational account of it , and they continued talking together , with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards , and gave the rest of the ladies the rest of the ladies share of Charlie ’s attentions . There could be no conversation in the noise of Mrs. Phillips ’s supper party , but Fitzwilliam manners recommended Fitzwilliam to everybody . Whatever Fitzwilliam said , was said well ; and whatever Fitzwilliam did , done gracefully . Elizabeth went away with Elizabeth head full of Fitzwilliam . Elizabeth could think of nothing but of Charlie , and of what Fitzwilliam had told Elizabeth , all the way home ; but there was not time for Elizabeth even to mention Fitzwilliam name as they went , for neither Lydia nor William Collins ’s were once silent . Lydia talked incessantly of lottery tickets , of the fish Lydia had lost and the fish Lydia had won ; and William Collins ’s in describing the civility of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips , protesting that Fitzwilliam did not in the least regard Fitzwilliam losses at whist , enumerating all the dishes at supper , and repeatedly fearing that Fitzwilliam crowded Fitzwilliam cousins , had more to say than Fitzwilliam could well manage before the coach stopped at the house . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth related to Jane the next day what had passed between Charlie and Elizabeth . Jane listened with astonishment and concern ; Jane knew not how to believe that Charlie could be so unworthy of Charlie regard ; and yet , it was not in Jane nature to question the veracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as George . The possibility of George having endured such unkindness , was enough to interest all Jane tender feelings ; and nothing remained therefore to be done , but to think well of them both , to defend the conduct of each , and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be otherwise explained . 
 
  “ them both have both , ” said Jane , “ been deceived , Jane dare say , in some way or other , of which we can form no idea . Interested people have perhaps misrepresented each to the other . It is , in short , impossible for us to conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated them both , without actual blame on either side . ” 
 
  “ Very true , indeed ; and now , my dear Jane , what have Jane got to say on behalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business ? Do clear the interested people who have probably been concerned in the business too , or we shall be obliged to think ill of somebody . ” 
 
  “ Laugh as much as Elizabeth choose , but Elizabeth will not laugh Jane out of Jane opinion . My dearest Elizabeth , do but consider in what a disgraceful light it places Charlie , to be treating Charlie father ’s favourite in such a manner , Charlie father ’s favourite . treating is impossible . No man of common humanity , no man who had any value for Charlie character , could be capable of treating . Can Charlie most intimate friends be so excessively deceived in Charlie ? Oh ! no . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth can much more easily believe Charlie being imposed on , than that Charlie should invent such a history of Charlie as Charlie gave Elizabeth last night ; names , facts , everything mentioned without ceremony . If it be not so , let Charlie contradict such a history of Charlie as Charlie gave Elizabeth last night ; names , facts , everything mentioned without ceremony . Besides , there was truth in Charlie looks . ” 
 
  “ It is difficult indeed — it is distressing . One does not know what to think . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth beg Jane pardon ; one knows exactly what to think . ” 
 
  But Jane could think with certainty on only one point — that Charlie , if Charlie had been imposed on , would have much to suffer when the affair became public . 
 
  The two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery , where this conversation passed , by the arrival of the very persons of whom The two young ladies had been speaking ; Charlie and Charlie sisters came to give Charlie and Charlie sisters personal invitation for the long - expected ball at Netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday . The two young ladies were delighted to see Charlie father ’s favourite again , called it an age since The two young ladies had met , and repeatedly asked what Charlie father ’s favourite had been doing with Charlie father ’s favourite since their separation . To the rest of the family The two young ladies paid little attention ; avoiding Mother as much as possible , saying not much to Elizabeth , and nothing at all to the others . The two young ladies were soon gone again , rising from The two young ladies seats with an activity which took The two young ladies brother by surprise , and hurrying off as if eager to escape from Mother ’s civilities . 
 
  The prospect of the long - expected ball at Netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday was extremely agreeable to every female of the family . Mother chose to consider it as given in compliment to Charlie father ’s favourite , and was particularly flattered by receiving the invitation from Charlie , instead of a ceremonious card . Jane pictured to Jane a happy evening in the society of Jane two friends , and the attentions of Jane two friends brother ; and Elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with Charlie , and of seeing a confirmation of everything in Charlie look and behaviour . The happiness anticipated by Catherine and Lydia depended less on any single event , or any particular person , for though Catherine and Lydia each , like Elizabeth , meant to dance half the evening with Charlie , Charlie was by no means the only partner who could satisfy Catherine and Lydia , and a ball was , at any rate , a ball . And even Mary could assure even Mary family that even Mary had no disinclination for it . 
 
  “ While even Mary can have even Mary mornings to even Mary , ” said even Mary , “ it is enough — even Mary think it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements . Society has claims on us all ; and even Mary profess even Mary one of those who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for everybody . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth ’s spirits were so high on this occasion , that though Elizabeth did not often speak unnecessarily to William Collins , Elizabeth could not help asking William Collins whether William Collins intended to accept Charlie and Charlie sisters personal invitation for the long - expected ball at Netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday , and if William Collins did , whether William Collins would think it proper to join in the evening ’s amusement ; and Elizabeth was rather surprised to find that William Collins entertained no scruple whatever on that head , and was very far from dreading a rebuke either from the Archbishop , or Cathleen , by venturing to dance . 
 
  “ William Collins am by no means of the opinion , William Collins assure Elizabeth , ” said William Collins , “ that a ball of this kind , given by a young man of character , to respectable people , can have any evil tendency ; and William Collins am so far from objecting to dancing William Collins , that William Collins shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all William Collins fair cousins in the course of the evening ; and William Collins take this opportunity of soliciting Elizabeth , Miss Elizabeth , for the two first dances especially , a preference which William Collins trust William Collins cousin Jane will attribute to the right cause , and not to any disrespect for William Collins cousin Jane . ” 
 
  Elizabeth felt Elizabeth completely taken in . Elizabeth had fully proposed being engaged by Charlie for the two first dances especially ; and to have William Collins instead ! Elizabeth liveliness had never been worse timed . There was no help for it , however . Charlie ’s happiness and Elizabeth own were perforce delayed a little longer , and William Collins ’s proposal accepted with as good a grace as Elizabeth could . Elizabeth was not the better pleased with William Collins gallantry from the idea William Collins gallantry suggested of something more . It now first struck Elizabeth , that Elizabeth was selected from among Elizabeth sisters as worthy of being mistress of Hunsford Parsonage , and of assisting to form a quadrille table at Rosings , in the absence of more eligible visitors . The idea soon reached to conviction , as Elizabeth observed William Collins increasing civilities toward Elizabeth , and heard William Collins frequent attempt at a compliment on Elizabeth wit and vivacity ; and though more astonished than gratified Elizabeth by this effect of Elizabeth charms , it was not long before Elizabeth mother gave Elizabeth to understand that the probability of their marriage was extremely agreeable to Mother . Elizabeth , however , did not choose to take the hint , being well aware that a serious dispute must be the consequence of any reply . William Collins might never make William Collins ’s proposal , and till William Collins did , it was useless to quarrel about William Collins . 
 
  If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of , the younger Miss Bennets would have been in a very pitiable state at this time , for from the day of Charlie and Charlie sisters personal invitation for the long - expected ball at Netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday , to the day of the long - expected ball at Netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday , there was such a succession of rain as prevented the younger Miss Bennets walking to Meryton once . No aunt , no officers , no news could be sought after — the very shoe - roses for Netherfield were got by proxy . Even Elizabeth might have found some trial of Elizabeth patience in weather which totally suspended the improvement of Elizabeth acquaintance with Charlie ; and nothing less than a dance on Tuesday , could have made such a Friday , Saturday , Sunday , and Monday endurable to Catherine and Lydia . 
 Chapter 
 
 Till Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in vain for Charlie among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a doubt of his being present had never occurred to her. The certainty of meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that might not unreasonably have alarmed her. She had dressed with more than usual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all that remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than might be won in the course of the evening. But in an instant arose the dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted for Fitzwilliam’s pleasure in the Bingleys’ invitation to the officers; and though this was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was pronounced by his friend Denny, to whom Lydia eagerly applied, and who told them that George had been obliged to go to town on business the day before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile, “I do not imagine his business would have called him away just now, if he had not wanted to avoid a certain gentleman here.”
 
 This part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lydia, was caught by Elizabeth, and, as it assured her that Fitzwilliam was not less answerable for George’s absence than if her first surmise had been just, every feeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate disappointment, that she could hardly reply with tolerable civility to the polite enquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make. Attendance, forbearance, patience with Fitzwilliam, was injury to George. She was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away with a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in speaking to Charles, whose blind partiality provoked her.
 
 But Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect of her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her spirits; and having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had not seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition to the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular notice. The first two dances, however, brought a return of distress; they were dances of mortification. William Collins, awkward and solemn, apologising instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being aware of it, gave her all the shame and misery which a disagreeable partner for a couple of dances can give. The moment of her release from him was ecstasy.
 
 She danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of George, and of hearing that he was universally liked. When those dances were over, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and was in conversation with her, when she found herself suddenly addressed by Fitzwilliam who took her so much by surprise in his application for her hand, that, without knowing what she did, she accepted him. He walked away again immediately, and she was left to fret over her own want of presence of mind; Charlotte tried to console her:
 
 “I dare say you will find him very agreeable.”
 
 “Heaven forbid! That would be the greatest misfortune of all! To find a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate! Do not wish me such an evil.”
 
 When the dancing recommenced, however, and Fitzwilliam approached to claim her hand, Charlotte could not help cautioning her in a whisper, not to be a simpleton, and allow her fancy for George to make her appear unpleasant in the eyes of a man ten times his consequence. Elizabeth made no answer, and took her place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which she was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to Fitzwilliam, and reading in her neighbours’ looks, their equal amazement in beholding it. They stood for some time without speaking a word; and she began to imagine that their silence was to last through the two dances, and at first was resolved not to break it; till suddenly fancying that it would be the greater punishment to her partner to oblige him to talk, she made some slight observation on the dance. He replied, and was again silent. After a pause of some minutes, she addressed him a second time with:—“It is your turn to say something now, Fitzwilliam. I talked about the dance, and you ought to make some sort of remark on the size of the room, or the number of couples.”
 
 He smiled, and assured her that whatever she wished him to say should be said.
 
 “Very well. That reply will do for the present. Perhaps by and by I may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones. But now we may be silent.”
 
 “Do you talk by rule, then, while you are dancing?”
 
 “Sometimes. One must speak a little, you know. It would look odd to be entirely silent for half an hour together; and yet for the advantage of some, conversation ought to be so arranged, as that they may have the trouble of saying as little as possible.”
 
 “Are you consulting your own feelings in the present case, or do you imagine that you are gratifying mine?”
 
 “Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great similarity in the turn of our minds. We are each of an unsocial, taciturn disposition, unwilling to speak, unless we expect to say something that will amaze the whole room, and be handed down to posterity with all the éclat of a proverb.”
 
 “This is no very striking resemblance of your own character, I am sure,” said he. “How near it may be to mine, I cannot pretend to say. You think it a faithful portrait undoubtedly.”
 
 “I must not decide on my own performance.”
 
 He made no answer, and they were again silent till they had gone down the dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often walk to Meryton. She answered in the affirmative, and, unable to resist the temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just been forming a new acquaintance.”
 
 The effect was immediate. A deeper shade of hauteur overspread his features, but he said not a word, and Elizabeth, though blaming herself for her own weakness, could not go on. At length Fitzwilliam spoke, and in a constrained manner said, “Charlie is blessed with such happy manners as may ensure his making friends—whether he may be equally capable of retaining them, is less certain.”
 
 “He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship,” replied Elizabeth with emphasis, “and in a manner which he is likely to suffer from all his life.”
 
 Fitzwilliam made no answer, and seemed desirous of changing the subject. At that moment, Sir William Lucas appeared close to them, meaning to pass through the set to the other side of the room; but on perceiving Fitzwilliam, he stopped with a bow of superior courtesy to compliment him on his dancing and his partner.
 
 “I have been most highly gratified indeed, my dear sir. Such very superior dancing is not often seen. It is evident that you belong to the first circles. Allow me to say, however, that your fair partner does not disgrace you, and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated, especially when a certain desirable event, my dear Elizabeth (glancing at her sister and Charles) shall take place. What congratulations will then flow in! I appeal to Fitzwilliam:—but let me not interrupt you, sir. You will not thank me for detaining you from the bewitching converse of that young lady, whose bright eyes are also upbraiding me.”
 
 The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by Fitzwilliam; but Sir William’s allusion to his friend seemed to strike him forcibly, and his eyes were directed with a very serious expression towards Charles and Jane, who were dancing together. Recovering himself, however, shortly, he turned to his partner, and said, “Sir William’s interruption has made me forget what we were talking of.”
 
 “I do not think we were speaking at all. Sir William could not have interrupted two people in the room who had less to say for themselves. We have tried two or three subjects already without success, and what we are to talk of next I cannot imagine.”
 
 “What think you of books?” said he, smiling.
 
 “Books—oh! no. I am sure we never read the same, or not with the same feelings.”
 
 “I am sorry you think so; but if that be the case, there can at least be no want of subject. We may compare our different opinions.”
 
 “No—I cannot talk of books in a ball-room; my head is always full of something else.”
 
 “The present always occupies you in such scenes—does it?” said he, with a look of doubt.
 
 “Yes, always,” she replied, without knowing what she said, for her thoughts had wandered far from the subject, as soon afterwards appeared by her suddenly exclaiming, “I remember hearing you once say, Fitzwilliam, that you hardly ever forgave, that your resentment once created was unappeasable. You are very cautious, I suppose, as to its being created?”
 
 “I am,” said he, with a firm voice.
 
 “And never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice?”
 
 “I hope not.”
 
 “It is particularly incumbent on those who never change their opinion, to be secure of judging properly at first.”
 
 “May I ask to what these questions tend?”
 
 “Merely to the illustration of your character,” said she, endeavouring to shake off her gravity. “I am trying to make it out.”
 
 “And what is your success?”
 
 She shook her head. “I do not get on at all. I hear such different accounts of you as puzzle me exceedingly.”
 
 “I can readily believe,” answered he gravely, “that reports may vary greatly with respect to me; and I could wish, Miss Bennet, that you were not to sketch my character at the present moment, as there is reason to fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either.”
 
 “But if I do not take your likeness now, I may never have another opportunity.”
 
 “I would by no means suspend any pleasure of yours,” he coldly replied. She said no more, and they went down the other dance and parted in silence; and on each side dissatisfied, though not to an equal degree, for in Fitzwilliam’s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards her, which soon procured her pardon, and directed all his anger against another.
 
 They had not long separated, when Caroline came towards her, and with an expression of civil disdain accosted her:
 
 “So, Elizabeth, I hear you are quite delighted with George! Your sister has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand questions; and I find that the young man quite forgot to tell you, among his other communication, that he was the son of old George, the late Fitzwilliam’s steward. Let me recommend you, however, as a friend, not to give implicit confidence to all his assertions; for as to Fitzwilliam’s using him ill, it is perfectly false; for, on the contrary, he has always been remarkably kind to him, though George has treated Fitzwilliam in a most infamous manner. I do not know the particulars, but I know very well that Fitzwilliam is not in the least to blame, that he cannot bear to hear George mentioned, and that though my brother thought that he could not well avoid including him in his invitation to the officers, he was excessively glad to find that he had taken himself out of the way. His coming into the country at all is a most insolent thing, indeed, and I wonder how he could presume to do it. I pity you, Elizabeth, for this discovery of your favourite’s guilt; but really, considering his descent, one could not expect much better.”
 
 “His guilt and his descent appear by your account to be the same,” said Elizabeth angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse than of being the son of Fitzwilliam’s steward, and of that, I can assure you, he informed me himself.”
 
 “I beg your pardon,” replied Caroline, turning away with a sneer. “Excuse my interference—it was kindly meant.”
 
 “Insolent girl!” said Elizabeth to herself. “You are much mistaken if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this. I see nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of Fitzwilliam.” She then sought her eldest sister, who had undertaken to make enquiries on the same subject of Charles. Jane met her with a smile of such sweet complacency, a glow of such happy expression, as sufficiently marked how well she was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening. Elizabeth instantly read her feelings, and at that moment solicitude for George, resentment against his enemies, and everything else, gave way before the hope of Jane’s being in the fairest way for happiness.
 
 “I want to know,” said she, with a countenance no less smiling than her sister’s, “what you have learnt about Charlie. But perhaps you have been too pleasantly engaged to think of any third person; in which case you may be sure of my pardon.”
 
 “No,” replied Jane, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing satisfactory to tell you. Charles does not know the whole of his history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have principally offended Fitzwilliam; but he will vouch for the good conduct, the probity, and honour of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that Charlie has deserved much less attention from Fitzwilliam than he has received; and I am sorry to say by his account as well as his sister’s, Charlie is by no means a respectable young man. I am afraid he has been very imprudent, and has deserved to lose Fitzwilliam’s regard.”
 
 “Charles does not know Charlie himself?”
 
 “No; he never saw him till the other morning at Meryton.”
 
 “This account then is what he has received from Fitzwilliam. I am satisfied. But what does he say of the living?”
 
 “He does not exactly recollect the circumstances, though he has heard them from Fitzwilliam more than once, but he believes that it was left to him conditionally only.”
 
 “I have not a doubt of Charles’s sincerity,” said Elizabeth warmly; “but you must excuse my not being convinced by assurances only. Charles’s defense of his friend was a very able one, I dare say; but since he is unacquainted with several parts of the story, and has learnt the rest from that friend himself, I shall venture to still think of both gentlemen as I did before.”
 
 She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on which there could be no difference of sentiment. Elizabeth listened with delight to the happy, though modest hopes which Jane entertained of Charles’s regard, and said all in her power to heighten her confidence in it. On their being joined by Charles himself, Elizabeth withdrew to Miss Lucas; to whose enquiry after the pleasantness of her last partner she had scarcely replied, before William Collins came up to them, and told her with great exultation that he had just been so fortunate as to make a most important discovery.
 
 “I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now in the room a near relation of my patroness. I happened to overhear the gentleman himself mentioning to the young lady who does the honours of the house the names of his cousin Cathleen, and of her mother Cathleen. How wonderfully these sort of things occur! Who would have thought of my meeting with, perhaps, a nephew of Cathleen in this assembly! I am most thankful that the discovery is made in time for me to pay my respects to him, which I am now going to do, and trust he will excuse my not having done it before. My total ignorance of the connection must plead my apology.”
 
 “You are not going to introduce yourself to Fitzwilliam!”
 
 “Indeed I am. I shall entreat his pardon for not having done it earlier. I believe him to be Cathleen’s nephew. It will be in my power to assure him that her ladyship was quite well yesterday se’nnight.”
 
 Elizabeth tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme, assuring him that Fitzwilliam would consider his addressing him without introduction as an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either side; and that if it were, it must belong to Fitzwilliam, the superior in consequence, to begin the acquaintance. William Collins listened to her with the determined air of following his own inclination, and, when she ceased speaking, replied thus:
 
 “My dear Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world in your excellent judgement in all matters within the scope of your understanding; but permit me to say, that there must be a wide difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity, and those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that I consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with the highest rank in the kingdom—provided that a proper humility of behaviour is at the same time maintained. You must therefore allow me to follow the dictates of my conscience on this occasion, which leads me to perform what I look on as a point of duty. Pardon me for neglecting to profit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant guide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by education and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young lady like yourself.” And with a low bow he left her to attack Fitzwilliam, whose reception of his advances she eagerly watched, and whose astonishment at being so addressed was very evident. Her cousin prefaced his speech with a solemn bow and though she could not hear a word of it, she felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the words “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Cathleen.” It vexed her to see him expose himself to such a man. Fitzwilliam was eyeing him with unrestrained wonder, and when at last William Collins allowed him time to speak, replied with an air of distant civility. William Collins, however, was not discouraged from speaking again, and Fitzwilliam’s contempt seemed abundantly increasing with the length of his second speech, and at the end of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way. William Collins then returned to Elizabeth.
 
 “I have no reason, I assure you,” said he, “to be dissatisfied with my reception. Fitzwilliam seemed much pleased with the attention. He answered me with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying that he was so well convinced of Cathleen’s discernment as to be certain she could never bestow a favour unworthily. It was really a very handsome thought. Upon the whole, I am much pleased with him.”
 
 As Elizabeth had no longer any interest of her own to pursue, she turned her attention almost entirely on her sister and Charles; and the train of agreeable reflections which her observations gave birth to, made her perhaps almost as happy as Jane. She saw her in idea settled in that very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection could bestow; and she felt capable, under such circumstances, of endeavouring even to like Charles’s two sisters. Her mother’s thoughts she plainly saw were bent the same way, and she determined not to venture near her, lest she might hear too much. When they sat down to supper, therefore, she considered it a most unlucky perverseness which placed them within one of each other; and deeply was she vexed to find that her mother was talking to that one person (Lady Lucas) freely, openly, and of nothing else but her expectation that Jane would soon be married to Charles. It was an animating subject, and Mother seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the match. His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but three miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and then it was such a comfort to think how fond the two sisters were of Jane, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as she could do. It was, moreover, such a promising thing for her younger daughters, as Jane’s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of other rich men; and lastly, it was so pleasant at her time of life to be able to consign her single daughters to the care of their sister, that she might not be obliged to go into company more than she liked. It was necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on such occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than Mother to find comfort in staying home at any period of her life. She concluded with many good wishes that Lady Lucas might soon be equally fortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no chance of it.
 
 In vain did Elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of her mother’s words, or persuade her to describe her felicity in a less audible whisper; for, to her inexpressible vexation, she could perceive that the chief of it was overheard by Fitzwilliam, who sat opposite to them. Her mother only scolded her for being nonsensical.
 
 “What is Fitzwilliam to me, pray, that I should be afraid of him? I am sure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say nothing he may not like to hear.”
 
 “For heaven’s sake, madam, speak lower. What advantage can it be for you to offend Fitzwilliam? You will never recommend yourself to his friend by so doing!”
 
 Nothing that she could say, however, had any influence. Her mother would talk of her views in the same intelligible tone. Elizabeth blushed and blushed again with shame and vexation. She could not help frequently glancing her eye at Fitzwilliam, though every glance convinced her of what she dreaded; for though he was not always looking at her mother, she was convinced that his attention was invariably fixed by her. The expression of his face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and steady gravity.
 
 At length, however, Mother had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and chicken. Elizabeth now began to revive. But not long was the interval of tranquillity; for, when supper was over, singing was talked of, and she had the mortification of seeing Mary, after very little entreaty, preparing to oblige the company. By many significant looks and silent entreaties, did she endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance, but in vain; Mary would not understand them; such an opportunity of exhibiting was delightful to her, and she began her song. Elizabeth’s eyes were fixed on her with most painful sensations, and she watched her progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very ill rewarded at their close; for Mary, on receiving, amongst the thanks of the table, the hint of a hope that she might be prevailed on to favour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another. Mary’s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; her voice was weak, and her manner affected. Elizabeth was in agonies. She looked at Jane, to see how she bore it; but Jane was very composedly talking to Charles. She looked at his two sisters, and saw them making signs of derision at each other, and at Fitzwilliam, who continued, however, imperturbably grave. She looked at her father to entreat his interference, lest Mary should be singing all night. He took the hint, and when Mary had finished her second song, said aloud, “That will do extremely well, child. You have delighted us long enough. Let the other young ladies have time to exhibit.”
 
 Mary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and Elizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father’s speech, was afraid her anxiety had done no good. Others of the party were now applied to.
 
 “If I,” said William Collins, “were so fortunate as to be able to sing, I should have great pleasure, I am sure, in obliging the company with an air; for I consider music as a very innocent diversion, and perfectly compatible with the profession of a clergyman. I do not mean, however, to assert that we can be justified in devoting too much of our time to music, for there are certainly other things to be attended to. The rector of a parish has much to do. In the first place, he must make such an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to himself and not offensive to his patron. He must write his own sermons; and the time that remains will not be too much for his parish duties, and the care and improvement of his dwelling, which he cannot be excused from making as comfortable as possible. And I do not think it of light importance that he should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards everybody, especially towards those to whom he owes his preferment. I cannot acquit him of that duty; nor could I think well of the man who should omit an occasion of testifying his respect towards anybody connected with the family.” And with a bow to Fitzwilliam, he concluded his speech, which had been spoken so loud as to be heard by half the room. Many stared—many smiled; but no one looked more amused than Father himself, while his wife seriously commended William Collins for having spoken so sensibly, and observed in a half-whisper to Lady Lucas, that he was a remarkably clever, good kind of young man.
 
 To Elizabeth it appeared that, had her family made an agreement to expose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would have been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit or finer success; and happy did she think it for Charles and her sister that some of the exhibition had escaped his notice, and that his feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he must have witnessed. That his two sisters and Fitzwilliam, however, should have such an opportunity of ridiculing her relations, was bad enough, and she could not determine whether the silent contempt of the gentleman, or the insolent smiles of the ladies, were more intolerable.
 
 The rest of the evening brought her little amusement. She was teased by William Collins, who continued most perseveringly by her side, and though he could not prevail on her to dance with him again, put it out of her power to dance with others. In vain did she entreat him to stand up with somebody else, and offer to introduce him to any young lady in the room. He assured her, that as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it; that his chief object was by delicate attentions to recommend himself to her and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to her the whole evening. There was no arguing upon such a project. She owed her greatest relief to her friend Miss Lucas, who often joined them, and good-naturedly engaged William Collins’s conversation to herself.
 
 She was at least free from the offense of Fitzwilliam’s further notice; though often standing within a very short distance of her, quite disengaged, he never came near enough to speak. She felt it to be the probable consequence of her allusions to Charlie, and rejoiced in it.
 
 The Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart, and, by a manoeuvre of Mother, had to wait for their carriage a quarter of an hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how heartily they were wished away by some of the family. Mrs. Hurst and her sister scarcely opened their mouths, except to complain of fatigue, and were evidently impatient to have the house to themselves. They repulsed every attempt of Mother at conversation, and by so doing threw a languor over the whole party, which was very little relieved by the long speeches of William Collins, who was complimenting Charles and his sisters on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and politeness which had marked their behaviour to their guests. Fitzwilliam said nothing at all. Father, in equal silence, was enjoying the scene. Charles and Jane were standing together, a little detached from the rest, and talked only to each other. Elizabeth preserved as steady a silence as either Mrs. Hurst or Caroline; and even Lydia was too much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “Lord, how tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.
 
 When at length they arose to take leave, Mother was most pressingly civil in her hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn, and addressed herself especially to Charles, to assure him how happy he would make them by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without the ceremony of a formal invitation. Charles was all grateful pleasure, and he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on her, after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next day for a short time.
 
 Mother was perfectly satisfied, and quitted the house under the delightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of settlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, she should undoubtedly see her daughter settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four months. Of having another daughter married to William Collins, she thought with equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure. Elizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the man and the match were quite good enough for her, the worth of each was eclipsed by Charles and Netherfield.
 Chapter 
 
  The next day opened a new scene at Longbourn . William Collins made William Collins declaration in form . Having resolved to do made without loss of time , as William Collins leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday , and having no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to William Collins even at the moment , William Collins set about made in a very orderly manner , with all the observances , which William Collins supposed a regular part of the business . On finding Mother , Elizabeth , and one of the younger girls together , soon after breakfast , William Collins addressed the mother in these words : 
 
  “ May William Collins hope , Mother , for Mother interest with Mother fair daughter Elizabeth , when William Collins solicit for the honour of a private audience with Elizabeth in the course of this morning ? ” 
 
  Before Elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise , Mother answered instantly , “ Oh dear!—yes — certainly . Mother am sure Elizabeth will be very happy — Mother am sure Elizabeth can have no objection . Come , one of the younger girls , Mother want one of the younger girls up stairs . ” And , gathering Mother work together , Mother was hastening away , when Elizabeth called out : 
 
  “ Mother , do not go . Elizabeth beg Mother will not go . William Collins must excuse Elizabeth . William Collins can have nothing to say to Elizabeth that anybody need not hear . Elizabeth am going away Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ No , no , nonsense , Elizabeth . Mother desire Elizabeth to stay where Elizabeth are . ” And upon Elizabeth ’s seeming really , with vexed and embarrassed looks , about to escape , Mother added : “ Elizabeth , Mother insist upon Elizabeth staying and hearing William Collins . ” 
 
  Elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction — and a moment ’s consideration making Elizabeth also sensible that it would be wisest to get it over as soon and as quietly as possible , Elizabeth sat down again and tried to conceal , by incessant employment the feelings which were divided between distress and diversion . Mother and one of the younger girls walked off , and as soon as Mother and one of the younger girls were gone , William Collins began . 
 
  “ Believe William Collins , William Collins dear Elizabeth , that Elizabeth modesty , so far from doing Elizabeth any disservice , rather adds to Elizabeth other perfections . Elizabeth would have been less amiable in William Collins eyes had there not been this little unwillingness ; but allow William Collins to assure Elizabeth , that William Collins have Elizabeth respected mother ’s permission for this address . Elizabeth can hardly doubt the purport of William Collins discourse , however Elizabeth natural delicacy may lead Elizabeth to dissemble ; William Collins attentions have been too marked to be mistaken . Almost as soon as William Collins entered the house , William Collins singled Elizabeth out as the companion of William Collins future life . But before William Collins am run away with by William Collins feelings on this subject , perhaps it would be advisable for William Collins to state William Collins reasons for marrying — and , moreover , for coming into Hertfordshire with the design of selecting a wife , as William Collins certainly did . ” 
 
  The idea of William Collins , with all William Collins solemn composure , being run away with by William Collins feelings , made Elizabeth so near laughing , that Elizabeth could not use the short pause William Collins allowed in any attempt to stop William Collins further , and William Collins continued : 
 
  “ William Collins reasons for marrying are , first , that William Collins think it a right thing for every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like William Collins ) to set the example of matrimony in every clergyman in easy circumstances ( like William Collins ) parish ; secondly , that William Collins am convinced that it will add very greatly to William Collins happiness ; and thirdly — which perhaps William Collins ought to have mentioned earlier , that it is the particular advice and recommendation of the very noble lady whom William Collins have the honour of calling patroness . Twice has the very noble lady whom William Collins have the honour of calling patroness condescended to give William Collins the very noble lady whom William Collins have the honour of calling patroness opinion ( unasked too ! ) on this subject ; and it was but the very Saturday night before William Collins left Hunsford — between our pools at quadrille , while Mrs. Jenkinson was arranging Cathleen ’s footstool , that the very noble lady whom William Collins have the honour of calling patroness said , ‘ William Collins , William Collins must marry . A clergyman like William Collins must marry . Choose properly , choose a gentlewoman for the very noble lady whom William Collins have the honour of calling patroness sake ; and for William Collins own , let a gentlewoman be an active , useful sort of person , not brought up high , but able to make a small income go a good way . This is the very noble lady whom William Collins have the honour of calling patroness advice . Find such a woman as soon as William Collins can , bring such a woman to Hunsford , and the very noble lady whom William Collins have the honour of calling patroness will visit such a woman . ’ Allow William Collins , by the way , to observe , Elizabeth , that William Collins do not reckon the notice and kindness of Cathleen ’s as among the least of the advantages in William Collins power to offer . Elizabeth will find Cathleen ’s manners beyond anything William Collins can describe ; and Elizabeth wit and vivacity , William Collins think , must be acceptable to Cathleen ’s , especially when tempered with the silence and respect which Cathleen ’s rank will inevitably excite . Thus much for William Collins general intention in favour of matrimony ; it remains to be told why William Collins views were directed towards Longbourn instead of William Collins own neighbourhood , where William Collins can assure Elizabeth there are many amiable young women . But the fact is , that being , as William Collins am , to inherit this estate after the death of Elizabeth honoured father ( who , however , may live many years longer ) , William Collins could not satisfy William Collins without resolving to choose a wife from among Elizabeth honoured father ( who , however , may live many years longer ) daughters , that the loss to Elizabeth honoured father ( who , however , may live many years longer ) daughters might be as little as possible , when the melancholy event takes place — which , however , as William Collins have already said , may not be for several years . This has been William Collins motive , William Collins fair cousin , and William Collins flatter William Collins This will not sink William Collins in Elizabeth esteem . And now nothing remains for William Collins but to assure Elizabeth in the most animated language of the violence of William Collins affection . To fortune William Collins am perfectly indifferent , and shall make no demand of that nature on Elizabeth honoured father ( who , however , may live many years longer ) , since William Collins am well aware that it could not be complied with ; and that one thousand pounds in the four per cents , which will not be Elizabeth till after Elizabeth mother ’s decease , is all that Elizabeth may ever be entitled to . On that head , therefore , William Collins shall be uniformly silent ; and Elizabeth may assure Elizabeth that no ungenerous reproach shall ever pass William Collins lips when we are married . ” 
 
  It was absolutely necessary to interrupt William Collins now . 
 
  “ William Collins are too hasty , William Collins , ” Elizabeth cried . “ William Collins forget that Elizabeth have made no answer . Let Elizabeth do it without further loss of time . Accept Elizabeth thanks for the compliment William Collins are paying Elizabeth . Elizabeth am very sensible of the honour of William Collins proposals , but it is impossible for Elizabeth to do otherwise than to decline William Collins proposals . ” 
 
  “ William Collins am not now to learn , ” replied William Collins , with a formal wave of the hand , “ that it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the man whom young ladies secretly mean to accept , when the man whom young ladies secretly mean to accept first applies for young ladies favour ; and that sometimes reject is repeated a second , or even a third time . William Collins am therefore by no means discouraged by what Elizabeth have just said , and shall hope to lead Elizabeth to the altar ere long . ” 
 
  “ Upon Elizabeth word , William Collins , ” cried Elizabeth , “ William Collins hope is a rather extraordinary one after Elizabeth declaration . Elizabeth do assure William Collins that Elizabeth am not one of those young ladies ( if such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk those young ladies ( if such young ladies there are ) who are so daring as to risk happiness on the chance of being asked a second time . Elizabeth am perfectly serious in Elizabeth refusal . William Collins could not make Elizabeth happy , and Elizabeth am convinced that Elizabeth am the last woman in the world who could make William Collins so . Nay , were William Collins friend Cathleen to know Elizabeth , Elizabeth am persuaded Cathleen ’s would find Elizabeth in every respect ill qualified for the situation . ” 
 
  “ Were it certain that Cathleen ’s would think so , ” said William Collins very gravely—“but William Collins can not imagine that Cathleen ’s would at all disapprove of Elizabeth . And Elizabeth may be certain when William Collins have the honour of seeing Cathleen ’s again , William Collins shall speak in the very highest terms of Elizabeth modesty , economy , and other amiable qualification . ” 
 
  “ Indeed , William Collins , all praise of Elizabeth will be unnecessary . William Collins must give Elizabeth leave to judge for Elizabeth , and pay Elizabeth the compliment of believing what Elizabeth say . Elizabeth wish William Collins very happy and very rich , and by refusing William Collins hand , do all in Elizabeth power to prevent William Collins being otherwise . In making Elizabeth the offer , William Collins must have satisfied the delicacy of William Collins feelings with regard to Elizabeth family , and may take possession of this estate whenever this estate falls , without any self - reproach . This matter may be considered , therefore , as finally settled . ” And rising as Elizabeth thus spoke , Elizabeth would have quitted the room , had William Collins not thus addressed Elizabeth : 
 
  “ When William Collins do William Collins the honour of speaking to Elizabeth next on the subject , William Collins shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than Elizabeth have now given William Collins ; though William Collins am far from accusing Elizabeth of cruelty at present , because William Collins know it to be the established custom of Elizabeth sex to reject a man on the first application , and perhaps Elizabeth have even now said as much to encourage William Collins suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of the female character . ” 
 
  “ Really , William Collins , ” cried Elizabeth with some warmth , “ William Collins puzzle Elizabeth exceedingly . If what Elizabeth have hitherto said can appear to William Collins in the form of encouragement , Elizabeth know not how to express Elizabeth refusal in such a way as to convince William Collins of Elizabeth refusal being one . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth must give William Collins leave to flatter William Collins , William Collins dear cousin , that Elizabeth refusal of William Collins addresses is merely words of course . William Collins reasons for believing it are briefly these : It does not appear to William Collins that William Collins hand is unworthy of Elizabeth acceptance , or that the establishment William Collins can offer would be any other than highly desirable . Elizabeth situation in life , Elizabeth connections with the family of de Bourgh , and Elizabeth relationship to William Collins own , are circumstances highly in Elizabeth favour ; and William Collins should take it into further consideration , that in spite of William Collins manifold attractions , it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made William Collins . William Collins portion is unhappily so small that William Collins portion will in all likelihood undo the effects of William Collins loveliness and amiable qualifications . As Elizabeth must therefore conclude that William Collins are not serious in William Collins rejection of Elizabeth , Elizabeth shall choose to attribute William Collins rejection of Elizabeth to William Collins wish of increasing Elizabeth love by suspense , according to the usual practice of elegant females . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth do assure William Collins , William Collins , that Elizabeth have no pretensions whatever to that kind of elegance which consists in tormenting a respectable man . Elizabeth would rather be paid the compliment of being believed sincere . Elizabeth thank William Collins again and again for the honour William Collins have done Elizabeth in William Collins proposals , but to accept William Collins proposals is absolutely impossible . Elizabeth feelings in every respect forbid accept . Can Elizabeth speak plainer ? Do not consider Elizabeth now as an elegant female , intending to plague William Collins , but as a rational creature , speaking the truth from a rational creature , speaking the truth from heart . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth are uniformly charming ! ” cried William Collins , with an air of awkward gallantry ; “ and William Collins am persuaded that when sanctioned by the express authority of both Elizabeth excellent parents , William Collins proposals will not fail of being acceptable . ” 
 
  To such perseverance in wilful self - deception Elizabeth would make no reply , and immediately and in silence withdrew ; determined , if William Collins persisted in considering Elizabeth repeated refusals as flattering encouragement , to apply to Elizabeth father , whose negative might be uttered in such a manner as to be decisive , and whose behaviour at least could not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant female . 
 Chapter 
 
  William Collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of William Collins successful love ; for Mother , having dawdled about in the vestibule to watch for the end of the conference , no sooner saw Elizabeth open the door and with quick step pass Elizabeth towards the staircase , than Mother entered the breakfast - room , and congratulated both William Collins and Mother in warm terms on the happy prospect of both William Collins and Mother nearer connection . William Collins received and returned congratulated with equal pleasure , and then proceeded to relate the particulars of their interview , with the result of which William Collins trusted William Collins had every reason to be satisfied , since the refusal which William Collins cousin had steadfastly given William Collins would naturally flow from Elizabeth bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of Elizabeth character . 
 
  This information , however , startled Mother ; Mother would have been glad to be equally satisfied that Elizabeth had meant to encourage William Collins by protesting against William Collins proposals , but Mother dared not believe meant , and could not help saying so . 
 
  “ But , depend upon it , William Collins , ” Mother added , “ that Elizabeth shall be brought to reason . Mother will speak to Elizabeth about it directly . Elizabeth is a very headstrong , foolish girl , and does not know Elizabeth own interest but Mother will make Elizabeth know Elizabeth own interest . ” 
 
  “ Pardon William Collins for interrupting Mother , Mother , ” cried William Collins ; “ but if Elizabeth is really headstrong and foolish , William Collins know not whether Elizabeth would altogether be a very desirable wife to a man in William Collins situation , who naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state . If therefore Elizabeth actually persists in rejecting William Collins suit , perhaps it were better not to force Elizabeth into accepting William Collins , because if liable to such defects of temper , Elizabeth could not contribute much to William Collins felicity . ” 
 
  “ William Collins , William Collins quite misunderstand Mother , ” said Mother , alarmed . “ Elizabeth is only headstrong in such matters as these . In everything else Elizabeth is as good - natured a girl as ever lived . Mother will go directly to Father , and we shall very soon settle it with Elizabeth , Mother am sure . ” 
 
  Mother would not give William Collins time to reply , but hurrying instantly to Father , called out as Mother entered the library , “ Oh ! Father , Father are wanted immediately ; we are all in an uproar . Father must come and make Elizabeth marry William Collins , for Elizabeth vows Elizabeth will not have William Collins , and if Father do not make haste William Collins will change William Collins mind and not have Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Father raised Father eyes from Father book as Elizabeth entered , and fixed Father eyes on Elizabeth face with a calm unconcern which was not in the least altered by Elizabeth communication . 
 
  “ Father have not the pleasure of understanding Elizabeth , ” said Father , when Elizabeth had finished Elizabeth communication . “ Of what are Elizabeth talking ? ” 
 
  “ Of William Collins and Elizabeth . Elizabeth declares Elizabeth will not have William Collins , and William Collins begins to say that William Collins will not have Elizabeth . ” 
 
  “ And what am Father to do on the occasion ? It seems an hopeless business . ” 
 
  “ Speak to Elizabeth about it Father . Tell Elizabeth that Father insist upon Elizabeth marrying William Collins . ” 
 
  “ Let Elizabeth be called down . Elizabeth shall hear Father opinion . ” 
 
  Mother rang the bell , and Elizabeth was summoned to the library . 
 
  “ Come here , Elizabeth , ” cried Elizabeth father as Elizabeth appeared . “ Father have sent for Elizabeth on an affair of importance . Father understand that William Collins has made Elizabeth an offer of marriage . Is an offer of marriage true ? ” Elizabeth replied that an offer of marriage was . “ Very well — and an offer of marriage Elizabeth have refused ? ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth have , Father . ” 
 
  “ Very well . We now come to the point . Elizabeth mother insists upon Elizabeth accepting an offer of marriage . Is it not so , Mother ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , or Elizabeth will never see Mother again . ” 
 
  “ An unhappy alternative is before Elizabeth , Elizabeth . From this day Elizabeth must be a stranger to one of Elizabeth parents . Elizabeth mother will never see Elizabeth again if Elizabeth do not marry William Collins , and Father will never see Elizabeth again if Elizabeth do . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning , but Mother , who had persuaded Mother that Mother husband regarded the affair as Mother wished , was excessively disappointed . 
 
  “ What do Father mean , Father , in talking this way ? Father promised Mother to insist upon Elizabeth marrying William Collins . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth , ” replied Mother husband , “ Father have two small favours to request . First , that Elizabeth will allow Father the free use of Father understanding on the present occasion ; and secondly , of Father room . Father shall be glad to have the library to Father as soon as may be . ” 
 
  Not yet , however , in spite of Mother disappointment in William Collins , did Mother give up the point . Mother talked to Elizabeth again and again ; coaxed and threatened Elizabeth by turns . Mother endeavoured to secure Jane in Mother interest ; but Jane , with all possible mildness , declined interfering ; and Elizabeth , sometimes with real earnestness , and sometimes with playful gaiety , replied to Mother attacks . Though Elizabeth manner varied , however , Elizabeth determination never did . 
 
  William Collins , meanwhile , was meditating in solitude on what had passed . William Collins thought too well of William Collins to comprehend on what motives William Collins cousin could refuse William Collins ; and though William Collins pride was hurt , William Collins suffered in no other way . William Collins regard for Elizabeth was quite imaginary ; and the possibility of Elizabeth deserving Elizabeth mother ’s reproach prevented William Collins feeling any regret . 
 
  While the family were in this confusion , Charlotte Lucas came to spend the day with the family . Charlotte Lucas was met in the vestibule by Lydia , who , flying to Charlotte Lucas , cried in a half whisper , “ Lydia am glad Charlotte Lucas are come , for there is such fun here ! What do Charlotte Lucas think has happened this morning ? William Collins has made an offer to Elizabeth , and Elizabeth will not have William Collins . ” 
 
  Charlotte Lucas hardly had time to answer , before they were joined by Kitty , who came to tell the same news ; and no sooner had they entered the breakfast - room , where Mother was alone , than Mother likewise began on the subject , calling on Charlotte Lucas for Charlotte Lucas compassion , and entreating Charlotte Lucas to persuade Charlotte Lucas friend Elizabeth to comply with the wishes of all Elizabeth family . “ Pray do , Mother dear Miss Lucas , ” Mother added in a melancholy tone , “ for nobody is on Mother side , nobody takes part with Mother . Mother am cruelly used , nobody feels for Mother poor nerves . ” 
 
  Charlotte Lucas reply was spared by the entrance of Jane and Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Aye , there Elizabeth comes , ” continued Mother , “ looking as unconcerned as may be , and caring no more for the family than if the family were at York , provided Elizabeth can have Elizabeth own way . But Mother tell Elizabeth , Elizabeth — if Elizabeth take it into Elizabeth head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way , Elizabeth will never get a husband at all — and Mother am sure Mother do not know who is to maintain Elizabeth when Elizabeth father is dead . Mother shall not be able to keep Elizabeth — and so Mother warn Elizabeth . Mother have done with Elizabeth from this very day . Mother told Elizabeth in the library , Elizabeth know , that Mother should never speak to Elizabeth again , and Elizabeth will find Mother as good as Mother word . Mother have no pleasure in talking to undutiful children . Not that Mother have much pleasure , indeed , in talking to anybody . People who suffer as Mother do from nervous complaints can have no great inclination for talking . Nobody can tell what Mother suffer ! But it is always so . Those who do not complain are never pitied . ” 
 
  Elizabeth listened in silence to this effusion , sensible that any attempt to reason with Mother or soothe Mother would only increase the irritation . Mother talked on , therefore , without interruption from any of Elizabeth , till Elizabeth were joined by William Collins , who entered the room with an air more stately than usual , and on perceiving whom , Mother said to Elizabeth , “ Now , Mother do insist upon it , that Elizabeth , hold Elizabeth tongues , and let Mother and William Collins have a little conversation together . ” 
 
  Elizabeth passed quietly out of the room , Jane and Kitty followed , but Lydia stood Lydia ground , determined to hear all Lydia could ; and Charlotte Lucas , detained first by the civility of William Collins Collins , whose enquiries after Charlotte Lucas and all Charlotte Lucas family were very minute , and then by a little curiosity , satisfied Charlotte Lucas with walking to the window and pretending not to hear . In a doleful voice Mother began a little conversation : “ Oh ! William Collins ! ” 
 
  “ Father dear madam , ” replied William Collins , “ let us be for ever silent on this point . Far be it from William Collins , ” William Collins presently continued , in a voice that marked William Collins displeasure , “ to resent the behaviour of Mother daughter . Resignation to inevitable evils is the duty of us all ; the peculiar duty of a young man who has been so fortunate as William Collins have been in early preferment ; and William Collins trust William Collins am resigned . Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt of William Collins positive happiness had Elizabeth honoured William Collins with Elizabeth hand ; for William Collins have often observed that resignation is never so perfect as when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of the blessing denied value in our estimation . Elizabeth will not , William Collins hope , consider William Collins as showing any disrespect to the family , William Collins dear madam , by thus withdrawing William Collins pretensions to Elizabeth favour , without having paid Mother and Father the compliment of requesting Mother and Father to interpose Mother and Father authority in William Collins behalf . William Collins conduct may , William Collins fear , be objectionable in having accepted William Collins dismission from Elizabeth lips instead of Mother own . But we are all liable to error . William Collins have certainly meant well through the whole affair . William Collins object has been to secure an amiable companion for William Collins , with due consideration for the advantage of all Mother family , and if William Collins manner has been at all reprehensible , William Collins here beg leave to apologise . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  The discussion of William Collins ’s offer was now nearly at an end , and Elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily attending The discussion of William Collins ’s offer , and occasionally from some peevish allusions of Elizabeth mother . As for William Collins ’s William Collins ’s , William Collins ’s feelings were chiefly expressed , not by embarrassment or dejection , or by trying to avoid Elizabeth , but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence . William Collins ’s scarcely ever spoke to Elizabeth , and the assiduous attentions which William Collins ’s had been so sensible of William Collins ’s were transferred for the rest of the day to Miss Lucas , whose civility in listening to William Collins ’s was a seasonable relief to The whole party , and especially to Miss Lucas , whose civility in listening to William Collins ’s was a seasonable relief to The whole party , and especially to friend .
