Fitzwilliam have withheld the advantages which Fitzwilliam must know to have been designed for Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam have deprived the best years of Fitzwilliam life of that independence which was no less Fitzwilliam due than Fitzwilliam desert . Fitzwilliam have done all this ! and yet Fitzwilliam can treat the mention of Fitzwilliam misfortune with contempt and ridicule . ” 
 
  “ And this , ” cried Fitzwilliam , as Fitzwilliam walked with quick steps across the room , “ is Elizabeth opinion of Fitzwilliam ! This is the estimation in which Elizabeth hold Fitzwilliam ! Fitzwilliam thank Elizabeth for explaining it so fully . Fitzwilliam faults , according to this calculation , are heavy indeed ! But perhaps , ” added Fitzwilliam , stopping in Fitzwilliam walk , and turning towards Elizabeth , “ Fitzwilliam faults might have been overlooked , had not Elizabeth pride been hurt by Fitzwilliam honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented Fitzwilliam forming any serious design . These bitter accusations might have been suppressed , had Fitzwilliam , with greater policy , concealed Fitzwilliam struggles , and flattered Elizabeth into the belief of Fitzwilliam being impelled by unqualified , unalloyed inclination ; by reason , by reflection , by everything . But disguise of every sort is Fitzwilliam abhorrence . Nor am Fitzwilliam ashamed of the feelings Fitzwilliam related . the feelings Fitzwilliam related were natural and just . Could Elizabeth expect Fitzwilliam to rejoice in the inferiority of Elizabeth connections?—to congratulate Fitzwilliam on the hope of relations , whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath Fitzwilliam own ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth felt Elizabeth growing more angry every moment ; yet Elizabeth tried to the utmost to speak with composure when Elizabeth said : 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam are mistaken , Fitzwilliam , if Fitzwilliam suppose that the mode of Fitzwilliam declaration affected Elizabeth in any other way , than as the mode of Fitzwilliam declaration spared Elizabeth the concern which Elizabeth might have felt in refusing Fitzwilliam , had Fitzwilliam behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner . ” 
 
  Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam start at this , but Fitzwilliam said nothing , and Elizabeth continued : 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam could not have made the offer of Fitzwilliam hand in any possible way that would have tempted Elizabeth to accept the offer of Fitzwilliam hand . ” 
 
  Again Fitzwilliam astonishment was obvious ; and Fitzwilliam looked at Elizabeth with an expression of mingled incredulity and mortification . Elizabeth went on : 
 
  “ From the very beginning — from the first moment , Elizabeth may almost say — of Elizabeth acquaintance with Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam manners , impressing Elizabeth with the fullest belief of Fitzwilliam arrogance , Fitzwilliam conceit , and Fitzwilliam selfish disdain of the feelings of others , were such as to form the groundwork of disapprobation on which succeeding events have built so immovable a dislike ; and Elizabeth had not known Fitzwilliam a month before Elizabeth felt that Fitzwilliam were the last man in the world whom Elizabeth could ever be prevailed on to marry . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth have said quite enough , Elizabeth . Fitzwilliam perfectly comprehend Elizabeth feelings , and have now only to be ashamed of what Fitzwilliam own have been . Forgive Fitzwilliam for having taken up so much of Elizabeth time , and accept Fitzwilliam best wishes for Elizabeth health and happiness . ” 
 
  And with these words Fitzwilliam hastily left the room , and Elizabeth heard Fitzwilliam the next moment open the front door and quit the house . 
 
  The tumult of Elizabeth mind , was now painfully great . Elizabeth knew not how to support Elizabeth , and from actual weakness sat down and cried for half - an - hour . Elizabeth astonishment , as Elizabeth reflected on what had passed , was increased by every review of it . That Elizabeth should receive an offer of marriage from Fitzwilliam ! That Fitzwilliam should have been in love with Elizabeth for so many months ! So much in love as to wish to marry Elizabeth in spite of all the objections which had made Fitzwilliam prevent Fitzwilliam marrying Fitzwilliam sister , and which must appear at least with equal force in Fitzwilliam own case — was almost incredible ! It was gratifying to have inspired unconsciously so strong an affection . But Fitzwilliam pride , Fitzwilliam abominable pride — Fitzwilliam shameless avowal of what Fitzwilliam had done with respect to Jane — Fitzwilliam unpardonable assurance in acknowledging , though Fitzwilliam could not justify it , and the unfeeling manner in which Fitzwilliam had mentioned Charlie , Fitzwilliam cruelty towards whom Fitzwilliam had not attempted to deny , soon overcame the pity which the consideration of Fitzwilliam attachment had for a moment excited . Elizabeth continued in very agitated reflections till the sound of Cathleen ’s carriage made Elizabeth feel how unequal Elizabeth was to encounter Charlie observation , and hurried Elizabeth away to Elizabeth room . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations which had at length closed Elizabeth eyes . Elizabeth could not yet recover from the surprise of what had happened ; it was impossible to think of anything else ; and , totally indisposed for employment , Elizabeth resolved , soon after breakfast , to indulge Elizabeth in air and exercise . Elizabeth was proceeding directly to Elizabeth favourite walk , when the recollection of Fitzwilliam ’s sometimes coming there stopped Elizabeth , and instead of entering the park , Elizabeth turned up the lane , which led farther from the turnpike - road . The park paling was still the boundary on one side , and Elizabeth soon passed one of the gates into the ground . 
 
  After walking two or three times along that part of the lane , which led farther from the turnpike - road , Elizabeth was tempted , by the pleasantness of the morning , to stop at the gates and look into the park . The five weeks which Elizabeth had now passed in Kent had made a great difference in the country , and every day was adding to the verdure of the early trees . Elizabeth was on the point of continuing Elizabeth walk , when Elizabeth caught a glimpse of a gentleman within the sort of grove which edged the park ; a gentleman was moving that way ; and , fearful of its being Fitzwilliam ’s , Elizabeth was directly retreating . But a gentleman was now near enough to see Elizabeth , and stepping forward with eagerness , pronounced Elizabeth name . Elizabeth had turned away ; but on hearing Elizabeth called , though in a voice which proved it to be Fitzwilliam ’s , Elizabeth moved again towards the gates . a gentleman had by that time reached the gates also , and , holding out a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took , said , with a look of haughty composure , “ a gentleman have been walking in the sort of grove which edged the park some time in the hope of meeting Elizabeth . Will Elizabeth do a gentleman the honour of reading a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took ? ” And then , with a slight bow , turned again into the plantation , and was soon out of sight . 
 
  With no expectation of pleasure , but with the strongest curiosity , Elizabeth opened a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took , and , to Elizabeth still increasing wonder , perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter - paper , written quite through , in a very close hand . an envelope containing two sheets of letter - paper , written quite through , in a very close hand an envelope containing two sheets of letter - paper , written quite through , in a very close hand was likewise full . Pursuing Elizabeth way along the lane , which led farther from the turnpike - road , Elizabeth then began it . a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took was dated from Rosings , at eight o’clock in the morning , and was as follows : — 
 
  “ Be not alarmed , Elizabeth , on receiving a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took , by the apprehension of a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took containing any repetition of those sentiments or renewal of those offers which were last night so disgusting to Elizabeth . Elizabeth write without any intention of paining Elizabeth , or humbling Elizabeth , by dwelling on wishes which , for the happiness of both , can not be too soon forgotten ; and the effort which the formation and the perusal of a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took must occasion , should have been spared , had not Elizabeth character required a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took to be written and read . Elizabeth must , therefore , pardon the freedom with which Elizabeth demand Elizabeth attention ; Elizabeth feelings , Elizabeth know , will bestow Elizabeth attention unwillingly , but Elizabeth demand Elizabeth attention of Elizabeth justice . 
 
  “ Two offenses of a very different nature , and by no means of equal magnitude , Elizabeth last night laid to Elizabeth charge . The first mentioned was , that , regardless of the sentiments of either , Elizabeth had detached Charles from Elizabeth sister , and the other , that Elizabeth had , in defiance of various claims , in defiance of honour and humanity , ruined the immediate prosperity and blasted the prospects of Elizabeth sister . Wilfully and wantonly to have thrown off the companion of Elizabeth youth , the acknowledged favourite of Elizabeth father , a young man who had scarcely any other dependence than on our patronage , and who had been brought up to expect its exertion , would be a depravity , to which the separation of two young persons , whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks , could bear no comparison . But from the severity of that blame which was last night so liberally bestowed , respecting each circumstance , Elizabeth shall hope to be in the future secured , when the following account of Elizabeth actions and Elizabeth actions motives has been read . If , in the explanation of Elizabeth actions , which is due to Elizabeth , Elizabeth am under the necessity of relating feelings which may be offensive to Elizabeth , Elizabeth can only say that Elizabeth am sorry . The necessity must be obeyed , and further apology would be absurd . 
 
  “ Elizabeth had not been long in Hertfordshire , before Elizabeth saw , in common with others , that Charles preferred Elizabeth elder sister to any other young woman in the country . But it was not till the evening of the dance at Netherfield that Elizabeth had any apprehension of Charles feeling a serious attachment . Elizabeth had often seen Charles in love before . At the dance at Netherfield , while Elizabeth had the honour of dancing with Elizabeth , Elizabeth was first made acquainted , by Sir William Lucas ’s accidental information , that Charles ’s attentions to Elizabeth sister had given rise to a general expectation of their marriage . Sir William Lucas ’s spoke of their marriage as a certain event , of which the time alone could be undecided . From that moment Elizabeth observed Sir William Lucas ’s behaviour attentively ; and Elizabeth could then perceive that Sir William Lucas ’s partiality for Elizabeth sister was beyond what Elizabeth had ever witnessed in Sir William Lucas ’s . Elizabeth sister Elizabeth also watched . Elizabeth sister look and manners were open , cheerful , and engaging as ever , but without any symptom of peculiar regard , and Elizabeth remained convinced from the evening ’s scrutiny , that though Elizabeth sister received Sir William Lucas ’s attentions with pleasure , Elizabeth sister did not invite Sir William Lucas ’s attentions by any participation of sentiment . If Elizabeth have not been mistaken here , Elizabeth must have been in error . Elizabeth superior knowledge of Elizabeth sister must make the latter probable . If it be so , if Elizabeth have been misled by such error to inflict pain on Elizabeth sister , Elizabeth resentment has not been unreasonable . But Elizabeth shall not scruple to assert , that the serenity of Elizabeth sister ’s countenance and air was such as might have given the most acute observer a conviction that , however amiable Elizabeth sister temper , Elizabeth sister heart was not likely to be easily touched . That Elizabeth was desirous of believing Elizabeth sister indifferent is certain — but Elizabeth will venture to say that Elizabeth investigation and decisions are not usually influenced by Elizabeth hopes or fears . Elizabeth did not believe Elizabeth sister to be indifferent because Elizabeth wished be ; Elizabeth believed be on impartial conviction , as truly as Elizabeth wished be in reason . Elizabeth objections to their marriage were not merely those which Elizabeth last night acknowledged to have required the utmost force of passion to put aside , in Elizabeth own case ; the want of connection could not be so great an evil to Sir William Lucas ’s as to Elizabeth . But there were other causes of repugnance ; causes which , though still existing , and existing to an equal degree in both instances , Elizabeth had Elizabeth endeavoured to forget , because other causes of repugnance were not immediately before Elizabeth . other causes of repugnance must be stated , though briefly . The situation of Elizabeth mother ’s family , though objectionable , was nothing in comparison to that total want of propriety so frequently , so almost uniformly betrayed by Elizabeth mother ’s , by Elizabeth three younger sisters , and occasionally even by Elizabeth father . Pardon Elizabeth . It pains Elizabeth to offend Elizabeth . But amidst Elizabeth concern for the defects of Elizabeth nearest relations , and Elizabeth displeasure at this representation of Elizabeth nearest relations , let it give Elizabeth consolation to consider that , to have conducted Elizabeth so as to avoid any share of the like censure , is praise no less generally bestowed on Elizabeth Elizabeth elder sister , than it is honourable to the sense and disposition of Elizabeth . Elizabeth will only say farther that from what passed that evening , Elizabeth opinion of all parties was confirmed , and every inducement heightened which could have led Elizabeth before , to preserve Elizabeth friend from what Elizabeth esteemed a most unhappy connection . Sir William Lucas ’s left Netherfield for London , on the day following , as Elizabeth , Elizabeth am certain , remember , with the design of soon returning . 
 
  “ The part which Elizabeth acted is now to be explained . Sir William Lucas ’s sisters ’ uneasiness had been equally excited with Elizabeth own ; our coincidence of feeling was soon discovered , and , alike sensible that no time was to be lost in detaching Sir William Lucas ’s , we shortly resolved on joining Sir William Lucas ’s directly in London . We accordingly went — and there Elizabeth readily engaged in the office of pointing out to Sir William Lucas ’s the certain evils of such a choice . Elizabeth described , and enforced the certain evils of such a choice earnestly . But , however this remonstrance might have staggered or delayed Sir William Lucas ’s determination , Elizabeth do not suppose that this remonstrance would ultimately have prevented their marriage , had this remonstrance not been seconded by the assurance that Elizabeth hesitated not in giving , of Elizabeth sister ’s indifference . Sir William Lucas ’s had before believed Elizabeth sister to return Sir William Lucas ’s affection with sincere , if not with equal regard . But Charles has great natural modesty , with a stronger dependence on Elizabeth judgement than on Sir William Lucas ’s own . To convince Sir William Lucas ’s , therefore , that Sir William Lucas ’s had deceived Sir William Lucas ’s , was no very difficult point . To persuade Sir William Lucas ’s against returning into Hertfordshire , when that conviction had been given , was scarcely the work of a moment . Elizabeth can not blame Elizabeth for having done thus much . There is but one part of Elizabeth conduct in the whole affair on which Elizabeth do not reflect with satisfaction ; but one part of Elizabeth conduct in the whole affair on which Elizabeth do not reflect with satisfaction is that Elizabeth condescended to adopt the measures of art so far as to conceal from Sir William Lucas ’s Elizabeth sister ’s being in town . Elizabeth knew Elizabeth sister ’s being in town Elizabeth , as Elizabeth sister ’s being in town was known to Caroline ; but Caroline brother is even yet ignorant of Elizabeth sister ’s being in town . That they might have met without ill consequence is perhaps probable ; but Sir William Lucas ’s regard did not appear to Elizabeth enough extinguished for Sir William Lucas ’s to see Elizabeth sister without some danger . Perhaps this concealment , this disguise was beneath Elizabeth ; this concealment , this disguise is done , however , and this concealment , this disguise was done for the best . On this subject Elizabeth have nothing more to say , no other apology to offer . If Elizabeth have wounded Elizabeth sister ’s feelings , wounded was unknowingly done and though the motives which governed Elizabeth may to Elizabeth very naturally appear insufficient , Elizabeth have not yet learnt to condemn the motives which governed Elizabeth . 
 
  “ With respect to that other , more weighty accusation , of having injured Elizabeth sister , Elizabeth can only refute that other , more weighty accusation , of having injured Elizabeth sister by laying before Elizabeth the whole of Elizabeth sister connection with Elizabeth mother ’s family . Of what Elizabeth sister has particularly accused Elizabeth Elizabeth am ignorant ; but of the truth of what Elizabeth shall relate , Elizabeth can summon more than one witness of undoubted veracity . 
 
  “ Elizabeth sister is the son of a very respectable man , who had for many years the management of all the Pemberley estates , and whose good conduct in the discharge of his trust naturally inclined Elizabeth father to be of service to his ; and on George , who was his godson , his kindness was therefore liberally bestowed . Elizabeth father supported Elizabeth sister at school , and afterwards at Cambridge — most important assistance , as Elizabeth sister own father , always poor from the extravagance of Elizabeth sister , would have been unable to give Elizabeth sister a gentleman ’s education . Elizabeth father was not only fond of Elizabeth sister society , whose manners were always engaging ; Elizabeth father had also the highest opinion of Elizabeth sister , and hoping the church would be Elizabeth sister profession , intended to provide for Elizabeth sister in the church . As for Elizabeth , it is many , many years since Elizabeth first began to think of Elizabeth sister in a very different manner . The vicious propensities — the want of principle , which Elizabeth sister was careful to guard from the knowledge of Elizabeth sister best friend , could not escape the observation of a young man of nearly the same age with Elizabeth sister , and who had opportunities of seeing Elizabeth sister in unguarded moments , which Fitzwilliam ’s could not have . Here again Elizabeth shall give Elizabeth pain — to what degree Elizabeth only can tell . But whatever may be the sentiments which Elizabeth sister has created , a suspicion of the sentiments which Elizabeth sister has created nature shall not prevent Elizabeth from unfolding Elizabeth sister real character — it adds even another motive . 
 
  “ Elizabeth father died about five years ago ; and Elizabeth father attachment to Elizabeth sister was to the last so steady , that in Elizabeth father will Elizabeth father particularly recommended it to Elizabeth , to promote Elizabeth sister advancement in the best manner that Elizabeth sister profession might allow — and if Elizabeth sister took orders , desired that a valuable family living might be Elizabeth sister as soon as a valuable family living became vacant . There was also a legacy of one thousand pounds . Elizabeth father did not long survive Elizabeth , and within half a year from these events , Elizabeth sister wrote to inform Elizabeth that , having finally resolved against taking orders , Elizabeth sister hoped Elizabeth should not think it unreasonable for Elizabeth sister to expect some more immediate pecuniary advantage , in lieu of the preferment , by which Elizabeth sister could not be benefited . Elizabeth sister had some intention , Elizabeth sister added , of studying law , and Elizabeth must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would be a very insufficient support therein . Elizabeth rather wished , than believed Elizabeth sister to be sincere ; but , at any rate , was perfectly ready to accede to Elizabeth sister proposal . Elizabeth knew that Elizabeth sister ought not to be a clergyman ; the business was therefore soon settled — Elizabeth sister resigned all claim to assistance in the church , were it possible that Elizabeth sister could ever be in a situation to receive assistance in the church , and accepted in return three thousand pounds . All connection between us seemed now dissolved . Elizabeth thought too ill of Elizabeth sister to invite Elizabeth sister to Pemberley , or admit Elizabeth sister society in town . In town Elizabeth believe Elizabeth sister chiefly lived , but Elizabeth sister studying the law was a mere pretence , and being now free from all restraint , Elizabeth sister life was a life of idleness and dissipation . For about three years Elizabeth heard little of Elizabeth sister ; but on the decease of the incumbent of the living which had been designed for Elizabeth sister , Elizabeth sister applied to Elizabeth again by letter for the presentation . Elizabeth sister circumstances , Elizabeth sister assured Elizabeth , and Elizabeth had no difficulty in believing it , were exceedingly bad . Elizabeth sister had found the law a most unprofitable study , and was now absolutely resolved on being ordained , if Elizabeth would present Elizabeth sister to the living in question — of which Elizabeth sister trusted there could be little doubt , as Elizabeth sister was well assured that Elizabeth had no other person to provide for , and Elizabeth could not have forgotten Elizabeth revered father ’s intentions . Elizabeth will hardly blame Elizabeth for refusing to comply with this entreaty , or for resisting every repetition to this entreaty . Elizabeth sister resentment was in proportion to the distress of Elizabeth sister circumstances — and Elizabeth sister was doubtless as violent in Elizabeth sister abuse of Elizabeth to others as in Elizabeth sister reproaches to Elizabeth . After this period every appearance of acquaintance was dropped . How Elizabeth sister lived Elizabeth know not . But last summer Elizabeth sister was again most painfully obtruded on Elizabeth notice . 
 
  “ Elizabeth must now mention a circumstance which Elizabeth would wish to forget Elizabeth , and which no obligation less than the present should induce Elizabeth to unfold to any human being . Having said thus much , Elizabeth feel no doubt of Elizabeth secrecy . Elizabeth sister , who is more than ten years Elizabeth junior , was left to the guardianship of Elizabeth mother ’s nephew , Fitzwilam , and Elizabeth . About a year ago , Elizabeth sister , who is more than ten years Elizabeth junior was taken from school , and an establishment formed for Elizabeth sister , who is more than ten years Elizabeth junior in London ; and last summer Elizabeth sister , who is more than ten years Elizabeth junior went with the lady who presided over an establishment , to Ramsgate ; and thither also went Elizabeth sister , undoubtedly by design ; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between Elizabeth sister and the lady who presided over an establishment ; and by the lady who presided over an establishment connivance and aid , Elizabeth sister so far recommended Elizabeth sister to Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to as a child , that Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to was persuaded to believe Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to in love , and to consent to an elopement . Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to was then but fifteen , which must be Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to excuse ; and after stating Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to imprudence , Elizabeth am happy to add , that Elizabeth owed the knowledge of Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to imprudence to Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to . Elizabeth joined them unexpectedly a day or two before an elopement , and then Georgiana , whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of Elizabeth sister kindness to , unable to support the idea of grieving and offending Elizabeth sister , acknowledged the whole to Elizabeth . Elizabeth may imagine what Elizabeth felt and how Elizabeth acted . Regard for Elizabeth sister credit and feelings prevented any public exposure ; but Elizabeth wrote to Elizabeth sister , and the lady who presided over an establishment was of course removed from the lady who presided over an establishment charge . Elizabeth sister chief object was unquestionably Elizabeth sister ’s fortune , which is thirty thousand pounds ; but Elizabeth can not help supposing that the hope of revenging Elizabeth sister on Elizabeth was a strong inducement . Elizabeth sister revenge would have been complete indeed . 
 
  “ a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took , Elizabeth , is a faithful narrative of every event in which us have been concerned together ; and if Elizabeth do not absolutely reject a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took as false , Elizabeth will , Elizabeth hope , acquit Elizabeth henceforth of cruelty towards Elizabeth sister . Elizabeth know not in what manner , under what form of falsehood Elizabeth sister had imposed on Elizabeth ; but Elizabeth sister success is not perhaps to be wondered at . Ignorant as Elizabeth previously were of everything concerning either , detection could not be in Elizabeth power , and suspicion certainly not in Elizabeth inclination . 
 
  “ Elizabeth may possibly wonder why all this was not told Elizabeth last night ; but Elizabeth was not then master enough of Elizabeth to know what could or ought to be revealed . For the truth of everything here related , Elizabeth can appeal more particularly to the testimony of Fitzwilam , who , from our near relationship and constant intimacy , and , still more , as one of the executors of Elizabeth father ’s will , has been unavoidably acquainted with every particular of these transactions . If Elizabeth abhorrence of Elizabeth should make Elizabeth assertions valueless , Elizabeth can not be prevented by the same cause from confiding in Elizabeth cousin ; and that there may be the possibility of consulting Elizabeth cousin , Elizabeth shall endeavour to find some opportunity of putting a letter , which Elizabeth instinctively took in Elizabeth hands in the course of the morning . Elizabeth will only add , God bless Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ’s ” 
 Chapter 
 
  If Elizabeth , when Fitzwilliam gave Elizabeth the letter , did not expect the letter to contain a renewal of Fitzwilliam offers , Elizabeth had formed no expectation at all of the letter contents . But such as the letter contents were , it may well be supposed how eagerly Elizabeth went through the letter contents , and what a contrariety of emotion the letter contents excited . Elizabeth feelings as Elizabeth read were scarcely to be defined . With amazement did Elizabeth first understand that Fitzwilliam believed any apology to be in Fitzwilliam power ; and steadfastly was Elizabeth persuaded , that Fitzwilliam could have no explanation to give , which a just sense of shame would not conceal . With a strong prejudice against everything Fitzwilliam might say , Elizabeth began Fitzwilliam account of what had happened at Netherfield . Elizabeth read with an eagerness which hardly left Elizabeth power of comprehension , and from impatience of knowing what the next sentence might bring , was incapable of attending to the sense of the one before Elizabeth eyes . Fitzwilliam belief of Elizabeth sister ’s insensibility Elizabeth instantly resolved to be false ; and Fitzwilliam account of the real , the worst objections to the match , made Elizabeth too angry to have any wish of doing Fitzwilliam justice . Fitzwilliam expressed no regret for what Fitzwilliam had done which satisfied Elizabeth ; Fitzwilliam style was not penitent , but haughty . Fitzwilliam style was all pride and insolence . 
 
  But when this subject was succeeded by Fitzwilliam account of Charlie — when Elizabeth read with somewhat clearer attention a relation of events which , if true , must overthrow every cherished opinion of Fitzwilliam worth , and which bore so alarming an affinity to Fitzwilliam own history of Fitzwilliam — Elizabeth feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition . Astonishment , apprehension , and even horror , oppressed Elizabeth . Elizabeth wished to discredit Fitzwilliam account of the real , the worst objections to the match entirely , repeatedly exclaiming , “ Fitzwilliam account of the real , the worst objections to the match must be false ! Fitzwilliam account of the real , the worst objections to the match can not be ! Fitzwilliam account of the real , the worst objections to the match must be the grossest falsehood!”—and when Elizabeth had gone through the letter , though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two , put the letter hastily away , protesting that Elizabeth would not regard the letter , that Elizabeth would never look in the letter again . 
 
  In this perturbed state of mind , with thoughts that could rest on nothing , Elizabeth walked on ; but it would not do ; in half a minute the letter was unfolded again , and collecting Elizabeth as well as Elizabeth could , Elizabeth again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to George , and commanded Elizabeth so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence . The account of Fitzwilliam connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what Fitzwilliam had related Fitzwilliam ; and the kindness of the late Fitzwilliam , though Elizabeth had not before known the kindness of the late Fitzwilliam extent , agreed equally well with Fitzwilliam own words . So far each recital confirmed the other ; but when Elizabeth came to the will , the difference was great . What George had said of the living was fresh in Elizabeth memory , and as Elizabeth recalled George very words , it was impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the other ; and , for a few moments , Elizabeth flattered Elizabeth that Elizabeth wishes did not err . But when Elizabeth read and re - read with the closest attention , the particulars immediately following of George ’s resigning all pretensions to the living , of George receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three thousand pounds , again was Elizabeth forced to hesitate . Elizabeth put down the letter , weighed every circumstance with what Elizabeth meant to be impartiality — deliberated on the probability of each statement — but with little success . On both sides it was only assertion . Again Elizabeth read on ; but every line proved more clearly that the affair , which Elizabeth had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render Fitzwilliam ’s conduct in the affair , which Elizabeth had believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to render Fitzwilliam ’s conduct in less than infamous , was capable of a turn which must make Fitzwilliam entirely blameless throughout the whole . 
 
  The extravagance and general profligacy which Fitzwilliam scrupled not to lay at Charlie ’s charge , exceedingly shocked Elizabeth ; the more so , as Elizabeth could bring no proof of The extravagance and general profligacy which Fitzwilliam scrupled not to lay at Charlie ’s charge injustice . Elizabeth had never heard of Fitzwilliam before Fitzwilliam entrance into the — — shire Militia , in which Fitzwilliam had engaged at the persuasion of the young man who , on meeting Fitzwilliam accidentally in town , had there renewed a slight acquaintance . Of Fitzwilliam former way of life nothing had been known in Hertfordshire but what Fitzwilliam told Fitzwilliam . As to Fitzwilliam real character , had information been in Elizabeth power , Elizabeth had never felt a wish of enquiring . Fitzwilliam countenance , voice , and manner had established Fitzwilliam at once in the possession of every virtue . Elizabeth tried to recollect some instance of goodness , some distinguished trait of integrity or benevolence , that might rescue Fitzwilliam from the attacks of Fitzwilliam ; or at least , by the predominance of virtue , atone for those casual errors under which Elizabeth would endeavour to class what Fitzwilliam had described as the idleness and vice of many years ’ continuance . But no such recollection befriended Elizabeth . Elizabeth could see Fitzwilliam instantly before Elizabeth , in every charm of air and address ; but Elizabeth could remember no more substantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood , and the regard which Fitzwilliam social powers had gained Fitzwilliam in the mess . After pausing on this point a considerable while , Elizabeth once more continued to read . But , alas ! the story which followed , of Fitzwilliam designs on Georgiana , received some confirmation from what had passed between Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth only the morning before ; and at last Elizabeth was referred for the truth of every particular to Fitzwilam himself — from whom Elizabeth had previously received the information of Fitzwilliam near concern in all Fitzwilliam cousin ’s affairs , and whose character Elizabeth had no reason to question . At one time Elizabeth had almost resolved on applying to Fitzwilliam , but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of applying , and at length wholly banished by the conviction that Fitzwilliam would never have hazarded such a proposal , if Fitzwilliam had not been well assured of Fitzwilliam cousin ’s corroboration . 
 
  Elizabeth perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation between George and Elizabeth , in George and Elizabeth first evening at Mr. Phillips ’s . Many of George expressions were still fresh in Elizabeth memory . Elizabeth was now struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger , and wondered the impropriety of such communications to a stranger had escaped Elizabeth before . Elizabeth saw the indelicacy of putting Fitzwilliam forward as Fitzwilliam had done , and the inconsistency of Fitzwilliam professions with Fitzwilliam conduct . Elizabeth remembered that Fitzwilliam had boasted of having no fear of seeing Fitzwilliam — that Fitzwilliam might leave Hertfordshire , but that Fitzwilliam should stand Fitzwilliam ground ; yet Fitzwilliam had avoided the Netherfield ball the very next week . Elizabeth remembered also that , till the Pemberley family had quitted Hertfordshire , Fitzwilliam had told Fitzwilliam story to no one but Elizabeth ; but that after quitted Fitzwilliam story had been everywhere discussed ; that Fitzwilliam had then no reserves , no scruples in sinking Fitzwilliam ’s character , though Fitzwilliam had assured Elizabeth that respect for the father would always prevent Fitzwilliam exposing Fitzwilliam . 
 
  How differently did everything now appear in which Fitzwilliam was concerned ! Fitzwilliam attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and hatefully mercenary ; and the mediocrity of Elizabeth fortune proved no longer the moderation of Fitzwilliam wishes , but Fitzwilliam eagerness to grasp at anything . Fitzwilliam behaviour to Elizabeth could now have had no tolerable motive ; Fitzwilliam had either been deceived with regard to Elizabeth fortune , or had been gratifying Fitzwilliam vanity by encouraging the preference which Elizabeth believed Elizabeth had most incautiously shown . Every lingering struggle in Fitzwilliam favour grew fainter and fainter ; and in farther justification of Fitzwilliam , Elizabeth could not but allow that Fitzwilliam , when questioned by Jane , had long ago asserted Fitzwilliam blamelessness in the affair ; that proud and repulsive as were Fitzwilliam manners , Elizabeth had never , in the whole course of their acquaintance — an acquaintance which had latterly brought their much together , and given Elizabeth a sort of intimacy with Fitzwilliam ways — seen anything that betrayed Fitzwilliam to be unprincipled or unjust — anything that spoke Fitzwilliam of irreligious or immoral habits ; that among Fitzwilliam own connections Fitzwilliam was esteemed and valued — that even George had allowed Fitzwilliam merit as a brother , and that Elizabeth had often heard Fitzwilliam speak so affectionately of Fitzwilliam sister as to prove Fitzwilliam capable of some amiable feeling ; that had Fitzwilliam actions been what Charlie represented Fitzwilliam actions , so gross a violation of everything right could hardly have been concealed from the world ; and that friendship between a person capable of it , and such an amiable man as Fitzwilliam , was incomprehensible . 
 
  Elizabeth grew absolutely ashamed of Elizabeth . Of neither Fitzwilliam nor George could Elizabeth think without feeling Elizabeth had been blind , partial , prejudiced , absurd . 
 
  “ How despicably Elizabeth have acted ! ” Elizabeth cried ; “ I , who have prided Elizabeth on Elizabeth discernment ! I , who have valued Elizabeth on Elizabeth abilities ! who have often disdained the generous candour of Elizabeth sister , and gratified Elizabeth vanity in useless or blameable mistrust ! How humiliating is this discovery ! Yet , how just a humiliation ! Had Elizabeth been in love , Elizabeth could not have been more wretchedly blind ! But vanity , not love , has been Elizabeth folly . Pleased with the preference of one , and offended by the neglect of the other , on the very beginning of their acquaintance , Elizabeth have courted prepossession and ignorance , and driven reason away , where either were concerned . Till this moment Elizabeth never knew Elizabeth . ” 
 
  From Elizabeth to Jane — from Jane to Fitzwilliam , Elizabeth thoughts were in a line which soon brought to Elizabeth recollection that Fitzwilliam ’s explanation there had appeared very insufficient , and Elizabeth read Fitzwilliam account of the real , the worst objections to the match again . Widely different was the effect of a second perusal . How could Elizabeth deny that credit to Fitzwilliam assertions in one instance , which Elizabeth had been obliged to give in the other ? Fitzwilliam declared Fitzwilliam to be totally unsuspicious of Elizabeth sister ’s attachment ; and Elizabeth could not help remembering what Charlie opinion had always been . Neither could Elizabeth deny the justice of Fitzwilliam description of Jane . Elizabeth felt that Jane ’s feelings , though fervent , were little displayed , and that there was a constant complacency in Jane air and manner not often united with great sensibility . 
 
  When Elizabeth came to that part of the letter in which Elizabeth family were mentioned in terms of such mortifying , yet merited reproach , Elizabeth sense of shame was severe . The justice of the charge struck Elizabeth too forcibly for denial , and the circumstances to which Fitzwilliam particularly alluded as having passed at the Netherfield ball , and as confirming all Fitzwilliam first disapprobation , could not have made a stronger impression on Fitzwilliam mind than on Elizabeth . 
 
  The compliment to Elizabeth and Jane was not unfelt . The compliment to Elizabeth and Jane soothed , but The compliment to Elizabeth and Jane could not console Elizabeth for the contempt which had thus been self - attracted by the rest of Elizabeth family ; and as Elizabeth considered that Jane ’s disappointment had in fact been the work of Jane nearest relations , and reflected how materially the credit of Elizabeth and Jane must be hurt by such impropriety of conduct , Elizabeth felt depressed beyond anything Elizabeth had ever known before . 
 
  After wandering along the lane for two hours , giving way to every variety of thought — re - considering events , determining probabilities , and reconciling Elizabeth , as well as Elizabeth could , to a change so sudden and so important , fatigue , and a recollection of Elizabeth long absence , made Elizabeth at length return home ; and Elizabeth entered the house with the wish of appearing cheerful as usual , and the resolution of repressing such reflections as must make Elizabeth unfit for conversation . 
 
  Elizabeth was immediately told that the two gentlemen from Rosings had each called during Elizabeth absence ; Fitzwilliam , only for a few minutes , to take leave — but that Fitzwilliam had been sitting with them at least an hour , hoping for Elizabeth return , and almost resolving to walk after Elizabeth till Elizabeth could be found . Elizabeth could but just affect concern in missing Fitzwilliam ; Elizabeth really rejoiced at it . Fitzwilliam was no longer an object ; Elizabeth could think only of the letter . 
 Chapter 
 
  The two gentlemen left Rosings the next morning , and William Collins having been in waiting near the lodges , to make The two gentlemen William Collins parting obeisance , was able to bring home the pleasing intelligence , of The two gentlemen appearing in very good health , and in as tolerable spirits as could be expected , after the melancholy scene so lately gone through at Rosings . To Rosings William Collins then hastened , to console Cathleen and Cathleen daughter ; and on William Collins return brought back , with great satisfaction , a message from her ladyship , importing that her ladyship felt her ladyship so dull as to make her ladyship very desirous of having them all to dine with her ladyship . 
 
  Cathleen daughter could not see Cathleen without recollecting that , had Cathleen daughter chosen it , Cathleen daughter might by this time have been presented to Cathleen as Cathleen future niece ; nor could Cathleen daughter think , without a smile , of what her ladyship ’s indignation would have been . “ What would her ladyship have said ? how would her ladyship have behaved ? ” were questions with which Cathleen amused Cathleen . 
 
  Their first subject was the diminution of the Rosings party . “ Cathleen assure you , Cathleen feel the diminution of the Rosings party exceedingly , ” said Cathleen ; “ Cathleen believe no one feels the loss of friends so much as Cathleen do . But Cathleen am particularly attached to these young men , and know these young men to be so much attached to Cathleen ! these young men were excessively sorry to go ! But so these young men always are . The dear Colonel rallied The dear Colonel spirits tolerably till just at last ; but Fitzwilliam seemed to feel the diminution of the Rosings party most acutely , more , Cathleen think , than last year . Fitzwilliam attachment to Rosings certainly increases . ” 
 
  William Collins had a compliment , and an allusion to throw in here , which were kindly smiled on by Cathleen and Cathleen daughter . 
 
  Cathleen observed , after dinner , that Miss Bennet seemed out of spirits , and immediately accounting for seemed Cathleen , by supposing that Miss Bennet did not like to go home again so soon , Cathleen added : 
 
  “ But if that is the case , Cathleen daughter must write to Cathleen daughter mother and beg that Cathleen daughter may stay a little longer . William Collins will be very glad of Cathleen daughter company , Cathleen am sure . ” 
 
  “ Cathleen daughter am much obliged to her ladyship for her ladyship kind invitation , ” replied Cathleen daughter , “ but it is not in Cathleen daughter power to accept her ladyship kind invitation . Cathleen daughter must be in town next Saturday . ” 
 
  “ Why , at that rate , them all will have been here only six weeks . her ladyship expected them all to stay two months . her ladyship told William Collins so before them all came . There can be no occasion for them all going so soon . Cathleen daughter mother could certainly spare them all for another fortnight . ” 
 
  “ But Cathleen daughter father can not . Cathleen daughter father wrote last week to hurry Cathleen daughter return . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Cathleen daughter father of course may spare Cathleen daughter , if Cathleen daughter mother can . Daughters are never of so much consequence to a father . And if them all will stay another month complete , it will be in her ladyship power to take one of them all as far as London , for her ladyship am going there early in June , for a week ; and as Dawson does not object to the barouche - box , there will be very good room for one of them all — and indeed , if the weather should happen to be cool , her ladyship should not object to taking them all , as them all are neither of you large . ” 
 
  “ her ladyship are all kindness , her ladyship ; but Cathleen daughter believe we must abide by we original plan . ” 
 
  Cathleen seemed resigned . “ William Collins , William Collins must send a servant with these young men . Cathleen daughter know Cathleen always speak Cathleen mind , and Cathleen can not bear the idea of these young men travelling post by these young men . travelling is highly improper . William Collins must contrive to send somebody . Cathleen have the greatest dislike in the world to that sort of thing . Young women should always be properly guarded and attended , according to Young women situation in life . When Cathleen niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer , Cathleen made a point of Cathleen niece Georgiana having two men - servants go with Cathleen niece Georgiana . Cathleen niece Georgiana , could not have appeared with propriety in a different manner . Cathleen am excessively attentive to all those things . William Collins must send John with these young men , William Collins . Cathleen am glad it occurred to Cathleen to mention send ; for it would really be discreditable to William Collins to let these young men go alone . ” 
 
  “ Cathleen daughter uncle is to send a servant for us . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! Cathleen daughter uncle ! Cathleen daughter uncle keeps a man - servant , does Cathleen daughter uncle ? her ladyship am very glad them all have somebody who thinks of these things . Where shall them all change horses ? Oh ! Bromley , of course . If them all mention Cathleen name at the Bell , them all will be attended to . ” 
 
  Cathleen had many other questions to ask respecting us journey , and as Cathleen did not answer many other questions to ask respecting us journey Cathleen , attention was necessary , which Cathleen daughter believed to be lucky for Cathleen daughter ; or , with a mind so occupied , Cathleen daughter might have forgotten where Cathleen daughter was . Reflection must be reserved for solitary hours ; whenever Cathleen daughter was alone , Cathleen daughter gave way to Reflection as the greatest relief ; and not a day went by without a solitary walk , in which Cathleen daughter might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant recollections . 
 
  Fitzwilliam ’s letter Cathleen daughter was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart . Cathleen daughter studied every sentence ; and Cathleen daughter feelings towards Fitzwilliam were at times widely different . When Cathleen daughter remembered the style of Fitzwilliam address , Cathleen daughter was still full of indignation ; but when Cathleen daughter considered how unjustly Cathleen daughter had condemned and upbraided Fitzwilliam , Cathleen daughter anger was turned against Cathleen daughter ; and Fitzwilliam disappointed feelings became the object of compassion . Fitzwilliam attachment excited gratitude , Fitzwilliam general character respect ; but Cathleen daughter could not approve Fitzwilliam ; nor could Cathleen daughter for a moment repent Cathleen daughter refusal , or feel the slightest inclination ever to see Fitzwilliam again . In Cathleen daughter own past behaviour , there was a constant source of vexation and regret ; and in the unhappy defects of Cathleen daughter family , a subject of yet heavier chagrin . the unhappy defects of Cathleen daughter family were hopeless of remedy . Cathleen daughter father , contented with laughing at the unhappy defects of Cathleen daughter family , would never exert Cathleen daughter father to restrain the wild giddiness of Cathleen daughter father youngest daughters ; and Cathleen daughter mother , with manners so far from right Cathleen daughter mother , was entirely insensible of the evil . Cathleen daughter had frequently united with Jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of Catherine and Lydia ; but while Catherine and Lydia were supported by Catherine and Lydia mother ’s indulgence , what chance could there be of improvement ? Catherine , weak - spirited , irritable , and completely under Lydia ’s guidance , had been always affronted by their advice ; and Lydia , self - willed and careless , would scarcely give Catherine and Lydia a hearing . Catherine and Lydia were ignorant , idle , and vain . While there was an officer in Meryton , Catherine and Lydia would flirt with an officer in Meryton ; and while Meryton was within a walk of Longbourn , Catherine and Lydia would be going there forever . 
 
  Anxiety on Jane ’s behalf was another prevailing concern ; and Fitzwilliam ’s explanation , by restoring Charles to all Charles former good opinion , heightened the sense of what Jane had lost . Fitzwilliam affection was proved to have been sincere , and Fitzwilliam conduct cleared of all blame , unless any could attach to the implicitness of Fitzwilliam confidence in Fitzwilliam friend . How grievous then was the thought that , of a situation so desirable in every respect , so replete with advantage , so promising for happiness , Jane had been deprived , by the folly and indecorum of Jane own family ! 
 
  When to these recollections was added the development of George ’s character , it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had seldom been depressed before , were now so much affected as to make it almost impossible for George ’s to appear tolerably cheerful . 
 
  them all engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of her ladyship stay as them all engagements at Rosings had been at first . The very last evening was spent there ; and her ladyship again enquired minutely into the particulars of them all journey , gave them all directions as to the best method of packing , and was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right way , that Cathleen daughter thought Cathleen daughter obliged , on Cathleen daughter return , to undo all the work of the morning , and pack Cathleen daughter trunk afresh . 
 
  When them all parted , Cathleen , with great condescension , wished them all a good journey , and invited them all to come to Hunsford again next year ; and Cathleen exerted Cathleen so far as to curtsey and hold out Cathleen hand to them all . 
 Chapter 
 
  On Saturday morning Elizabeth and William Collins met for breakfast a few minutes before the others appeared ; and William Collins took the opportunity of paying the parting civilities which William Collins deemed indispensably necessary . 
 
  “ William Collins know not , Miss Elizabeth , ” said William Collins , “ whether William Collins has yet expressed William Collins sense of Elizabeth kindness in coming to William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins ; but William Collins am very certain Elizabeth will not leave the house without receiving William Collins thanks for it . The favour of Elizabeth company has been much felt , William Collins assure Elizabeth . William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins know how little there is to tempt anyone to William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins humble abode . William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins plain manner of living , William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins small rooms and few domestics , and the little William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins see of the world , must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like Elizabeth ; but William Collins hope Elizabeth will believe William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins grateful for the condescension , and that William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins have done everything in William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins power to prevent Elizabeth spending Elizabeth time unpleasantly . ” 
 
  Elizabeth was eager with Elizabeth thanks and assurances of happiness . Elizabeth had spent six weeks with great enjoyment ; and the pleasure of being with Charlotte , and the kind attentions Elizabeth had received , must make Elizabeth feel the obliged . William Collins was gratified , and with a more smiling solemnity replied : 
 
  “ It gives William Collins great pleasure to hear that Elizabeth have passed Elizabeth time not disagreeably . William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins have certainly done William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins best ; and most fortunately having it in William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins power to introduce Elizabeth to very superior society , and , from William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins connection with Rosings , the frequent means of varying the humble home scene , William Collins think William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins may flatter William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins that your Hunsford visit can not have been entirely irksome . William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins situation with regard to Cathleen ’s family is indeed the sort of extraordinary advantage and blessing which few can boast . You see on what a footing William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins are . You see how continually William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins are engaged there . In truth William Collins must acknowledge that , with all the disadvantages of the house , William Collins should not think anyone abiding in the house an object of compassion , while anyone abiding in the house are sharers of William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins intimacy at Rosings . ” 
 
  Words were insufficient for the elevation of William Collins feelings ; and William Collins was obliged to walk about the room , while Elizabeth tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences . 
 
  “ William Collins may , in fact , carry a very favourable report of us into Hertfordshire , Elizabeth dear cousin . Elizabeth flatter Elizabeth at least that Elizabeth will be able to do so . Cathleen ’s great attentions to William Collins Elizabeth have been a daily witness of ; and altogether Elizabeth trust it does not appear that Elizabeth friend has drawn an unfortunate — but on this point it will be as well to be silent . Only let William Collins assure Elizabeth , William Collins dear Miss Elizabeth , that William Collins can from William Collins heart most cordially wish Elizabeth equal felicity in marriage . William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins have but one mind and one way of thinking . There is in everything a most remarkable resemblance of character and ideas between William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins . William Collins dear Charlotte and William Collins seem to have been designed for each other . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where seem was the case , and with equal sincerity could add , that Elizabeth firmly believed and rejoiced in Charlotte domestic comforts . Elizabeth was not sorry , however , to have the recital of Charlotte domestic comforts interrupted by William Collins . Poor Charlotte ! it was melancholy to leave Charlotte to such society ! But Charlotte had chosen it with Charlotte eyes open ; and though evidently regretting that Charlotte visitors were to go , Charlotte did not seem to ask for compassion . Charlotte home and Charlotte housekeeping , Charlotte parish and Charlotte poultry , and all Charlotte home and Charlotte housekeeping , Charlotte parish and Charlotte poultry , and all dependent concerns , had not yet lost Charlotte home and Charlotte housekeeping , Charlotte parish and Charlotte poultry , and all charms . 
 
  At length the chaise arrived , the trunks were fastened on , the parcels placed within , and it was pronounced to be ready . After an affectionate parting between the friends , Elizabeth was attended to the carriage by William Collins , and as they walked down the garden William Collins was commissioning Elizabeth with William Collins best respects to all Elizabeth family , not forgetting William Collins thanks for the kindness William Collins had received at Longbourn in the winter , and William Collins compliments to Edward and Madeline , though unknown . William Collins then handed Elizabeth in , Maria followed , and the door was on the point of being closed , when William Collins suddenly reminded they , with some consternation , that they had hitherto forgotten to leave any message for the ladies at Rosings . 
 
  “ But , ” William Collins added , “ Elizabeth will of course wish to have Elizabeth humble respects delivered to the ladies at Rosings , with Elizabeth grateful thanks for the ladies at Rosings kindness to Elizabeth while Elizabeth have been here . ” 
 
  Elizabeth made no objection ; the door was then allowed to be shut , and the carriage drove off . 
 
  “ Good gracious ! ” cried Maria , after a few minutes ’ silence , “ it seems but a day or two since they first came ! and yet how many things have happened ! ” 
 
  “ A great many indeed , ” said Elizabeth companion with a sigh . 
 
  “ they have dined nine times at Rosings , besides drinking tea there twice ! How much Elizabeth shall have to tell ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth added privately , “ And how much Elizabeth shall have to conceal ! ” 
 
  they journey was performed without much conversation , or any alarm ; and within four hours of they leaving Hunsford they reached Edward ’s house , where they were to remain a few days . 
 
  Jane looked well , and Elizabeth had little opportunity of studying Jane spirits , amidst the various engagements which the kindness of Elizabeth aunt had reserved for they . But Jane was to go home with Elizabeth , and at Longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation . 
 
  It was not without an effort , meanwhile , that Elizabeth could wait even for Longbourn , before Elizabeth told Jane of Fitzwilliam ’s proposals . To know that Elizabeth had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish Jane , and must , at the same time , so highly gratify whatever of Elizabeth own vanity Elizabeth had not yet been able to reason away , was such a temptation to openness as nothing could have conquered but the state of indecision in which Elizabeth remained as to the extent of what Elizabeth should communicate ; and Elizabeth fear , if Elizabeth once entered on the subject , of being hurried into repeating something of Charlotte which might only grieve Jane further . 
 Chapter 
 
  It was the second week in May , in which the three young ladies set out together from Gracechurch Street for the town of — — , in Hertfordshire ; and , as the three young ladies drew near the appointed inn where Father ’s carriage was to meet the three young ladies , the three young ladies quickly perceived , in token of the coachman ’s punctuality , both Kitty and Lydia looking out of a dining - room up stairs . both Kitty and Lydia had been above an hour in the appointed inn where Father ’s carriage was to meet the three young ladies , happily employed in visiting an opposite milliner , watching the sentinel on guard , and dressing a salad and cucumber . 
 
  After welcoming the three young ladies , both Kitty and Lydia triumphantly displayed a table set out with such cold meat as an inn larder usually affords , exclaiming , “ Is not this nice ? Is not this an agreeable surprise ? ” 
 
  “ And both Kitty and Lydia mean to treat the three young ladies , ” added Lydia , “ but the three young ladies must lend both Kitty and Lydia the money , for both Kitty and Lydia have just spent both Kitty and Lydia at the shop out there . ” Then , showing Lydia purchases—“Look here , Lydia have bought this bonnet . Lydia do not think this bonnet is very pretty ; but Lydia thought Lydia might as well buy this bonnet as not . Lydia shall pull this bonnet to pieces as soon as Lydia get home , and see if Lydia can make this bonnet up any better . ” 
 
  And when Lydia sisters abused this bonnet as ugly , Lydia added , with perfect unconcern , “ Oh ! but there were two or three much uglier in the shop ; and when Lydia have bought some prettier - coloured satin to trim this bonnet with fresh , Lydia think it will be very tolerable . Besides , this bonnet will not much signify what one wears this summer , after the — — shire have left Meryton , and the — — shire are going in a fortnight . ” 
 
  “ Are the — — shire indeed ! ” cried Elizabeth , with the greatest satisfaction . 
 
  “ the — — shire are going to be encamped near Brighton ; and Elizabeth do so want Father ’s to take us all there for the summer ! take would be such a delicious scheme ; and Elizabeth dare say would hardly cost anything at all . Mamma would like to go too of all things ! Only think what a miserable summer else we shall have ! ” 
 
  “ Yes , ” thought Elizabeth , “ take would be a delightful scheme indeed , and completely do for us all at once . Good Heaven ! Brighton , and a whole campful of soldiers , to us , who have been overset already by one poor regiment of militia , and the monthly balls of Meryton ! ” 
 
  “ Now Lydia have got some news for the three young ladies , ” said Lydia , as the three young ladies sat down at table . “ What do the three young ladies think ? some news is excellent news — capital news — and about a certain person we all like ! ” 
 
  Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other , and the waiter was told the waiter need not stay . Lydia laughed , and said : 
 
  “ Aye , that is just like the three young ladies formality and discretion . Lydia thought the waiter must not hear , as if the waiter cared ! Lydia dare say the waiter often hears worse things said than Lydia am going to say . But the waiter is an ugly fellow ! Lydia am glad the waiter is gone . Lydia never saw such a long chin in Lydia life . Well , but now for Lydia news ; Lydia news is about a certain person we all like ; too good for the waiter , is Lydia news not ? There is no danger of a certain person we all like marrying Mary King . There ’s for the three young ladies ! Mary King is gone down to Mary King uncle at Liverpool : gone to stay . a certain person we all like is safe . ” 
 
  “ And Mary King is safe ! ” added Elizabeth ; “ safe from a connection imprudent as to fortune . ” 
 
  “ Mary King is a great fool for going away , if Mary King liked a certain person we all like . ” 
 
  “ But Jane hope there is no strong attachment on either side , ” said Jane . 
 
  “ Lydia am sure there is not on a certain person we all like . Lydia will answer for it , a certain person we all like never cared three straws about Mary King — who could about Mary King ? ” Elizabeth Elizabeth was shocked to think that , however incapable of such coarseness of expression Elizabeth , the coarseness of the sentiment was little other than Elizabeth own breast had harboured and fancied liberal ! 
 
  As soon as the three young ladies had ate , and the elder ones paid , Father ’s carriage was ordered ; and after some contrivance , the three young ladies , with all the three young ladies boxes , work - bags , and parcels , and the unwelcome addition of Kitty ’s and Lydia ’s purchases , were seated in Father ’s carriage . 
 
  “ How nicely the three young ladies are all crammed in , ” cried Lydia . “ Lydia am glad Lydia bought Lydia bonnet , if bought is only for the fun of having another bandbox ! Well , now let the three young ladies be quite comfortable and snug , and talk and laugh all the way home . And in the first place , let the three young ladies hear what has happened to the three young ladies since the three young ladies went away . Have the three young ladies seen any pleasant men ? Have the three young ladies had any flirting ? Lydia was in great hopes that one of the three young ladies would have got a husband before the three young ladies came back . Jane will be quite an old maid soon , Lydia declare . Jane is almost three - and - twenty ! Lord , how ashamed Elizabeth should be of not being married before three - and - twenty ! Elizabeth aunt Phillips wants the three young ladies so to get husbands , the three young ladies ca n’t think . Elizabeth aunt Phillips says Elizabeth had better have taken William Collins ; but Elizabeth do not think there would have been any fun in taken . Lord ! how Elizabeth should like to be married before any of the three young ladies ; and then Elizabeth would chaperon the three young ladies about to all the balls . Dear Elizabeth ! Kitty and Elizabeth had such a good piece of fun the other day at Colonel Forster ’s . Kitty and Elizabeth were to spend the day there , and Colonel Forster ’s promised to have a little dance in the evening ; ( by the bye , Mrs. Forster and Elizabeth are such friends ! ) and so Colonel Forster ’s asked the two Harringtons to come , but Harriet was ill , and so Pen was forced to come by Pen ; and then , what do the three young ladies think Kitty and Elizabeth did ? Kitty and Elizabeth dressed up Chamberlayne in woman ’s clothes on purpose to pass for a lady , only think what fun ! Not a soul knew of dressed , but Colonel Forster ’s and Colonel Forster ’s , and Kitty and Elizabeth , except Elizabeth aunt , for Kitty and Elizabeth were forced to borrow one of Elizabeth aunt gowns ; and you can not imagine how well Chamberlayne looked ! When Denny , and a certain person we all like , and Pratt , and two or three more of the men came in , Denny , and a certain person we all like , and Pratt , and two or three more of the men did not know Chamberlayne in the least . Lord ! how Elizabeth laughed ! and so did Elizabeth aunt . Elizabeth thought Elizabeth should have died . And that made the men suspect something , and then the men soon found out what was the matter . ” 
 
  With such kinds of histories of their parties and good jokes , did Lydia , assisted by Kitty ’s hints and additions , endeavour to amuse Lydia companions all the way to Longbourn . Elizabeth listened as little as Elizabeth could , but there was no escaping the frequent mention of a certain person we all like name . 
 
  the three young ladies reception at home was most kind . Mother rejoiced to see Jane in undiminished beauty ; and more than once during dinner did Father ’s say voluntarily to Elizabeth : 
 
  “ Mother am glad Elizabeth are come back , Elizabeth . ” 
 
  the three young ladies party in the dining - room was large , for almost all the Lucases came to meet Maria and hear the news ; and various were the subjects that occupied the three young ladies : Lady Lucas was enquiring of Maria , after the welfare and poultry of Lady Lucas eldest daughter ; Mother was doubly engaged , on one hand collecting an account of the present fashions from Jane , who sat some way below Mother , and , on the other , retailing them all to the younger Lucases ; and Lydia , in a voice rather louder than any other person ’s , was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who would hear Lydia . 
 
  “ Oh ! Mary , ” said Lydia , “ Lydia wish Mary had gone with Kitty and Elizabeth , for Kitty and Elizabeth had such fun ! As Kitty and Elizabeth went along , Kitty and Elizabeth drew up the blinds , and pretended there was nobody in Father ’s carriage ; and Lydia should have gone so all the way , if Kitty had not been sick ; and when Kitty and Elizabeth got to a certain person we all like , Lydia do think Kitty and Elizabeth behaved very handsomely , for Kitty and Elizabeth treated the other three with the nicest cold luncheon in the world , and if Mary would have gone , Kitty and Elizabeth would have treated Mary too . And then when Kitty and Elizabeth came away it was such fun ! Lydia thought Kitty and Elizabeth never should have got into Father ’s carriage . Lydia was ready to die of laughter . And then Kitty and Elizabeth were so merry all the way home ! Kitty and Elizabeth talked and laughed so loud , that anybody might have heard Kitty and Elizabeth ten miles off ! ” 
 
  To this Mary very gravely replied , “ Far be it from Mary , Mary dear sister , to depreciate such pleasures ! such pleasures would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds . But Mary confess such pleasures would have no charms for Mary — Mary should infinitely prefer a book . ” 
 
  But of this answer Lydia heard not a word . Lydia seldom listened to anybody for more than half a minute , and never attended to Mary at all . 
 
  In the afternoon Lydia was urgent with the rest of the three young ladies to walk to Meryton , and to see how everybody went on ; but Elizabeth steadily opposed the scheme . It should not be said that the Miss Bennets could not be at home half a day before the Miss Bennets were in pursuit of the officers . There was another reason too for Elizabeth opposition . Elizabeth dreaded seeing Charlie again , and was resolved to avoid seeing as long as possible . The comfort to Elizabeth of the officers approaching removal was indeed beyond expression . In a fortnight the three young ladies were to go — and once gone , Elizabeth hoped there could be nothing more to plague Elizabeth on Charlie account . 
 
  Elizabeth had not been many hours at home before Elizabeth found that the Brighton scheme , of which Lydia had given them a hint at the appointed inn where Father ’s carriage was to meet the three young ladies , was under frequent discussion between Elizabeth parents . Elizabeth saw directly that Father ’s had not the smallest intention of yielding ; but Father ’s answers were at the same time so vague and equivocal , that Elizabeth mother , though often disheartened , had never yet despaired of succeeding at last . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth ’s impatience to acquaint Jane with what had happened could no longer be overcome ; and at length , resolving to suppress every particular in which Jane was concerned , and preparing Jane to be surprised , Elizabeth ’s related to Jane the next morning the chief of the scene between Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth ’s . 
 
  Jane astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly partiality which made any admiration of Elizabeth ’s appear perfectly natural ; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings . Jane was sorry that Fitzwilliam should have delivered Fitzwilliam sentiments in a manner so little suited to recommend Fitzwilliam sentiments ; but still more was Jane grieved for the unhappiness which Elizabeth ’s refusal must have given Fitzwilliam . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam being so sure of succeeding was wrong , ” said Jane , “ and certainly ought not to have appeared ; but consider how much Fitzwilliam being so sure of succeeding must increase Fitzwilliam disappointment ! ” 
 
  “ Indeed , ” replied Elizabeth ’s , “ Elizabeth ’s am heartily sorry for Fitzwilliam ; but Fitzwilliam has other feelings , which will probably soon drive away Fitzwilliam regard for Elizabeth ’s . Jane do not blame Elizabeth ’s , however , for refusing Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ Blame Elizabeth ’s ! Oh , no . ” 
 
  “ But Elizabeth ’s blame Elizabeth ’s for having spoken so warmly of George ? ” 
 
  “ No — Elizabeth ’s do not know that Elizabeth ’s were wrong in saying what Elizabeth ’s did . ” 
 
  “ But Jane will know it , when Elizabeth ’s tell Jane what happened the very next day . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s then spoke of the letter , repeating the whole of the letter contents as far as the letter contents concerned George . What a stroke was this for poor Jane ! who would willingly have gone through the world without believing that so much wickedness existed in the whole race of mankind , as was here collected in George . Nor was Fitzwilliam ’s vindication , though grateful to Jane feelings , capable of consoling Jane for such discovery . Most earnestly did Jane labour to prove the probability of error , and seek to clear the one without involving the other . 
 
  “ This will not do , ” said Elizabeth ’s ; “ Jane never will be able to make both of them good for anything . Take Jane choice , but Jane must be satisfied with only one . There is but such a quantity of merit between both of them ; just enough to make one good sort of man ; and of late it has been shifting about pretty much . For Elizabeth ’s part , Elizabeth ’s am inclined to believe it all Fitzwilliam ’s ; but Jane shall do as Jane choose . ” 
 
  It was some time , however , before a smile could be extorted from Jane . 
 
  “ Jane do not know when Jane have been more shocked , ” said Jane . “ George so very bad ! It is almost past belief . And poor Fitzwilliam ! Elizabeth ’s , only consider what Fitzwilliam must have suffered . Such a disappointment ! and with the knowledge of Elizabeth ’s ill opinion , too ! and having to relate such a thing of Fitzwilliam sister ! It is really too distressing . Elizabeth ’s am sure Elizabeth ’s must feel it so . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! no , Elizabeth ’s regret and compassion are all done away by seeing Elizabeth ’s so full of both . Elizabeth ’s know Elizabeth ’s will do Fitzwilliam such ample justice , that Elizabeth ’s am growing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent . Elizabeth ’s profusion makes Elizabeth ’s saving ; and if Elizabeth ’s lament over Fitzwilliam much longer , Elizabeth ’s heart will be as light as a feather . ” 
 
  “ Poor George ! there is such an expression of goodness in George countenance ! such an openness and gentleness in George manner ! ” 
 
  “ There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of those two young men . One has got all the goodness , and the other all the appearance of all the goodness . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s never thought Fitzwilliam so deficient in the appearance of it as Elizabeth ’s used to do . ” 
 
  “ And yet Elizabeth ’s meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike to Fitzwilliam , without any reason . It is such a spur to one ’s genius , such an opening for wit , to have a dislike of that kind . One may be continually abusive without saying anything just ; but one can not always be laughing at a man without now and then stumbling on something witty . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s , when Elizabeth ’s first read the letter , Elizabeth ’s am sure Elizabeth ’s could not treat the matter as Elizabeth ’s do now . ” 
 
  “ Indeed , Elizabeth ’s could not . Elizabeth ’s was uncomfortable enough , Elizabeth ’s may say unhappy . And with no one to speak to about what Elizabeth ’s felt , no Jane to comfort Elizabeth ’s and say that Elizabeth ’s had not been so very weak and vain and nonsensical as Elizabeth ’s knew Elizabeth ’s had ! Oh ! how Elizabeth ’s wanted Elizabeth ’s ! ” 
 
  “ How unfortunate that Elizabeth ’s should have used such very strong expressions in speaking of George to Fitzwilliam , for now such very strong expressions do appear wholly undeserved . ” 
 
  “ Certainly . But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness is a most natural consequence of the prejudices Elizabeth ’s had been encouraging . There is one point on which Elizabeth ’s want Jane advice . Elizabeth ’s want to be told whether Elizabeth ’s ought , or ought not , to make our acquaintances in general understand George ’s character . ” Jane Jane paused a little , and then replied , “ Surely there can be no occasion for exposing George so dreadfully . What is Jane opinion ? ” 
 
  “ That exposing ought not to be attempted . Fitzwilliam has not authorised Jane to make Fitzwilliam communication public . On the contrary , every particular relative to Fitzwilliam sister was meant to be kept as much as possible to Jane ; and if Jane endeavour to undeceive people as to the rest of Fitzwilliam conduct , who will believe Jane ? The general prejudice against Fitzwilliam is so violent , that it would be the death of half the good people in Meryton to attempt to place Fitzwilliam in an amiable light . Jane am not equal to it . George will soon be gone ; and therefore it will not signify to anyone here what George really is . Some time hence it will be all found out , and then we may laugh at their stupidity in not knowing it before . At present Jane will say nothing about it . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s are quite right . To have George errors made public might ruin George for ever . George is now , perhaps , sorry for what George has done , and anxious to re - establish a character . We must not make George desperate . ” 
 
  The tumult of Elizabeth ’s mind was allayed by this conversation . Elizabeth ’s had got rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on Elizabeth ’s for a fortnight , and was certain of a willing listener in Jane , whenever Elizabeth ’s might wish to talk again of either . But there was still something lurking behind , of which prudence forbade the disclosure . Elizabeth ’s dared not relate the other half of the letter , nor explain to Jane how sincerely Elizabeth ’s had been valued by Fitzwilliam . Here was knowledge in which no one could partake ; and Elizabeth ’s was sensible that nothing less than a perfect understanding between the parties could justify Elizabeth ’s in throwing off this last encumbrance of mystery . “ And then , ” said Elizabeth ’s , “ if that very improbable event should ever take place , Elizabeth ’s shall merely be able to tell what Charles may tell in a much more agreeable manner Charles . The liberty of communication can not be Elizabeth ’s till The liberty of communication has lost all The liberty of communication value ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s was now , on being settled at home , at leisure to observe the real state of Jane spirits . Jane was not happy . Jane still cherished a very tender affection for Charles . Having never even fancied Jane in love before , Jane regard had all the warmth of first attachment , and , from Jane age and disposition , greater steadiness than most first attachments often boast ; and so fervently did Jane value Charles remembrance , and prefer Charles to every other man , that all Jane good sense , and all Jane attention to the feelings of Jane friends , were requisite to check the indulgence of those regrets which must have been injurious to Jane own health and Jane friends tranquillity .
