  “ Well , Elizabeth ’s , ” said prudence one day , “ what is Elizabeth ’s opinion now of this sad business of Jane ’s ? For prudence part , prudence am determined never to speak of this sad business of Jane ’s again to anybody . prudence told prudence sister Phillips so the other day . But prudence can not find out that Jane saw anything of Charles in London . Well , Charles is a very undeserving young man — and prudence do not suppose there ’s the least chance in the world of Jane ever getting Charles now . There is no talk of Charles coming to Netherfield again in the summer ; and prudence have enquired of everybody , too , who is likely to know . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s do not believe Charles will ever live at Netherfield any more . ” 
 
  “ Oh well ! it is just as Charles chooses . Nobody wants Charles to come . Though prudence shall always say Charles used Jane extremely ill ; and if prudence was Jane , prudence would not have put up with used . Well , Elizabeth ’s comfort is , Elizabeth ’s am sure Jane will die of a broken heart ; and then Charles will be sorry for what Charles has done . ” 
 
  But as Elizabeth ’s could not receive comfort from any such expectation , Elizabeth ’s made no answer . 
 
  “ Well , Elizabeth ’s , ” continued Elizabeth ’s mother , soon afterwards , “ and so the Collinses live very comfortable , do the Collinses ? Well , well , Elizabeth ’s only hope it will last . And what sort of table do the Collinses keep ? Charlotte is an excellent manager , Elizabeth ’s dare say . If Charlotte is half as sharp as Charlotte mother , Charlotte is saving enough . There is nothing extravagant in the Collinses housekeeping , Elizabeth ’s dare say . ” 
 
  “ No , nothing at all . ” 
 
  “ A great deal of good management , depend upon nothing extravagant in the Collinses housekeeping . Yes , yes . the Collinses will take care not to outrun the Collinses income . the Collinses will never be distressed for money . Well , much good may it do the Collinses ! And so , Elizabeth ’s suppose , the Collinses often talk of having Longbourn when Elizabeth ’s father is dead . the Collinses look upon Longbourn as quite the Collinses own , Elizabeth ’s dare say , whenever that happens . ” 
 
  “ It was a subject which the Collinses could not mention before Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  “ No ; it would have been strange if the Collinses had ; but Elizabeth ’s make no doubt the Collinses often talk of it between the Collinses . Well , if the Collinses can be easy with an estate that is not lawfully the Collinses own , so much the better . Elizabeth ’s should be ashamed of having one that was only entailed on Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  The first week of the regiment ’s return was soon gone . The second began . The second was the last of the regiment ’s stay in Meryton , and all the young ladies in the neighbourhood were drooping apace . The dejection was almost universal . The elder Miss Bennets alone were still able to eat , drink , and sleep , and pursue the usual course of The elder Miss Bennets alone employments . Very frequently were The elder Miss Bennets alone reproached for this insensibility by Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family . 
 
  “ Good Heaven ! what is to become of Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family ? What are Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family to do ? ” would Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family often exclaim in the bitterness of woe . “ How can Elizabeth be smiling so , Elizabeth ? ” 
 
  Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother shared all Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family grief ; Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother remembered what Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother had Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother endured on a similar occasion , five - and - twenty years ago . 
 
  “ Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother am sure , ” said Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother , “ Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother cried for two days together when Colonel Miller ’s regiment went away . Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother thought Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother should have broken Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother heart . ” 
 
  “ Lydia am sure Lydia shall break Lydia , ” said Lydia . 
 
  “ If one could but go to Brighton ! ” observed Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother . 
 
  “ Oh , yes!—if one could but go to Brighton ! But papa is so disagreeable . ” 
 
  “ A little sea - bathing would set me up forever . ” 
 
  “ And me aunt Phillips is sure A little sea - bathing would do me a great deal of good , ” added Kitty . 
 
  Such were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through Longbourn House . Elizabeth tried to be diverted by the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through Longbourn House ; but all sense of pleasure was lost in shame . Elizabeth felt anew the justice of Fitzwilliam ’s objections ; and never had Elizabeth been so much disposed to pardon Fitzwilliam ’s interference in the views of Fitzwilliam ’s friend . 
 
  But the gloom of Lydia ’s prospect was shortly cleared away ; for Lydia received an invitation from Mrs. Forster , the wife of the colonel of the regiment ’s , to accompany Lydia to Brighton . Lydia was a very young woman , and very lately married . A resemblance in good humour and good spirits had recommended Lydia and Lydia to each other , and out of Lydia and Lydia three months ’ acquaintance Lydia and Lydia had been intimate two . 
 
  The rapture of Lydia on this occasion , Lydia adoration of Lydia , the delight of Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother , and the mortification of Kitty , are scarcely to be described . Wholly inattentive to Lydia sister ’s feelings , Lydia flew about Longbourn House in restless ecstasy , calling for everyone ’s congratulations , and laughing and talking with more violence than ever ; whilst the luckless Kitty continued in the parlour repining at Kitty fate in terms as unreasonable as Kitty accent was peevish . 
 
  “ Lydia can not see why Lydia should not ask Lydia as well as Lydia , ” said Lydia , “ Though Lydia am not Lydia particular friend . Lydia have just as much right to be asked as Lydia has , and more too , for Lydia am two years older . ” 
 
  In vain did Elizabeth attempt to make Lydia reasonable , and Jane to make Lydia resigned . As for Elizabeth herself , this invitation was so far from exciting in Elizabeth the same feelings as in Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother and Lydia , that Elizabeth considered this invitation as the death warrant of all possibility of common sense for Lydia ; and detestable as such a step must make Elizabeth were it known , Elizabeth could not help secretly advising Elizabeth father not to let Elizabeth go . Elizabeth represented to Elizabeth father all the improprieties of Lydia ’s general behaviour , the little advantage Lydia could derive from the friendship of such a woman as Lydia , and the probability of Lydia being yet more imprudent with such a companion at Brighton , where the temptations must be greater than at home . Elizabeth father heard Elizabeth attentively , and then said : 
 
  “ Lydia will never be easy until Lydia has exposed Lydia in some public place or other , and we can never expect Lydia to do exposed with so little expense or inconvenience to Lydia family as under the present circumstances . ” 
 
  “ If Elizabeth father were aware , ” said Elizabeth , “ of the very great disadvantage to us all which must arise from the public notice of Lydia ’s unguarded and imprudent manner — nay , which has already arisen from it , Elizabeth am sure Elizabeth father would judge differently in the affair . ” 
 
  “ Already arisen ? ” repeated Elizabeth father . “ What , has Lydia frightened away some of Elizabeth lovers ? Poor little Elizabeth ! But do not be cast down . Such squeamish youths as can not bear to be connected with a little absurdity are not worth a regret . Come , let Elizabeth father see the list of pitiful fellows who have been kept aloof by Lydia ’s folly . ” 
 
  “ Indeed Elizabeth are mistaken . Elizabeth father have no such injuries to resent . It is not of particular , but of general evils , which Elizabeth father am now complaining . Our importance , our respectability in the world must be affected by the wild volatility , the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark Lydia ’s character . Excuse Elizabeth , for Elizabeth must speak plainly . If Elizabeth father , Elizabeth father , will not take the trouble of checking Lydia exuberant spirits , and of teaching Lydia that Lydia present pursuits are not to be the business of Lydia life , Lydia will soon be beyond the reach of amendment . Lydia character will be fixed , and Lydia will , at sixteen , be the most determined flirt that ever made Lydia or Lydia family ridiculous ; a flirt , too , in the worst and meanest degree of flirtation ; without any attraction beyond youth and a tolerable person ; and , from the ignorance and emptiness of Lydia mind , wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal contempt which Lydia rage for admiration will excite . In this danger Kitty also is comprehended . Kitty will follow wherever Lydia leads . Lydia Oh ! Elizabeth dear father , can Elizabeth father suppose it possible that they will not be censured and despised wherever they are known , and that they sisters will not be often involved in the disgrace ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth father saw that Elizabeth whole heart was in the subject , and affectionately taking Elizabeth hand said in reply : 
 
  “ Do not make Elizabeth uneasy , Elizabeth . Wherever Elizabeth and Jane are known Elizabeth must be respected and valued ; and Elizabeth will not appear to less advantage for having a couple of — or Elizabeth father may say , three — very silly sisters . We shall have no peace at Longbourn House if Lydia does not go to Brighton . Let Lydia go , then . the colonel of the regiment ’s is a sensible man , and will keep Lydia out of any real mischief ; and Lydia is luckily too poor to be an object of prey to anybody . At Brighton Lydia will be of less importance even as a common flirt than Lydia has been here . The officers will find women better worth The officers notice . Let Our hope , therefore , that Lydia being there may teach Lydia Lydia own insignificance . At any rate , Lydia can not grow many degrees worse , without authorising Our to lock Lydia up for the rest of Lydia life . ” 
 
  With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content ; but Elizabeth own opinion continued the same , and Elizabeth left Elizabeth father disappointed and sorry . It was not in Elizabeth nature , however , to increase Elizabeth vexations by dwelling on Elizabeth vexations . Elizabeth was confident of having performed Elizabeth duty , and to fret over unavoidable evils , or augment unavoidable evils by anxiety , was no part of Elizabeth disposition . 
 
  Had Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother known the substance of Lydia conference with Lydia father , Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother indignation would hardly have found expression in Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother united volubility . In Lydia ’s imagination , a visit to Brighton comprised every possibility of earthly happiness . Lydia saw , with the creative eye of fancy , the streets of that gay bathing - place covered with officers . Lydia saw Lydia the object of attention , to tens and to scores of them at present unknown . Lydia saw all the glories of the camp — the camp tents stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines , crowded with the young and the gay , and dazzling with scarlet ; and , to complete the view , Lydia saw Lydia seated beneath a tent , tenderly flirting with at least six officers at once . 
 
  Had Lydia known Lydia sister sought to tear Lydia from such prospects and such realities as these , what would have been Lydia sensations ? Lydia sensations could have been understood only by Lydia mother , who might have felt nearly the same . Lydia ’s going to Brighton was all that consoled Lydia for Lydia melancholy conviction of Lydia husband ’s never intending to go there Lydia husband ’s . 
 
  But Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother were entirely ignorant of what had passed ; and Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother raptures continued , with little intermission , to the very day of Lydia ’s leaving home . 
 
  Elizabeth was now to see Charlie for the last time . Having been frequently in company with Charlie since Elizabeth return , agitation was pretty well over ; the agitations of former partiality entirely so . Elizabeth had even learnt to detect , in the very gentleness which had first delighted Elizabeth , an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary . In Charlie present behaviour to Elizabeth , moreover , Elizabeth had a fresh source of displeasure , for the inclination Charlie soon testified of renewing those intentions which had marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve , after what had since passed , to provoke Elizabeth . Elizabeth lost all concern for Charlie in finding Elizabeth thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous gallantry ; and while Elizabeth steadily repressed such idle and frivolous gallantry , could not but feel the reproof contained in Charlie believing , that however long , and for whatever cause , Charlie attentions had been withdrawn , Elizabeth vanity would be gratified , and Elizabeth preference secured at any time by Charlie attentions renewal . 
 
  On the very last day of the regiment ’s remaining at Meryton , Charlie dined , with others of the officers , at Longbourn House ; and so little was Elizabeth disposed to part from Charlie in good humour , that on Charlie making some enquiry as to the manner in which Elizabeth time had passed at Hunsford , Elizabeth mentioned Fitzwilam ’s and Fitzwilliam ’s having both spent three weeks at Rosings , and asked Charlie , if Charlie was acquainted with Fitzwilliam ’s . 
 
  Charlie looked surprised , displeased , alarmed ; but with a moment ’s recollection and a returning smile , replied , that Charlie had formerly seen Fitzwilliam ’s often ; and , after observing that Fitzwilliam ’s was a very gentlemanlike man , asked Elizabeth how Elizabeth had liked Fitzwilliam ’s . Elizabeth answer was warmly in Fitzwilliam ’s favour . With an air of indifference Charlie soon afterwards added : 
 
  “ How long did Elizabeth say Fitzwilliam ’s was at Rosings ? ” 
 
  “ Nearly three weeks . ” 
 
  “ And Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam ’s frequently ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , almost every day . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ’s manners are very different from Fitzwilliam ’s cousin ’s . ” 
 
  “ Yes , very different . But Elizabeth think Fitzwilliam ’s improves upon acquaintance . ” 
 
  “ Indeed ! ” cried Charlie with a look which did not escape Charlie . “ And pray , may Charlie ask ? — ” But checking Charlie , Charlie added , in a gayer tone , “ Is it in address that Fitzwilliam ’s improves ? Has Fitzwilliam ’s deigned to add aught of civility to Fitzwilliam ’s ordinary style?—for Charlie dare not hope , ” Charlie continued in a lower and more serious tone , “ that Fitzwilliam ’s is improved in essentials . ” 
 
  “ Oh , no ! ” said Elizabeth . “ In essentials , Elizabeth believe , Fitzwilliam ’s is very much what Fitzwilliam ’s ever was . ” 
 
  While Elizabeth spoke , Charlie looked as if scarcely knowing whether to rejoice over Elizabeth words , or to distrust Elizabeth words meaning . There was a something in Elizabeth countenance which made Charlie listen with an apprehensive and anxious attention , while Elizabeth added : 
 
  “ When Elizabeth said that Fitzwilliam ’s improved on acquaintance , Elizabeth did not mean that Fitzwilliam ’s mind or Fitzwilliam ’s manners were in a state of improvement , but that , from knowing Fitzwilliam ’s better , Fitzwilliam ’s disposition was better understood . ” 
 
  Charlie alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated look ; for a few minutes Charlie was silent , till , shaking off Charlie embarrassment , Charlie turned to Elizabeth again , and said in the gentlest of accents : 
 
  “ Elizabeth , will readily comprehend how sincerely Charlie must rejoice that Fitzwilliam ’s is wise enough to assume even the appearance of what is right . Fitzwilliam ’s pride , in that direction , may be of service , if not to Fitzwilliam ’s , to many others , for Fitzwilliam ’s pride must only deter Fitzwilliam ’s from such foul misconduct as Charlie have suffered by . Charlie only fear that the sort of cautiousness to which Elizabeth , Charlie imagine , have been alluding , is merely adopted on Fitzwilliam ’s visits to Fitzwilliam ’s aunt , of whose good opinion and judgement Fitzwilliam ’s stands much in awe . Fitzwilliam ’s fear of Fitzwilliam ’s aunt , of whose good opinion and judgement Fitzwilliam ’s stands much in awe has always operated , Charlie know , when they were together ; and a good deal is to be imputed to Fitzwilliam ’s wish of forwarding the match with Cathleen , which Charlie am certain Fitzwilliam ’s has very much at heart . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could not repress a smile at this , but Elizabeth answered only by a slight inclination of the head . Elizabeth saw that Charlie wanted to engage Elizabeth on the old subject of Charlie grievances , and Elizabeth was in no humour to indulge Charlie . The rest of the evening passed with the appearance , on Charlie side , of usual cheerfulness , but with no further attempt to distinguish Elizabeth ; and Lydia and Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother parted at last with mutual civility , and possibly a mutual desire of never meeting again . 
 
  When the party broke up , Lydia returned with Lydia to Meryton , from whence they were to set out early the next morning . The separation between Lydia and Lydia family was rather noisy than pathetic . Kitty was the only one who shed tears ; but Kitty did weep from vexation and envy . Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother was diffuse in Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother good wishes for the felicity of Lydia , and impressive in Kitty and Lydia , whose own misery was extreme , and who could not comprehend such hard - heartedness in any of the family affectionate mother injunctions that Lydia should not miss the opportunity of enjoying Lydia as much as possible — advice which there was every reason to believe would be well attended to ; and in the clamorous happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell , the more gentle adieus of Lydia sisters were uttered without being heard . 
 Chapter 
 
  Had Elizabeth ’s opinion been all drawn from Elizabeth ’s own family , Elizabeth ’s could not have formed a very pleasing opinion of conjugal felicity or domestic comfort . Elizabeth ’s father , captivated by youth and beauty , and that appearance of good humour which youth and beauty generally give , had married a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for a woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in their marriage put an end to all real affection for . Respect , esteem , and confidence had vanished for ever ; and all Elizabeth ’s father views of domestic happiness were overthrown . But Elizabeth ’s father was not of a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which Elizabeth ’s father own imprudence had brought on , in any of those pleasures which too often console the unfortunate for the unfortunate folly or the unfortunate vice . Elizabeth ’s father was fond of the country and of books ; and from these tastes had arisen Elizabeth ’s father principal enjoyments . To Elizabeth ’s father wife Elizabeth ’s father was very little otherwise indebted , than as Elizabeth ’s father wife ignorance and folly had contributed to Elizabeth ’s father amusement . This is not the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to a man wife ; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting , the true philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given . 
 
  Elizabeth ’s , however , had never been blind to the impropriety of Elizabeth ’s father ’s behaviour as a husband . Elizabeth ’s had always seen Elizabeth ’s father ’s behaviour as a husband with pain ; but respecting Elizabeth ’s father abilities , and grateful for Elizabeth ’s father affectionate treatment of Elizabeth ’s , Elizabeth ’s endeavoured to forget what Elizabeth ’s could not overlook , and to banish from Elizabeth ’s thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which , in exposing Elizabeth ’s father wife to the contempt of Elizabeth ’s father wife own children , was so highly reprehensible . But Elizabeth ’s had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage , nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill - judged a direction of talents ; talents , which , rightly used , might at least have preserved the respectability of Elizabeth ’s father daughters , even if incapable of enlarging the mind of Elizabeth ’s father wife . 
 
  When Elizabeth ’s had rejoiced over George ’s departure Elizabeth ’s found little other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment . Their parties abroad were less varied than before , and at home Elizabeth ’s had a mother and sister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around a mother and sister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around threw a real gloom over a mother and sister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around domestic circle ; and , though Kitty might in time regain Kitty natural degree of sense , since the disturbers of Elizabeth ’s brain were removed , Elizabeth ’s other sister , from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended , was likely to be hardened in all Elizabeth ’s other sister , from whose disposition greater evil might be apprehended folly and assurance by a situation of such double danger as a watering - place and a camp . Upon the whole , therefore , Elizabeth ’s found , what has been sometimes found before , that an event to which Elizabeth ’s had looked forward with impatient desire did not , in taking place , bring all the satisfaction Elizabeth ’s had promised Elizabeth ’s . It was consequently necessary to name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity — to have some other point on which Elizabeth ’s wishes and hopes might be fixed , and by again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation , console Elizabeth ’s for the present , and prepare for another disappointment . Elizabeth ’s tour to the Lakes was now the object of Elizabeth ’s happiest thoughts ; Elizabeth ’s tour to the Lakes was Elizabeth ’s best consolation for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of Elizabeth ’s mother and Kitty made inevitable ; and could Elizabeth ’s have included Kitty in the scheme , every part of the scheme would have been perfect . 
 
  “ But it is fortunate , ” thought Elizabeth ’s , “ that Elizabeth ’s have something to wish for . Were the whole arrangement complete , Elizabeth ’s disappointment would be certain . But here , by carrying with Elizabeth ’s one ceaseless source of regret in Elizabeth ’s sister ’s absence , Elizabeth ’s may reasonably hope to have all Elizabeth ’s expectations of pleasure realised . A scheme of which every part promises delight can never be successful ; and general disappointment is only warded off by the defence of some little peculiar vexation . ” 
 
  When Elizabeth ’s went away Elizabeth ’s promised to write very often and very minutely to Elizabeth ’s father wife and Kitty ; but Elizabeth ’s letters were always long expected , and always very short . Those to Elizabeth ’s father wife contained little else than that they were just returned from the library , where such and such officers had attended they , and where Elizabeth ’s had seen such beautiful ornaments as made Elizabeth ’s quite wild ; that Elizabeth ’s had a new gown , or a new parasol , which Elizabeth ’s would have described more fully , but was obliged to leave off in a violent hurry , as Mrs. Forster called Elizabeth ’s , and they were going off to the camp ; and from Elizabeth ’s correspondence with Elizabeth ’s sister , there was still less to be learnt — for Elizabeth ’s letters to Kitty , though rather longer , were much too full of lines under the words to be made public . 
 
  After the first fortnight or three weeks of Elizabeth ’s absence , health , good humour , and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn . Everything wore a happier aspect . The families who had been in town for the winter came back again , and summer finery and summer engagements arose . Elizabeth ’s father wife was restored to Elizabeth ’s father wife usual querulous serenity ; and , by the middle of June , Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without tears ; an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth ’s hope that by the following Christmas Elizabeth ’s might be so tolerably reasonable as not to mention an officer above once a day , unless , by some cruel and malicious arrangement at the War Office , another regiment should be quartered in Meryton . 
 
  The time fixed for the beginning of Edward and Madeline northern tour was now fast approaching , and a fortnight only was wanting of The time fixed for the beginning of Edward and Madeline northern tour , when a letter arrived from Madeline , which at once delayed Edward and Madeline northern tour commencement and curtailed Edward and Madeline northern tour extent . Edward would be prevented by business from setting out till a fortnight later in July , and must be in London again within a month , and as that left too short a period for Edward and Madeline to go so far , and see so much as Edward and Madeline had proposed , or at least to see it with the leisure and comfort Edward and Madeline had built on , Edward and Madeline were obliged to give up the Lakes , and substitute a more contracted tour , and , according to the present plan , were to go no farther northwards than Derbyshire . In Derbyshire there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of Edward and Madeline three weeks ; and to Madeline Madeline had a peculiarly strong attraction . Madeline , was probably as great an object of Elizabeth ’s curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock , Chatsworth , Dovedale , or the Peak . 
 
  Elizabeth ’s was excessively disappointed ; Elizabeth ’s had set Elizabeth ’s heart on seeing the Lakes , and still thought there might have been time enough . But it was Elizabeth ’s business to be satisfied — and certainly Elizabeth ’s temper to be happy ; and all was soon right again . 
 
  With the mention of Derbyshire there were many ideas connected . It was impossible for Elizabeth ’s to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and the word owner . “ But surely , ” said Elizabeth ’s , “ Elizabeth ’s may enter the word owner county with impunity , and rob Derbyshire of a few petrified spars without the word owner perceiving Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  The period of expectation was now doubled . Four weeks were to pass away before Elizabeth ’s uncle and aunt ’s arrival . But Elizabeth ’s uncle and aunt ’s did pass away , and Edward and Madeline , with Edward and Madeline four children , did at length appear at Longbourn . Edward and Madeline four children , were to be left under the particular care of Edward and Madeline four children cousin Jane , who was the general favourite , and whose steady sense and sweetness of temper exactly adapted Kitty for attending to Edward and Madeline four children in every way — teaching Edward and Madeline four children , playing with Edward and Madeline four children , and loving Edward and Madeline four children . 
 
  Edward and Madeline stayed only one night at Longbourn , and set off the next morning with Elizabeth ’s in pursuit of novelty and amusement . One enjoyment was certain — that of suitableness of companions ; a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear inconveniences — cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure — and affection and intelligence , which might supply it among Edward and Madeline if there were disappointments abroad . 
 
  It is not the object of this work to give a description of Derbyshire , nor of any of the remarkable places through which Edward and Madeline route thither lay ; Oxford , Blenheim , Warwick , Kenilworth , Birmingham , etc . are sufficiently known . A small part of Derbyshire is all the present concern . To the little town of Lambton , the scene of Madeline ’s former residence , and where Madeline had lately learned some acquaintance still remained , Edward and Madeline bent Edward and Madeline steps , after having seen all the principal wonders of Derbyshire ; and within five miles of the little town of Lambton , the scene of Madeline ’s former residence , and where Madeline had lately learned some acquaintance still remained , Elizabeth ’s found from Madeline that Pemberley was situated . Pemberley was not in Edward and Madeline direct road , nor more than a mile or two out of Edward and Madeline direct road . In talking over Edward and Madeline route the evening before , Madeline expressed an inclination to see Pemberley again . Edward declared Edward willingness , and Elizabeth ’s was applied to for Elizabeth ’s approbation . 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s , should not Elizabeth ’s like to see a place of which Elizabeth ’s have heard so much ? ” said Elizabeth ’s aunt ; “ a place , too , with which so many of Elizabeth ’s acquaintances are connected . George ’s passed all George ’s youth there , Elizabeth ’s know . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s was distressed . Elizabeth ’s felt that Elizabeth ’s had no business at Pemberley , and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing Pemberley . Elizabeth ’s must own that Elizabeth ’s was tired of seeing great houses ; after going over so many , Elizabeth ’s really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains . 
 
  Madeline abused Madeline stupidity . “ If Pemberley were merely a fine house richly furnished , ” said Madeline , “ Madeline should not care about Pemberley Madeline ; but the grounds are delightful . They have some of the finest woods in the country . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s said no more — but Elizabeth ’s mind could not acquiesce . The possibility of meeting Fitzwilliam , while viewing Pemberley , instantly occurred . meeting would be dreadful ! Elizabeth ’s blushed at The possibility of meeting Fitzwilliam , while viewing Pemberley , and thought it would be better to speak openly to Elizabeth ’s aunt than to run such a risk . But against this there were objections ; and Elizabeth ’s finally resolved that it could be the last resource , if Elizabeth ’s private enquiries to the absence of the family were unfavourably answered . 
 
  Accordingly , when Elizabeth ’s retired at night , Elizabeth ’s asked the chambermaid whether Pemberley were not a very fine place ? what was the name of Pemberley proprietor ? and , with no little alarm , whether the family were down for the summer ? A most welcome negative followed the last question — and Elizabeth ’s alarms now being removed , Elizabeth ’s was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see Pemberley Elizabeth ’s ; and when the subject was revived the next morning , and Elizabeth ’s was again applied to , could readily answer , and with a proper air of indifference , that Elizabeth ’s had not really any dislike to the scheme . To Pemberley , therefore , they were to go . 
 Chapter 
 
 Elizabeth, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of Pemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned in at the lodge, her spirits were in a high flutter.
 
 The park was very large, and contained great variety of ground. They entered it in one of its lowest points, and drove for some time through a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent.
 
 Elizabeth’s mind was too full for conversation, but she saw and admired every remarkable spot and point of view. They gradually ascended for half-a-mile, and then found themselves at the top of a considerable eminence, where the wood ceased, and the eye was instantly caught by Pemberley House, situated on the opposite side of a valley, into which the road with some abruptness wound. It was a large, handsome stone building, standing well on rising ground, and backed by a ridge of high woody hills; and in front, a stream of some natural importance was swelled into greater, but without any artificial appearance. Its banks were neither formal nor falsely adorned. Elizabeth was delighted. She had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste. They were all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she felt that to be mistress of Pemberley might be something!
 
 They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and, while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of meeting its owner returned. She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been mistaken. On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the hall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to wonder at her being where she was.
 
 The housekeeper came; a respectable-looking elderly woman, much less fine, and more civil, than she had any notion of finding her. They followed her into the dining-parlour. It was a large, well proportioned room, handsomely fitted up. Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went to a window to enjoy its prospect. The hill, crowned with wood, which they had descended, receiving increased abruptness from the distance, was a beautiful object. Every disposition of the ground was good; and she looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered on its banks and the winding of the valley, as far as she could trace it, with delight. As they passed into other rooms these objects were taking different positions; but from every window there were beauties to be seen. The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture suitable to the fortune of its proprietor; but Elizabeth saw, with admiration of his taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine; with less of splendour, and more real elegance, than the furniture of Rosings.
 
 “And of this place,” thought she, “I might have been mistress! With these rooms I might now have been familiarly acquainted! Instead of viewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and welcomed to them as visitors my uncle and aunt. But no,”—recollecting herself—“that could never be; my uncle and aunt would have been lost to me; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”
 
 This was a lucky recollection—it saved her from something very like regret.
 
 She longed to enquire of the housekeeper whether her master was really absent, but had not the courage for it. At length however, the question was asked by her uncle; and she turned away with alarm, while Mrs. Reynolds replied that he was, adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with a large party of friends.” How rejoiced was Elizabeth that their own journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day!
 
 Her aunt now called her to look at a picture. She approached and saw the likeness of Charlie, suspended, amongst several other miniatures, over the mantelpiece. Her aunt asked her, smilingly, how she liked it. The housekeeper came forward, and told them it was a picture of a young gentleman, the son of her late master’s steward, who had been brought up by him at his own expense. “He is now gone into the army,” she added; “but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”
 
 Madeline looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth could not return it.
 
 “And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures, “is my master—and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the other—about eight years ago.”
 
 “I have heard much of your master’s fine person,” said Madeline, looking at the picture; “it is a handsome face. But, Elizabeth, you can tell us whether it is like or not.”
 
 Mrs. Reynolds respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase on this intimation of her knowing her master.
 
 “Does that young lady know Fitzwilliam?”
 
 Elizabeth coloured, and said: “A little.”
 
 “And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, ma’am?”
 
 “Yes, very handsome.”
 
 “I am sure I know none so handsome; but in the gallery up stairs you will see a finer, larger picture of him than this. This room was my late master’s favourite room, and these miniatures are just as they used to be then. He was very fond of them.”
 
 This accounted to Elizabeth for Charlie’s being among them.
 
 Mrs. Reynolds then directed their attention to one of Georgiana, drawn when she was only eight years old.
 
 “And is Georgiana as handsome as her brother?” said Madeline.
 
 “Oh! yes—the handsomest young lady that ever was seen; and so accomplished!—She plays and sings all day long. In the next room is a new instrument just come down for her—a present from my master; she comes here to-morrow with him.”
 
 Edward, whose manners were very easy and pleasant, encouraged her communicativeness by his questions and remarks; Mrs. Reynolds, either by pride or attachment, had evidently great pleasure in talking of her master and his sister.
 
 “Is your master much at Pemberley in the course of the year?”
 
 “Not so much as I could wish, sir; but I dare say he may spend half his time here; and Georgiana is always down for the summer months.”
 
 “Except,” thought Elizabeth, “when she goes to Ramsgate.”
 
 “If your master would marry, you might see more of him.”
 
 “Yes, sir; but I do not know when that will be. I do not know who is good enough for him.”
 
 Edward and Madeline smiled. Elizabeth could not help saying, “It is very much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.”
 
 “I say no more than the truth, and everybody will say that knows him,” replied the other. Elizabeth thought this was going pretty far; and she listened with increasing astonishment as the housekeeper added, “I have never known a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him ever since he was four years old.”
 
 This was praise, of all others most extraordinary, most opposite to her ideas. That he was not a good-tempered man had been her firmest opinion. Her keenest attention was awakened; she longed to hear more, and was grateful to her uncle for saying:
 
 “There are very few people of whom so much can be said. You are lucky in having such a master.”
 
 “Yes, sir, I know I am. If I were to go through the world, I could not meet with a better. But I have always observed, that they who are good-natured when children, are good-natured when they grow up; and he was always the sweetest-tempered, most generous-hearted boy in the world.”
 
 Elizabeth almost stared at her. “Can this be Fitzwilliam?” thought she.
 
 “His father was an excellent man,” said Madeline.
 
 “Yes, ma’am, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him—just as affable to the poor.”
 
 Elizabeth listened, wondered, doubted, and was impatient for more. Mrs. Reynolds could interest her on no other point. She related the subjects of the pictures, the dimensions of the rooms, and the price of the furniture, in vain. Edward, highly amused by the kind of family prejudice to which he attributed her excessive commendation of her master, soon led again to the subject; and she dwelt with energy on his many merits as they proceeded together up the great staircase.
 
 “He is the best landlord, and the best master,” said she, “that ever lived; not like the wild young men nowadays, who think of nothing but themselves. There is not one of his tenants or servants but will give him a good name. Some people call him proud; but I am sure I never saw anything of it. To my fancy, it is only because he does not rattle away like other young men.”
 
 “In what an amiable light does this place him!” thought Elizabeth.
 
 “This fine account of him,” whispered her aunt as they walked, “is not quite consistent with his behaviour to our poor friend.”
 
 “Perhaps we might be deceived.”
 
 “That is not very likely; our authority was too good.”
 
 On reaching the spacious lobby above they were shown into a very pretty sitting-room, lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than the apartments below; and were informed that it was but just done to give pleasure to Georgiana, who had taken a liking to the room when last at Pemberley.
 
 “He is certainly a good brother,” said Elizabeth, as she walked towards one of the windows.
 
 Mrs. Reynolds anticipated Georgiana’s delight, when she should enter the room. “And this is always the way with him,” she added. “Whatever can give his sister any pleasure is sure to be done in a moment. There is nothing he would not do for her.”
 
 The picture-gallery, and two or three of the principal bedrooms, were all that remained to be shown. In the former were many good paintings; but Elizabeth knew nothing of the art; and from such as had been already visible below, she had willingly turned to look at some drawings of Georgiana’s, in crayons, whose subjects were usually more interesting, and also more intelligible.
 
 In the gallery there were many family portraits, but they could have little to fix the attention of a stranger. Elizabeth walked in quest of the only face whose features would be known to her. At last it arrested her—and she beheld a striking resemblance to Fitzwilliam, with such a smile over the face as she remembered to have sometimes seen when he looked at her. She stood several minutes before the picture, in earnest contemplation, and returned to it again before they quitted the gallery. Mrs. Reynolds informed them that it had been taken in his father’s lifetime.
 
 There was certainly at this moment, in Elizabeth’s mind, a more gentle sensation towards the original than she had ever felt at the height of their acquaintance. The commendation bestowed on him by Mrs. Reynolds was of no trifling nature. What praise is more valuable than the praise of an intelligent servant? As a brother, a landlord, a master, she considered how many people’s happiness were in his guardianship!—how much of pleasure or pain was it in his power to bestow!—how much of good or evil must be done by him! Every idea that had been brought forward by the housekeeper was favourable to his character, and as she stood before the canvas on which he was represented, and fixed his eyes upon herself, she thought of his regard with a deeper sentiment of gratitude than it had ever raised before; she remembered its warmth, and softened its impropriety of expression.
 
 When all of the house that was open to general inspection had been seen, they returned downstairs, and, taking leave of the housekeeper, were consigned over to the gardener, who met them at the hall-door.
 
 As they walked across the hall towards the river, Elizabeth turned back to look again; her uncle and aunt stopped also, and while the former was conjecturing as to the date of the building, the owner of it himself suddenly came forward from the road, which led behind it to the stables.
 
 They were within twenty yards of each other, and so abrupt was his appearance, that it was impossible to avoid his sight. Their eyes instantly met, and the cheeks of both were overspread with the deepest blush. He absolutely started, and for a moment seemed immovable from surprise; but shortly recovering himself, advanced towards the party, and spoke to Elizabeth, if not in terms of perfect composure, at least of perfect civility.
 
 She had instinctively turned away; but stopping on his approach, received his compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be overcome. Had his first appearance, or his resemblance to the picture they had just been examining, been insufficient to assure the other two that they now saw Fitzwilliam, the gardener’s expression of surprise, on beholding his master, must immediately have told it. They stood a little aloof while he was talking to their niece, who, astonished and confused, scarcely dared lift her eyes to his face, and knew not what answer she returned to his civil enquiries after her family. Amazed at the alteration of his manner since they last parted, every sentence that he uttered was increasing her embarrassment; and every idea of the impropriety of her being found there recurring to her mind, the few minutes in which they continued were some of the most uncomfortable in her life. Nor did he seem much more at ease; when he spoke, his accent had none of its usual sedateness; and he repeated his enquiries as to the time of her having left Longbourn, and of her stay in Derbyshire, so often, and in so hurried a way, as plainly spoke the distraction of his thoughts.
 
 At length every idea seemed to fail him; and, after standing a few moments without saying a word, he suddenly recollected himself, and took leave.
 
 The others then joined her, and expressed admiration of his figure; but Elizabeth heard not a word, and wholly engrossed by her own feelings, followed them in silence. She was overpowered by shame and vexation. Her coming there was the most unfortunate, the most ill-judged thing in the world! How strange it must appear to him! In what a disgraceful light might it not strike so vain a man! It might seem as if she had purposely thrown herself in his way again! Oh! why did she come? Or, why did he thus come a day before he was expected? Had they been only ten minutes sooner, they should have been beyond the reach of his discrimination; for it was plain that he was that moment arrived—that moment alighted from his horse or his carriage. She blushed again and again over the perverseness of the meeting. And his behaviour, so strikingly altered—what could it mean? That he should even speak to her was amazing!—but to speak with such civility, to enquire after her family! Never in her life had she seen his manners so little dignified, never had he spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting. What a contrast did it offer to his last address in Rosings Park, when he put his letter into her hand! She knew not what to think, or how to account for it.
 
 They had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, and every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground, or a finer reach of the woods to which they were approaching; but it was some time before Elizabeth was sensible of any of it; and, though she answered mechanically to the repeated appeals of her uncle and aunt, and seemed to direct her eyes to such objects as they pointed out, she distinguished no part of the scene. Her thoughts were all fixed on that one spot of Pemberley House, whichever it might be, where Fitzwilliam then was. She longed to know what at the moment was passing in his mind—in what manner he thought of her, and whether, in defiance of everything, she was still dear to him. Perhaps he had been civil only because he felt himself at ease; yet there had been that in his voice which was not like ease. Whether he had felt more of pain or of pleasure in seeing her she could not tell, but he certainly had not seen her with composure.
 
 At length, however, the remarks of her companions on her absence of mind aroused her, and she felt the necessity of appearing more like herself.
 
 They entered the woods, and bidding adieu to the river for a while, ascended some of the higher grounds; when, in spots where the opening of the trees gave the eye power to wander, were many charming views of the valley, the opposite hills, with the long range of woods overspreading many, and occasionally part of the stream. Edward expressed a wish of going round the whole park, but feared it might be beyond a walk. With a triumphant smile they were told that it was ten miles round. It settled the matter; and they pursued the accustomed circuit; which brought them again, after some time, in a descent among hanging woods, to the edge of the water, and one of its narrowest parts. They crossed it by a simple bridge, in character with the general air of the scene; it was a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited; and the valley, here contracted into a glen, allowed room only for the stream, and a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice-wood which bordered it. Elizabeth longed to explore its windings; but when they had crossed the bridge, and perceived their distance from the house, Madeline, who was not a great walker, could go no farther, and thought only of returning to the carriage as quickly as possible. Her niece was, therefore, obliged to submit, and they took their way towards the house on the opposite side of the river, in the nearest direction; but their progress was slow, for Edward, though seldom able to indulge the taste, was very fond of fishing, and was so much engaged in watching the occasional appearance of some trout in the water, and talking to the man about them, that he advanced but little. Whilst wandering on in this slow manner, they were again surprised, and Elizabeth’s astonishment was quite equal to what it had been at first, by the sight of Fitzwilliam approaching them, and at no great distance. The walk being here less sheltered than on the other side, allowed them to see him before they met. Elizabeth, however astonished, was at least more prepared for an interview than before, and resolved to appear and to speak with calmness, if he really intended to meet them. For a few moments, indeed, she felt that he would probably strike into some other path. The idea lasted while a turning in the walk concealed him from their view; the turning past, he was immediately before them. With a glance, she saw that he had lost none of his recent civility; and, to imitate his politeness, she began, as they met, to admire the beauty of the place; but she had not got beyond the words “delightful,” and “charming,” when some unlucky recollections obtruded, and she fancied that praise of Pemberley from her might be mischievously construed. Her colour changed, and she said no more.
 
 Madeline was standing a little behind; and on her pausing, he asked her if she would do him the honour of introducing him to her friends. This was a stroke of civility for which she was quite unprepared; and she could hardly suppress a smile at his being now seeking the acquaintance of some of those very people against whom his pride had revolted in his offer to herself. “What will be his surprise,” thought she, “when he knows who they are? He takes them now for people of fashion.”
 
 The introduction, however, was immediately made; and as she named their relationship to herself, she stole a sly look at him, to see how he bore it, and was not without the expectation of his decamping as fast as he could from such disgraceful companions. That he was surprised by the connection was evident; he sustained it, however, with fortitude, and so far from going away, turned back with them, and entered into conversation with Edward. Elizabeth could not but be pleased, could not but triumph. It was consoling that he should know she had some relations for whom there was no need to blush. She listened most attentively to all that passed between them, and gloried in every expression, every sentence of her uncle, which marked his intelligence, his taste, or his good manners.
 
 The conversation soon turned upon fishing; and she heard Fitzwilliam invite him, with the greatest civility, to fish there as often as he chose while he continued in the neighbourhood, offering at the same time to supply him with fishing tackle, and pointing out those parts of the stream where there was usually most sport. Madeline, who was walking arm-in-arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look expressive of wonder. Elizabeth said nothing, but it gratified her exceedingly; the compliment must be all for herself. Her astonishment, however, was extreme, and continually was she repeating, “Why is he so altered? From what can it proceed? It cannot be for me—it cannot be for my sake that his manners are thus softened. My reproofs at Hunsford could not work such a change as this. It is impossible that he should still love me.”
 
 After walking some time in this way, the two ladies in front, the two gentlemen behind, on resuming their places, after descending to the brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious water-plant, there chanced to be a little alteration. It originated in Madeline, who, fatigued by the exercise of the morning, found Elizabeth’s arm inadequate to her support, and consequently preferred her husband’s. Fitzwilliam took her place by her niece, and they walked on together. After a short silence, the lady first spoke. She wished him to know that she had been assured of his absence before she came to the place, and accordingly began by observing, that his arrival had been very unexpected—“for your housekeeper,” she added, “informed us that you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and indeed, before we left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected in the country.” He acknowledged the truth of it all, and said that business with his steward had occasioned his coming forward a few hours before the rest of the party with whom he had been travelling. “They will join me early to-morrow,” he continued, “and among them are some who will claim an acquaintance with you—Charles and his sisters.”
 
 Elizabeth answered only by a slight bow. Her thoughts were instantly driven back to the time when Charles’s name had been the last mentioned between them; and, if she might judge by his complexion, his mind was not very differently engaged.
 
 “There is also one other person in the party,” he continued after a pause, “who more particularly wishes to be known to you. Will you allow me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance during your stay at Lambton?”
 
 The surprise of such an application was great indeed; it was too great for her to know in what manner she acceded to it. She immediately felt that whatever desire Georgiana might have of being acquainted with her must be the work of her brother, and, without looking farther, it was satisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made him think really ill of her.
 
 They now walked on in silence, each of them deep in thought. Elizabeth was not comfortable; that was impossible; but she was flattered and pleased. His wish of introducing his sister to her was a compliment of the highest kind. They soon outstripped the others, and when they had reached the carriage, Edward and Madeline were half a quarter of a mile behind.
 
 He then asked her to walk into the house—but she declared herself not tired, and they stood together on the lawn. At such a time much might have been said, and silence was very awkward. She wanted to talk, but there seemed to be an embargo on every subject. At last she recollected that she had been travelling, and they talked of Matlock and Dove Dale with great perseverance. Yet time and her aunt moved slowly—and her patience and her ideas were nearly worn out before the tête-à-tête was over.
 
 On Edward and Madeline’s coming up they were all pressed to go into the house and take some refreshment; but this was declined, and they parted on each side with utmost politeness. Fitzwilliam handed the ladies into the carriage; and when it drove off, Elizabeth saw him walking slowly towards the house.
 
 The observations of her uncle and aunt now began; and each of them pronounced him to be infinitely superior to anything they had expected. “He is perfectly well behaved, polite, and unassuming,” said her uncle.
 
 “There is something a little stately in him, to be sure,” replied her aunt, “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming. I can now say with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud, I have seen nothing of it.”
 
 “I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us. It was more than civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such attention. His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.”
 
 “To be sure, Elizabeth,” said her aunt, “he is not so handsome as George; or, rather, he has not George’s countenance, for his features are perfectly good. But how came you to tell me that he was so disagreeable?”
 
 Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could; said that she had liked him better when they had met in Kent than before, and that she had never seen him so pleasant as this morning.
 
 “But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied her uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him at his word, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off his grounds.”
 
 Elizabeth felt that they had entirely misunderstood his character, but said nothing.
 
 “From what we have seen of him,” continued Madeline, “I really should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by anybody as he has done by poor George. He has not an ill-natured look. On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when he speaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance that would not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But, to be sure, the good lady who showed us his house did give him a most flaming character! I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a liberal master, I suppose, and that in the eye of a servant comprehends every virtue.”
 
 Elizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of his behaviour to George; and therefore gave them to understand, in as guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from his relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor George’s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire. In confirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming her authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.
 
 Madeline was surprised and concerned; but as they were now approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs to think of anything else. Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk they had no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
 
 The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth much attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing but think, and think with wonder, of Fitzwilliam’s civility, and, above all, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.

  Elizabeth had settled it that Fitzwilliam would bring Fitzwilliam sister to visit Elizabeth the very day after Elizabeth reaching Pemberley ; and was consequently resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning . But Elizabeth conclusion was false ; for on the very morning after these visitors arrival at Lambton , these visitors came . these visitors had been walking about the place with some of these visitors new friends , and were just returning to the inn to dress these visitors for dining with the same family , when the sound of a carriage drew these visitors to a window , and these visitors saw these visitors driving up the street . Elizabeth immediately recognizing the livery , guessed what the livery meant , and imparted no small degree of Elizabeth surprise to Elizabeth relations by acquainting Elizabeth relations with the honour which Elizabeth expected . Elizabeth relations were all amazement ; and the embarrassment of Elizabeth manner as Elizabeth spoke , joined to the circumstance the circumstance , and many of the circumstances of the preceding day , opened to Elizabeth relations a new idea on the business . Nothing had ever suggested it before , but Elizabeth relations felt that there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a quarter than by supposing a partiality for Elizabeth relations niece . While these newly - born notions were passing in Elizabeth relations heads , the perturbation of Elizabeth ’s feelings was at every moment increasing . Elizabeth was quite amazed at Elizabeth own discomposure ; but amongst other causes of disquiet , Elizabeth dreaded lest the partiality of Fitzwilliam should have said too much in Elizabeth favour ; and , more than commonly anxious to please , Elizabeth naturally suspected that every power of pleasing would fail Elizabeth . 
 
  Elizabeth retreated from a window , fearful of being seen ; and as Elizabeth walked up and down the room , endeavouring to compose Elizabeth , saw such looks of enquiring surprise in Elizabeth relations as made everything worse . 
 
  these visitors appeared , and this formidable introduction took place . With astonishment did Elizabeth see that Fitzwilliam sister was at least as much embarrassed as Elizabeth . Since Fitzwilliam sister being at Lambton , Elizabeth had heard that Fitzwilliam sister was exceedingly proud ; but the observation of a very few minutes convinced Elizabeth that Fitzwilliam sister was only exceedingly shy . Elizabeth found it difficult to obtain even a word from Fitzwilliam sister beyond a monosyllable .

Fitzwilliam sister was less handsome than Fitzwilliam sister brother ; but there was sense and good humour in Fitzwilliam sister face , and Fitzwilliam sister manners were perfectly unassuming and gentle . Elizabeth , who had expected to find in Elizabeth as acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Fitzwilliam had been , was much relieved by discerning such different feelings .

All Elizabeth ’s anger against Charles had been long done away ; but had Elizabeth still felt any , All Elizabeth ’s anger against Charles could hardly have stood All Elizabeth ’s anger against Charles ground against the unaffected cordiality with which Charles expressed Charles on seeing Elizabeth again . Charles enquired in a friendly , though general way , after Elizabeth family , and looked and spoke with the same good - humoured ease that Charles had ever done . 
 
  To Edward and Madeline Charles was scarcely a less interesting personage than to Elizabeth . Edward and Madeline had long wished to see Charles . The whole party before them , indeed , excited a lively attention . The suspicions which had just arisen of Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth directed Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth observation towards each with an earnest though guarded enquiry ; and Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth soon drew from Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth observation the full conviction that one of Fitzwilliam and Elizabeth at least knew what it was to love . Of Elizabeth sensations Elizabeth sensations remained a little in doubt ; but that Charles was overflowing with admiration was evident enough . 
 
  Elizabeth , on Elizabeth side , had much to do . Elizabeth wanted to ascertain the feelings of each of Elizabeth visitors ; Elizabeth wanted to compose Elizabeth own , and to make Elizabeth agreeable to all ; and in the latter object , where Elizabeth feared most to fail , Elizabeth was most sure of success , for those to whom Elizabeth endeavoured to give pleasure were prepossessed in Elizabeth favour . Charles was ready , Fitzwilliam sister was eager , and Fitzwilliam determined , to be pleased .

Sometimes Elizabeth could fancy that Charles talked less than on former occasions , and once or twice pleased Elizabeth with the notion that , as Charles looked at Elizabeth , Charles was trying to trace a resemblance . Charles observed to Elizabeth , at a moment when the others were talking together , and in a tone which had something of real regret , that it “ was a very long time since Charles had had the pleasure of seeing Jane ; ” and , before Elizabeth could reply , Charles added , “ It is above eight months . We have not met since the 26th of November , when we were all dancing together at Netherfield . ”

There was not much in the question , nor in the preceding remark ; but there was a look and a manner which gave them meaning .

When Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam thus seeking the acquaintance and courting the good opinion of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a disgrace — when Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam thus civil , not only to Elizabeth , but to the very relations whom Fitzwilliam had openly disdained , and recollected their last lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage — the difference , the change was so great , and struck so forcibly on Elizabeth mind , that Elizabeth could hardly restrain Elizabeth astonishment from being visible . Never , even in the company of Fitzwilliam dear friends at Netherfield , or Fitzwilliam dignified relations at Rosings , had Elizabeth seen Fitzwilliam so desirous to please , so free from self - consequence or unbending reserve , as now , when no importance could result from the success of Fitzwilliam endeavours , and when even the acquaintance of those to whom Fitzwilliam attentions were addressed would draw down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and Rosings .

Fitzwilliam sister , though with a diffidence which marked Fitzwilliam sister little in the habit of giving invitations , readily obeyed . Madeline looked at Madeline niece , desirous of knowing how Elizabeth , felt disposed as to the invitation acceptance , but Elizabeth had turned away Elizabeth head .   Charles expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth again , having still a great deal to say to Elizabeth , and many enquiries to make after all their Hertfordshire friends . Elizabeth , construing all this into a wish of hearing Charles speak of Elizabeth sister , was pleased , and on this account , as well as some others , found Elizabeth , when Elizabeth visitors left their , capable of considering the last half - hour with some satisfaction , though while the last half - hour was passing , the enjoyment of the last half - hour had been little . Eager to be alone , and fearful of enquiries or hints from Elizabeth relations , Elizabeth stayed with Elizabeth relations only long enough to hear Elizabeth relations favourable opinion of Charles , and then hurried away to dress . 
 
  But Elizabeth had no reason to fear Edward and Madeline ’s curiosity ; it was not Edward and Madeline wish to force Elizabeth communication . Edward and Madeline saw much to interest , but nothing to justify enquiry .

Edward and Madeline could not be untouched by Fitzwilliam politeness ; and had Edward and Madeline drawn Fitzwilliam character from Edward and Madeline own feelings and Fitzwilliam servant ’s report , without any reference to any other account , the circle in Hertfordshire to which Fitzwilliam was known would not have recognized Fitzwilliam character for Fitzwilliam . There was now an interest , however , in believing Elizabeth ; and Edward and Madeline soon became sensible that the authority of a servant who had known Fitzwilliam since Fitzwilliam was four years old , and whose own manners indicated respectability , was not to be hastily rejected . Edward and Madeline had nothing to accuse Fitzwilliam of but pride ; pride Fitzwilliam probably had , and if not , it would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market - town where the same family did not visit . It was acknowledged , however , that Fitzwilliam was a liberal man , and did much good among the poor . 
 
  With respect to Fitzwilliam sister , Elizabeth visitors soon found that Fitzwilliam sister was not held there in much estimation ; for though the chief of Fitzwilliam sister concerns with the son of Fitzwilliam sister patron were imperfectly understood , it was yet a well - known fact that , on Fitzwilliam sister quitting Hertfordshire , Fitzwilliam sister had left many debts behind Fitzwilliam sister , which Fitzwilliam afterwards discharged . 
 
  As for Elizabeth , Elizabeth thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than the last ; and the evening , though as this evening passed this evening seemed long , was not long enough to determine Elizabeth feelings towards Fitzwilliam ; and Elizabeth lay awake two whole hours endeavouring to make Elizabeth feelings towards Fitzwilliam out . Elizabeth certainly did not hate Fitzwilliam . No ; hatred had vanished long ago , and Elizabeth had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against Fitzwilliam , that could be so called . But above all , above respect and esteem , there was a motive within Elizabeth of goodwill which could not be overlooked . a motive within Elizabeth of goodwill which could not be overlooked was gratitude ; gratitude , not merely for having once loved Elizabeth , but for loving Elizabeth still well enough to forgive all the petulance and acrimony of Elizabeth manner in rejecting Fitzwilliam , and all the unjust accusations accompanying Elizabeth rejection . Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam greatest enemy , seemed , on this accidental meeting , most eager to preserve the acquaintance , and without any indelicate display of regard , or any peculiarity of manner , where their two selves only were concerned , was soliciting the good opinion of Elizabeth friends , and bent on making Elizabeth known to Fitzwilliam sister . Elizabeth respected , Elizabeth esteemed , Elizabeth was grateful to Fitzwilliam , Elizabeth felt a real interest in Fitzwilliam welfare ; and Elizabeth only wanted to know how far Elizabeth wished Fitzwilliam welfare to depend upon Elizabeth , and how far it would be for the happiness of both that Elizabeth should employ the power , which Elizabeth fancy told Elizabeth Elizabeth still possessed , of bringing on Elizabeth the renewal of Fitzwilliam addresses .

They were , therefore , to go . Elizabeth was pleased ; though when Elizabeth asked Elizabeth the reason , Elizabeth had very little to say in reply .

  Convinced as Elizabeth now was that Caroline ’s dislike of Elizabeth had originated in jealousy , Elizabeth could not help feeling how unwelcome Elizabeth appearance at Pemberley must be to Elizabeth , and was curious to know with how much civility on Elizabeth side the acquaintance would now be renewed .

Elizabeth face is too thin ; Elizabeth complexion has no brilliancy ; and Elizabeth features are not at all handsome . Elizabeth teeth are tolerable , but not out of the common way ; and as for Elizabeth eyes , which have sometimes been called so fine , Caroline ’s could never see anything extraordinary in Elizabeth eyes , which have sometimes been called so fine . Fitzwilliam was resolutely silent , however , and , from a determination of making Fitzwilliam speak , Caroline ’s continued : 
 
  “ Caroline ’s remember , when we first knew Elizabeth in Hertfordshire , how amazed we all were to find that Elizabeth was a reputed beauty ; and Caroline ’s particularly recollect Fitzwilliam saying one night , after we had been dining at Netherfield , ‘ Elizabeth a beauty!—I should as soon call Caroline ’s a wit . ’ But afterwards Elizabeth seemed to improve on Fitzwilliam , and Caroline ’s believe Fitzwilliam thought Elizabeth rather pretty at one time . ” 
 
  “ Yes , ” replied Fitzwilliam , who could contain Fitzwilliam no longer , “ but that was only when Fitzwilliam first saw Elizabeth , for it is many months since Fitzwilliam have considered Elizabeth as one of the handsomest women of Fitzwilliam acquaintance . ”
