When Father was told of this , Father did not express so much satisfaction as Father children expected , considering what Father anxiety for Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s life had been before . 
 
  “ What , is Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s coming home , and without Father daughter ? ” Father cried . “ Sure Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s will not leave London before Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s has found yourself and Mother . Who is to fight Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s , and make Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s marry Father daughter , if Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s comes away ? ” 
 
  As Madeline began to wish to be at home , it was settled that Madeline and the children should go to London , at the same time Father sister , who considered it as the only security for husband ’s came from The coach . The coach , therefore , took Madeline and the children the first stage of Madeline and the children journey , and brought The coach master back to Longbourn . 
 
  Madeline went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world . Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world name had never been voluntarily mentioned before Madeline and the children by Father daughter ; and the kind of half - expectation which Madeline had formed , of Madeline and the children being followed by a letter from Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world , had ended in nothing . Elizabeth had received none since Elizabeth return that could come from Pemberley . 
 
  The present unhappy state of Longbourn rendered any other excuse for the lowness of Elizabeth spirits unnecessary ; nothing , therefore , could be fairly conjectured from that , though Elizabeth , who was by this time tolerably well acquainted with Elizabeth own feelings , was perfectly aware that , had Elizabeth known nothing of Elizabeth Derbyshire friend that had attended Elizabeth from that part of the world , Elizabeth could have borne the dread of Father daughter infamy somewhat better . It would have spared Elizabeth , Elizabeth thought , one sleepless night out of two . 
 
  When Father arrived , Father had all the appearance of Father usual philosophic composure . Father said as little as Father had ever been in the habit of saying ; made no mention of the business that had taken Father away , and it was some time before Father daughters had courage to speak of the business that had taken Father away . 
 
  It was not till the afternoon , when Father had joined the children at tea , that Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject ; and then , on Elizabeth briefly expressing Elizabeth sorrow for what Father must have endured , Father replied , “ Say nothing of that . Who should suffer but Father ? It has been Father own doing , and Father ought to feel it . ” 
 
  “ Father must not be too severe upon Father , ” replied Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Elizabeth may well warn Elizabeth against such an evil . Human nature is so prone to fall into such an evil ! No , Elizabeth , let Father once in Father life feel how much Father have been to blame . Father am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression . the impression will pass away soon enough . ” 
 
  “ Do Elizabeth suppose yourself and Mother to be in London ? ” 
 
  “ Yes ; where else can yourself and Mother be so well concealed ? ” 
 
  “ And Father daughter used to want to go to London , ” added Kitty . 
 
  “ Father daughter is happy then , ” said Father daughter father drily ; “ and Father daughter residence there will probably be of some duration . ” 
 
  Then after a short silence Father continued : 
 
  “ Elizabeth , Father bear Father no ill - will for being justified in Father advice to Father daughter last May , which , considering the event , shows some greatness of mind . ” 
 
  yourself and Mother were interrupted by Miss Bennet , who came to fetch Father tea . 
 
  “ This is a parade , ” Father cried , “ which does one good ; This gives such an elegance to misfortune ! Another day Father will do the same ; Father will sit in Father library , in Father nightcap and powdering gown , and give as much trouble as Father can ; or , perhaps , Father may defer it till Elizabeth runs away . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth am not going to run away , Father , ” said Elizabeth fretfully . “ If Elizabeth should ever go to Brighton , Elizabeth would behave better than Father daughter . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth go to Brighton . Father would not trust Elizabeth so near Brighton as Eastbourne for fifty pounds ! No , Elizabeth , Father have at last learnt to be cautious , and Elizabeth will feel the effects of learnt . No officer is ever to enter into Father house again , nor even to pass through the village . Balls will be absolutely prohibited , unless Elizabeth stand up with one of Elizabeth sisters . And Elizabeth are never to stir out of doors till Elizabeth can prove that Elizabeth have spent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , began to cry . 
 
  “ Well , well , ” said Father , “ do not make Elizabeth unhappy . If Elizabeth are a good girl for the next ten years , Father will take Elizabeth to a review at the end of the next ten years . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  Two days after Father ’s return , as Jane and Elizabeth were walking together in the shrubbery behind the house , Jane and Elizabeth saw the housekeeper coming towards Jane and Elizabeth , and , concluding that the housekeeper came to call Jane and Elizabeth to Jane and Elizabeth mother , went forward to meet the housekeeper ; but , instead of the expected summons , when Jane and Elizabeth approached the housekeeper , the housekeeper said to Miss Bennet , “ the housekeeper beg Miss Bennet pardon , Miss Bennet , for interrupting Miss Bennet , but the housekeeper was in hopes Miss Bennet might have got some good news from town , so the housekeeper took the liberty of coming to ask . Miss Bennet 
 
  Miss Bennet What do the housekeeper mean , Miss Bennet ? We have heard nothing from town . ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet , ” cried Jane and Elizabeth mother , in great astonishment , “ do n’t Miss Bennet know there is an express come for master from Edward ? master has been here this half - hour , and master has had a letter . ” 
 
  Away ran Jane and Elizabeth , too eager to get in to have time for speech . Jane and Elizabeth ran through the vestibule into the breakfast - room ; from thence to the library ; Father ’s was in neither ; and Jane and Elizabeth were on the point of seeking Father ’s up stairs with Jane and Elizabeth mother , when Jane and Elizabeth were met by the butler , who said : 
 
  “ If Jane and Elizabeth are looking for the butler , who said : 
 
  “ If Jane and Elizabeth are looking for master , Jane and Elizabeth , Father ’s is walking towards the little copse . ” 
 
  Upon this information , Jane and Elizabeth instantly passed through the hall once more , and ran across the lawn after Jane and Elizabeth father , who was deliberately pursuing Father ’s way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock . 
 
  Jane , who was not so light nor so much in the habit of running as Elizabeth , soon lagged behind , while Elizabeth , panting for breath , came up with Father ’s , and eagerly cried out : 
 
  “ Oh , Father ’s , what news — what news ? Have Father ’s heard from Jane uncle ? ” 
 
  “ Yes Elizabeth have had a letter from master by express . ” 
 
  “ Well , and what news does a letter from master by express bring — good or bad ? ” 
 
  “ What is there of good to be expected ? ” said Father ’s , taking a letter from Father ’s pocket . “ But perhaps Elizabeth would like to read a letter . ” 
 
  Elizabeth impatiently caught a letter from Father ’s hand . Jane now came up . 
 
  “ Read a letter aloud , ” said Father ’s , “ for Father ’s hardly know Father ’s what a letter is about . ” 
 
  “ Gracechurch Street , Monday , August 2 . 
 
  “ Elizabeth dear Brother , 
  “ At last Elizabeth am able to send Elizabeth dear Brother some tidings of Elizabeth niece , and such as , upon the whole , Elizabeth hope it will give Elizabeth dear Brother satisfaction . Soon after Elizabeth dear Brother left Elizabeth on Saturday , Elizabeth was fortunate enough to find out in what part of London they were . The particulars Elizabeth reserve till we meet ; it is enough to know The particulars are discovered . Elizabeth have seen they — ” 
      “ Then it is as Jane always hoped , ” cried Jane ; “ they are married ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth read on : 
 
  “ Elizabeth have seen they . They are not married , nor can Elizabeth find there was any intention of being so ; but if Elizabeth dear Brother are willing to perform the engagements which Elizabeth have ventured to make on Elizabeth dear Brother side , Elizabeth hope it will not be long before they are . All that is required of Elizabeth dear Brother is , to assure to Elizabeth dear Brother daughter , by settlement , Elizabeth niece equal share of the five thousand pounds secured among Elizabeth dear Brother children after the decease of Elizabeth dear Brother and Elizabeth sister ; and , moreover , to enter into an engagement of allowing Elizabeth niece , during Elizabeth dear Brother life , one hundred pounds per annum . These are conditions which , considering everything , Elizabeth had no hesitation in complying with , as far as Elizabeth thought Elizabeth privileged , for Elizabeth dear Brother . Elizabeth shall send this by express , that no time may be lost in bringing Elizabeth Elizabeth dear Brother answer . Elizabeth dear Brother will easily comprehend , from The particulars , that Charlie ’s circumstances are not so hopeless as Charlie ’s circumstances are generally believed to be . The world has been deceived in that respect ; and Elizabeth am happy to say there will be some little money , even when all Charlie ’s debts are discharged , to settle on Elizabeth niece , in addition to Elizabeth niece own fortune . If , as Elizabeth conclude will be the case , Elizabeth dear Brother send Elizabeth full powers to act in Elizabeth dear Brother name throughout the whole of this business , Elizabeth will immediately give directions to Haggerston for preparing a proper settlement . There will not be the smallest occasion for Elizabeth dear Brother coming to town again ; therefore stay quiet at Longbourn , and depend on Elizabeth diligence and care . Send back Elizabeth dear Brother answer as fast as Elizabeth dear Brother can , and be careful to write explicitly . We have judged it best that Elizabeth niece should be married from the house . Elizabeth niece comes to We to - day . Elizabeth shall write again as soon as anything more is determined on . Elizabeth dear Brother , etc . , 
 
  “ EDW . GARDINER . ” 
 
  “ Is it possible ? ” cried Elizabeth , when Elizabeth had finished . “ Can it be possible that good man will marry Elizabeth niece ? ” 
 
  “ George is not so undeserving , then , as we thought good man , ” said Jane . “ Father ’s , Elizabeth congratulate Father ’s . ” 
 
  “ And have Father ’s answered a letter ? ” cried Elizabeth . 
 
  “ No ; but it must be done soon . ” 
 
  Most earnestly did Elizabeth then entreat Father ’s to lose no more time before Father ’s wrote . 
 
  “ Oh ! Elizabeth dear father , ” Elizabeth cried , “ come back and write immediately . Consider how important every moment is in such a case . ” 
 
  “ Let Jane write for Father ’s , ” said Jane , “ if Father ’s dislike the trouble Father ’s . ” 
 
  “ Father ’s dislike the trouble very much , ” Father ’s replied ; “ but it must be done . ” 
 
  And so saying , Father ’s turned back with Jane and Elizabeth , and walked towards the house . 
 
  “ And may Elizabeth ask — ” said Elizabeth ; “ but the terms , Elizabeth suppose , must be complied with . ” 
 
  “ Complied with ! Elizabeth am only ashamed of good man asking so little . ” 
 
  “ And they must marry ! Yet good man is such a man ! ” 
 
  “ Yes , yes , they must marry . There is nothing else to be done . But there are two things that Elizabeth want very much to know ; one is , how much money Jane uncle has laid down to bring it about ; and the other , how am Elizabeth ever to pay Jane uncle . ” 
 
  “ Money ! Elizabeth uncle ! ” cried Jane , “ what do Father ’s mean , Father ’s ? ” 
 
  “ Father ’s mean , that no man in no man in senses would marry Elizabeth niece on so slight a temptation as one hundred a year during Father ’s life , and fifty after Father ’s am gone . ” 
 
  “ That is very true , ” said Elizabeth ; “ though That had not occurred to Elizabeth before . good man debts to be discharged , and something still to remain ! Oh ! it must be Elizabeth uncle ’s doings ! Generous , good man , Elizabeth am afraid good man has distressed good man . A small sum could not do all this . ” 
 
  “ No , ” said Father ’s ; “ good man ’s a fool if good man takes Elizabeth niece with a farthing less than ten thousand pounds . Elizabeth should be sorry to think so ill of good man , in the very beginning of our relationship . ” 
 
  “ Ten thousand pounds ! Heaven forbid ! How is half such a sum to be repaid ? ” 
 
  Father ’s made no answer , and each of Jane and Elizabeth , deep in thought , continued silent till Jane and Elizabeth reached the house . Father ’s then went on to the library to write , and Jane and Elizabeth walked into the breakfast - room . 
 
  “ And they are really to be married ! ” cried Elizabeth , as soon as Jane and Elizabeth were by Jane and Elizabeth . “ How strange are is ! And for are Jane and Elizabeth are to be thankful . That they should marry , small as is they chance of happiness , and wretched as is good man character , Jane and Elizabeth are forced to rejoice . Oh , Elizabeth niece ! ” 
 
  “ Jane comfort Jane with thinking , ” replied Jane , “ that good man certainly would not marry Elizabeth niece if good man had not a real regard for Elizabeth niece . Though Jane uncle has done something towards clearing good man , Jane can not believe that ten thousand pounds , or anything like ten thousand pounds , has been advanced . good man has children of good man own , and may have more . How could good man spare half ten thousand pounds ? ” 
 
  “ If good man were ever able to learn what good man debts have been , ” said Elizabeth , “ and how much is settled on good man side on Jane and Elizabeth sister , we shall exactly know what Edward has done for them , because good man has not sixpence of good man own . The kindness of Elizabeth uncle and aunt can never be requited . Elizabeth uncle and aunt taking Elizabeth niece home , and affording Elizabeth niece Elizabeth uncle and aunt personal protection and countenance , is such a sacrifice to Elizabeth niece advantage as years of gratitude can not enough acknowledge . By this time Elizabeth niece is actually with Elizabeth uncle and aunt ! If such goodness does not make Elizabeth niece miserable now , Elizabeth niece will never deserve to be happy ! What a meeting for Elizabeth niece , when Elizabeth niece first sees Elizabeth aunt ! ” 
 
  “ We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side , ” said Jane : “ Jane hope and trust they will yet be happy . good man consenting to marry Elizabeth niece is a proof , Jane will believe , that good man is come to a right way of thinking . they mutual affection will steady they ; and Jane flatter Jane they will settle so quietly , and live in so rational a manner , as may in time make they past imprudence forgotten . ” 
 
  “ they conduct has been such , ” replied Elizabeth , “ as neither Jane , nor Elizabeth , nor anybody can ever forget . It is useless to talk of they conduct . ” 
 
  It now occurred to Jane and Elizabeth that Jane and Elizabeth mother was in all likelihood perfectly ignorant of what had happened . Jane and Elizabeth went to the library , therefore , and asked Jane and Elizabeth father whether Father ’s would not wish Jane and Elizabeth to make happened known to Jane and Elizabeth mother . Father ’s was writing and , without raising Father ’s head , coolly replied : 
 
  “ Just as Elizabeth please . ” 
 
  “ May we take Elizabeth uncle ’s letter to read to Elizabeth niece ? ” 
 
  “ Take whatever Elizabeth like , and get away . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth took a letter from Father ’s writing - table , and they went up stairs together . Mary and Kitty were both with Jane and Elizabeth mother : one communication would , therefore , do for all . After a slight preparation for good news , a letter was read aloud . Jane and Elizabeth mother could hardly contain Jane and Elizabeth mother . As soon as Jane had read Edward ’s hope of Elizabeth niece being soon married , Jane joy burst forth , and every following sentence added to Jane joy exuberance . Jane was now in an irritation as violent from delight , as Jane had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation . To know that Elizabeth niece would be married was enough . Jane was disturbed by no fear for Jane felicity , nor humbled by any remembrance of Jane misconduct . 
 
  “ Elizabeth niece ! ” Jane cried . “ This is delightful indeed ! Elizabeth niece will be married ! Jane shall see Elizabeth niece again ! Elizabeth niece will be married at sixteen ! Jane good , kind brother ! Jane knew how it would be . Jane knew Edward would manage everything ! How Jane long to see Elizabeth niece ! and to see good man too ! But the clothes , the clothes ! Jane will write to Jane sister Gardiner about the clothes directly . Elizabeth , Elizabeth dear , run down to Father ’s , and ask Father ’s how much Father ’s will give Elizabeth niece . Stay , stay , Elizabeth will go Elizabeth . Ring the bell , Kitty , for Miss Bennet . Elizabeth will put on Elizabeth things in a moment . Jane How merry we shall be together when we meet ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of these transports , by leading Elizabeth thoughts to the obligations which Edward ’s behaviour laid them all under . 
 
  “ For we must attribute this happy conclusion , ” Elizabeth added , “ in a great measure to Edward kindness . We are persuaded that Edward has pledged Edward to assist Charlie ’s with money . ” 
 
  “ Well , ” cried Elizabeth mother , “ it is all very right ; who should do assist but Jane uncle ? If Edward had not had a family of Edward own , Elizabeth and Elizabeth children must have had all Edward money , Elizabeth dear Brother know ; and it is the first time Elizabeth and Elizabeth children have ever had anything from Edward , except a few presents . Well ! Jane and Elizabeth mother am so happy ! In a short time Elizabeth shall have Elizabeth niece married . Jane and Elizabeth mother How well it sounds ! And Elizabeth niece was only sixteen last June . Elizabeth dear Jane , Elizabeth am in such a flutter , that Elizabeth am sure Elizabeth ca n’t write ; so Elizabeth will dictate , and Jane write for Elizabeth . We will settle with Jane father about the money afterwards ; but the things should be ordered immediately . ” 
 
  Elizabeth was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico , muslin , and cambric , and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders , had not Jane , though with some difficulty , persuaded Elizabeth to wait till Elizabeth father was at leisure to be consulted . One day ’s delay , Jane observed , would be of small importance ; and Jane mother was too happy to be quite so obstinate as usual . Other schemes , too , came into Elizabeth head . 
 
  “ Elizabeth will go to Meryton , ” said Elizabeth , “ as soon as Elizabeth am dressed , and tell the good , good news to Elizabeth niece . And as Elizabeth come back , Elizabeth can call on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long . Kitty , run down and order the carriage . An airing would do Elizabeth a great deal of good , Elizabeth am sure . Girls , can Elizabeth do anything for Girls in Meryton ? Oh ! Here comes Miss Bennet ! Miss Bennet , have Miss Bennet heard the good , good news ? Elizabeth niece is going to be married ; and you shall all have a bowl of punch to make merry at Elizabeth niece wedding . ” 
 
  Miss Bennet began instantly to express Miss Bennet joy . Elizabeth received Miss Bennet congratulations amongst the rest , and then , sick of this folly , took refuge in Elizabeth own room , that Elizabeth might think with freedom . 
 
  Elizabeth niece situation must , at best , be bad enough ; but that Elizabeth niece situation was no worse , Elizabeth had need to be thankful . Elizabeth felt it so ; and though , in looking forward , neither rational happiness nor worldly prosperity could be justly expected for Elizabeth sister , in looking back to what they had feared , only two hours ago , Elizabeth felt all the advantages of what they had gained . 
 Chapter 
 
  Father had very often wished before this period of Father life that , instead of spending Father whole income , Father had laid by an annual sum for the better provision of Father children , and of Father wife , if Father wife survived Father . Father now wished it more than ever . Had Father done Father duty in that respect , Father wife need not have been indebted to Father wife uncle for whatever of honour or credit could now be purchased for Father wife . The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be Father wife husband might then have rested in The satisfaction of prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be Father wife husband proper place . 
 
  Father was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone should be forwarded at the sole expense of Father brother - in - law , and Father was determined , if possible , to find out the extent of Father brother - in - law assistance , and to discharge the obligation as soon as Father could . 
 
  When first Father had married , economy was held to be perfectly useless , for , of course , Father brother - in - law and Father wife were to have a son . a son was to join in cutting off the entail , as soon as a son should be of age , and Father wife and younger children would by that means be provided for . Five daughters successively entered the world , but yet a son was to come ; and Father wife , for many years after Father wife birth , had been certain that a son would . This event had at last been despaired of , but it was then too late to be saving . Father wife had no turn for economy , and Father wife husband ’s love of independence had alone prevented Father brother - in - law and Father wife exceeding Father brother - in - law and Father wife income . 
 
  Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Father wife and Father children . But in what proportions Five thousand pounds should be divided amongst Father children depended on the will of the parents . This was one point , with regard to Father wife , at least , which was now to be settled , and Father could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before Father . In terms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of Father brother - in - law , though expressed most concisely , Father then delivered on paper Father perfect approbation of all that was done , and Father willingness to fulfil the engagements that had been made for Father . Father had never before supposed that , could Father brother - in - law be prevailed on to marry Father daughter , marry would be done with so little inconvenience to Father as by the present arrangement . Father would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser by the hundred that was to be paid them ; for , what with Father wife board and pocket allowance , and the continual presents in money which passed to Father wife through Father wife mother ’s hands , Father wife expenses had been very little within that sum . 
 
  That it would be done with such trifling exertion on Father side , too , was another very welcome surprise ; for Father wish at present was to have as little trouble in the business as possible . When the first transports of rage which had produced Father activity in seeking Father wife were over , Father naturally returned to all Father former indolence . Father letter was soon dispatched ; for , though dilatory in undertaking business , Father was quick in Father letter execution . Father begged to know further particulars of what Father was indebted to Father brother - in - law , but was too angry with Father wife to send any message to Father wife . 
 
  The good news spread quickly through the house , and with proportionate speed through the neighbourhood . The good news was borne in the neighbourhood with decent philosophy . To be sure , it would have been more for the advantage of conversation had Father wife come upon the town ; or , as the happiest alternative , been secluded from the world , in some distant farmhouse . But there was much to be talked of in marrying Father wife ; and the good - natured wishes for Father wife well - doing which had proceeded before from all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton lost but a little of all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton spirit in this change of circumstances , because with such an husband Father wife misery was considered certain . 
 
  It was a fortnight since Father wife had been downstairs ; but on this happy day Father wife again took Father wife seat at the head of Father wife table , and in spirits oppressively high . No sentiment of shame gave a damp to Father wife triumph . The marriage of a daughter , which had been the first object of Father wife wishes since Jane was sixteen , was now on the point of accomplishment , and Father wife thoughts and Father wife words ran wholly on those attendants of elegant nuptials , fine muslins , new carriages , and servants . Father wife was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a proper situation for Father wife daughter , and , without knowing or considering what their income might be , rejected many as deficient in size and importance . 
 
  “ Haye Park might do , ” said Father wife , “ if the Gouldings could quit Haye Park — or the great house at Stoke , if the drawing - room were larger ; but Ashworth is too far off ! Father wife could not bear to have Father wife ten miles from Father wife ; and as for Pulvis Lodge , the attics are dreadful . ” 
 
  Father wife husband allowed Father wife to talk on without interruption while the servants remained . But when the servants had withdrawn , Father wife husband ’s said to Father wife : “ Father wife , before Father wife take any or all of these houses for Father wife son and Father wife , let us come to a right understanding . Into one house in this neighbourhood Father wife son and Father wife shall never have admittance . Father wife husband ’s will not encourage the impudence of either , by receiving Father wife son and Father wife at Longbourn . ” 
 
  A long dispute followed this declaration ; but Father was firm . A long dispute soon led to another ; and Father wife found , with amazement and horror , that Father wife husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for Father wife . Father protested that Father wife should receive from Father no mark of affection whatever on the occasion . Father wife could hardly comprehend it . That Father anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable resentment as to refuse Father wife a privilege without which Father wife marriage would scarcely seem valid , exceeded all Father wife could believe possible . Father wife was more alive to the disgrace which Father wife want of new clothes must reflect on Father wife nuptials , than to any sense of shame at Father wife eloping and living with Father brother - in - law a fortnight before Father wife nuptials took place . 
 
  Father wife was now most heartily sorry that Father wife had , from the distress of the moment , been led to make Father brother - in - law acquainted with their fears for Father wife sister ; for since Father wife marriage would so shortly give the proper termination to the elopement , their might hope to conceal the elopement unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the spot . 
 
  Father wife had no fear of the elopement spreading farther through Father brother - in - law means . There were few people on whose secrecy Father wife would have more confidently depended ; but , at the same time , there was no one whose knowledge of a sister ’s frailty would have mortified Father wife so much — not , however , from any fear of disadvantage from a sister ’s frailty individually to Father wife , for , at any rate , there seemed a gulf impassable between them . Had Father wife marriage been concluded on the most honourable terms , it was not to be supposed that Father brother - in - law would connect Father brother - in - law with a family where , to every other objection , would now be added an alliance and relationship of the nearest kind with Father brother - in - law Father brother - in - law so justly scorned . 
 
  From such a connection Father wife could not wonder that Father brother - in - law would shrink . The wish of procuring Father wife regard , which Father wife had assured Father wife of Father brother - in - law feeling in Derbyshire , could not in rational expectation survive such a blow as this . Father wife was humbled , Father wife was grieved ; Father wife repented , though Father wife hardly knew of what . Father wife became jealous of Father brother - in - law esteem , when Father wife could no longer hope to be benefited by Father brother - in - law esteem . Father wife wanted to hear of Father brother - in - law , when there seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence . Father wife was convinced that Father wife could have been happy with Father brother - in - law , when it was no longer likely they should meet . 
 
  What a triumph for Father brother - in - law , as Father wife often thought , could Father brother - in - law know that the proposals which Father wife had proudly spurned only four months ago , would now have been most gladly and gratefully received ! Father brother - in - law was as generous , Father wife doubted not , as the most generous of Father brother - in - law sex ; but while Father brother - in - law was mortal , there must be a triumph . 
 
  Father wife began now to comprehend that Father brother - in - law was exactly the man who , in disposition and talents , would most suit Father wife . Father brother - in - law understanding and temper , though unlike Father wife own , would have answered all Father wife wishes . It was an union that must have been to the advantage of both ; by Father wife ease and liveliness , Father brother - in - law mind might have been softened , Father brother - in - law manners improved ; and from Father brother - in - law judgement , information , and knowledge of the world , Father wife must have received benefit of greater importance . 
 
  But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what connubial felicity really was . An union of a different tendency , and precluding the possibility of the other , was soon to be formed in both family . 
 
  How Father brother - in - law and Father wife were to be supported in tolerable independence , Father wife could not imagine . But how little of permanent happiness could belong to a couple who were only brought together because a couple who were only brought together because passions were stronger than a couple who were only brought together because virtue , Father wife could easily conjecture . 
 
  Edward soon wrote again to Edward brother . To Father ’s acknowledgments Edward briefly replied , with assurance of Edward eagerness to promote the welfare of any of Edward family ; and concluded with entreaties that the subject might never be mentioned to Edward again . The principal purport of Edward letter was to inform Edward brother that Charlie had resolved on quitting the militia . 
 
  “ It was greatly Edward wish that Charlie should do so , ” Edward added , “ as soon as Charlie marriage was fixed on . And Edward think Edward brother will agree with Edward , in considering the removal from the militia as highly advisable , both on Charlie account and Edward niece ’s . It is Charlie ’s intention to go into the regulars ; and among Charlie former friends , there are still some who are able and willing to assist Charlie in the army . Charlie has the promise of an ensigncy in General — — ’s regiment , now quartered in the North . It is an advantage to have General — — ’s regiment , now quartered in the North so far from this part of the kingdom . Charlie promises fairly ; and Edward hope among different people , where they may each have a character to preserve , they will both be more prudent . Edward have written to Colonel Forster , to inform Colonel Forster of our present arrangements , and to request that Colonel Forster will satisfy the various creditors of Charlie in and near Brighton , with assurances of speedy payment , for which Edward have pledged Edward . And will Edward brother give Edward brother the trouble of carrying similar assurances to Charlie creditors in Meryton , of whom Edward shall subjoin a list according to Charlie information ? Charlie has given in all Charlie debts ; Edward hope at least Charlie has not deceived us . Charlie has our directions , and all will be completed in a week . They will then join Charlie regiment , unless they are first invited to Longbourn ; and Edward understand from Madeline , that Father wife is very desirous of seeing Edward brother before Father wife leaves the South . Father wife is well , and begs to be dutifully remembered to Edward brother and Father wife mother.—Yours , etc . , 
 
  “ Edward . ” 
 
  Father and Father daughters saw all the advantages of Father brother - in - law removal from the — — shire as clearly as Edward could do . But Father wife was not so well pleased with Father brother - in - law removal . Father wife being settled in the North , just when Father wife had expected most pleasure and pride in Father wife company , for Father wife had by no means given up Father wife plan of their residing in Hertfordshire , was a severe disappointment ; and , besides , it was such a pity that Father wife should be taken from a regiment where Father wife was acquainted with everybody , and had so many favourites . 
 
  “ Father wife is so fond of Colonel Forster , ” said Father wife , “ it will be quite shocking to send Father wife away ! And there are several of the young men , too , that Father wife likes very much . The officers may not be so pleasant in General — — ’s regiment , now quartered in the North . ” 
 
  Father wife request , for such it might be considered , of being admitted into both family again before Father wife set off for the North , received at first an absolute negative . But Jane and Elizabeth , who agreed in wishing , for the sake of Father wife feelings and consequence , that Father wife should be noticed on Father wife marriage by Father wife parents , urged Father brother - in - law so earnestly yet so rationally and so mildly , to receive Father wife and Father brother - in - law at Longbourn , as soon as Father wife and Father brother - in - law were married , that Father brother - in - law was prevailed on to think as Father wife and Father brother - in - law thought , and act as Father wife and Father brother - in - law wished . And Father wife and Father brother - in - law mother had the satisfaction of knowing that Father wife would be able to show Father wife in the neighbourhood before Father wife was banished to the North . When Father wrote again to Father brother , therefore , Father sent Father permission for Father wife and Father brother - in - law to come ; and it was settled , that as soon as the ceremony was over , Father wife and Father brother - in - law should proceed to Longbourn . Father wife was surprised , however , that Father brother - in - law should consent to such a scheme , and had Father wife consulted only Father wife own inclination , any meeting with Father brother - in - law would have been the last object of Father wife wishes . 
 Chapter 
 
  Their sister ’s wedding day arrived ; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for Their sister ’s probably more than Their sister ’s felt for Their sister ’s . The carriage was sent to meet the young couple at — — , and the young couple were to return in The carriage by dinner - time . the young couple arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets , and Jane more especially , who gave Their sister ’s the feelings which would have attended Jane , had Jane been the culprit , and was wretched in the thought of what Jane sister must endure . 
 
  the young couple came . The family were assembled in the breakfast room to receive the young couple . Smiles decked the face of Mother as the carriage drove up to the door ; Mother husband looked impenetrably grave ; Mother daughters , alarmed , anxious , uneasy . 
 
  Their sister ’s voice was heard in the vestibule ; the door was thrown open , and Their sister ’s ran into the room . Their sister ’s mother stepped forwards , embraced Their sister ’s , and welcomed Their sister ’s with rapture ; gave Mother hand , with an affectionate smile , to George , who followed George , who followed lady ; and wished the young couple joy with an alacrity which shewed no doubt of the young couple happiness . 
 
  the young couple reception from Father , to whom the young couple then turned , was not quite so cordial . Father , to whom the young couple then turned countenance rather gained in austerity ; and Father , to whom the young couple then turned scarcely opened Father , to whom the young couple then turned lips . The easy assurance of the young couple , indeed , was enough to provoke Father , to whom the young couple then turned . Elizabeth was disgusted , and the elder Miss Bennets was shocked . Their sister ’s was Lydia still ; untamed , unabashed , wild , noisy , and fearless . Their sister ’s turned from sister to sister , demanding their congratulations ; and when at length their sat down , looked eagerly round the room , took notice of some little alteration in the room , and observed , with a laugh , that it was a great while since Their sister ’s had been there . 
 
  George , who followed was not at all more distressed than Their sister ’s , but George , who followed manners were always so pleasing , that had George , who followed character and George , who followed marriage been exactly what George , who followed character and George , who followed marriage ought , George , who followed smiles and George , who followed easy address , while George , who followed claimed their relationship , would have delighted their . Elizabeth had not before believed George , who followed quite equal to such assurance ; but Elizabeth sat down , resolving within Elizabeth to draw no limits in future to the impudence of an impudent man . Elizabeth blushed , and Jane blushed ; but the cheeks of Jane and Elizabeth Jane and Elizabeth confusion suffered no variation of colour . 
 
  There was no want of discourse . Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother could neither of Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother talk fast enough ; and George , who followed , began enquiring after George , who followed acquaintance in that neighbourhood , with a good humoured ease which Elizabeth felt very unable to equal in Elizabeth replies . Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother seemed each of Their sister ’s and Their sister ’s mother to have the happiest memories in the world . Nothing of the past was recollected with pain ; and Their sister ’s led voluntarily to subjects which Their sister ’s sisters would not have alluded to for the world . 
 
  “ Only think of its being three months , ” Their sister ’s cried , “ since Their sister ’s went away ; it seems but a fortnight Their sister ’s declare ; and yet there have been things enough happened in the time . Good gracious ! when Their sister ’s went away , Their sister ’s am sure Their sister ’s had no more idea of being married till Their sister ’s came back again ! though Their sister ’s thought it would be very good fun if Their sister ’s was . ” 
 
  Father , to whom the young couple then turned lifted up Father , to whom the young couple then turned eyes . Jane was distressed . Elizabeth looked expressively at Their sister ’s ; but Elizabeth Elizabeth chose to be insensible , gaily continued , “ Oh ! Mother , do the people hereabouts know Elizabeth am married to - day ? Elizabeth was afraid the people hereabouts might not ; and we overtook William Goulding in William Goulding curricle , so Elizabeth was determined William Goulding should know am , and so Elizabeth let down the side - glass next to William Goulding , and took off Elizabeth glove , and let Elizabeth hand just rest upon the window frame , so that William Goulding might see the ring , and then Elizabeth bowed and smiled like anything . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth could bear it no longer . Elizabeth got up , and ran out of the room ; and returned no more , till Elizabeth heard the young couple passing through the hall to the dining parlour . Elizabeth then joined the young couple soon enough to see Their sister ’s , with anxious parade , walk up to Their sister ’s mother ’s right hand , and hear Their sister ’s say to Jane , “ Ah ! Jane , Their sister ’s take Jane place now , and Jane must go lower , because Their sister ’s am a married woman . ” 
 
  It was not to be supposed that time would give Their sister ’s that embarrassment from which Their sister ’s had been so wholly free at first . Their sister ’s ease and good spirits increased . Their sister ’s longed to see Mrs. Phillips , the Lucases , and all their other neighbours , and to hear Their sister ’s called “ Mrs. Wickham ” by each of Mrs. Phillips , the Lucases , and all their other neighbours ; and in the mean time , Their sister ’s went after dinner to show Their sister ’s ring , and boast of being married , to Mrs. Phillips and the two housemaids . 
 
  “ Well , Mother , ” said Their sister ’s , when they were all returned to the breakfast room , “ and what do Mother think of Mother husband ? Is not Mother husband a charming man ? Their sister ’s am sure Their sister ’s sisters must all envy Their sister ’s . Their sister ’s only hope Their sister ’s sisters may have half Their sister ’s good luck . Their sister ’s sisters must all go to Brighton . Brighton is the place to get husbands . What a pity it is , Mother , we did not all go . ” 
 
  “ Very true ; and if Mother had Mother will , we should . But Mother dear Lydia , Mother do n’t at all like Their sister ’s going such a way off . Must going be so ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , lord ! yes;—there is nothing in that . Their sister ’s shall like it of all things . Mother and George , who followed , and Their sister ’s sisters , must come down and see us . us shall be at Newcastle all the winter , and Their sister ’s dare say there will be some balls , and Their sister ’s will take care to get good partners for them all . ” 
 
  “ Mother should like it beyond anything ! ” said Their sister ’s mother . 
 
  “ And then when Their sister ’s go away , Their sister ’s may leave one or two of Mother sisters behind Their sister ’s ; and Mother dare say Mother shall get husbands for one or two of Mother sisters before the winter is over . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth thank Mother for Elizabeth share of the favour , ” said Elizabeth ; “ but Elizabeth do not particularly like Mother way of getting husbands . ” 
 
  the young couple visitors were not to remain above ten days with the young couple . Charlie had received Charlie commission before Charlie left London , and Charlie was to join Charlie regiment at the end of a fortnight . 
 
  No one but Mother regretted that the young couple visitors stay would be so short ; and Mother made the most of the time by visiting about with Their sister ’s , and having very frequent parties at home . very frequent parties at home were acceptable to all ; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did think , than such as did not . 
 
  George , who followed affection for Their sister ’s was just what Elizabeth had expected to find George , who followed affection for Their sister ’s ; not equal to Their sister ’s for George , who followed . Elizabeth had scarcely needed Elizabeth present observation to be satisfied , from the reason of things , that their elopement had been brought on by the strength of Their sister ’s love , rather than by George , who followed ; and Elizabeth would have wondered why , without violently caring for Their sister ’s , George , who followed chose to elope with Their sister ’s at all , had Their sister ’s not felt certain that George , who followed flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances ; and if was were the case , George , who followed was not the young man to resist an opportunity of having a companion . 
 
  Their sister ’s was exceedingly fond of George , who followed . George , who followed was Their sister ’s dear George on every occasion ; no one was to be put in competition with George , who followed . George , who followed did every thing best in the world ; and Their sister ’s was sure George , who followed would kill more birds on the first of September , than any body else in the country . 
 
  One morning , soon after the young couple visitors arrival , as Their sister ’s was sitting with Their sister ’s two elder sisters , Their sister ’s said to Elizabeth : 
 
  “ Elizabeth , Their sister ’s never gave Elizabeth an account of Their sister ’s wedding , Their sister ’s believe . Elizabeth were not by , when Their sister ’s told Mother and the others all about Their sister ’s wedding . Are not Elizabeth curious to hear how Their sister ’s wedding was managed ? ” 
 
  “ No really , ” replied Elizabeth ; “ Elizabeth think there can not be too little said on the subject . ” 
 
  “ La ! Their sister ’s are so strange ! But Their sister ’s must tell the young couple how Their sister ’s wedding went off . We were married , you know , at St. Clement ’s , because George , who followed lodgings were in St. Clement ’s . And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven o’clock . Their sister ’s uncle and aunt and Their sister ’s were to go together ; and the others were to meet We at the church . Well , Monday morning came , and Their sister ’s was in such a fuss ! Their sister ’s was so afraid , you know , that something would happen to put Their sister ’s wedding off , and then Their sister ’s should have gone quite distracted . And there was Their sister ’s aunt , all the time Their sister ’s was dressing , preaching and talking away just as if Their sister ’s aunt was reading a sermon . However , Their sister ’s did not hear above one word in ten , for Their sister ’s was thinking , Mother may suppose , of Their sister ’s dear George . Their sister ’s longed to know whether George , who followed would be married in George , who followed blue coat . ” 
 
  “ Well , and so we breakfasted at ten as usual ; Their sister ’s thought it would never be over ; for , by the bye , the young couple are to understand , that Their sister ’s uncle and aunt were horrid unpleasant all the time Their sister ’s was with Their sister ’s uncle and aunt . If the young couple ’ll believe Their sister ’s , Their sister ’s did not once put Their sister ’s foot out of doors , though Their sister ’s was there a fortnight . Not one party , or scheme , or anything . To be sure London was rather thin , but , however , the Little Theatre was open . Well , and so just as the carriage came to the door , Their sister ’s uncle was called away upon business to that horrid man Mr. Stone . And then , you know , when once they get together , there is no end of it . Well , Their sister ’s was so frightened Their sister ’s did not know what to do , for Their sister ’s uncle was to give Their sister ’s away ; and if we were beyond the hour , we could not be married all day . But , luckily , Their sister ’s uncle came back again in ten minutes ’ time , and then we all set out . However , Their sister ’s recollected afterwards that if Their sister ’s uncle had been prevented going , Their sister ’s wedding need not be put off , for Fitzwilliam might have done as well . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ! ” repeated Elizabeth , in utter amazement . 
 
  “ Oh , yes!—he was to come there with George , who followed , you know . But gracious Their sister ’s ! Their sister ’s quite forgot ! Their sister ’s ought not to have said a word about it . Their sister ’s promised them so faithfully ! What will George , who followed say ? It was to be such a secret ! ” 
 
  “ If it was to be secret , ” said Jane , “ say not another word on the subject . Their sister ’s may depend upon Jane seeking no further . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! certainly , ” said Elizabeth , though burning with curiosity ; “ we will ask Their sister ’s no questions . ” 
 
  “ Thank Elizabeth , ” said Their sister ’s , “ for if Elizabeth did , Their sister ’s should certainly tell the young couple , and then George , who followed would be angry . ” 
 
  On such encouragement to ask , Elizabeth was forced to put it out of Elizabeth power , by running away . 
 
  But to live in ignorance on such a point was impossible ; or at least it was impossible not to try for information . Fitzwilliam had been at Elizabeth sister ’s wedding . It was exactly a scene , and exactly among people , where Fitzwilliam had apparently least to do , and least temptation to go . Conjectures as to the meaning of it , rapid and wild , hurried into Elizabeth brain ; but Elizabeth was satisfied with none . Those that best pleased Elizabeth , as placing Fitzwilliam conduct in the noblest light , seemed most improbable . Elizabeth could not bear such suspense ; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper , wrote a short letter to Their sister ’s aunt , to request an explanation of what Their sister ’s had dropt , if an explanation of what Their sister ’s had dropt were compatible with the secrecy which had been intended . 
 
  “ the young couple may readily comprehend , ” Elizabeth added , “ what Elizabeth curiosity must be to know how a person unconnected with any of us , and ( comparatively speaking ) a stranger to our family , should have been amongst the young couple at such a time . Pray write instantly , and let Their sister ’s understand it — unless it is , for very cogent reasons , to remain in the secrecy which Their sister ’s seems to think necessary ; and then Their sister ’s must endeavour to be satisfied with ignorance . ” 
 
  “ Not that Their sister ’s shall , though , ” Their sister ’s added to Their sister ’s , as Their sister ’s finished a short letter ; “ and Their sister ’s aunt , if Their sister ’s aunt do not tell Their sister ’s in an honourable manner , Their sister ’s shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it out . ” 
 
  Jane ’s delicate sense of honour would not allow Jane to speak to Elizabeth privately of what Their sister ’s had let fall ; Elizabeth was glad of it;—till it appeared whether Elizabeth enquiries would receive any satisfaction , Elizabeth had rather be without a confidante . 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to Elizabeth letter as soon as Elizabeth possibly could . GARDINER am sure another motive would never disgrace a most unexpected visitor . a most unexpected visitor had been some days in town , before a most unexpected visitor was able to discover Elizabeth sister and Charlie ; but a most unexpected visitor had something to direct a most unexpected visitor search , which was more than ourselves had ; and the consciousness of something to direct a most unexpected visitor search , which was more than ourselves had was another reason for a most unexpected visitor resolving to follow ourselves .

This Mrs. Younge then took a large house in Edward - street , and has since maintained This Mrs. Younge by letting lodgings . But a most unexpected visitor found Lydia absolutely resolved on remaining where Lydia was . Lydia was sure they should be married some time or other , and it did not much signify when . George must go somewhere , but George did not know where , and George knew George should have nothing to live on . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam asked George why George had not married Elizabeth sister at once . Though George was not imagined to be very rich , Fitzwilliam would have been able to do something for George , and George situation must have been benefited by marriage . But Fitzwilliam found , in reply to this question , that George still cherished the hope of more effectually making George fortune by marriage in some other country . Under such circumstances , however , George was not likely to be proof against the temptation of immediate relief .

GARDINER have been all round the park . A low phaeton , with a nice little pair of ponies , would be the very thing .

  “ Elizabeth , very sincerely , 
  “ M. GARDINER . ” 
 
  The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits , in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the greatest share . The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had produced of what Fitzwilliam might have been doing to forward Elizabeth sister match , which Elizabeth had feared to encourage as an exertion of goodness too great to be probable , and at the same time dreaded to be just , from the pain of obligation , were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true ! Fitzwilliam had followed them purposely to town , Fitzwilliam had taken on Fitzwilliam all the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research ; in which supplication had been necessary to a woman whom Fitzwilliam must abominate and despise , and where Fitzwilliam was reduced to meet , frequently meet , reason with , persuade , and finally bribe , Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam always most wished to avoid , and whose very name it was punishment to Fitzwilliam to pronounce . Fitzwilliam had done all this for Elizabeth sister . Elizabeth heart did whisper that Fitzwilliam had done all this for Elizabeth . But whisper was a hope shortly checked by other considerations , and Elizabeth soon felt that even Elizabeth vanity was insufficient , when required to depend on Fitzwilliam affection for Elizabeth — for a woman who had already refused Fitzwilliam — as able to overcome a sentiment so natural as abhorrence against relationship with George . George George ! Every kind of pride must revolt from the connection . George had , to be sure , done much . Elizabeth was ashamed to think how much . But George had given a reason for George interference , which asked no extraordinary stretch of belief . It was reasonable that George should feel George had been wrong ; George had liberality , and George had the means of exercising liberality ; and though Elizabeth would not place Elizabeth as George principal inducement , Elizabeth could , perhaps , believe that remaining partiality for Elizabeth might assist George endeavours in a cause where Elizabeth peace of mind must be materially concerned . It was painful , exceedingly painful , to know that they were under obligations to George . They owed the restoration of Lydia , Lydia character , every thing , to George . Oh ! how heartily did Elizabeth grieve over every ungracious sensation Elizabeth had ever encouraged , every saucy speech Elizabeth had ever directed towards George . For Elizabeth Elizabeth was humbled ; but Elizabeth was proud of George . Proud that in a cause of compassion and honour , George had been able to get the better of George . Elizabeth sister commendation of George was hardly enough ; but Elizabeth sister commendation of George pleased Elizabeth . GARDINER name to George . ”

  “ How should M. GARDINER have liked making sermons ? ”

 Chapter 
 
  Charlie was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation that Charlie never again distressed Charlie , or provoked Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , by introducing the subject of this conversation ; and Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was pleased to find that Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had said enough to keep Charlie quiet .

  “ Charlie dear sister Elizabeth may depend on it , ” replied the other , “ for Mrs. Nicholls was in Meryton last night ; the other saw Mrs. Nicholls passing by , and went out the other on purpose to know the truth of it ; and Mrs. Nicholls told the other that it was certain true . Charlie comes down on Thursday at the latest , very likely on Wednesday . Mrs. Nicholls was going to the butcher ’s , Mrs. Nicholls told the other , on purpose to order in some meat on Wednesday , and Mrs. Nicholls has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed . ”

Charlie dear sister Elizabeth forced Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear into visiting Charlie last year , and promised , if Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear went to see Charlie , Charlie should marry one of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear daughters . But , however , that sha n’t prevent Charlie dear sister Elizabeth asking Charlie to dine here , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth am determined . We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon . have will make thirteen with We , so there will be just room at table for Charlie . ” 
 
  Consoled by this resolution , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was the better able to bear Charlie incivility ; though it was very mortifying to know that Charlie dear sister Elizabeth neighbours might all see Charlie , in consequence of it , before Charlie dear sister Elizabeth neighbours did . As the day of Charlie coming drew near , —

Jane mother means well ; but Charlie dear sister Elizabeth does not know , no one can know , how much Jane suffer from what Charlie dear sister Elizabeth says . Happy shall Charlie dear sister Elizabeth be , when Charlie stay at Netherfield is over ! ”

Charlie dear sister Elizabeth must feel it ; and the usual satisfaction of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , because Charlie dear sister Elizabeth have always so much . ” 
 
  Charlie arrived . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , through the assistance of servants , contrived to have the earliest tidings of arrived , that the period of anxiety and fretfulness on Charlie dear sister Elizabeth side might be as long as it could . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth counted the days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent ; hopeless of seeing Charlie before . But on the third morning after Charlie arrival in Derbyshire , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth saw Charlie , from Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dressing - room window , enter the paddock and ride towards the house . 
 
  Charlie dear sister Elizabeth daughters were eagerly called to partake of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth joy . Jane resolutely kept Jane place at the table ; but Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , to satisfy Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , went to the window — Charlie dear sister Elizabeth looked,—she saw Fitzwilliam with Charlie , and sat down again by Charlie dear sister Elizabeth sister . 
 
  “ There is a gentleman with Charlie , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , ” said Kitty ; “ who can a gentleman with Charlie be ? ” 
 
  “ Some acquaintance or other , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth suppose ; Charlie dear sister Elizabeth am sure Charlie dear sister Elizabeth do not know . ” 
 
  “ La ! ” replied Kitty , “ a gentleman with Charlie looks just like that man that used to be with Charlie before . Mr. what’s - that man that used to be with Charlie before - name . That tall , proud man . ” 
 
  “ Good gracious ! Fitzwilliam!—and so it does , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth vow . Well , any friend of Charlie will always be welcome here , to be sure ; but else Charlie dear sister Elizabeth must say that Charlie dear sister Elizabeth hate the very sight of a gentleman with Charlie . ” Jane Jane looked at Charlie dear sister Elizabeth with surprise and concern . Jane knew but little of Charlie and Lydia ’s meeting in Derbyshire , and therefore felt for the awkwardness which must attend Jane sister , in seeing Charlie almost for the first time after receiving Charlie explanatory letter . Both sisters were uncomfortable enough . Each felt for the other , and of course for Both sisters ; and Charlie dear sister Elizabeth talked on , of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dislike of Fitzwilliam , and Charlie dear sister Elizabeth resolution to be civil to Fitzwilliam only as Charlie friend , without being heard by either of Both sisters . But Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had sources of uneasiness which could not be suspected by Jane , to whom Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had never yet had courage to shew Madeline ’s letter , or to relate Charlie dear sister Elizabeth own change of sentiment towards Fitzwilliam . To Jane , Fitzwilliam could be only a man whose proposals Jane had refused , and whose merit Jane had undervalued ; but to Charlie dear sister Elizabeth own more extensive information , Fitzwilliam was the person to whom the whole family were indebted for the first of benefits , and whom Charlie dear sister Elizabeth regarded Charlie dear sister Elizabeth with an interest , if not quite so tender , at least as reasonable and just as what Jane felt for Charlie . Jane astonishment at Fitzwilliam coming — at Fitzwilliam coming to Netherfield , to Longbourn , and voluntarily seeking Jane again , was almost equal to what Jane had known on first witnessing Fitzwilliam altered behaviour in Derbyshire . 
 
  The colour which had been driven from Jane face , returned for half a minute with an additional glow , and a smile of delight added lustre to Jane eyes , as Jane thought for that space of time that Fitzwilliam affection and wishes must still be unshaken . But Jane would not be secure . 
 
  “ Let Jane first see how Fitzwilliam behaves , ” said Jane ; “ it will then be early enough for expectation . ” 
 
  Jane sat intently at work , striving to be composed , and without daring to lift up Jane eyes , till anxious curiosity carried Jane eyes to the face of Jane as the servant was approaching the door . Jane looked a little paler than usual , but more sedate than Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had expected . On the gentlemen ’s appearing , Jane colour increased ; yet Jane received the gentlemen ’s with tolerable ease , and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any symptom of resentment or any unnecessary complaisance . 
 
  Charlie dear sister Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow , and sat down again to Charlie dear sister Elizabeth work , with an eagerness which it did not often command . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had ventured only one glance at Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam looked serious , as usual ; and , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth thought , more as Fitzwilliam had been used to look in Derbyshire , than as Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had seen Fitzwilliam at Pemberley . But , perhaps Fitzwilliam could not in Charlie dear sister Elizabeth mother ’s presence be what Fitzwilliam was before Charlie dear sister Elizabeth uncle and aunt . It was a painful , but not an improbable , conjecture . 
 
  Charlie , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had likewise seen for an instant , and in that short period saw Charlie looking both pleased and embarrassed . Charlie was received by Charlie dear sister Elizabeth with a degree of civility which made Charlie dear sister Elizabeth two daughters ashamed , especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth curtsey and address to Charlie friend ’s . 
 
  Elizabeth , particularly , who knew that Charlie dear sister Elizabeth mother owed to Charlie dear sister Elizabeth the preservation of Lydia ’s from irremediable infamy , was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill applied . 
 
  Fitzwilliam , after enquiring of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth how Edward and Madeline did , a question which Charlie dear sister Elizabeth could not answer without confusion , said scarcely anything . Fitzwilliam was not seated by Charlie dear sister Elizabeth ; perhaps that was the reason of Fitzwilliam silence ; but it had not been so in Derbyshire . There Fitzwilliam had talked to Charlie dear sister Elizabeth friends , when Fitzwilliam could not to Charlie dear sister Elizabeth . But now several minutes elapsed without bringing the sound of Fitzwilliam voice ; and when occasionally , unable to resist the impulse of curiosity , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth raised Charlie dear sister Elizabeth eyes to Fitzwilliam face , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth as often found Fitzwilliam looking at Jane as at Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , and frequently on no object but the ground . More thoughtfulness and less anxiety to please , than when Charlie and Lydia ’s last met , were plainly expressed . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was disappointed , and angry with Charlie dear sister Elizabeth for being so . 
 
  “ Could Charlie dear sister Elizabeth expect it to be otherwise ! ” said Charlie dear sister Elizabeth . “ Yet why did Fitzwilliam come ? ” 
 
  Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was in no humour for conversation with anyone but Fitzwilliam ; and to Fitzwilliam Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had hardly courage to speak . 
 
  Charlie dear sister Elizabeth enquired after Fitzwilliam sister , but could do no more . 
 
  “ It is a long time , Charlie , since Charlie went away , ” said Charlie dear sister Elizabeth . 
 
  Charlie readily agreed to it . 
 
  “ Charlie dear sister Elizabeth began to be afraid Charlie would never come back again . People did say Charlie meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas ; but , however , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth hope meant is not true . A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood , since Charlie went away . Lydia ’s is married and settled . And one of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth own daughters . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth suppose Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear have heard of it ; indeed , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear must have seen it in the papers . It was in The Times and The Courier , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear know ; though it was not put in as it ought to be . It was only said , ‘ Lately , George , to Lydia ’s , ’ without there being a syllable said of Lydia ’s father , or the place where Lydia ’s lived , or anything . It was Charlie dear sister Elizabeth brother Gardiner ’s drawing up too , and Charlie dear sister Elizabeth wonder how Charlie dear sister Elizabeth brother Gardiner ’s came to make such an awkward business of it . Did Charlie see it ? ” 
 
  Charlie replied that Charlie did , and made Charlie congratulations . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dared not lift up Charlie dear sister Elizabeth eyes . How Fitzwilliam looked , therefore , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth could not tell . 
 
  “ It is a delightful thing , to be sure , to have Charlie dear sister Elizabeth well married , ” continued Charlie dear sister Elizabeth mother , “ but at the same time , Charlie , it is very hard to have Lydia ’s taken such a way from Charlie dear sister Elizabeth . Charlie and Lydia ’s are gone down to Newcastle , a place quite northward , it seems , and there Charlie and Lydia ’s are to stay Charlie dear sister Elizabeth do not know how long . Charlie regiment is there ; for Charlie dear sister Elizabeth suppose Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear have heard of Fitzwilliam leaving the — — shire , and of Fitzwilliam being gone into the regulars . Thank Heaven ! Fitzwilliam has some friends , though perhaps not so many as Fitzwilliam deserves . ” 
 
  Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , was in such misery of shame , that Charlie dear sister Elizabeth could hardly keep Charlie dear sister Elizabeth seat . It drew from Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , however , the exertion of speaking , which nothing else had so effectually done before ; and Charlie dear sister Elizabeth asked Charlie whether Charlie meant to make any stay in the country at present . A few weeks , Charlie believed . 
 
  “ When Charlie have killed all Charlie own birds , Charlie , ” said Charlie dear sister Elizabeth mother , “ Charlie dear sister Elizabeth beg Charlie will come here , and shoot as many as Charlie please on Father ’s manor . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth am sure Father will be vastly happy to oblige Charlie , and will save all the best of the covies for Charlie . ” 
 
  Charlie dear sister Elizabeth misery increased , at such unnecessary , such officious attention ! Were the same fair prospect to arise at present as had flattered them a year ago , every thing , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was persuaded , would be hastening to the same vexatious conclusion . At that instant , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth felt that years of happiness could not make Jane or Charlie dear sister Elizabeth amends for moments of such painful confusion . 
 
  “ The first wish of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth heart , ” said Charlie dear sister Elizabeth to Charlie dear sister Elizabeth , “ is never more to be in company with either of them . them society can afford no pleasure that will atone for such wretchedness as this ! Let Charlie dear sister Elizabeth never see either one or the other again ! ” 
 
  Yet the misery , for which years of happiness were to offer no compensation , received soon afterwards material relief , from observing how much the beauty of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth sister re - kindled the admiration of Fitzwilliam . When first Fitzwilliam came in , Fitzwilliam had spoken to Lydia ’s but little ; but every five minutes seemed to be giving Lydia ’s more of Fitzwilliam attention . Fitzwilliam found Lydia ’s as handsome as Lydia ’s had been last year ; as good natured , and as unaffected , though not quite so chatty . Jane was anxious that no difference should be perceived in Lydia ’s at all , and was really persuaded that Lydia ’s talked as much as ever . But Lydia ’s mind was so busily engaged , that Lydia ’s did not always know when Lydia ’s was silent . 
 
  When the gentlemen ’s rose to go away , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was mindful of Charlie dear sister Elizabeth intended civility , and Charlie and Lydia ’s were invited and engaged to dine at Longbourn in a few days time . 
 
  “ Charlie are quite a visit in Charlie dear sister Elizabeth debt , Charlie , ” Charlie dear sister Elizabeth added , “ for when Charlie went to town last winter , Charlie promised to take a family dinner with us , as soon as Charlie returned . Charlie dear sister Elizabeth have not forgot , Charlie see ; and Charlie dear sister Elizabeth assure Charlie dear sister Elizabeth dear , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth was very much disappointed that Charlie did not come back and keep Charlie engagement . ” 
 
  Charlie looked a little silly at this reflection , and said something of Charlie concern at having been prevented by business . Charlie and Lydia ’s then went away . 
 
  Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had been strongly inclined to ask Charlie and Lydia ’s to stay and dine there that day ; but , though Charlie dear sister Elizabeth always kept a very good table , Charlie dear sister Elizabeth did not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man on whom Charlie dear sister Elizabeth had such anxious designs , or satisfy the appetite and pride of one who had ten thousand a year . 
 Chapter 
 
  As soon as the gentlemen were gone , Elizabeth walked out to recover Elizabeth spirits ; or in other words , to dwell without interruption on those subjects that must deaden them more . Fitzwilliam ’s behaviour astonished and vexed Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Why , if Fitzwilliam ’s came only to be silent , grave , and indifferent , ” said Elizabeth , “ did Fitzwilliam ’s come at all ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth could settle it in no way that gave Elizabeth pleasure . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ’s could be still amiable , still pleasing , to Elizabeth uncle and aunt , when Fitzwilliam ’s was in town ; and why not to Elizabeth ? If Fitzwilliam ’s fears Elizabeth , why come hither ? If Fitzwilliam ’s no longer cares for Elizabeth , why silent ? Teasing , teasing , man ! Elizabeth will think no more about Fitzwilliam ’s . ” 
 
  Elizabeth resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach of Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed better satisfied with their visitors , than Elizabeth .

Elizabeth know Elizabeth own strength , and Elizabeth shall never be embarrassed again by Fitzwilliam ’s coming . Elizabeth am glad Fitzwilliam ’s dines here on Tuesday . It will then be publicly seen that , on both sides , we meet only as common and indifferent acquaintance . ”

  They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday ; and Mother , in the meanwhile , was giving way to all the happy schemes , which the good humour and common politeness of Charles , in half an hour ’s visit , had revived . 
 
  On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn ; and the two who were most anxiously expected , to the credit of the two who were most anxiously expected , to the credit of punctuality as sportsmen , were in very good time . Elizabeth prudent mother , occupied by the same ideas , forbore to invite Charles to sit by Mother . Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed placed Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed by Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed . Though Elizabeth dared not depend upon the consequence , Elizabeth yet received pleasure from observing Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed behaviour . Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed behaviour gave Elizabeth all the animation that Elizabeth spirits could boast ; for Elizabeth was in no cheerful humour . Fitzwilliam ’s was almost as far from Elizabeth as the table could divide them . Fitzwilliam ’s was on one side of Elizabeth mother . Elizabeth knew how little such a situation would give pleasure to either , or make either appear to advantage . Elizabeth was not near enough to hear any of their discourse , but Elizabeth could see how seldom their spoke to each other , and how formal and cold was their manner whenever their did . Elizabeth mother ’s ungraciousness , made the sense of what their owed Fitzwilliam ’s more painful to Elizabeth ’s mind ; and Elizabeth would , at times , have given anything to be privileged to tell Fitzwilliam ’s that Fitzwilliam ’s kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the family . 
 
  Elizabeth was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of bringing their together ; that the whole of the visit would not pass away without enabling their to enter into something more of conversation than the mere ceremonious salutation attending Fitzwilliam ’s entrance . Anxious and uneasy , the period which passed in the dining - room , before the gentlemen came , was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made Elizabeth uncivil . Elizabeth looked forward to the gentlemen entrance as the point on which all Elizabeth chance of pleasure for the evening must depend .

And on the gentlemen ’s approaching , one of the ladies moved closer to Elizabeth than ever , and said , in a whisper : 
 
  “ the gentlemen sha n’t come and part us , one of the ladies am determined . us want none of the gentlemen ; do us ? ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam ’s had walked away to another part of the dining - room . Elizabeth followed Fitzwilliam ’s with Elizabeth eyes , envied everyone to whom Fitzwilliam ’s spoke , had scarcely patience enough to help anybody to coffee ; and then was enraged against Elizabeth for being so silly ! 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam ’s How could Elizabeth ever be foolish enough to expect a renewal of Fitzwilliam ’s love ? Is there one among the sex , who would not protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman ? There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth was a little revived , however , by Fitzwilliam ’s bringing back Fitzwilliam ’s coffee cup Fitzwilliam ’s ; and Elizabeth seized the opportunity of saying : 
 
  “ Is Fitzwilliam ’s sister at Pemberley still ? ” 
 
  “ Yes , Fitzwilliam ’s sister will remain there till Christmas . ” 
 
  “ And quite alone ? Have all Fitzwilliam ’s sister friends left Fitzwilliam ’s sister ? ” 
 
  “ Mrs. Annesley is with Fitzwilliam ’s sister . The others have been gone on to Scarborough , these three weeks . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could think of nothing more to say ; but if Fitzwilliam ’s wished to converse with Elizabeth , Fitzwilliam ’s might have better success . Fitzwilliam ’s stood by Elizabeth , however , for some minutes , in silence ; and , at last , on one of the ladies whispering to Elizabeth again , Fitzwilliam ’s walked away .

Elizabeth now lost every expectation of pleasure . their were confined for the evening at different tables , and Elizabeth had nothing to hope , but that Fitzwilliam ’s eyes were so often turned towards Elizabeth side of the room , as to make Fitzwilliam ’s play as unsuccessfully as Elizabeth . 
 
  Mother had designed to keep the two Netherfield gentlemen to supper ; but the two Netherfield gentlemen carriage was unluckily ordered before any of the others , and Mother had no opportunity of detaining the two Netherfield gentlemen . 
 
  “ Well the ladies , ” said Mother , as soon as the ladies were left to the ladies , “ What say Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed to the day ? Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed think every thing has passed off uncommonly well , Elizabeth sister , who joined Elizabeth with a cheerful look , which showed assure the ladies .   “ the day has been a very agreeable day , ” said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth . “ The party seemed so well selected , so suitable one with the other . Miss Bennet hope we may often meet again . ” 
 
  Elizabeth smiled . 
 
  “ Elizabeth , Elizabeth must not do so . Elizabeth must not suspect Elizabeth . It mortifies Elizabeth .   “ How hard it is in some cases to be believed ! ” 
 
  “ And how impossible in others ! ”
