 Chapter 
 
  A few days after this visit , Charles called again , and alone . Charles friend had left Charles that morning for London , but was to return home in ten days time . Charles sat with the ladies above an hour , and was in remarkably good spirits . Mother invited Charles to dine with the ladies ; but , with many expressions of concern , Charles confessed Charles engaged elsewhere . 
 
  “ Next time Charles call , ” said Mother , “ Mother hope we shall be more lucky . ” 
 
  Charles should be particularly happy at any time , etc . etc . ; and if Mother would give Charles leave , would take an early opportunity of waiting on the ladies . 
 
  “ Can Charles come to - morrow ? ” 
 
  Yes , Charles had no engagement at all for to - morrow ; and invited was accepted with alacrity . 
 
  Charles came , and in such very good time that the ladies were none of the ladies dressed . In ran Mother to Mother daughter ’s room , in Mother dressing gown , and with Mother hair half finished , crying out : 
 
  “ Mother daughter ’s , make haste and hurry down . Charles is come — Charles is come . Charles is , indeed . Make haste , make haste . Here , Sarah , come to Miss Bennet this moment , and help Bennet on with Bennet gown . Never mind Miss Elizabeth ’s hair . ” 
 
  “ We will be down as soon as we can , ” said Mother daughter ’s ; “ but Mother daughter ’s dare say Kitty is forwarder than either of We , for Kitty went up stairs half an hour ago . ” 
 
  “ Oh ! hang Kitty ! what has Kitty to do with it ? Come be quick , be quick ! Where is Mother daughter ’s sash , Mother dear ? ” 
 
  But when Mother daughter ’s mother was gone , Mother daughter ’s would not be prevailed on to go down without one of Mother daughter ’s sisters . 
 
  The same anxiety to get the ladies by the ladies was visible again in the evening . After tea , Father retired to the library , as was Father custom , and Mary went up stairs to Mary instrument . Two obstacles of the ladies being thus removed , Mother sat looking and winking at Elizabeth ’s and Catherine for a considerable time , without making any impression on Elizabeth ’s and Catherine . Elizabeth ’s would not observe Mother ; and when at last Kitty did , Kitty very innocently said , “ What is the matter Mother ? What do Mother keep winking at Kitty for ? What am Kitty to do ? ” 
 
  “ Nothing Kitty , nothing . Mother did not wink at Kitty . ” Mother then sat still five minutes longer ; but unable to waste such a precious occasion , Mother suddenly got up , and saying to Kitty , “ Come here , Kitty , Mother want to speak to Kitty , ” took Kitty out of the room . Mother daughter ’s instantly gave a look at Elizabeth ’s which spoke Mother daughter ’s distress at such premeditation , and Mother daughter ’s entreaty that Elizabeth ’s would not give in to such premeditation . In a few minutes , Mother half - opened the door and called out : 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s Mother dear , Mother want to speak with Elizabeth ’s . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s was forced to go . 
 
  “ We may as well leave Elizabeth ’s and Catherine by Elizabeth ’s and Catherine Elizabeth ’s know ; ” said Elizabeth ’s mother , as soon as Elizabeth ’s was in the hall . “ Kitty and Mother are going up stairs to sit in Mother dressing - room . ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s made no attempt to reason with Elizabeth ’s mother , but remained quietly in the hall , till Kitty and Mother were out of sight , then returned into the drawing - room . 
 
  Mother ’s schemes for this day were ineffectual . Charles was every thing that was charming , except the professed lover of Mother daughter . Charles ease and cheerfulness rendered Charles a most agreeable addition to their evening party ; and Charles bore with the ill - judged officiousness of the mother , and heard all Mother silly remarks with a forbearance and command of countenance particularly grateful to Mother daughter ’s . 
 
  Charles scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper ; and before Charles went away , an engagement was formed , chiefly through Charles own and Mother ’s means , for Charles coming next morning to shoot with Mother husband . 
 
  After this day , Mother daughter ’s said no more of Mother daughter ’s indifference . Not a word passed between the ladies concerning Charles ; but Elizabeth ’s went to bed in the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded , unless Fitzwilliam returned within the stated time . Seriously , however , Elizabeth ’s felt tolerably persuaded that all this must have taken place with Charles concurrence . 
 
  Charles was punctual to Charles appointment ; and Charles and Father spent the morning together , as had been agreed on . Charles was much more agreeable than Charles companion expected . There was nothing of presumption or folly in Charles that could provoke Charles ridicule , or disgust Charles into silence ; and Charles was more communicative , and less eccentric , than the other had ever seen Charles . Charles of course returned with Charles to dinner ; and in the evening Mother ’s invention was again at work to get every body away from Charles and Mother daughter ’s . Elizabeth ’s , went into the breakfast room for that purpose soon after tea ; for as the others were all going to sit down to cards , Elizabeth ’s could not be wanted to counteract Elizabeth ’s mother ’s schemes . 
 
  But on returning to the drawing - room , when a letter to write was finished , Elizabeth ’s saw , to Elizabeth ’s infinite surprise , there was reason to fear that Elizabeth ’s mother had been too ingenious for Elizabeth ’s . On opening the door , Elizabeth ’s perceived Mother daughter ’s and Charles standing together over the hearth , as if engaged in earnest conversation ; and had this led to no suspicion , the faces of Mother daughter ’s and Charles , as Mother daughter ’s and Charles hastily turned round and moved away from each other , would have told it all . Mother daughter ’s and Charles situation was awkward enough ; but Elizabeth ’s Elizabeth ’s thought was still worse . Not a syllable was uttered by either ; and Elizabeth ’s was on the point of going away again , when Charles , who as well as the other had sat down , suddenly rose , and whispering a few words to Charles sister , ran out of the room . 
 
  Mother daughter ’s could have no reserves from Elizabeth ’s ; and instantly embracing Elizabeth ’s , acknowledged , with the liveliest emotion , that Elizabeth ’s was the happiest creature in the world . 
 
  “ ’ Tis too much ! ” Mother daughter ’s added , “ by far too much . Mother daughter ’s do not deserve it . Oh ! why is not everybody as happy ? ” 
 
  Elizabeth ’s congratulations were given with a sincerity , a warmth , a delight , which words could but poorly express . Every sentence of kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Mother daughter ’s . But Mother daughter ’s would not allow Mother daughter ’s to stay with Elizabeth ’s , or say half that remained to be said for the present . 
 
  “ Mother daughter ’s must go instantly to Mother daughter ’s mother ; ” Mother daughter ’s cried . “ Mother daughter ’s would not on any account trifle with Mother affectionate solicitude ; or allow Mother to hear it from anyone but Mother daughter ’s . He is gone to Mother daughter ’s father already . Oh ! Elizabeth ’s , to know that what Mother daughter ’s have to relate will give such pleasure to all Mother daughter ’s dear family ! how shall Mother daughter ’s bear so much happiness ! ” 
 
  Mother daughter ’s then hastened away to Mother daughter ’s mother , who had purposely broken up the card party , and was sitting up stairs with Kitty . 
 
  Elizabeth ’s Elizabeth ’s , now smiled at the rapidity and ease with which an affair was finally settled , that had given them so many previous months of suspense and vexation . 
 
  “ And this , ” said Elizabeth ’s , “ is the end of all He friend ’s anxious circumspection ! of all He sister ’s falsehood and contrivance ! the happiest , wisest , most reasonable end ! ” 
 
  In a few minutes Elizabeth ’s was joined by Charles , whose conference with Elizabeth ’s father had been short and to the purpose . 
 
  “ Where is He sister ’s ? ” said Charles hastily , as Charles opened the door . 
 
  “ With Charles mother up stairs . He sister ’s will be down in a moment , Charles dare say . ” 
 
  Charles then shut the door , and , coming up to Elizabeth ’s , claimed the good wishes and affection of a sister . Elizabeth ’s honestly and heartily expressed Elizabeth ’s delight in the prospect of their relationship . their shook hands with great cordiality ; and then , till Elizabeth ’s sister came down , Elizabeth ’s had to listen to all Charles had to say of Charles own happiness , and of Mother daughter ’s perfections ; and in spite of Charles being a lover , Elizabeth ’s really believed all Charles expectations of felicity to be rationally founded , because all Charles expectations of felicity had for basis the excellent understanding , and super - excellent disposition of Mother daughter ’s , and a general similarity of feeling and taste between Mother daughter ’s and Charles . 
 
  It was an evening of no common delight to the ladies ; the satisfaction of Miss Bennet ’s mind gave a glow of such sweet animation to Bennet face , as made Bennet look handsomer than ever . Kitty simpered and smiled , and hoped Kitty turn was coming soon . Mother could not give Mother consent or speak Mother approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy Mother feelings , though Mother talked to Charles of nothing else for half an hour ; and when Father joined the ladies at supper , Father voice and manner plainly showed how really happy Father was . 
 
  Not a word , however , passed Father lips in allusion to it , till the ladies visitor took the ladies visitor leave for the night ; but as soon as the ladies visitor was gone , Father turned to Father daughter , and said : 
 
  “ Mother daughter ’s , Father congratulate Mother daughter ’s . Mother daughter ’s will be a very happy woman . ” 
 
  Mother daughter ’s went to Father instantly , kissed Father , and thanked Father for Father goodness . 
 
  “ Mother daughter ’s are a good girl ; ” Father replied , “ and Father have great pleasure in thinking Mother daughter ’s will be so happily settled . Father have not a doubt of Mother daughter ’s doing very well together . Mother daughter ’s tempers are by no means unlike . Mother daughter ’s are each of Mother daughter ’s so complying , that nothing will ever be resolved on ; so easy , that every servant will cheat Mother daughter ’s ; and so generous , that Mother daughter ’s will always exceed Mother daughter ’s income . ” 
 
  “ Father hope not so . Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters would be unpardonable in Father . ” 
 
  “ Exceed their income ! Mother dear Father , ” cried Father wife , “ what are Father talking of ? Why , Father has four or five thousand a year , and very likely more . ” Then addressing Mother daughter ’s , “ Oh ! Elizabeth ’s , Father wife am so happy ! Father wife am sure Father wife sha n’t get a wink of sleep all night . Father wife knew how it would be . Father wife always said it must be so , at last . Father wife was sure Mother daughter ’s could not be so beautiful for nothing ! Father wife remember , as soon as ever Father wife saw Charles , when Charles first came into Hertfordshire last year , Father wife thought how likely it was that Mother daughter ’s should come together . Oh ! Charles is the handsomest young man that ever was seen ! ” 
 
  George , Lydia , were all forgotten . Mother daughter ’s was beyond competition Father wife favourite child . At that moment , Mother daughter ’s cared for no other . Mother daughter ’s younger sisters soon began to make interest with Mother daughter ’s for objects of happiness which Mother daughter ’s might in future be able to dispense . 
 
  Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield ; and Kitty begged very hard for a few balls there every winter . 
 
  Charles , from this time , was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn ; coming frequently before breakfast , and always remaining till after supper ; unless when some barbarous neighbour , who could not be enough detested , had given Charles an invitation to dinner which Charles thought Charles obliged to accept . 
 
  Elizabeth ’s had now but little time for conversation with Elizabeth ’s sister ; for while Charles was present , Mother daughter ’s had no attention to bestow on anyone else ; but Mother daughter ’s found Mother daughter ’s considerably useful to Charles and Father in those hours of separation that must sometimes occur . In the absence of Mother daughter ’s , Charles always attached Charles to Elizabeth ’s , for the pleasure of talking of Elizabeth ’s ; and when Charles was gone , Mother daughter ’s constantly sought the same means of relief . 
 
  “ Charles has made Mother daughter ’s so happy , ” said Mother daughter ’s , one evening , “ by telling Mother daughter ’s that Charles was totally ignorant of Mother daughter ’s being in town last spring ! Mother daughter ’s had not believed it possible . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s suspected as much , ” replied Elizabeth ’s . “ But how did Charles account for it ? ” 
 
  “ It must have been Charles sister ’s doing . They were certainly no friends to Charles acquaintance with Mother daughter ’s , which Elizabeth ’s can not wonder at , since Charles might have chosen so much more advantageously in many respects . But when they see , as Elizabeth ’s trust they will , that Charles is happy with Mother daughter ’s , they will learn to be contented , and their shall be on good terms again ; though their can never be what their once were to their . ” 
 
  “ That is the most unforgiving speech , ” said Elizabeth ’s , “ that Elizabeth ’s ever heard Mother daughter ’s utter . Good girl ! It would vex Elizabeth ’s , indeed , to see Mother daughter ’s again the dupe of Charles pretended regard . ” 
 
  “ Would Elizabeth ’s believe it , Elizabeth ’s , that when Charles went to town last November , Charles really loved Mother daughter ’s , and nothing but a persuasion of Mother daughter ’s being indifferent would have prevented Charles coming down again ! ” 
 
  “ Charles made a little mistake to be sure ; but it is to the credit of Charles modesty . ” 
 
  This naturally introduced a panegyric from Mother daughter ’s on Charles diffidence , and the little value Charles put on Charles own good qualities . Elizabeth ’s was pleased to find that Charles had not betrayed the interference of Charles friend ; for , though Mother daughter ’s had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world , Mother daughter ’s knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice Mother daughter ’s against Charles . 
 
  “ Mother daughter ’s am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed ! ” cried Mother daughter ’s . “ Oh ! Elizabeth ’s , why am Mother daughter ’s thus singled from Mother daughter ’s family , and blessed above Mother daughter ’s family ! If Mother daughter ’s could but see Elizabeth ’s as happy ! If there were but such another man for Elizabeth ’s ! ” 
 
  “ If Elizabeth ’s were to give Mother daughter ’s forty such men , Mother daughter ’s never could be so happy as Elizabeth ’s . Till Mother daughter ’s have Elizabeth ’s disposition , Elizabeth ’s goodness , Mother daughter ’s never can have Elizabeth ’s happiness . No , no , let Mother daughter ’s shift for Mother daughter ’s ; and , perhaps , if Mother daughter ’s have very good luck , Mother daughter ’s may meet with another William Collins in time . ” 
 
  The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a secret . Mother was privileged to whisper The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family to Mrs. Phillips , and Mother ventured , without any permission , to do the same by all Mother neighbours in Meryton . 
 
  The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the world , though only a few weeks before , when Lydia had first run away , the Longbourn family had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune . 
 Chapter 
 
  One morning , about a week after Charles ’s engagement with Jane had been formed , as Charles ’s and the females of the family were sitting together in the dining - room , Charles ’s and the females of the family attention was suddenly drawn to the window , by the sound of a carriage ; and Charles ’s and the females of the family perceived a chaise and four driving up the lawn . It was too early in the morning for visitors , and besides , the equipage did not answer to that of any of Charles ’s and the females of the family neighbours . The horses were post ; and neither a carriage , nor the livery of the servant who preceded a carriage , were familiar to Charles ’s and the females of the family . Charles ’s and the females of the family visitor was Cathleen .

Elizabeth had mentioned Elizabeth name to Elizabeth mother on Charles ’s and the females of the family visitor entrance , though no request of introduction had been made .

Mother youngest of all is lately married , and Mother eldest is somewhere about the grounds , walking with a young man who , Mother believe , will soon become a part of the family . ”

Elizabeth saw Mr. and Mrs. Collins the night before last . ” Elizabeth Elizabeth now expected that Mother would produce a letter for Elizabeth from Charlotte , as it seemed the only probable motive for Elizabeth calling . But no letter appeared , and Elizabeth was completely puzzled .

 Chapter 
 
  The discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw Elizabeth into , could not be easily overcome ; nor could Elizabeth , for many hours , learn to think of this extraordinary visit less than incessantly . Cathleen , it appeared , had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings , for the sole purpose of breaking off Cathleen supposed engagement with Fitzwilliam . It was a rational scheme , to be sure ! but from what the report of their engagement could originate , Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine ; till Elizabeth recollected that Fitzwilliam being the intimate friend of Charles , and Cathleen being the sister of Jane , was enough , at a time when the expectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another , to supply the idea . Elizabeth had not Elizabeth forgotten to feel that the marriage of Jane must bring them more frequently together . And Elizabeth neighbours at Lucas Lodge , therefore ( for through Elizabeth neighbours at Lucas Lodge communication with the Collinses , the report of their engagement , Elizabeth concluded , had reached Cathleen ) , had only set that down as almost certain and immediate , which Elizabeth had looked forward to as possible at some future time . 
 
  In revolving Cathleen ’s expressions , however , Elizabeth could not help feeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of Cathleen persisting in this interference . From what Cathleen had said of Cathleen resolution to prevent their marriage , it occurred to Elizabeth that Elizabeth must meditate an application to Elizabeth nephew ; and how Elizabeth nephew might take a similar representation of the evils attached to a connection with Elizabeth , Elizabeth dared not pronounce . Elizabeth knew not the exact degree of Elizabeth nephew affection for Elizabeth , or Elizabeth nephew dependence on Elizabeth judgment , but it was natural to suppose that Elizabeth nephew thought much higher of Elizabeth than Elizabeth could do ; and it was certain that , in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with one , whose immediate connections were so unequal to Elizabeth nephew own , Elizabeth would address Elizabeth nephew on Elizabeth nephew weakest side . With Elizabeth nephew notions of dignity , Elizabeth nephew would probably feel that the arguments , which to Elizabeth had appeared weak and ridiculous , contained much good sense and solid reasoning . 
 
  If Elizabeth nephew had been wavering before as to what Elizabeth nephew should do , which had often seemed likely , the advice and entreaty of so near a relation might settle every doubt , and determine Elizabeth nephew at once to be as happy as dignity unblemished could make Elizabeth nephew . In that case Elizabeth nephew would return no more . Cathleen might see Elizabeth nephew in Cathleen way through town ; and Elizabeth nephew engagement to Charles of coming again to Netherfield must give way . 
 
  “ If , therefore , an excuse for not keeping Elizabeth nephew promise should come to Elizabeth nephew friend within a few days , ” Elizabeth added , “ Elizabeth shall know how to understand an excuse for not keeping Elizabeth nephew promise . Elizabeth shall then give over every expectation , every wish of Elizabeth nephew constancy . If Elizabeth nephew is satisfied with only regretting Elizabeth , when Elizabeth nephew might have obtained Elizabeth affections and hand , Elizabeth shall soon cease to regret Elizabeth nephew at all . ” 
 
  The surprise of the rest of the family , on hearing who the rest of the family visitor had been , was very great ; but the rest of the family obligingly satisfied The surprise of the rest of the family , with the same kind of supposition which had appeased Cathleen curiosity ; and Elizabeth was spared from much teasing on the subject . 
 
  The next morning , as Elizabeth was going downstairs , Elizabeth was met by Elizabeth father , who came out of Elizabeth father , who came out of library with a letter in Elizabeth father , who came out of hand .

Fitzwilliam , who never looks at any woman but to see a blemish , and who probably never looked at Elizabeth in Fitzwilliam life ! It is admirable ! ” 
 
  Elizabeth tried to join in Elizabeth father , who came out of pleasantry , but could only force one most reluctant smile . Never had Elizabeth father , who came out of wit been directed in a manner so little agreeable to Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Are Elizabeth not diverted ? ” 
 
  “ Oh ! yes . Pray read on . ” 
 
  “ ‘ After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to Elizabeth ladyship last night , Elizabeth immediately , with Elizabeth usual condescension , expressed what Elizabeth felt on the occasion ; when it became apparent , that on the score of some family objections on the part of Elizabeth , Elizabeth would never give Elizabeth consent to what Elizabeth termed so disgraceful a match . William Collins must not , however , neglect the duties of William Collins station , or refrain from declaring William Collins amazement at hearing that Elizabeth received the young couple into Elizabeth house as soon as the young couple were married . received was an encouragement of vice ; and had William Collins been the rector of Longbourn , William Collins should very strenuously have opposed received . The rest of William Collins letter is only about William Collins dear Charlotte ’s situation , and William Collins expectation of a young olive - branch . But , Elizabeth , Elizabeth look as if Elizabeth did not enjoy it . Elizabeth are not going to be missish , Elizabeth father , who came out of hope , and pretend to be affronted at an idle report . For what do we live , but to make sport for our neighbours , and laugh at our neighbours in our turn ? ”

 Chapter 
 
  Instead of receiving any such letter of excuse from Charles friend , as Elizabeth half expected Charles to do , Charles was able to bring Fitzwilliam with Charles to Longbourn before many days had passed after Cathleen ’s visit . The gentlemen arrived early ; and , before Mother had time to tell Charles of The gentlemen having seen Mother aunt , of which Mother daughter sat in momentary dread , Charles , who wanted to be alone with Jane , proposed The gentlemen walking out . proposed was agreed to . Mother was not in the habit of walking ; Mary could never spare time ; but The gentlemen set off together . Charles and Jane , however , soon allowed The gentlemen to outstrip Charles and Jane . Charles and Jane lagged behind , while Elizabeth , Kitty , and Fitzwilliam were to entertain each other . Very little was said by either ; Kitty was too much afraid of Kitty to talk ; Elizabeth was secretly forming a desperate resolution ; and perhaps Fitzwilliam might be doing the same . 
 
  They walked towards the Lucases , because Kitty wished to call upon Maria ; and as Elizabeth saw no occasion for making it a general concern , when Kitty left They Elizabeth went boldly on with Kitty alone . Now was the moment for Elizabeth resolution to be executed , and , while Elizabeth courage was high , Elizabeth immediately said : 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam , Elizabeth am a very selfish creature ; and , for the sake of giving relief to Elizabeth own feelings , care not how much Elizabeth may be wounding Fitzwilliam . Elizabeth can no longer help thanking Fitzwilliam for Fitzwilliam unexampled kindness to Maria . Ever since Elizabeth have known Fitzwilliam unexampled kindness to Maria , Elizabeth have been most anxious to acknowledge to Fitzwilliam how gratefully Elizabeth feel Fitzwilliam unexampled kindness to Maria . Were it known to the rest of Elizabeth family , Elizabeth should not have merely Elizabeth own gratitude to express . ”

  “ Fitzwilliam must not blame Elizabeth aunt . Madeline thoughtlessness first betrayed to Elizabeth that Fitzwilliam had been concerned in the matter ; and , of course , Elizabeth could not rest till Elizabeth knew the particulars . Let Elizabeth thank Fitzwilliam again and again , in the name of all Elizabeth family , for that generous compassion which induced Elizabeth to take so much trouble , and bear so many mortifications , for the sake of discovering so many mortifications . ” 
 
  “ If Elizabeth will thank Fitzwilliam , ” Fitzwilliam replied , “ let it be for Elizabeth alone . That the wish of giving happiness to Elizabeth might add force to the other inducements which led Fitzwilliam on , Fitzwilliam shall not attempt to deny . But Elizabeth family owe Fitzwilliam nothing . Much as Fitzwilliam respect Elizabeth family , Fitzwilliam believe Fitzwilliam thought only of Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Elizabeth was too much embarrassed to say a word . After a short pause , Elizabeth companion added , “ Elizabeth are too generous to trifle with Fitzwilliam . If Elizabeth feelings are still what Elizabeth feelings were last April , tell Fitzwilliam so at once . Fitzwilliam affections and wishes are unchanged , but one word from Elizabeth will silence Fitzwilliam on this subject for ever . ” 
 
  Elizabeth , feeling all the more than common awkwardness and anxiety of Fitzwilliam situation , now forced Elizabeth to speak ; and immediately , though not very fluently , gave Fitzwilliam to understand that Elizabeth sentiments had undergone so material a change , since the period to which Fitzwilliam alluded , as to make Elizabeth receive with gratitude and pleasure Fitzwilliam present assurances . The happiness which this reply produced , was such as Fitzwilliam had probably never felt before ; and Fitzwilliam expressed Fitzwilliam on the occasion as sensibly and as warmly as a man violently in love can be supposed to do . Had Elizabeth been able to encounter Fitzwilliam eye , Elizabeth might have seen how well the expression of heartfelt delight , diffused over Fitzwilliam face , became Fitzwilliam ; but , though Elizabeth could not look , Elizabeth could listen , and Fitzwilliam told Elizabeth of feelings , which , in proving of what importance Elizabeth was to Fitzwilliam , made Fitzwilliam affection every moment more valuable .

Elizabeth soon learnt that they were indebted for They present good understanding to the efforts of Fitzwilliam aunt , who did call on Fitzwilliam in her ladyship ’s return through London , and there relate her ladyship ’s journey to Longbourn , her ladyship ’s journey to Longbourn motive , and the substance of her ladyship ’s conversation with Elizabeth ; dwelling emphatically on every expression of Elizabeth which , in her ladyship ’s apprehension , peculiarly denoted her ladyship ’s perverseness and assurance ; in the belief that such a relation must assist her ladyship ’s endeavours to obtain that promise from her ladyship ’s nephew which her ladyship ’s had refused to give . But , unluckily for her ladyship ’s ladyship , her ladyship ’s journey to Longbourn effect had been exactly contrariwise .

Elizabeth knew enough of Elizabeth disposition to be certain that , had Elizabeth been absolutely , irrevocably decided against Elizabeth , Elizabeth would have acknowledged decided to Cathleen ’s , frankly and openly . ”

  “ What did Elizabeth say of Elizabeth , that Elizabeth did not deserve ? For , though Elizabeth accusations were ill - founded , formed on mistaken premises , Elizabeth behaviour to Elizabeth at the time had merited the severest reproof . Elizabeth behaviour to Elizabeth at the time was unpardonable . Elizabeth can not think of Elizabeth behaviour to Elizabeth at the time without abhorrence . ”

  “ Elizabeth can not be so easily reconciled to Elizabeth . The recollection of what Elizabeth then said , of Elizabeth conduct , Elizabeth manners , Elizabeth expressions during the whole of it , is now , and has been many months , inexpressibly painful to Elizabeth . Elizabeth reproof , so well applied , Elizabeth shall never forget : ‘ had Elizabeth behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner . ’ Those were Elizabeth words . Fitzwilliam know not , Fitzwilliam can scarcely conceive , how Elizabeth words have tortured me;—though it was some time , Elizabeth confess , before Elizabeth was reasonable enough to allow Elizabeth words justice . ”

The turn of Elizabeth countenance Elizabeth shall never forget , as Elizabeth said that Elizabeth could not have addressed Elizabeth in any possible way that would induce Elizabeth to accept Elizabeth . ”

  Elizabeth explained what Fitzwilliam letter effect on Elizabeth had been , and how gradually all Elizabeth former prejudices had been removed .

Fitzwilliam hope Elizabeth have destroyed Fitzwilliam letter . Fitzwilliam can remember some expressions which might justly make Elizabeth hate Fitzwilliam . ”

The feelings of the person who wrote , and the person who received Fitzwilliam letter , are now so widely different from what The feelings of the person who wrote , and the person who received Fitzwilliam letter were then , that every unpleasant circumstance attending Fitzwilliam letter ought to be forgotten . Elizabeth must learn some of Fitzwilliam philosophy . Think only of the past as the past remembrance gives Elizabeth pleasure . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam can not give Elizabeth credit for any philosophy of the kind . Elizabeth retrospections must be so totally void of reproach , that the contentment arising from Elizabeth retrospections is not of philosophy , but , what is much better , of innocence . But with Fitzwilliam , it is not so . Painful recollections will intrude which can not , which ought not , to be repelled . Fitzwilliam have been a selfish being all Fitzwilliam life , in practice , though not in principle . As a child Fitzwilliam was taught what was right , but Fitzwilliam was not taught to correct Fitzwilliam temper . Fitzwilliam was given good principles , but left to follow good principles in pride and conceit . Unfortunately an only son ( for many years an only child ) , Fitzwilliam was spoilt by Fitzwilliam parents , who , though good Fitzwilliam parents , who , though good ( Fitzwilliam father , particularly , all that was benevolent and amiable ) , allowed , encouraged , almost taught Fitzwilliam to be selfish and overbearing ; to care for none beyond Fitzwilliam own family circle ; to think meanly of all the rest of the world ; to wish at least to think meanly of all the rest of the world sense and worth compared with Fitzwilliam own . Such Fitzwilliam was , from eight to eight and twenty ; and such Fitzwilliam might still have been but for Elizabeth , dearest , loveliest Elizabeth ! What do Fitzwilliam not owe Elizabeth ! Elizabeth taught Fitzwilliam a lesson , hard indeed at first , but most advantageous . By Elizabeth , Fitzwilliam was properly humbled . Fitzwilliam came to Elizabeth without a doubt of Fitzwilliam reception . Elizabeth showed Fitzwilliam how insufficient were all Fitzwilliam pretensions to please a woman worthy of being pleased . ” 
 
  “ Had Elizabeth then persuaded Elizabeth that Elizabeth should ? ” 
 
  “ Indeed Elizabeth had . What will Elizabeth think of Elizabeth vanity ? Elizabeth believed Elizabeth to be wishing , expecting Elizabeth addresses . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth manners must have been in fault , but not intentionally , Elizabeth assure Elizabeth . Elizabeth never meant to deceive Elizabeth , but Elizabeth spirits might often lead Elizabeth wrong . How Elizabeth must have hated Fitzwilliam after that evening ? ” 
 
  “ Hate Fitzwilliam ! Elizabeth was angry perhaps at first , but Elizabeth anger soon began to take a proper direction . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth am almost afraid of asking what Elizabeth thought of Elizabeth , when They met at Pemberley . Elizabeth blamed Elizabeth for coming ? ” 
 
  “ No indeed ; Elizabeth felt nothing but surprise . ” 
 
  “ Elizabeth surprise could not be greater than Elizabeth in being noticed by Elizabeth . Elizabeth conscience told Elizabeth that Elizabeth deserved no extraordinary politeness , and Elizabeth confess that Elizabeth did not expect to receive more than Elizabeth due . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam object then , ” replied Fitzwilliam , “ was to show Elizabeth , by every civility in Fitzwilliam power , that Fitzwilliam was not so mean as to resent the past ; and Fitzwilliam hoped to obtain Elizabeth forgiveness , to lessen Elizabeth ill opinion , by letting Elizabeth see that Elizabeth reproofs had been attended to . How soon any other wishes introduced any other wishes Fitzwilliam can hardly tell , but Fitzwilliam believe in about half an hour after Fitzwilliam had seen Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam then told Elizabeth of Georgiana ’s delight in Georgiana ’s acquaintance , and of Georgiana ’s disappointment at Georgiana ’s acquaintance sudden interruption ; which naturally leading to the cause of Georgiana ’s acquaintance sudden interruption , Georgiana ’s soon learnt that Fitzwilliam resolution of following Georgiana ’s from Derbyshire in quest of Georgiana ’s sister had been formed before Fitzwilliam quitted the inn , and that Fitzwilliam gravity and thoughtfulness there had arisen from no other struggles than what such a purpose must comprehend . 
 
  Elizabeth expressed Elizabeth gratitude again , but it was too painful a subject to each , to be dwelt on farther . 
 
  After walking several miles in a leisurely manner , and too busy to know anything about it , they found at last , on examining They watches , that it was time to be at home . 
 
  “ What could become of Charles and Jane ! ” was a wonder which introduced the discussion of Charles and Jane affairs . Fitzwilliam was delighted with Charles and Jane engagement ; Fitzwilliam friend had given Fitzwilliam the earliest information of Charles and Jane engagement . 
 
  “ Elizabeth must ask whether Fitzwilliam were surprised ? ” said Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Not at all . When Fitzwilliam went away , Fitzwilliam felt that Charles and Jane engagement would soon happen . ” 
 
  “ That is to say , Fitzwilliam had given Fitzwilliam permission . Elizabeth guessed as much . ” And though Fitzwilliam exclaimed at the term , Elizabeth found that it had been pretty much the case . 
 
  “ On the evening before Fitzwilliam going to London , ” said Fitzwilliam , “ Fitzwilliam made a confession to Charles , which Fitzwilliam believe Fitzwilliam ought to have made long ago . Fitzwilliam told Charles of all that had occurred to make Fitzwilliam former interference in Charles affairs absurd and impertinent . Charles surprise was great . Charles had never had the slightest suspicion . Fitzwilliam told Charles , moreover , that Fitzwilliam believed Fitzwilliam mistaken in supposing , as Fitzwilliam had done , that Jane was indifferent to Charles ; and as Fitzwilliam could easily perceive that Charles attachment to Jane was unabated , Fitzwilliam felt no doubt of Charles and Jane happiness together . ” 
 
  Elizabeth could not help smiling at Fitzwilliam easy manner of directing Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Did Fitzwilliam speak from Fitzwilliam own observation , ” said Elizabeth , “ when Fitzwilliam told Charles that Elizabeth sister loved Charles , or merely from Elizabeth information last spring ? ” 
 
  “ From the former . Fitzwilliam had narrowly observed Jane during the two visits which Fitzwilliam had lately made here ; and Fitzwilliam was convinced of Jane affection . ” 
 
  “ And Fitzwilliam assurance of Jane affection , Elizabeth suppose , carried immediate conviction to Charles . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam assurance of Jane affection did . Charles is most unaffectedly modest . Charles diffidence had prevented Charles depending on Charles own judgment in so anxious a case , but Charles reliance on Fitzwilliam made every thing easy . Fitzwilliam was obliged to confess one thing , which for a time , and not unjustly , offended Charles . Fitzwilliam could not allow Fitzwilliam to conceal that Elizabeth sister had been in town three months last winter , that Fitzwilliam had known been , and purposely kept been from Charles . Charles was angry . But Charles anger , Fitzwilliam am persuaded , lasted no longer than Charles remained in any doubt of Elizabeth sister ’s sentiments . Charles has heartily forgiven Fitzwilliam now . ” 
 
  Elizabeth longed to observe that Charles had been a most delightful friend ; so easily guided that Charles worth was invaluable ; but Elizabeth checked Elizabeth . Elizabeth remembered that Charles had yet to learn to be laughed at , and it was rather too early to begin . In anticipating the happiness of Charles , which of course was to be inferior only to Fitzwilliam own , Fitzwilliam continued the conversation till they reached the house . In the hall they parted . 
 Chapter 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth , where can Jane dear Elizabeth have been walking to ? ” was a question which Jane dear Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as Jane dear Elizabeth entered their room , and from all the others when their sat down to table . Jane dear Elizabeth had only to say in reply , that their had wandered about , till Jane dear Elizabeth was beyond Jane dear Elizabeth own knowledge . Jane dear Elizabeth coloured as Jane dear Elizabeth spoke ; but neither coloured , nor anything else , awakened a suspicion of the truth . 
 
  The evening passed quietly , unmarked by anything extraordinary . The acknowledged lovers talked and laughed , the unacknowledged were silent . Fitzwilliam was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth ; and Jane dear Elizabeth , agitated and confused , rather knew that Jane dear Elizabeth was happy than felt Jane dear Elizabeth to be so ; for , besides the immediate embarrassment , there were other evils before Jane dear Elizabeth . Jane dear Elizabeth anticipated what would be felt in the family when Jane dear Elizabeth situation became known ; Jane dear Elizabeth was aware that no one liked Fitzwilliam but Jane ; and even feared that with the others it was a dislike which not all Fitzwilliam fortune and consequence might do away . 
 
  At night Jane dear Elizabeth opened Jane dear Elizabeth heart to Jane . Though suspicion was very far from Miss Bennet ’s general habits , Miss Bennet ’s was absolutely incredulous here . 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth are joking , Jane dear Elizabeth . This can not be!—engaged to Fitzwilliam ! No , no , Jane dear Elizabeth shall not deceive Miss Bennet ’s . Miss Bennet ’s know This to be impossible . ” 
 
  “ This is a wretched beginning indeed ! Jane dear Elizabeth sole dependence was on Jane ; and Jane dear Elizabeth am sure nobody else will believe Jane dear Elizabeth , if Jane do not . Yet , indeed , Jane dear Elizabeth am in earnest . Jane dear Elizabeth speak nothing but the truth . Fitzwilliam still loves Jane dear Elizabeth , and their are engaged . ” 
 
  Jane looked at Jane dear Elizabeth doubtingly . “ Oh , Jane dear Elizabeth ! it can not be . Miss Bennet ’s know how much Jane dear Elizabeth dislike Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet ’s know nothing of the matter . That is all to be forgot . Perhaps Jane dear Elizabeth did not always love Fitzwilliam so well as Jane dear Elizabeth do now . But in such cases as these , a good memory is unpardonable . This is the last time Jane dear Elizabeth shall ever remember it Jane dear Elizabeth . ” Miss Bennet ’s Miss Bennet ’s still looked all amazement . Jane dear Elizabeth again , and more seriously assured Miss Bennet ’s of its truth . 
 
  “ Good Heaven ! can it be really so ! Yet now Jane must believe Jane dear Elizabeth , ” cried Jane . “ Jane dear Elizabeth , Miss Bennet ’s would — Miss Bennet ’s do congratulate Jane dear Elizabeth — but are Jane dear Elizabeth certain ? forgive the question — are Jane dear Elizabeth quite certain that Jane dear Elizabeth can be happy with Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ There can be no doubt of be . It is settled between their already , that their are to be the happiest couple in the world . But are Jane pleased , Jane ? Shall Jane like to have such a brother ? ” 
 
  “ Very , very much . Nothing could give either Fitzwilliam or Jane more delight . But we considered it , we talked of it as impossible . And do Jane dear Elizabeth really love Fitzwilliam quite well enough ? Oh , Jane dear Elizabeth ! do anything rather than marry without affection . Are Jane dear Elizabeth quite sure that Jane dear Elizabeth feel what Jane dear Elizabeth ought to do ? ” 
 
  “ Oh , yes ! Miss Bennet ’s will only think Jane dear Elizabeth feel more than Jane dear Elizabeth ought to do , when Jane dear Elizabeth tell Miss Bennet ’s all . ” 
 
  “ What do Jane dear Elizabeth mean ? ” 
 
  “ Why , Jane dear Elizabeth must confess that Jane dear Elizabeth love Fitzwilliam better than Jane dear Elizabeth do Fitzwilliam . Jane dear Elizabeth am afraid Miss Bennet ’s will be angry . ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet ’s dearest sister , now be serious . Miss Bennet ’s want to talk very seriously . Let Miss Bennet ’s know every thing that Miss Bennet ’s am to know , without delay . Will Jane dear Elizabeth tell Miss Bennet ’s how long Jane dear Elizabeth have loved Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ loved has been coming on so gradually , that Jane dear Elizabeth hardly know when loved began . But Jane dear Elizabeth believe Jane dear Elizabeth must date loved from Jane dear Elizabeth first seeing Fitzwilliam beautiful grounds at Pemberley . ” 
 
  Another entreaty that Jane dear Elizabeth would be serious , however , produced the desired effect ; and Jane dear Elizabeth soon satisfied Jane by Jane dear Elizabeth solemn assurances of attachment . When convinced on that article , Miss Bennet ’s had nothing further to wish . 
 
  “ Now Miss Bennet ’s am quite happy , ” said Miss Bennet ’s , “ for Jane dear Elizabeth will be as happy as Miss Bennet ’s . Miss Bennet ’s always had a value for Fitzwilliam . Were it for nothing but Fitzwilliam love of Jane dear Elizabeth , Miss Bennet ’s must always have esteemed Fitzwilliam ; but now , as Fitzwilliam friend and Jane dear Elizabeth husband , there can be only Charles and Jane dear Elizabeth more dear to Miss Bennet ’s . But Jane dear Elizabeth , Jane dear Elizabeth have been very sly , very reserved with Miss Bennet ’s . How little did Jane dear Elizabeth tell Miss Bennet ’s of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton ! Miss Bennet ’s owe all that Miss Bennet ’s know of it to another , not to Jane dear Elizabeth . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth told Miss Bennet ’s the motives of Jane dear Elizabeth secrecy . Jane dear Elizabeth had been unwilling to mention Fitzwilliam ; and the unsettled state of Jane dear Elizabeth own feelings had made Jane dear Elizabeth equally avoid the name of Fitzwilliam friend . But now Jane dear Elizabeth would no longer conceal from Miss Bennet ’s Fitzwilliam share in Lydia ’s marriage . All was acknowledged , and half the night spent in conversation . 
 
  “ Good gracious ! ” cried Miss Bennet ’s , as Miss Bennet ’s stood at a window the next morning , “ if that disagreeable Fitzwilliam is not coming here again with Fitzwilliam ! What can Fitzwilliam mean by being so tiresome as to be always coming here ? Miss Bennet ’s had no notion but Fitzwilliam would go a - shooting , or something or other , and not disturb our with Fitzwilliam company . What shall our do with Fitzwilliam ? Jane dear Elizabeth , Jane dear Elizabeth must walk out with Fitzwilliam again , that Fitzwilliam may not be in Fitzwilliam way . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal ; yet was really vexed that Jane dear Elizabeth mother should be always giving Fitzwilliam such an epithet . 
 
  As soon as they entered , Fitzwilliam looked at Jane dear Elizabeth so expressively , and shook hands with such warmth , as left no doubt of Fitzwilliam good information ; and Fitzwilliam soon afterwards said aloud , “ Miss Bennet ’s , have Miss Bennet ’s no more lanes hereabouts in which Jane dear Elizabeth may lose Jane dear Elizabeth way again to - day ? ” 
 
  “ Miss Bennet ’s advise Fitzwilliam , and Jane dear Elizabeth , and Kitty , ” said Miss Bennet ’s , “ to walk to Oakham Mount this morning . walk is a nice long walk , and Fitzwilliam has never seen the view . ” 
 
  “ walk may do very well for Fitzwilliam , and Jane dear Elizabeth , and Kitty , ” replied Fitzwilliam ; “ but Fitzwilliam am sure walk will be too much for Kitty . Wo n’t it , Kitty ? ” Kitty owned that Kitty had rather stay at home . Fitzwilliam professed a great curiosity to see the view from Oakham Mount , and Jane dear Elizabeth silently consented . As Jane dear Elizabeth went up stairs to get ready , Miss Bennet ’s followed Jane dear Elizabeth , saying : 
 
  “ Miss Bennet ’s am quite sorry , Jane dear Elizabeth , that Jane dear Elizabeth should be forced to have Fitzwilliam all to Jane dear Elizabeth . But Miss Bennet ’s hope Jane dear Elizabeth will not mind have : it is all for Jane ’s sake , Jane dear Elizabeth know ; and there is no occasion for talking to Fitzwilliam , except just now and then . So , do not put Jane dear Elizabeth to inconvenience . ” 
 
  During their walk , it was resolved that Father ’s consent should be asked in the course of the evening . Jane dear Elizabeth reserved to Jane dear Elizabeth the application for Miss Bennet ’s . Jane dear Elizabeth could not determine how Miss Bennet ’s would take the application for Miss Bennet ’s ; sometimes doubting whether all Fitzwilliam wealth and grandeur would be enough to overcome Miss Bennet ’s abhorrence of Fitzwilliam . But whether Jane dear Elizabeth were violently set against the match , or violently delighted with the match , it was certain that Jane dear Elizabeth manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit to Jane dear Elizabeth sense ; and Jane dear Elizabeth could no more bear that Fitzwilliam should hear the first raptures of Jane dear Elizabeth joy , than the first vehemence of Jane dear Elizabeth disapprobation . 
 
  In the evening , soon after Father ’s withdrew to the library , Jane dear Elizabeth saw Fitzwilliam rise also and follow Father ’s , and Jane dear Elizabeth agitation on seeing it was extreme . Jane dear Elizabeth did not fear Jane dear Elizabeth father ’s opposition , but Father ’s was going to be made unhappy ; and that it should be through Jane dear Elizabeth means — that Jane dear Elizabeth , should be distressing Father ’s by Jane dear Elizabeth choice , should be filling Father ’s with fears and regrets in disposing of Jane dear Elizabeth — was a wretched reflection , and Jane dear Elizabeth sat in misery till Fitzwilliam appeared again , when , looking at Fitzwilliam , Jane dear Elizabeth was a little relieved by Fitzwilliam smile . In a few minutes Fitzwilliam approached the table where Jane dear Elizabeth was sitting with Kitty ; and , while pretending to admire Jane dear Elizabeth work said in a whisper , “ Go to Father ’s , Father ’s wants Jane dear Elizabeth in the library . ” Jane dear Elizabeth was gone directly . 
 
  Father ’s was walking about the room , looking grave and anxious . “ Jane dear Elizabeth , ” said Father ’s , “ what are Jane dear Elizabeth doing ? Are Jane dear Elizabeth out of Jane dear Elizabeth senses , to be accepting Fitzwilliam ? Have not Jane dear Elizabeth always hated Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  How earnestly did Jane dear Elizabeth then wish that Jane dear Elizabeth former opinions had been more reasonable , Jane dear Elizabeth expressions more moderate ! It would have spared Jane dear Elizabeth from explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give ; but explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give were now necessary , and Jane dear Elizabeth assured Father ’s , with some confusion , of Jane dear Elizabeth attachment to Fitzwilliam . 
 
  “ Or , in other words , Jane dear Elizabeth are determined to have Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam is rich , to be sure , and Jane dear Elizabeth may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane . But will more fine clothes and fine carriages make Jane dear Elizabeth happy ? ” 
 
  “ Have Father ’s any other objection , ” said Jane dear Elizabeth , “ than Father ’s belief of Jane dear Elizabeth indifference ? ” 
 
  “ None at all . We all know Fitzwilliam to be a proud , unpleasant sort of man ; but this would be nothing if Jane dear Elizabeth really liked Fitzwilliam . ” 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth do , Jane dear Elizabeth do like Fitzwilliam , ” Jane dear Elizabeth replied , with tears in Jane dear Elizabeth eyes , “ Jane dear Elizabeth love Fitzwilliam . Indeed Fitzwilliam has no improper pride . Fitzwilliam is perfectly amiable . Father ’s do not know what Fitzwilliam really is ; then pray do not pain Jane dear Elizabeth by speaking of Fitzwilliam in such terms . ” 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth , ” said Jane dear Elizabeth father , “ Father ’s have given Fitzwilliam Father ’s consent . Fitzwilliam is the kind of man , indeed , to whom Father ’s should never dare refuse anything , which Fitzwilliam condescended to ask . Father ’s now give it to Jane dear Elizabeth , if Jane dear Elizabeth are resolved on having Fitzwilliam . But let Father ’s advise Jane dear Elizabeth to think better of it . Father ’s know Jane dear Elizabeth disposition , Jane dear Elizabeth . Father ’s know that Jane dear Elizabeth could be neither happy nor respectable , unless Jane dear Elizabeth truly esteemed Fitzwilliam ; unless Jane dear Elizabeth looked up to Fitzwilliam as a superior . Jane dear Elizabeth lively talents would place Jane dear Elizabeth in the greatest danger in an unequal marriage . Jane dear Elizabeth could scarcely escape discredit and misery . Jane dear Elizabeth , let Father ’s not have the grief of seeing Jane dear Elizabeth unable to respect Jane dear Elizabeth partner in life . Jane dear Elizabeth know not what Jane dear Elizabeth are about . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth , was earnest and solemn in Jane dear Elizabeth reply ; and at length , by repeated assurances that Fitzwilliam was really the object of Jane dear Elizabeth choice , by explaining the gradual change which Jane dear Elizabeth estimation of Fitzwilliam had undergone , relating Jane dear Elizabeth absolute certainty that Fitzwilliam affection was not the work of a day , but had stood the test of many months ’ suspense , and enumerating with energy all Fitzwilliam good qualities , Jane dear Elizabeth did conquer Jane dear Elizabeth father ’s incredulity , and reconcile Father ’s to the match . 
 
  “ Well , Father ’s dear , ” said Father ’s , when Jane dear Elizabeth ceased speaking , “ Father ’s have no more to say . If this be the case , Fitzwilliam deserves Jane dear Elizabeth . Father ’s could not have parted with Jane dear Elizabeth , Father ’s Elizabeth , to anyone less worthy . ” 
 
  To complete the favourable impression , Jane dear Elizabeth then told Father ’s what Fitzwilliam had voluntarily done for Lydia ’s . Father ’s heard Jane dear Elizabeth with astonishment . 
 
  “ This is an evening of wonders , indeed ! And so , Fitzwilliam did every thing ; made up the match , gave the money , paid Fitzwilliam debts , and got Fitzwilliam Fitzwilliam commission ! So much the better . It will save Father ’s a world of trouble and economy . Had it been Jane dear Elizabeth uncle ’s doing , Father ’s must and would have paid Jane dear Elizabeth uncle ’s ; but these violent young lovers carry every thing these violent young lovers own way . Father ’s shall offer to pay Fitzwilliam to - morrow ; Fitzwilliam will rant and storm about Fitzwilliam love for Jane dear Elizabeth , and there will be an end of the matter . ” 
 
  Father ’s then recollected Jane dear Elizabeth embarrassment a few days before , on Father ’s reading William Collins ’s letter ; and after laughing at Jane dear Elizabeth some time , allowed Jane dear Elizabeth at last to go — saying , as Miss Bennet ’s quitted the room , “ If any young men come for Mary or Kitty , send any young men in , for Miss Bennet ’s am quite at leisure . ” 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight ; and , after half an hour ’s quiet reflection in Jane dear Elizabeth own room , Jane dear Elizabeth was able to join the others with tolerable composure . Every thing was too recent for gaiety , but the evening passed tranquilly away ; there was no longer anything material to be dreaded , and the comfort of ease and familiarity would come in time . 
 
  When Miss Bennet ’s went up to Miss Bennet ’s dressing - room at night , Jane dear Elizabeth followed Miss Bennet ’s , and made the important communication . the important communication effect was most extraordinary ; for on first hearing the important communication , Miss Bennet ’s sat quite still , and unable to utter a syllable . Nor was it under many , many minutes that Miss Bennet ’s could comprehend what Miss Bennet ’s heard ; though not in general backward to credit what was for the advantage of Miss Bennet ’s family , or that came in the shape of a lover to any of the family . Miss Bennet ’s began at length to recover , to fidget about in Miss Bennet ’s chair , get up , sit down again , wonder , and bless Miss Bennet ’s . 
 
  “ Good gracious ! Father ’s bless Miss Bennet ’s ! only think ! dear Miss Bennet ’s ! Fitzwilliam ! Who would have thought it ! And is it really true ? Oh ! Miss Bennet ’s sweetest Elizabeth ! how rich and how great Jane dear Elizabeth will be ! What pin - money , what jewels , what carriages Jane dear Elizabeth will have ! Jane ’s is nothing to it — nothing at all . Miss Bennet ’s am so pleased — so happy . Such a charming man!—so handsome ! so tall!—Oh , Miss Bennet ’s dear Elizabeth ! pray apologise for Miss Bennet ’s having disliked Fitzwilliam so much before . Miss Bennet ’s hope Fitzwilliam will overlook disliked . Jane dear Elizabeth A house in town ! Every thing that is charming ! Three daughters married ! Ten thousand a year ! Oh , Lord ! What will become of Jane dear Elizabeth . Jane dear Elizabeth shall go distracted . ” 
 
  This was enough to prove that Miss Bennet ’s approbation need not be doubted : and Jane dear Elizabeth , rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by Jane dear Elizabeth , soon went away . But before Jane dear Elizabeth had been three minutes in Jane dear Elizabeth own room , Jane dear Elizabeth mother followed Jane dear Elizabeth . 
 
  “ Jane dear Elizabeth , ” Miss Bennet ’s cried , “ Miss Bennet ’s can think of nothing else ! Ten thousand a year , and very likely more ! ’ Tis as good as a Lord ! And a special licence . Jane dear Elizabeth must and shall be married by a special licence . But Miss Bennet ’s dearest love , tell Miss Bennet ’s what dish Fitzwilliam is particularly fond of , that Miss Bennet ’s may have it to - morrow . ” 
 
  This was a sad omen of what Miss Bennet ’s behaviour to Fitzwilliam might be ; and Jane dear Elizabeth found that , though in the certain possession of Fitzwilliam warmest affection , and secure of Jane dear Elizabeth relations ’ consent , there was still something to be wished for . But the morrow passed off much better than Jane dear Elizabeth expected ; for Miss Bennet ’s luckily stood in such awe of Fitzwilliam that Miss Bennet ’s ventured not to speak to Fitzwilliam , unless it was in Miss Bennet ’s power to offer Fitzwilliam any attention , or mark Miss Bennet ’s deference for Fitzwilliam opinion . 
 
  Jane dear Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing Jane dear Elizabeth father taking pains to get acquainted with Fitzwilliam ; and Father ’s soon assured Jane dear Elizabeth that Father ’s was rising every hour in Father ’s esteem . 
 
  “ Father ’s admire all Father ’s three sons - in - law highly , ” said Father ’s . “ Fitzwilliam , perhaps , is Father ’s favourite ; but Father ’s think Father ’s shall like Jane dear Elizabeth husband quite as well as Jane ’s . ” 
 Chapter 
 
  Elizabeth ’s spirits soon rising to playfulness again , Elizabeth ’s wanted Fitzwilliam to account for Fitzwilliam having ever fallen in love with Elizabeth ’s . “ How could Fitzwilliam begin ? ” said Elizabeth ’s . “ Elizabeth ’s can comprehend Fitzwilliam going on charmingly , when Fitzwilliam had once made a beginning ; but what could set Fitzwilliam off in the first place ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam can not fix on the hour , or the spot , or the look , or the words , which laid the foundation . It is too long ago . Fitzwilliam was in the middle before Fitzwilliam knew that Fitzwilliam had begun . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam beauty Fitzwilliam had early withstood , and as for Fitzwilliam manners — Fitzwilliam behaviour to Fitzwilliam was at least always bordering on the uncivil , and Fitzwilliam never spoke to Fitzwilliam without rather wishing to give Fitzwilliam pain than not . Now be sincere ; did Fitzwilliam admire Fitzwilliam for Fitzwilliam impertinence ? ” 
 
  “ For the liveliness of Elizabeth ’s mind , Fitzwilliam did . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam may as well call Fitzwilliam impertinence impertinence at once . Fitzwilliam impertinence was very little less . The fact is , that Fitzwilliam were sick of civility , of deference , of officious attention . Fitzwilliam were disgusted with the women who were always speaking , and looking , and thinking for Fitzwilliam approbation alone . Fitzwilliam roused , and interested Fitzwilliam , because Fitzwilliam was so unlike the women who were always speaking , and looking , and thinking for Fitzwilliam approbation alone . Had Fitzwilliam not been really amiable , Fitzwilliam would have hated Fitzwilliam for it ; but in spite of the pains Fitzwilliam took to disguise Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam feelings were always noble and just ; and in Fitzwilliam heart , Fitzwilliam thoroughly despised the persons who so assiduously courted Fitzwilliam . There — Fitzwilliam have saved Fitzwilliam the trouble of accounting for it ; and really , all things considered , Fitzwilliam begin to think it perfectly reasonable . To be sure , Fitzwilliam knew no actual good of Fitzwilliam — but nobody thinks of that when nobody fall in love . ” 
 
  “ Was there no good in Fitzwilliam affectionate behaviour to Jane while Jane was ill at Netherfield ? ” 
 
  “ Dearest Jane ! who could have done less for Jane ? But make a virtue of it by all means . Fitzwilliam good qualities are under Fitzwilliam protection , and Fitzwilliam are to exaggerate Fitzwilliam good qualities as much as possible ; and , in return , it belongs to Fitzwilliam to find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with Fitzwilliam as often as may be ; and Fitzwilliam shall begin directly by asking Fitzwilliam what made Fitzwilliam so unwilling to come to the point at last . What made Fitzwilliam so shy of Fitzwilliam , when Fitzwilliam first called , and afterwards dined here ? Why , especially , when Fitzwilliam called , did Fitzwilliam look as if Fitzwilliam did not care about Fitzwilliam ? ” 
 
  “ Because Fitzwilliam were grave and silent , and gave Fitzwilliam no encouragement . ” 
 
  “ But Fitzwilliam was embarrassed . ” 
 
  “ And so was I. ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam might have talked to Fitzwilliam more when Fitzwilliam came to dinner . ” 
 
  “ A man who had felt less , might . ” 
 
  “ How unlucky that Fitzwilliam should have a reasonable answer to give , and that Fitzwilliam should be so reasonable as to admit it ! But Fitzwilliam wonder how long Fitzwilliam would have gone on , if Fitzwilliam had been left to Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam wonder when Fitzwilliam would have spoken , if Fitzwilliam had not asked Fitzwilliam ! Fitzwilliam resolution of thanking Fitzwilliam for Fitzwilliam kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect . Too much , Fitzwilliam am afraid ; for what becomes of the moral , if our comfort springs from a breach of promise ? for Fitzwilliam ought not to have mentioned the subject . mentioned will never do . ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam need not distress Fitzwilliam . The moral will be perfectly fair . Cathleen ’s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of removing all Fitzwilliam doubts . Fitzwilliam am not indebted for Fitzwilliam present happiness to Fitzwilliam eager desire of expressing Fitzwilliam gratitude . Fitzwilliam was not in a humour to wait for any opening of Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam aunt ’s intelligence had given Fitzwilliam hope , and Fitzwilliam was determined at once to know every thing . ” 
 
  “ Cathleen ’s has been of infinite use , which ought to make Cathleen ’s happy , for Cathleen ’s loves to be of use . But tell Elizabeth ’s , what did Fitzwilliam come down to Netherfield for ? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed ? or had Fitzwilliam intended any more serious consequence ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam real purpose was to see Fitzwilliam , and to judge , if Fitzwilliam could , whether Fitzwilliam might ever hope to make Fitzwilliam love Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam avowed one , or what Fitzwilliam avowed to Fitzwilliam , was to see whether Cathleen ’s were still partial to Charles , and if Cathleen ’s were , to make the confession to Charles which Fitzwilliam have since made . ” 
 
  “ Shall Fitzwilliam ever have courage to announce to Cathleen ’s what is to befall Cathleen ’s ? ” 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam am more likely to want time than courage , Fitzwilliam . But it ought to be done , and if Fitzwilliam will give Fitzwilliam a sheet of paper , it shall be done directly . ” 
 
  “ And if Fitzwilliam had not a letter to write Fitzwilliam , Fitzwilliam might sit by Fitzwilliam and admire the evenness of Fitzwilliam writing , as another young lady once did . But Fitzwilliam have an aunt , too , who must not be longer neglected . ” 
 
  From an unwillingness to confess how much Elizabeth ’s intimacy with Fitzwilliam had been over - rated , Elizabeth ’s had never yet answered Madeline ’s long letter ; but now , having that to communicate which Elizabeth ’s knew would be most welcome , Elizabeth ’s was almost ashamed to find that Elizabeth ’s uncle and aunt had already lost three days of happiness , and immediately wrote as follows : 
 
  “ Elizabeth ’s would have thanked Fitzwilliam before , Fitzwilliam , as Elizabeth ’s ought to have done , for Fitzwilliam long , kind , satisfactory , detail of particulars ; but to say the truth , Elizabeth ’s was too cross to write . Fitzwilliam supposed more than really existed . But now suppose as much as Fitzwilliam choose ; give a loose rein to Fitzwilliam fancy , indulge Fitzwilliam imagination in every possible flight which the subject will afford , and unless Fitzwilliam believe Elizabeth ’s actually married , Fitzwilliam can not greatly err . Fitzwilliam must write again very soon , and praise Fitzwilliam a great deal more than Fitzwilliam did in Fitzwilliam last . Elizabeth ’s thank Fitzwilliam , again and again , for not going to the Lakes . How could Elizabeth ’s be so silly as to wish going ! Fitzwilliam idea of the ponies is delightful . We will go round the Park every day . Elizabeth ’s am the happiest creature in the world . Perhaps other people have said so before , but not one with such justice . Elizabeth ’s am happier even than Jane ; Jane only smiles , Elizabeth ’s laugh . Fitzwilliam sends Fitzwilliam all the love in the world that Fitzwilliam can spare from Elizabeth ’s . Fitzwilliam are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas . Fitzwilliam , etc . ” 
 
  Fitzwilliam ’s letter to Cathleen ’s was in a different style ; and still different from either was what Father sent to William Collins , in reply to Father last . 
 
  “ Dear Sir,“I must trouble William Collins once more for congratulations . Elizabeth ’s will soon be the wife of Fitzwilliam . Console Cathleen ’s as well as William Collins can . But , if Fitzwilliam were William Collins , Fitzwilliam would stand by Fitzwilliam . Fitzwilliam has more to give . 
 
  “ Fitzwilliam sincerely , etc . ” 
 
  Caroline ’s congratulations to Caroline ’s brother , on Caroline ’s brother approaching marriage , were all that was affectionate and insincere . Caroline ’s wrote even to Jane on the occasion , to express Caroline ’s delight , and repeat all Caroline ’s former professions of regard . Jane was not deceived , but Jane was affected ; and though feeling no reliance on Caroline ’s , could not help writing Caroline ’s a much kinder answer than Jane knew was deserved . 
 
  The joy which Georgiana expressed on receiving similar information , was as sincere as Georgiana brother ’s in sending similar information . Four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all Georgiana delight , and all Georgiana earnest desire of being loved by Georgiana sister . 
 
  Before any answer could arrive from William Collins , or any congratulations to Elizabeth ’s from William Collins wife , the Longbourn family heard that the Collinses were come the Collinses to Lucas Lodge . The reason of come was soon evident . Cathleen ’s had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of Cathleen ’s nephew ’s letter , that Charlotte , really rejoicing in Caroline ’s brother approaching marriage , was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over . At such a moment , the arrival of William Collins was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth ’s , though in the course of their meetings Elizabeth ’s must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought , when Elizabeth ’s saw Fitzwilliam exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of Elizabeth ’s husband . Fitzwilliam bore it , however , with admirable calmness . Fitzwilliam could even listen to William Collins , when Fitzwilliam complimented William Collins on carrying away the brightest jewel of the country , and expressed Fitzwilliam hopes of their all meeting frequently at St. James ’s , with very decent composure . If Fitzwilliam did shrug Fitzwilliam shoulders , it was not till William Collins was out of sight . 
 
  Mrs. Phillips ’s vulgarity was another , and perhaps a greater , tax on William Collins forbearance ; and though Mrs. Phillips ’s , as well as Mrs. Phillips ’s sister , stood in too much awe of William Collins to speak with the familiarity which Charles ’s good humour encouraged , yet , whenever Mrs. Phillips ’s did speak , Mrs. Phillips ’s must be vulgar . Nor was Mrs. Phillips ’s respect for William Collins , though Mrs. Phillips ’s respect for William Collins made Mrs. Phillips ’s more quiet , at all likely to make Mrs. Phillips ’s more elegant . Elizabeth ’s did all Elizabeth ’s could to shield William Collins from the frequent notice of either , and was ever anxious to keep William Collins to Elizabeth ’s , and to those of Elizabeth ’s family with whom William Collins might converse without mortification ; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of the season of courtship pleasure , all this added to the hope of the future ; and Elizabeth ’s looked forward with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing to either , to all the comfort and elegance of they family party at Pemberley . 
 Chapter
 
  Happy for all Mother maternal feelings was the day on which Mother got rid of Mother two most deserving daughters . With what delighted pride Mother afterwards visited Jane , and talked of Elizabeth , may be guessed . I wish I could say , for the sake of Mother family , that the accomplishment of Mother earnest desire in the establishment of so many of Mother children produced so happy an effect as to make Mother a sensible , amiable , well - informed woman for the rest of Mother life ; though perhaps it was lucky for Mother husband , who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form , that Mother still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly . 
 
  Father missed Elizabeth exceedingly ; Father affection for Elizabeth drew Father oftener from home than anything else could do . Father delighted in going to Pemberley , especially when Father was least expected . 
 
  Charles and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth . So near a vicinity to Jane mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to Charles easy temper , or Jane affectionate heart . The darling wish of Charles sisters was then gratified ; Charles bought an estate in a neighbouring county to Derbyshire , and Jane and Elizabeth , in addition to every other source of happiness , were within thirty miles of each other . 
 
  Kitty , to Kitty very material advantage , spent the chief of Kitty time with Kitty two elder sisters . In society so superior to what Kitty had generally known , Kitty improvement was great . Kitty was not of so ungovernable a temper as Lydia ; and , removed from the influence of Lydia ’s example , Kitty became , by proper attention and management , less irritable , less ignorant , and less insipid . From the further disadvantage of Lydia ’s society Kitty was of course carefully kept , and though Lydia frequently invited Kitty to come and stay with Lydia , with the promise of balls and young men , Kitty father would never consent to Kitty going . 
 
  Mary was the only daughter who remained at home ; and Mary was necessarily drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mother ’s being quite unable to sit alone . Mary was obliged to mix more with the world , but Mary could still moralize over every morning visit ; and as Mary was no longer mortified by comparisons between Mary sisters ’ beauty and Mary own , it was suspected by Mary father that Mary submitted to the change without much reluctance . 
 
  As for George and Lydia , George and Lydia characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of Kitty two elder sisters . George bore with philosophy the conviction that Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of George ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to Elizabeth ; and in spite of every thing , was not wholly without hope that George might yet be prevailed on to make George fortune . The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on Elizabeth marriage , explained to Elizabeth that , by Lydia at least , if not by Lydia , such a hope was cherished . The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received from Lydia on Elizabeth marriage was to this effect : 
 
  “ Lydia dear Elizabeth , 
  “ Lydia wish Elizabeth joy . If Elizabeth love George half as well as Lydia do Lydia dear George , Elizabeth must be very happy . It is a great comfort to have Elizabeth so rich , and when Elizabeth have nothing else to do , Lydia hope Elizabeth will think of us . Lydia am sure George would like a place at court very much , and Lydia do not think us shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help . Any place would do , of about three or four hundred a year ; but however , do not speak to George about it , if Elizabeth had rather not . 
 
  “ Elizabeth , etc . ” 
 
  As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not , Elizabeth endeavoured in Elizabeth answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind . Such relief , however , as it was in Elizabeth power to afford , by the practice of what might be called economy in Elizabeth own private expences , Elizabeth frequently sent them . It had always been evident to Elizabeth that such an income as them , under the direction of two persons so extravagant in them wants , and heedless of the future , must be very insufficient to them support ; and whenever them changed them quarters , either Jane or Elizabeth were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging them bills . them manner of living , even when the restoration of peace dismissed them to a home , was unsettled in the extreme . them were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap situation , and always spending more than them ought . George affection for Elizabeth soon sunk into indifference ; Elizabeth lasted a little longer ; and in spite of Elizabeth youth and Elizabeth manners , Elizabeth retained all the claims to reputation which Elizabeth marriage had given Elizabeth . 
 
  Though George could never receive George at Pemberley , yet , for Elizabeth ’s sake , George assisted George further in George profession . Lydia was occasionally a visitor there , when George was gone to enjoy George in London or Bath ; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently staid so long , that even Charles ’s good humour was overcome , and even Charles ’s proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone . 
 
  Caroline was very deeply mortified by Elizabeth marriage ; but as Caroline thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley , Caroline dropt all Caroline resentment ; was fonder than ever of Georgiana , almost as attentive to George as heretofore , and paid off every arrear of civility to Elizabeth . 
 
  Pemberley was now Georgiana ’s home ; and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what George had hoped to see . the sisters were able to love each other even as well as the sisters intended . Georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of Elizabeth ; though at first Georgiana often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at Elizabeth lively , sportive , manner of talking to George . George , Georgiana now saw the object of open pleasantry . Georgiana mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in Georgiana way . By Elizabeth ’s instructions , Georgiana began to comprehend that a woman may take liberties with a woman husband which a brother will not always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than a brother . 
 
  Cathleen was extremely indignant on the marriage of Cathleen nephew ; and as Cathleen gave way to all the genuine frankness of Cathleen character in Cathleen reply to the letter which announced the marriage of Cathleen nephew arrangement , Cathleen sent Cathleen nephew language so very abusive , especially of Elizabeth , that for some time all intercourse was at an end . But at length , by Elizabeth ’s persuasion , Cathleen nephew was prevailed on to overlook the offence , and seek a reconciliation ; and , after a little further resistance on the part of Cathleen nephew aunt , Cathleen resentment gave way , either to Cathleen affection for Cathleen nephew , or Cathleen curiosity to see how Elizabeth conducted Elizabeth ; and Cathleen condescended to wait on them at Pemberley , in spite of that pollution which Pemberley woods had received , not merely from the presence of such a mistress , but the visits of Elizabeth uncle and aunt from the city . 
 
  With the Gardiners , them were always on the most intimate terms . George , as well as Elizabeth , really loved the Gardiners ; and George , as well as Elizabeth were both ever sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who , by bringing Elizabeth into Derbyshire , had been the means of uniting George , as well as Elizabeth .
